Ninetales has trouble breaking Dragon-types such as Noivern and Dragalge; Fairy-types such as Togekiss, Sylveon, and Gardevoir deal with Noivern, while bulky Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross can handle both. Choice Scarf Gardevoir is notably an excellent teammate, as it also provides Healing Wish support late-game, whereas Ninetales can blow through bulky Steel-types such as Registeel and Doublade. Knock Off users such as Mienshao and Seismitoad can remove annoying items such as Assault Vest on Reuniclus, Heavy-Duty Boots on Noivern, and Leftovers on Snorlax. Entry hazard setters such as Registeel, Metagross, and Golisopod are great, as they help in wearing down walls. Golisopod is an exceptional partner, as it provides both Knock Off and Spikes support, and it switches into Ground-type moves. Seismitoad sets Stealth Rock and also uses Knock Off. Ninetales can form a semi-sun core with Shiftry, which has good offensive synergy with Ninetales and can provide Knock Off support, although the lack of sun turns can limit the pair's effectiveness.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Fire teams appreciate Ninetales's Drought ability to summon sun, boosting Fire-type moves for the team and weakening opposing Water-type attacks. A coveted move in Nasty Plot lets it shred apart opposing teams and take up the role of a wallbreaker too. Its access to a strong Grass-type move in Solar Beam, which charges in one turn when sun is up, lets it take care of Rock-, Water-, and Ground-types such as Rhyperior, Jellicent, and Gastrodon. With Nasty Plot and Extrasensory, Ninetales is also able to deal with Toxapex, which can otherwise stomach hits from it. Hypnosis is an option over Extrasensory to put to sleep troublesome Pokemon like Tyranitar and Toxapex on a predicted switch-in. Against defensive teams like Poison, Ninetales should focus on setting up with Nasty Plot to break through the opposition, while against offensive teams like hyper offense Ghost, Ninetales should focus on direct attacking due to the lack of a defensive backbone to tank hits. Maximum Special Attack investment lets Ninetales hit as hard as possible, and maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature allows it to outspeed slower Pokemon that could KO Ninetales, such as Indeedee and Obstagoon. Heat Rock maximizes the number of sun turns, increasing the damage of Fire-type moves for Ninetales and its teammates.

All of Ninetales's teammates enjoy its ability to set sun. Charizard appreciates Ninetales's wallbreaking ability that allows it to clean late-game, as well as providing sun to activate Solar Power. In return, Charizard can take care of threats like Dragapult and Tyranitar with Dragon Pulse and Focus Blast, respectively. Choice Band Arcanine forms a good wallbreaking core with Ninetales, weakening each other's checks and counters. Arcanine also appreciates Hypnosis support from Ninetales to further limit its checks like Hippowdon. Cinderace can swap Stealth Rock from its side of the field with Court Change and threaten common hazard setters like Tyranitar with High Jump Kick. Torkoal can provide Ninetales with essential Stealth Rock support to score easier KOs and keep opposing hazards away with Rapid Spin, as they would otherwise undermine Ninetales's potential as a wallbreaker. In addition, Torkoal can set sun against slower weather setters like Pelipper and Hippowdon. Rotom-H can provide Ninetales with Volt Switch and Defog support; additionally, they can run Nasty Plot sets together to overwhelm shared checks.

zu.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower is an alternative to Fire Blast that provides more accuracy and consistency, but it is significantly weaker. Substitute can be used to avoid status from foes like Pyukumku and Audino, while Agility helps Ninetales clean better late-game; however, Ninetales generally prefers retaining Scorching Sands.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant can take Energy Ball and retaliate with a powerful Water-type STAB attack. However, they have difficulty checking Ninetales after Nasty Plot. Pyukumuku is notable, as it ignores Nasty Plot with Unaware and can stall Ninetales with Toxic + Recover.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Piloswine and Silvally-Ground can threaten Ninetales with their STAB moves, but they should be wary of Energy Ball.

Revenge Killers: Foes such as Manectric, Cinccino, and Choice Scarf Sawk can outspeed and revenge kill Ninetales. It is also susceptible to priority from Kangaskhan, Gurdurr, and Shiftry if it is weakened.

Status: Ninetales is vulnerable to being worn down by Toxic from foes like Audino and Miltank, while Thunder Wave from Qwilfish and Uxie cripples its Speed and makes it much easier to revenge kill.

Dragon-types: Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Ninetales's moves and can threaten it with a strong attack or status.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Ninetales is a notable sweeper thanks to its access to Nasty Plot, excellent coverage options, and good Speed tier. Nasty Plot lets Ninetales break through bulky walls such as Audino with its powerful Fire Blast and clean weakened teams. Energy Ball targets Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Jellicent and Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Ground. Scorching Sands is Ninetales's best move against Qwilfish and opposing Fire-types like Rapidash and Coalossal.

Ninetales fits on balance and offense teams as a mid- and late-game wallbreaker and revenge killer. Wallbreaking partners such as Rotom and Cinccino complement Ninetales; Rotom is able to threaten Water-types and safely bring in Ninetales with Volt Switch, while Cinccino is able to handle specially defensive walls like Pyukumuku and Miltank that wall Ninetales. In return, they benefit from its ability to handle Ferroseed. Grass-types like Tangela and the aforementioned Ferroseed are also good partners, handling problematic foes like Silvally-Ground and Piloswine. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie, Cofagrigus, and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Heavy-Duty Boots and prevent Ninetales from being worn down by entry hazards; Uxie and Cofagrigus can also take on revenge killers such as Kangaskhan and Choice Scarf Sawk, while Qwilfish can provide entry hazard support to wear down foes like Piloswine and Poliwrath. Cleaners such as Frosmoth and Calm Mind Alcremie can take advantage of Ninetales's wallbreaking to set up and clean late-game.

uu.overview: Alolan Ninetales is the only relevant Pokemon in UU that can consistently set up Aurora Veil. Its great Speed tier allows it to set up Aurora Veil in front of common Pokemon like Keldeo and Zarude, and its access to support moves like Hypnosis allows it to gain momentum with a free switch and bring in frail sweepers like Diggersby and Thundurus-T more easily. Sadly, Ice / Fairy is not a great defensive typing, as Alolan Ninetales will drop easily to both offensive and defensive variants of Steel-types like Aegislash, Jirachi, and Celesteela, making it difficult to consistently get Aurora Veil up against some teams. Additionally, a lot of common leads can give Alolan Ninetales a hard time, such as Lycanroc-D, and Choice Scarf Jirachi KO it before it can set up Aurora Veil. Furthermore, the presence of rain in the metagame can hinder Alolan Ninetales's ability to set up Aurora Veil at times.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Alolan Ninetales has access to Nasty Plot, which can significantly boost its offensive presence while maintaining some bulk investment. This lets it take advantage of its great offensive typing and Speed tier to try to sweep or do heavy damage on its own; however, it cannot break through most Steel- and Fire-types even with multiple Nasty Plot boosts. Encore can give a safe switch to gain momentum for any of Alolan Ninetales's teammates. It also can be used to shut down Pokemon that attempt to set up, such as Substitute Primarina and Swords Dance Aegislash.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Alolan Ninetales is in big trouble against any Steel-type Pokemon, in particular Choice Scarf Jirachi, which will OHKO it with Iron Head before it can set up Aurora Veil. Slower Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash take negligible damage from Freeze-Dry and will OHKO Alolan Ninetales even after it sets up Aurora Veil.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Moltres, Rotom-H, and Chandelure also resist Freeze-Dry, so Alolan Ninetales cannot do much against them. Rotom-H is a great Defogger against Alolan Ninetales, as it takes negligible damage from Freeze-Dry and can remove Aurora Veil immediately once it is set up, as well as threaten Alolan Ninetales with Overheat.

Faster Threats: Alolan Ninetales struggles against Pokemon that are faster and can threaten to KO it or hinder its ability to properly set up Aurora Veil. Lycanroc-D and Jolly Scolipede are faster and can OHKO it.

Weather Changers: Weather teams, in particular sun teams with Torkoal and rain teams with Pelipper, will give Alolan Ninetales a hard time trying to keep Aurora Veil up. Alolan Ninetales will typically need to carry Hail in order to counteract the effects of the changing weather.

sets.name: Aurora Veil
sets.description:
Setting up Aurora Veil at all costs is the main priority for Alolan Ninetales. Freeze-Dry is the only offensive move Alolan Ninetales needs, as it hits a substantial number of UU Pokemon such as Salamence, Gyarados, and Amoonguss for super effective damage. Moonblast allows Alolan Ninetales to OHKO Crawdaunt, Buzzwole, and Kommo-o. Hypnosis can be used to put Pokemon to sleep that threaten to remove Aurora Veil with Defog or after Aurora Veil is up to allow you to safely switch in one of your sweepers. It also can be used to cripple Steel-types like Aegislash that threaten to KO Alolan Ninetales, but at 60% accuracy, this is very risky. Hail is an option as well, although it is useful only against opposing weather teams like rain that try to cancel the Snow Warning hail. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Alolan Ninetales to ignore entry hazards and come in as much as possible to set Aurora Veil.

Alolan Ninetales fits exclusively on hyper offense teams, as only these teams can maximize the utility offered from Aurora Veil. Azumarill is typically a great partner, since it can help check Lycanroc-D with Aqua Jet. Azumarill can also use Belly Drum more easily under Aurora Veil and proceed to clean out most of the enemy team, as it no longer has to rely exclusively on Aqua Jet while Aurora Veil is up. Alolan Ninetales struggles against all Steel-type Pokemon, including slower ones like Celesteela, which can OHKO it through Aurora Veil. A partner like Krookodile or Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can help ease the pressure from these foes, the former also being able to support its teammates with Stealth Rock. Other good teammates include offensive Steel-types like Autotomize Celesteela and Swords Dance Aegislash, which can set up very easily under Aurora Veil to begin a sweep. Aegislash especially appreciates this as it can potentially activate a Weakness Policy more easily. Clangorous Soul Kommo-o and Dragon Dance Gyarados can also attempt to boost more than once under Aurora Veil. They both help pressure Fire-types like Moltres and Rotom-H, which would otherwise threaten Alolan Ninetales and remove Aurora Veil with Defog.

sets.name: Aurora Veil (Ice)
sets.description:
Alolan Ninetales is essential to Ice teams as a fast Aurora Veil setter capable of providing helpful offensive utility. Aurora Veil halves damage from oncoming attacks for Alolan Ninetales and its teammates. Freeze-Dry allows Alolan Ninetales to beat Water-types like Seismitoad, Gyarados, and Pelipper. Moonblast is its strongest Fairy-type STAB move, letting it beat Fighting-types like Keldeo and Kommo-o, as well as other threats to Ice teams like Cloyster and Duraludon. Lastly, Encore is essential for taking advantage of setup sweepers like Grimmsnarl, Snorlax, Corviknight, and Bisharp. Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment is optimal for Alolan Ninetales's role as an offensive support Pokemon, and a Timid nature lets it outspeed Keldeo and Kyurem. Snow Warning and Light Clay provide the conditions for Alolan Ninetales to set Aurora Veil and maximize its duration.

Setup sweepers like Cloyster greatly benefit from Aurora Veil. Galarian Darmanitan can dispatch of threatening Steel-types like Excadrill, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn, and appreciates Aurora Veil to survive hits from faster Choice Scarf users that would OHKO it otherwise, such as Gengar and Dragapult. Additionally, Aurora Veil allows Avalugg to fill its defensive role more effectively, being able to remove entry hazards that threaten Alolan Ninetales. Mamoswine greatly appreciates Alolan Ninetales's ability to beat Water-types like Keldeo and Seismitoad while being able to beat Aegislash and Bisharp in return. Choice Scarf Weavile is an excellent teammate that can remove faster Choice Scarf users like Jirachi and Gengar, which would prevent Alolan Ninetales from setting up Aurora Veil.

sets.name: Aurora Veil Setter (Fairy)
sets.description:
Alolan Ninetales's fast Aurora Veil allows Fairy teams to better take advantage of their setup sweepers. Freeze-Dry nails Water- and Ground-type Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Pelipper, while Moonblast allows Alolan Ninetales to hit Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-type such as Sableye, Hydreigon, Kyurem-B, and Kommo-o hard. Encore enables Alolan Ninetales to lock setup sweepers such as Corviknight, Snorlax, and Centiskorch and defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Hippowdon into inopportune moves. Light Clay and Snow Warning pair with Aurora Veil to maximize its duration and enable setup, enabling teammates such as Mimikyu to more easily take advantage of it. The given EVs and a Timid nature allow Alolan Ninetales to be as strong and fast as possible and take on Pokemon such as Cloyster and Toxapex. Alolan Ninetales should time when its sets Aurora Veil against other teams with access to weather, as it can easily be blocked if hail is overridden.

All of Alolan Ninetales teammates appreciate its ability to set up Aurora Veil, especially the setup sweepers. Calm Mind Hatterene, Swords Dance Mimikyu, Bulk Up Grimmsnarl, and Nasty Plot Togekiss are the team's setup sweepers that can take advantage of Aurora Veil, allowing them to tank hits with more ease and making setting up easier. Hatterene also can bounce back entry hazards for Alolan Ninetales thanks to Magic Bounce, which also allows it to keep up Aurora Veil against Defog users such as Galarian Weezing and Pelipper. Other teammates such as Gardevoir and Primarina appreciate the Aurora Veil, as it allows them to spam their attacks with little drawback. Gardevoir especially helps Alolan Ninetales, as it can take advantage of opposing weather teams thanks to Trace and its Choice Scarf to revenge kill their sweepers with ease, such as Excadrill and Barraskewda. Clefable is another support Pokemon available to Aurora Veil teams, being able to support them with Thunder Wave and Healing Wish or set up Stealth Rock, allowing its teammates to break through the foe's team with more ease. Stealth Rock also allows Alolan Ninetales to at least 2HKO all Pokemon in the Water matchup, such as taking out Toxapex with Freeze-Dry and OHKOing Cloyster with Moonblast. Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl can take on Pokemon that can beat Ninetales such as Jirachi and Gengar with Sucker Punch, and Togekiss can tank attacks from Choice Scarf users that take can OHKO Alolan Ninetales such as Duraludon and paralyze them with Thunder Wave. Lastly, Ribombee's Sticky Web allows Alolan Ninetales to outspeed Choice Scarf users such as Terrakion, Dracovish, and Duraludon.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Ice

Blizzard can be used over Encore to enable Alolan Ninetales to nab an OHKO on Mega Pinsir; however, without Encore, it cannot force setup sweepers such as Bisharp and hazard settlers like Galarian Corsola to lock into uility moves. Heavy-Duty Boots is a niche option to avoid taking Stealth Rock damage. Choice Scarf is another option that enables Alolan Ninetales to outpace Mega Lopunny, Mega Gallade, and Choice Scarf Terrakion, but this means fewer turns of Aurora Veil and making it harder for setup sweepers like Alolan Sandslash and Cloyster to setup.

Checks and Counters

Ice

Steel-types: Alolan Ninetales has trouble dealing with Steel-types like Mega Scizor, Jirachi, and Excadrill due to resisting both of Alolan Ninetales's moves and can take care of it with Bullet Punch and Iron Head.

Super Effective Attacks: Fire-types like Mega Charizard X, Blacephalon, and Cinderace are able to tank any of Alolan Ninetales attacks and OHKO it. Mega Charizard Y and Torkoal can also prevent Aurora Veil from being set up thanks to Drought. Fast Rock-types like Mega Aerodactyl and Mega Diancie are able to OHKO Alolan Ninetales with their STAB attacks. Poison-types like Gengar are able to OHKO Alolan Ninetales with Sludge Wave.

Special Walls: Special Defensive walls such as Blissey and Empoleon can take any of Alolan Ninetales attacks, and take care of it with their attacks or using Toxic.

Stealth Rock: Alolan Ninetales is greatly hindered by Stealth Rock, which limits the times it can switch in to provide hail and Aurora Veil.

Revenge Killers: Fast Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Mega Gallade along with Choice Scarf users like Greninja, Terrakion, and Excadrill can easily outpace and take care of Alolan Ninetales.

sets.name: Aurora Veil (Ice)
sets.description:
Alolan Ninetales is a great asset to Ice-type teams due to summoning hail and using Aurora Veil to allow its teammates to take less damage from attacks. Alolan Ninetales's Fairy typing is good to threaten Fighting- and Dark-types like Keldeo and Mega Sableye with STAB Moonblast, and it has a great Speed tier to outpace Pokemon such as Keldeo and Terrakion. Freeze-Dry is used to hit Water-types such as Swampert, Pelipper, Mantine, and Gastrodon. Encore allows Alolan Ninetales to lock entry hazard settlers and setup sweepers like Galarian Corsola, Torkoal, and Bisharp into non-damaging moves. Light Clay is used to maintain Aurora Veil for eight turns, and Snow Warning is needed to summon hail. 252 Special Attack EVs make Alolan Ninetales hit as hard as possible. A Timid nature with 252 Speed EVs is vital for Alolan Ninetales to outpace Keldeo and Hydreigon.

All teammates appreciate Alolan Ninetales providing Aurora Veil to help take attacks and its Moonblast threatening Keldeo and Terrakion. Alolan Sandslash loves Alolan Ninetales summoning hail to enable Slush Rush, allowing it to outpace Mega Aerodactyl and Mega Diancie. Alolan Ninetales in return can take care of Landorus and Nidoking outside hail. Avalugg is a great wall that can come in on Excadrill's and Bisharp's attacks and take care of them with Body Press. It can also use Rapid Spin to get rid of entry hazards that prevent Alolan Ninetales from repeatedly coming in. Cloyster is a great partner, as it loves the support from Aurora Veil to safety set up and sweep and can take care of troublesome Rock- and Fire-types once it set up, like Mega Tyranitar, Mega Aerodactyl, Mega Charizard Y, and Victini. Piloswine is also a great partner that can take care of Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y thanks to Thick Fat and provide Stealth Rock. Mamoswine is another option, as it can also provide Stealth Rock support, takes neutral damage from Fire- and Rock-type attacks and helps against Rock-, Fire-, Steel- and Poison-types like Tyranitar, Heatran, Magnezone, and Toxapex. Kyurem is a great wallbreaker; helps out Alolan Ninetales by taking care of troublesome Steel-types such Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone with Earth Power; and helps out in the Water-type matchup with Freeze-Dry to 2HKO Toxapex, which Alolan Ninetales has trouble beating. Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan is a great wallbreaker and a great way to take care of troubling Steel-types like Excadrill, Heatran, and Jirachi that threaten Alolan Ninetales out. Choice Scarf Weavile is a great check to a set-up Cloyster thanks to Foul Play and troublesome Ghost- and Psychic-types like Gengar, Blacephalon, Victini and Jirachi thanks to Knock Off and Pursuit. Knock Off is also useful to get rid of Heavy-Duty Boots from Blissey, Leftovers from Tyranitar, and Eviolite from Porygon2.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Thief is a decent option if Golbat is the main Knock Off switch-in, but this often requires giving up useful utility in Defog or Taunt. Acrobatics can be used instead of Brave Bird and lacks recoil damage, but it requires Golbat to lose its Eviolite, so it is less preferred. 252 HP / 80 SpD / 176 Spe is a fast specially defensive spread that Golbat can opt for with a Jolly nature in order to check Gastly and Lampent at the cost of being more vulnerable to physical attackers such as Raboot.

Checks and Counters

Electabuzz: Electabuzz can revenge kill Golbat and cripple physical variants of Golbat with Static.

Psychic-types: Galarian Mr. Mime and Kadabra both outspeed Golbat and can KO it with Psychic once its Eviolite has been removed. Hattrem and Duosion are bulky enough to switch in and are also able to threaten Golbat out with their STAB attacks.

Wallbreakers: Choice Band Lairon, Choice Band Raboot, and Choice Specs Magmar can break past Golbat with their powerful STAB moves. However, with the exception of Lairon, these Pokemon cannot switch into Golbat's attacks safely.

Residual Damage and Knock Off: Stealth Rock reduces Golbat's longevity, limiting its opportunities to switch in and forcing it to use Roost more often. Golbat often has to switch into Knock Off from Pokemon such as Tangela and Gurdurr, making it more susceptible to being worn down long term.

Status: Mareanie and Magmar can cripple Golbat with burns, which limit the damage output of physical variants. Sleep and paralysis from Ivysaur, Tangela, and Electabuzz make Golbat an easy target for revenge killers.

sets.name: Stallbreaker
sets.description:
With a great defensive typing, access to Taunt, and reliable recovery, Golbat makes for an excellent stallbreaker. Additionally, it has excellent walling capabilities, checking common Pokemon such as Tangela, Thwackey, Gurdurr, and Raboot. Super Fang lets Golbat deal reliable damage to bulkier foes such as Koffing, Ferroseed, and Metang. Taunt lets Golbat prevent Clefairy and Mareanie from recovering health and setting entry hazards. Brave Bird is a strong STAB move that threatens 2HKOs on common setup sweepers like Thwackey and Gurdurr, and it finishes off walls that have been weakened by Super Fang. Infiltrator lets Golbat bypass Substitutes of Rufflet and Lampent. With 84 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature, Golbat outspeeds Adamant Thwackey and Jolly Fraxure.

Golbat works best when paired with sweepers like Thwackey, Electabuzz, and Magmar, which benefit from its ability to break down walls with Super Fang. Golbat is able to check physical sweepers, so it is a good idea to pair it with specially defensive walls like Mareanie and Clefairy that can switch into attacks from Magmar and Electabuzz, respectively. Checks to Kadabra and Galarian Mr. Mime such as Ferroseed, Galarian Corsola, and Klang are also appreciated. Electabuzz outspeeds Golbat and threatens it out with its STAB moves, so Ground-types such as Piloswine, Marshtomp, and Gabite make for great partners, having the added benefit of providing Stealth Rock. Pokemon with entry hazard control such as Gurdurr, Hattrem, and Wartortle address Golbat's Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Golbat's solid defensive typing forces switches, giving it many opportunities to use Defog. U-turn lets Golbat keep up momentum on expected switch-ins such as Mareanie and Klang, while Toxic cripples entry hazard setters like Galarian Corsola and Piloswine that it would otherwise be unable to break past.

Pokemon that are weak to Stealth Rock like Magmar, Lampent, and Galarian Mr. Mime benefit the most from Defog. The former two also appreciate Golbat's ability to pivot them in safely while also luring in Steel-types like Metang and Klang. Pivots such as Thwackey also benefit from the hazard removal that Golbat provides and can form a solid VoltTurn core with Golbat. Shell Smash Wartortle can act as secondary entry hazard removal and benefits from Golbat's ability to reliably check Grass-types like Thwackey and Roselia. Special walls like Ferroseed and Marshtomp check Psychic-types and Electric-types, respectively.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot and a wide movepool let Golbat pose as a menacing wallbreaker and sweeper. Air Slash 2HKOes common Grass- and Fighting-types such as Thwackey, Tangela, and Gurdurr. Heat Wave nails Ferroseed as well as doing solid damage to other Steel-types, which often resist Golbat's Air Slash. Roost provides Golbat with recovery and lets it set up multiple times against passive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Galarian Corsola. Alternatively, Giga Drain targets Thick Fat Piloswine.

Golbat should avoid setting up until faster Psychic-types have been removed, namely Kadabra and Galarian Mr. Mime, as they can all revenge kill it easily. Dark- and Steel-types such as Klang and Galarian Linoone help to keep these Pokemon in check. Physical wallbreakers like Fraxure and Thwackey make for great partners, as they break past specially defensive walls such as Mareanie and Galarian Corsola that would give Golbat trouble, with the latter also having access to Knock Off to weaken foes. Stealth Rock and Spikes users like Galarian Corsola and Ferroseed provide important chip damage for Golbat to clean teams. Entry hazard removal from Wartortle or Galarian Mr. Mime is also important, as this lets Golbat avoid being OHKOed by Piloswine's Icicle Crash and Choice Band Raboot's Flare Blitz, and it is vital for Golbat variants without Roost.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Stun Spore and Toxic may work over Sleep Powder, and they help debilitate targets like Golbat and Galarian Corsola for longer. Infestation is another option for trapping Pokemon that Gloom can outstall and may want to still stay in on it for a turn; Gurdurr may want to secure a Defog, or Ferroseed setting up Spikes. However, there a limited amount of targets that Gloom can trap, as attackers like Thwackey and Pikachu are able to escape through pivoting.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Specially offensive Fire-types like Magmar and Lampent check all of Gloom's sets, and only fear status attempts from it. On the other end, Strength Sap allows a healthy Gloom to outstall Raboot, which is less consistent as a check.

Psychic-types: Kadabra and Galarian Mr. Mime revenge kill a weakened Gloom. Hattrem works as well, and goes a step further by preventing it from recovering with Strength Sap.

Wallbreakers: Multiple wallbreakers like Choice Band Rufflet, Piloswine, and Choice Specs Porygon have super effective coverage to break past Gloom; Piloswine also has strong priority for offensive Gloom sets.

Stallbreakers: Taunt users like Golbat, Electabuzz, and Galarian Linoone shut down Gloom and prevent it from recovering, make it potentially lose these match ups despite it having a favorable typing. Subsitute Rufflet also has a setup oppertunity against Gloom.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Gloom works as a wall to many relevant physical attackers thanks to its great bulk, Grass / Poison typing, and utility-centered movepool. Strength Sap allows Gloom to recover its health against Machoke and Thwackey while also lowering their Attack in the process. Alternatively, Leech Seed or Sleep Powder can be used over Giga Drain; the former is helpful for wearing down walls like Galarian Corsola and RestTalk Klang, while the latter threatens switch-ins like Raboot. Another option is Moonblast, which punishes the physical Fighting- and Dark-types Gloom can wall like Gurdurr, Flame Orb Machoke, and Defensive Vullaby. Moonlight is yet another recovery move for Gloom, providing Gloom with recovery not blocked by Magic Bounce users, notably Hattrem. Stench has a small opportunity to flinch slower targets like Charjabug and Duosion.

While opposing Magic Bounce users are still around, Gloom should rely on Moonlight for its recovery or play offensively with Sludge Bomb and Moonblast. Use Gloom as a check to nonthreatening physical attackers mid-game like Thwackey and Gabite. So long as it has a safe switch-in and retained its Eviolite, it can also wall physical attackers with unfavorable type matchups like Piloswine with Strength Sap if needed. By checking the most common Fighting-types, Gloom becomes a solid defensive pivot when paired with Pokemon vulnerable to Fighting-types like Piloswine, Galarian Linoone, and Klang. The latter two can also check Psychic-types for Gloom, as it fears being revenged killed by Galarian Mr. Mime and Kadabra otherwise. Gloom also struggles with special Fire- and Ice-type coverage from Pokemon like Magmar and Wartortle, so having a defensive Water-type like Mareanie or Palpitoad can help as well. Special walls like Galarian Corsola and Vullaby pair well to patch Gloom's mediocre special defense bulk and its weaknesses to Fire- and Psychic-type attacks, and these examples can remove entry hazards so that Gloom can consistently switch and wall what it needs to.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Gloom's ability Chlorophyll and supportive movepool makes it a potent sweeper with Sun support. However, Ivysaur outclasses it in this regard, so Gloom should only be used with Ivysaur rather than in place of it. Gloom can double its Special Attack with Growth under Sun and break through Pokemon like Mareanie, Gurdurr, and Galarian Corsola. Sludge Bomb is another STAB attack for Pokemon that resist Grass like Magmar and Fraxure. The last option is used for further utility, with Strength Sap allowing Gloom to heal itself and provide additional opportunities to use Growth against physical attackers like Golbat and Machoke, while Moonlight provides Gloom with a source of healing that is not blocked by Magic Bounce Hattrem. Sleep Powder can also be used in the last slot to help break past Grass-resists like Metang and Lampent, although the healing is typically preferred. 216 Speed EVs allow Gloom to outrun Kadabra in the sun, and the rest of the EVs go into HP for general bulk.

Without Sunny Day itself, Gloom absolutely needs to be paired with sun support from Drought Vulpix. Vulpix and other strong Fire-types like Magmar and Charmeleon also benefit from sun, and they provide coverage to nail walls like Ferroseed and Klang that Gloom struggles with on its own. Gloom should be reserved for sweeping until it can outrun and break the remaining targets. Ivysaur and Tangela are very useful partners for this, using Weather Ball and Knock Off, respectively, to weaken Pokemon like Ferroseed, Klang, and Lampent into range for Gloom to sweep. Slow pivots such as Golbat and Vullaby can bring in Gloom safely with U-turn, especially against walls that Gloom cannot break. Cleaners like Shift Gear Klang and Shell Smash Wartortle also appreciate Gloom's ability to weaken bulkier Pokemon for them to sweep after.

nu.overview: With its great typing, amazing bulk, and numerous utility options, Vileplume acts as a check to common Pokemon in the tier such as Flygon, Dhelmise, and Guzzlord. Its great Poison / Grass typing and reliable recovery options make it difficult for opposing teams to wear down. With Effect Spore, it has a chance to passively punish physical attackers and pivots. Vileplume's natural strength and unique combination of STAB moves in Giga Drain and Sludge Bomb make it difficult to switch into. Vileplume can also serve as a great tool against bulky Steel-types like Copperajah and Bronzong, as Corrosive Gas removes their held items and Sleep Powder puts them to sleep. However, Vileplume is slow and vulnerable to Psychic- and Fire-types as well as strong special attackers such as Goodra, Dragalge, and Exploud. Vileplume is also easily worn down by entry hazards, and it has difficulty switching into strong physical wallbreakers like Golurk and Tyrantrum.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Leech Seed inflicts residual damage on opposing Pokemon and gives Vileplume an option for more recovery. While having less PP than Leech Seed, Synthesis gives Vileplume consistent recovery. Moonblast can put out some extra damage on Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon-types like Passimian and Guzzlord. Aromatherapy can be used if the team needs a cleric option. Growth can turn Vileplume into a wincon late-game at the cost of its utility in Corrosive Gas or Sleep Powder.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types: Psychic-types such as Starmie and Celebi threaten Vileplume with Psychic or Stored Power. They can force out Vileplume, but none of them want to get poisoned by Sludge Bomb.

Flying-types: Aerodactyl can dish out huge damage with Dual Wingbeat. Ninjask and Braviary resist Giga Drain, and Braviary also gains a Defiant boost from Strength Sap. However, all of them have to be wary about switching into Sludge Bomb and getting poisoned.

Fire-types: Salazzle, Talonflame, and Charizard can threaten out Vileplume with their strong STAB options, but switching into Corrosive Gas is problematic, as it removes their Heavy-Duty Boots.

Strong Wallbreakers: Choice Band users such as Tyrantrum and Sirfetch'd threaten Vileplume with Head Smash and Brave Bird, respectively. Dragalge, Guzzlord, and Exploud threaten Vileplume with their STAB moves and coverage.

Strength Sap Blockers: Xatu, Espeon, and Goodra can all block Vileplume's recovery from Strength Sap with Magic Bounce and Sap Sipper, limiting its ability to switch into Sirfetch'd and Flygon.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Set Details

Strength Sap is one of Vileplume’s biggest assets to check Pokemon like Copperajah and Flygon. Corrosive Gas removes the item of common switch-ins like Bronzong, Copperajah, and Arcanine. Alternatively, Sleep Powder can be used to put common switch-ins such as Talonflame and Arcanine to sleep, making it safer for Vileplume to switch out on them. Black Sludge gives Vileplume extra recovery, but running no item is better for checking Knock Off and Poltergeist users like Drapion and Golurk.

Vileplume is weak to Flying-types, so Steel- and Rock-types such as Bronzong, Copperajah, and Diancie that can check Talonflame and Braviary are appreciated. In return, Vileplume can check Rotom-C, Decidueye, and Vaporeon for them. Vileplume struggles against strong Psychic-types such as Starmie and Indeedee-F; therefore, partners like Bronzong and Copperajah are great. Vileplume in return checks Fighting-types such as Passimian for them. Vileplume dislikes Fire-types like Salazzle, so Mantine and Goodra are great partners for it. Vileplume and Guzzlord form a great core, since they are able to wall physical and special attackers while canceling out each other's weaknesses; Vileplume helps with Fighting- and Fairy-types, and Guzzlord helps with Psychic-types. Offensive teammates like Flygon and Starmie both target Dragalge and Arcanine, which Vileplume has trouble with.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Vileplume's reliable bulk and good defensive typing allow it to act as a switch-in to common pivots in RU such as Zarude and Mienshao, while its ability Effect Spore lets it pressure physical attackers such as Cobalion and Sharpedo. Unfortunately, Vileplume can get worn down quickly and is often forced to use its recovery to remain healthy, which gives openings to Pokemon it invites in like Toxtricity and common Flying-types such as Noivern and Crobat. Strength Sap is Vileplume’s main recovery move and allows it to lower the Attack stat of an opposing physical attacker. Corrosive Gas is used to remove important items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Choice items from Pokemon such as Cobalion, Crobat, and Toxtricity. Alternatively, Sleep Powder can be used to put common switch-ins such as Crobat and Noivern to sleep, generating free turns for itself and its teammates. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 144 Def / 112 SpD can be used to avoid a 4HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt. Vileplume is best suited for balance teams that need a check for prominent physical attackers such as Zarude and Mienshao. Due to Vileplume's weakness to Fire-types, bulky Water-types such as Suicune and Milotic can be great teammates. In return, Vileplume can handle offensive Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Raikou. Since Vileplume often invites in Flying-types like Crobat and Tornadus, checks to these Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Raikou are good partners. Registeel and Steelix also make great teammates for Vileplume, since they are able to check offensive Psychic-types such as Gardevoir and Necrozma. Since Vileplume often switches into pivots, taking damage from entry hazards can quickly wear it down and limit its defensive capabilities, so entry hazard removal from Togekiss or Crobat is important.

lc.overview: Diglett is one of the most important forces in the metagame because it reliably revenge kills key threats with Arena Trap and has an LC-best Speed tier. Diglett has excellent synergy with the tier's premier U-turn users, Mienfoo and Vullaby, and can pick apart teams with the help of their pivoting. It checks strong, speedy offensive threats like Ponyta and Abra as well as defensive cornerstones like Onix, Pawniard, and Mareanie. In spite of its somewhat low stats and limited movepool, Diglett is quite versatile and can be tailored in response to what foes its team needs trapped. However, Diglett is only moderately powerful, and it can sometimes struggle to make an impact against the staples of bulky teams like Ferroseed, Foongus, and Timburr. It is also extremely frail and has limited opportunities to reach the battlefield intact, requiring clever pivoting and switching to reach its full potential.
lc.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf Diglett is an option that can revenge kill extremely fast threats like Choice Scarf users, Speed-boosted Ponyta and Staryu, and opposing Diglett. Air Balloon is a niche item to beat Sticky Web teams and opposing Arena Trap users while having some utility against Onix as well. Focus Sash is an option to make Diglett a dedicated lead on hyper offense teams and set Stealth Rock, but it is unreliable because of the variability of lead matchups and the prevalence of entry hazards. Protect is an option to block Mienfoo's Fake Out and High Jump Kick, and it is especially useful on Air Balloon sets seeking to preserve their item.

Checks and Counters

Arena Trap Users: Opposing Diglett and Trapinch are often the most effective counters to Diglett, as they each trap and KO it. Trapinch can either pick off a weakened Diglett with First Impression or survive most hits and OHKO even Eviolite Diglett with Earthquake, while opposing Choice Scarf and Air Balloon Diglett can revenge kill Diglett without worrying about losing a Speed tie and being KOed by Earthquake. Trace Porygon is an unorthodox Arena Trap user that can tank hits from Diglett with its great bulk and KO it in return. However, all of these trappers cannot stop Air Balloon Diglett from switching out from them.

Grookey: Grookey's Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake, making it difficult for Diglett to deal damage and successfully trap targets like Mareanie and Pawniard that are at full health, and Grookey can easily KO Diglett with priority Grassy Glide. Grookey also resists Earthquake and can set up with Swords Dance or generate momentum with Knock Off and U-turn. Diglett can circumvent Grassy Terrain by running Earth Power.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers like Scraggy, Agility Porygon, and Nasty Plot Vullaby can take advantage of Diglett's relative inability to threaten them to boost and sweep. Diglett can weaken these threats by slowing them down with Rock Tomb or sacrificing itself with Final Gambit to put them in the range of priority attacks.

sets.name: Eviolite
sets.description:
Moves

Earthquake is Diglett's strongest move and deals major damage to its main trapping targets like Ponyta, Pawniard, and Mareanie. Final Gambit allows you to effectively trade Diglett for an opposing threat like Staryu or Nasty Plot Vullaby or get major chip damage on a defensive anchor like Ferroseed. Beat Up reliably KOes Focus Sash Abra with five hits and also hits Natu and Galarian Ponyta hard. Earth Power allows Diglett to bypass Onix's Weak Armor to safely 2HKO it and function while Grookey's Grassy Terrain is up. Earth Power also lets Diglett safely 2HKO Mareanie without fearing a Scald burn. Sucker Punch is fairly weak but can be run on teams that need priority. Stealth Rock is an option on hyper offense teams that cannot afford to run a traditional entry hazard setter. Rock Tomb is a niche option that can prevent Scraggy from setting up effectively.

Set Details

The given HP investment allows Diglett to OHKO offensive Staryu from full health with Final Gambit. Maximum Speed investment and a Jolly nature allow Diglett to hit 20 Speed and outpace the entire unboosted metagame. The remaining EVs are placed in Attack to boost Diglett's damage output. Eviolite bolsters Diglett's meager bulk enough to survive one hit from certain Pokemon it likes to trap such as Onix and Mareanie, allowing it to safely 2HKO them or switch into them while at full health and revenge kill them. Eviolite also allows Diglett to switch into and survive Focus Sash Abra's Psychic and to almost always survive Analytic Magnemite's Flash Cannon after Stealth Rock.

Usage Tips

Diglett should be used to trap and KO key Pokemon for its teammates. Eviolite Diglett is most useful when its health is tactically preserved so that it remains able to deal with its main targets, as it lacks the power to OHKO many of them. Due to its modest bulk, it can afford to switch into a Mareanie or Onix that has had its Eviolite removed with Knock Off and then KO it. Final Gambit should be used to heavily damage bulky Pokemon lacking reliable recovery like Ferroseed when Diglett no longer has targets to trap, and it can also be deployed to weaken Nasty Plot Vullaby, which may try to set up on Diglett. Be wary of KOing a foe with Diglett when you still need it, especially if your opponent has a Trapinch or Diglett of their own, as each can trap and revenge kill Diglett before its role is fulfilled.

Team Options

Eviolite Diglett works best on teams that need it to deal with Mareanie or need its combination of high Speed and the ability to trap Weak Armor Onix. Mienfoo is an exceptional partner because it can lure in Mareanie and pivot into Diglett with U-turn. Timburr and Ponyta also appreciate Diglett trapping Mareanie, while Vullaby and Ponyta benefit from it trapping Onix. Nasty Plot Vullaby especially appreciates Diglett's ability to deter and trap would-be checks like Onix and Magnemite. Abra and Galarian Ponyta enjoy Diglett trapping Pawniard. Fighting-types and setup sweepers appreciate Diglett trapping Focus Sash Abra.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
Moves

Earthquake is Diglett's most powerful move, dealing heavy damage to neutral targets and Onix and almost always OHKOing standard Pawniard, Mareanie, and Ponyta. Substitute allows Diglett to elude Sucker Punch from Pawniard and safely KO it, as Adamant Pawniard would otherwise OHKO it. Beat Up is the most reliable option to trap Abra, KOing Focus Sash variants with four hits, and it also deals heavy damage to Galarian Ponyta. Rock Slide threatens Vullaby, often OHKOing it after Stealth Rock. Sucker Punch can be useful for revenge killing Choice Scarf users like Vulpix and Porygon while providing the team with a moderately strong priority move. Memento can be run to create an opportunity for a setup sweeper, like Nasty Plot Vullaby, especially if Diglett has no obvious targets to trap in a match.

Set Details

Maximum Attack investment is crucial for Diglett to reliably KO Pawniard, Mareanie, and Ponyta with their Eviolites intact, while maximum Speed investment and a Jolly nature allow it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and revenge kill speedy threats like Ponyta, Abra, and Staryu. Life Orb enables Diglett to get crucial KOs and makes its middling Attack stat respectable.

Usage Tips

Diglett should be used to trap and KO Pokemon that its teammates cannot easily deal with. This set's power can let Diglett trap unusually bulky targets after they have been weakened or lost their Eviolites, such as Mienfoo and Foongus. Life Orb Diglett is extremely frail and must be deployed carefully to eliminate its required targets before being KOed. Diglett benefits from pivoting that lets it switch into targets unscathed. Additionally, it rewards aggressive double switches and predictions made after its targets are brought in to deal with other threats, which generates major offensive pressure. You should be careful not to leave Diglett exposed to being trapped by Trapinch or opposing Diglett before it has removed its main target.

Team Options

Life Orb Diglett works best on teams that need its offensive presence and ability to trap and OHKO its frequent targets. Diglett has excellent synergy with pivots that can bait in targets like Onix, Pawniard, and Mareanie and give it a free switch, like Mienfoo and Vullaby. Vullaby in turn appreciates Diglett trapping and KOing Flying-resistant Pokemon like Pawniard and Onix, and Mienfoo appreciates it removing Mareanie. Other Fighting-types like Timburr and Fire-types like Ponyta similarly take advantage of Mareanie's removal. Mareanie can take hits from priority users that try to revenge kill Diglett like Timburr and Corphish while benefiting from Diglett's ability to trap Abra and Magnemite. Abra and Wingull appreciate Diglett trapping Pawniard.

sets.name: Focus Sash Trapper
sets.description:
Dugtrio serves as a trapper for Ground-type teams with its excellent ability in Arena Trap. Thanks to it, Dugtrio can pick off weakened foes or eliminate problematic threats such as Dracovish and Weavile without allowing them to counteract. Earthquake is Dugtrio's primary and strongest attack. Stone Edge is mainly used to hit Flying-types such as Gyarados and Charizard. Reversal hits extremely hard when Focus Sash is consumed, allowing Dugtrio to do significant damage to Normal- and Ice-type Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Mamoswine. Sucker Punch allows Dugtrio to hit common Choice Scarf users such as Galarian Darmanitan and Dracovish, and common priority users such as Mamoswine. Screech can be used as an alternative to further complement its physical presence, allowing Dugtrio to trap foes more consistently by reducing their Defense. Focus Sash complements its ability Arena Trap, as it guarantees at least one Pokemon trapped from full HP. Dugtrio should seek trapping opportunities to pick off weakened foes or slower Pokemon that it can reliably beat.

Dugtrio needs to keep its Focus Sash intact in order to trap fast threats such as Weavile effectively, so Excadrill makes an excellent teammate for Dugtrio, as it can use Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards for Dugtrio. It can also handle Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Ribombee that either use Dugtrio as setup fodder or simply easily KO it without fear of Reversal. Hippowdon makes another decent teammate for Dugtrio with its access to Sand Stream and Stealth Rock; the cumulated passive chip damage allows Dugtrio to trap more consistently throughout the match. With its great bulk, Hippowdon can also pivot for Dugtrio after it traps and removes a threat and a revenge killer is sent out by the opponent. Mamoswine is a good offensive teammate with nearly unresisted coverage that allows it to punch many holes in opposing teams; this allows Mamoswine and Dugtrio to complement each other excellently. Dugtrio can trap and eliminate Pokemon that were weakened by Mamoswine, while it also can be used to trap fast Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Dracovish to grant Mamoswine freedom. Seismitoad is a good defensive partner with access to Toxic, which can generate chip damage for Dugtrio for consistent trapping. With its ability in Water Absorb, it can also check Dracovish. Rhyperior makes a good teammate for Dugtrio, as it can handle the Flying-types that Dugtrio cannot trap and struggles against, most notably Corviknight.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Persian's uncontested Speed tier, Technician Fake Out, and solid coverage make it a decent, although weak, revenge killer. However, it suffers extreme competition in this role from Pikachu, which boasts Extreme Speed and a greater offensive presence at the expense of some Speed. Fake Out lets Persian get extra damage on the foe without punishment and stall for extra poison damage, letting it follow up with Double-Edge in order to secure KOs on targets like the Silvally formes. Fake Out can also be used to pick off heavily weakened targets that have boosted their Speed, like Fraxure, in a pinch. Knock Off removes items from bulky switch-ins that otherwise disregard anything Persian can do to them, such as Mawile, Dusclops, and Hippopotas, and provides coverage for Ghost-types like Drakloak. U-turn lets Persian keep up momentum for its team, saving it from floundering against bulky foes like Stonjourner, Mawile, and Dusclops. Hypnosis can be used over Knock Off to better cripple switch-ins like Mawile but is unreliable due to its poor accuracy and leaves Persian unable to damage Ghost-types outside of U-turn. Silk Scarf is preferred in order to boost Persian's most important attacks without further cutting into its already limited longevity. Technician is vital in order to let Fake Out deal significant damage.

Persian is a good fit for bulky offense teams utilizing Spikes, which help it gradually overwhelm its switch-ins with Spikes damage, Fake Out, and U-turn. Offensive Roselia is an effective Spiker that Persian can bring in on switchins such as Mareanie, Gourgeist, and Dubwool via U-turn to set up Spikes. Roselia can also utilize Sleep Powder to put shared checks like Mawile and Pawniard to sleep. Offensive entry hazard setters like Crustle and Pawniard help weaken foes early-game, and their hazards greatly aid Persian in its role as a revenge killer. Persian can form an effective VoltTurn core with teammates like Manectric, Raichu, and Raboot, all of which can cover Pokemon that can safely switch in on Persian such as Mawile, Stonjourner, and Pawniard. Silvally-Psychic can put offensive pressure on Fighting-types Persian struggles with, such as Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop, while also threatening to set up and breaking down targets like Mawile to help Persian clean late-game. Mr. Rime can't switch in easily but can pressure Throh and Hitmontop, and its access to hazard control helps keep Persian from being overwhelmed by residual damage. Stacking other priority users like Pawniard and Falinks with Persian can form a powerful anti-setup core that takes pressure off Persian. Both examples also deter Defog with Defiant, making them good choices for teams utilizing Spikes.

nu.overview: Arcanine's typing and ability in Intimidate allow it to effectively check Copperajah as well as other foes like Escavalier, Tauros, and Dhelmise. It then functions as a defensive pivot with Teleport, allowing it to gain momentum against its switch-ins like Salazzle and Starmie. Arcanine's Teleport is also vital for teams with frail wallbreakers like Tyrantrum and Exploud, as it allows them to safely get in against Mantine and Sylveon without the risk of status and chip damage. However, Arcanine risks compromising its longevity when using Teleport on walls and is easily worn down by Toxic and Knock Off. Additionally, it fails in the face of common physical attackers like Tyrantrum, Golurk, and Diancie. Arcanine relies heavily on Teleport and supportive teammates to punish its checks, and if it loses this support late-game, its passivity becomes a glaring issue against foes like Dragalge and Blastoise.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Arcanine has a vast offensive movepool and mixed offensive stats to make it less passive, so attacks like Extreme Speed, Wild Charge, and Scorching Sands work as alternatives to Flamethrower or Toxic. Offensive sets enjoy this coverage as well but are inefficient due to being easy to wall and wear down.

Checks and Counters

Dragon-types: By resisting Flamethrower and being immune to Toxic, Dragalge can safely switch in against Arcanine and punish it with all of its usual coverage. Arcanine should also be wary of Dragalge, Tyrantrum, and Goodra, but Teleport at least allows it to bring in faster wallbreakers if it still has valid support.

Water-types: Offensive Water-types like Starmie and Blastoise are the hardest for Arcanine to deal with, and while defensive examples like Mantine and Vaporeon are checks as well, they are more manageable with Toxic and Teleport.

Ground-types: Arcanine fails to switch into and wall Golurk and Mudsdale, although it may have a better chance if it opts for Will-O-Wisp.

Residual Damage: Switching into attacks and following up with Teleport will wear Arcanine down, and it will lose momentum anytime it is forced to recover. Moreover, Arcanine's effectiveness is limited by Knock Off, Corrosive Gas, and Toxic from walls like Escavalier, Vileplume, and Bronzong.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Set Details

Teleport is essential for Arcanine to slowly pivot, as it can stomach attacks from Copperajah and bring in revenge killers unscathed. Toxic hurts walls like Sylveon, Vaporeon, and Mantine that take next to nothing from Flamethrower. Will-O-Wisp is an alternative to Toxic so that Arcanine punishes Sirfetch'd, Diancie, and Tyrantrum more effectively. With 64 Speed EVs, Arcanine is faster than Adamant Tyrantrum.

As a check to physically offensive Steel-types, Arcanine finds itself being invaluable to Sylveon and Diancie, and they in return offer Heal Bell to cure Toxic poison. Arcanine also helps special attackers like Goodra, Rotom-C, and Dragalge for the same reason, and the latter two are additional pivots that chain momentum with Arcanine. Wallbreakers like Golurk, Tyrantrum, and Exploud all find safe opportunities to switch into walls via Teleport support, and when they find themselves threatened by revenge killers such as Tauros and Decidueye, Arcanine again is a good defensive answer. Vileplume and Mudsdale cover Knock Off users that Arcanine is vulnerable to like Sirfetch'd and Guzzlord. For specially offensive threats, Mantine and Vaporeon will help, and so will Decidueye and Choice Scarf Heliolisk to offensively pressure Blastoise and Starmie. Ground-type checks like Bronzong, Rotom-C, and Xatu are valuable so Arcanine won't have to take an Earthquake.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
A good Attack stat combined with decent coverage and useful priority in Extreme Speed makes Arcanine a hard-hitting physical wallbreaker for Fire-type teams. Its decent Speed stat lets it outspeed Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Togekiss, and Toxtricity while having a Speed tie with Kyurem-B, Obstagoon, and Indeedee. Its ability Intimidate provides some utility support, as it allows Arcanine to deter physical attackers like Gyarados for the team. Being a STAB move, Flare Blitz is the hardest-hitting move on the set and hits very hard under sun, letting Arcanine heavily damage Pokemon like Mandibuzz. Wild Charge lets Arcanine deal with Water-type Pokemon such as Toxapex, Pelipper, Mantine, and Gyarados. Close Combat allows Arcanine to beat Thick Fat Snorlax and threaten Normal-type teams and is also good against common Rock-types like Tyranitar that can switch into its Flare Blitz. Extreme Speed lets Arcanine beat faster Pokemon like Hydreigon, Keldeo, and Alolan Raichu after they have been weakened. The Speed from being Jolly nature is preferred but an Adamant nature is another option that allows Arcanine to hit harder and makes Extreme Speed more powerful, but it comes at the cost of it not being able to Speed tie with other base 95 Speed Pokemon.

Choice Scarf Charizard appreciates Arcanine weakening walls for it. In return, Charizard deals with troublesome and faster Pokemon like Dragapult, Zeraora, and Choice Scarf Excadrill. Rotom-H can pressure Water-type Pokemon like Toxapex and can pivot into Arcanine through Volt Switch. Torkoal and Ninetales provide essential sun support for Arcanine to boost its Flare Blitz, even further letting it wallbreak easily without much prediction. They can also put opposing Pokemon to sleep with moves like Yawn and Hypnosis respectively, giving Arcanine more opportunities to switch in during the battle. Additionally, Torkoal can keep hazards away with Rapid Spin, while Ninetales can beat Ground- and Water-type Pokemon such as Rhyperior and Rotom-W with Solar Beam. Cinderace can also keep Stealth Rock off the field with Court Change and provide U-turn support as well as form a priority spam core with Arcanine thanks to Sucker Punch. Arcanine also appreciates Cinderace beating faster Pokemon like Hydreigon and Dragapult for it. Salazzle can put defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Seismitoad on a timer with Toxic, making it easier for Arcanine to beat them. It can absorb Toxic Spikes for the team, too.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Normal / Fairy Arcanine can opt to run a more offensive set with Flare Blitz over Morning Sun to help patch its weakness to Steel-types. An alternative spread of 80 HP / 252 Atk / 176 Spe can be used to slightly increase Arcanine's bulk while ensuring it still outspeeds threats like Rillaboom and offensive Magearna. Leftovers can be used to increase Arcanine's longevity, though Life Orb's immediate power is generally preferred. Normal / Fighting Arcanine with Close Combat can be used to hit Steel-types without recoil, though this set needs Crunch to hit Ghost-types. Wild Charge can be used to hit bulky Water-types such as Mew, Slowbro, and Galarian Slowking, though the recoil makes this option riskier.

Checks and Counters

Heatran: Steel / Ground Heatran is the most reliable check to Arcanine, as it has high bulk, is Normal-resistant, and can threaten to KO Arcanine; even Normal / Fire Arcanine is unable to threaten Heatran due to Flash Fire.

Ghost-types: Both offensive and defensive Ghost-types are a massive threat to Arcanine. Defensive Ghost-types such as Slowbro, Galarian Slowking, and Cresselia are able to wall Arcanine well, though they can be vulnerable to Normal / Dark Arcanine. On the other hand, offensive Ghost-types like Latios, Alakazam, and Heracross are able to take advantage of Arcanine's Speed tier and their Ghost immunity to threaten it.

Toxapex: Toxapex threatens Arcanine with Toxic, walls all of its sets, and prevents it from setting up with Haze.

Defensive Steel-types: Defensive Steel-types like Mew, Reuniclus, and Salamence are able to check Normal / Fairy Arcanine well and threaten to KO it with their STAB attacks, though they are vulnerable to Arcanine's Normal / Fire sets.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Slowbro, Salamence, and Mew make great checks to Normal / Fire Arcanine and threaten to KO it with their STAB attacks while also being passable checks to other Arcanine sets as well.

Residual Damage: Fire-type Arcanine is prone to residual damage from Life Orb and Flare Blitz, and often wears itself down throughout the match, making it easier to revenge kill or even causing itself to faint.

sets.name: Extreme Speed
sets.description:
Arcanine is a powerful attacker that utilizes STAB Extreme Speed to threaten a large portion of offensive Pokemon. Play Rough is a powerful secondary STAB attack that allows Arcanine to OHKO threats such as Fighting / Flying Tornadus-T, Spectrier, and Lycanroc-D. Flare Blitz can be used to provide Arcanine with a Normal / Fire typing, which lets it break Steel-types such as Mew, Reuniclus, and Magearna. Flare Blitz should be used in conjunction with Heavy-Duty Boots and Intimidate to eliminate Arcanine's weakness to entry hazards. Crunch lets Arcanine hit Ghost-types; this option can be used as either a STAB option that grants it a Normal / Dark typing or a coverage option on Normal / Fire sets. Morning Sun provides Arcanine with recovery and increases its longevity as a wallbreaker. Arcanine becomes a powerful setup sweeper with Howl; this allows it to break past walls and sweep offensive threats with ease. Life Orb increases the power of Arcanine's attacks and increases its wallbreaking power. Toxic is another option to hinder its bulkier checks such as Slowbro and Salamence. While Flash Fire is primarily used for an immunity to Will-O-Wisp, Arcanine's immunity to Fire-type attacks can be beneficial against threats such as Victini and Hydreigon.

Hydreigon, Latias, and offensive Clefable appreciate Arcanine's ability to pressure specially defensive walls, namely Unaware Clefable and Blissey; in return, they are able to pressure physical walls such as Salamence, Cresselia, and Toxapex. Dark-types like Spectrier, Lycanroc-D, and Tornadus-T are particularly good partners to Normal / Fairy and Normal / Fire Arcanine, as they heavily pressure Arcanine's Ghost-type checks. Normal / Fairy Arcanine is vulnerable to bulky Steel-types such as Mew, Reuniclus, and Melmetal, so Fire-type partners like Volcarona, Hydreigon, and Victini are useful to cover this weakness. Normal / Fire Arcanine appreciates Grass- and Electric-types such as Rillaboom, Naganadel, and Latias that can pressure bulky Water-types.

sets.name: Altarianite
sets.description:
Arcanine stands out as an effective speed control in Mix and Mega due to its powerful form of priority, potent Fire / Fairy STAB combination, and access to Teleport. This Pokemon can perform a wide range of roles such as revenge killing, late-game sweeping, and slow pivot. Altarianite adds a secondary Fairy typing to Arcanine's Fire typing and allows it to fire off Fairy-type STAB Pixilate Extreme Speed, allowing Arcanine to outpace and deal with a large range of the offensive threats in Mix and Mega. Flare Blitz is Arcanine's secondary STAB option and gives it the ability to blow past Steel-types that resist Extreme Speed, such as Corviknight and Solgaleo. Morning Sun gives provides Arcanine with defensive utility and longevity throughout the game and works well with Arcanine's pre-Mega ability Intimidate to act as an emergency check to other Altarianite users like Dragonite. Teleport allows Arcanine to slow pivot out, which gives it a solid niche over other Extreme Speed users less able to make use of the switches they force.

Arcanine struggles the most against some of the premier physical walls like Toxapex, Lunala, and Slowbro, so partners that can exploit these Pokemon like Lucarionite Zygarde, Spectrier, and Pheromosa are all good partners. Pheromosa is particularly useful here, as its access to U-turn allows it to keep up the momentum Arcanine wins with Teleport against most teams. In turn, Arcanine is one of the best offensive checks to other Altarianite users like Dragonite, and can bring these relatively fragile Pokemon in safely. Zeraora and Lucarionite Terrakion allow Arcanine to wear down and overwhelm shared physical checks like Slowbro and Lunala, who often prove incapable of staying healthy enough to answer all of them throughout the match. Ampharosite Blissey also pairs extremely well with Arcanine, as it can reliably set Stealth Rock to punish the switches Arcanine forces and can set Toxic on most of Arcanine's defensive checks. In turn, Arcanine serves as reliable speed control on the builds where Blissey fits best and is capable of stopping the threats that seek to exploit Blissey's added Dragon-typing.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Arcanine can use its powerful Fire-type STAB moves against many top threats in the metagame such as non-Occa Berry Whimsicott, Galarian Darmanitan, and Corviknight. In addition to this, its fantastic ability in Intimidate makes its good physical bulk better, allowing it to even face foes that can hit it super effectively such as Haxorus and Choice Scarf Excadrill. Flare Blitz is Arcanine's STAB move of choice, allowing it to OHKO Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Excadrill. Close Combat can help with handling and OHKOing Normal-, Rock-, and Dark-types such as Choice Specs Porygon-Z, Tyranitar, and non-Choice Specs Hydreigon, while Play Rough lets you OHKO Urshifu-S while still being able to OHKO non-Choice Specs Hydreigon. Outrage is useful for the plethora of Dragon-types in 1v1 such as Haxorus, Dracovish, and Dragapult, assuming they aren't holding a Haban Berry. Extreme Speed gives Arcanine a guaranteed matchup against Choice Scarf Togekiss as Arcanine 3HKOes with priority whilst Togekiss can only 3HKO back but lacks priority itself. Wild Charge can also be used for a better matchup against non-bulky Gyarados. The given HP and Special Defense investment allows Arcanine to avoid the OHKO from Timid Choice Specs Dragapult's Draco Meteor. The given Speed investment outspeeds Timid Choice Specs Porygon-Z. You can also use a simple spread with maximum Attack and Speed investment, which lets you OHKO non-bulky Urshifu-S with Close Combat at the cost of the Choice Specs Dragapult matchup.

Water-types like bulky Assault Vest or Chilan Berry Primarina or Azumarill are great teammates due to their great coverage against Rock- and Ground-types like Crustle and Rhyperior. In return, Arcanine covers for Grass-types such as Rillaboom, Celebi and non-Occa Berry Whimsicott. In addition to this, Grass-types such as Rillaboom cover Arcanine's weaknesses in Rock-, Ground- and Water-types such as Rhyperior and Gastrodon, and Arcanine in return covers for some of their weaknesses such as Bug-types like Durant and certain opposing Grass-types like Venusaur.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Arcanine is an excellent physical wall that can also counter some special attackers like Magnezone, Chandelure, and Aegislash. Intimidate combined with Arcanine's defensive utility in Will-O-Wisp and Burn Up lets it take physical hits from the likes of Galarian Darmanitan, non-Swords Dance Haxorus, and Choice Band Crustle. Will-O-Wisp is used to cripple physical attackers such as Diggersby as well as Sawk and Avalugg while also breaking their Sturdy. Arcanine uses Morning Sun to deal with Pokemon that may otherwise overwhelm it, like Choice Band Haxorus and Golisopod. Burn Up KOes Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan and offensive Rillaboom and also removes Arcanine's Fire typing so that it is no longer weak to Rock-, Ground-, and Water-type attacks, which proves to be useful in matchups against non-Lum Berry Crustle, non-Swords Dance Rhyperior, and Adamant Choice Band Dracovish. Snarl is used to lower the Special Attack of Pokemon like Magnezone, Galarian Weezing, and Chandelure. Flamethrower deals consistent damage against threats Arcanine needs to hit more than once such as defensive Rillaboom, Taunt Zeraora, and Corviknight. Sitrus Berry gives Arcanine a source of immediate recovery to aid it in dealing with Choice Band Mold Breaker Haxorus and Assault Vest Kyurem so that it doesn't get knocked out after the first hit. Maximum Defense investment alongside 72 HP EVs with a Bold nature allows Arcanine to survive a Choice Band-boosted Earthquake from Jolly Galarian Darmanitan. 136 Speed EVs ensure that Arcanine is faster than Modest base 80 Speed Pokemon and below, such as Choice Specs Chandelure, offensive Venusaur, and Adamant Choice Band Dracovish and Diggersby. The leftover 48 EVs are invested into Special Attack to maximize the damage of Burn Up and Snarl. When using Flamethrower over Snarl, a spread of 244 HP / 136 Def / 8 SpA / 120 Spe should be used, which ensures Arcanine will always survive a Choice Specs-boosted Hyper Beam from Modest Magnezone while still surviving an Earthquake from Jolly Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, though it comes at the expense of no longer outspeeding fully invested base 80 Speed Pokemon.

Generally, Arcanine will find itself using Will-O-Wisp against physical attackers, although there are some matchups where this isn't ideal. Against non-Lum Berry Crustle, Choice Band Dracovish, and Choice Band Diggersby, Arcanine should use Burn Up to rid itself of its Fire typing followed by Will-O-Wisp and Morning Sun; this is because Burn Up is 100% accurate and achieves the same effect of halving damage as using Will-O-Wisp would, so you don't run the risk of losing on account of a miss. Certain defensive Primarina variants, like Assault Vest, can also be beaten by Arcanine through the use of Burn Up, Snarl, and Will-O-Wisp, but because Primarina can often run numerous varying techs, Arcanine shouldn't be relied on as a Primarina answer. Will-O-Wisp is also useful against special attackers like Magnezone, since it breaks its Sturdy so that Burn Up can then KO it. Will-O-Wisp also chips down Aegislash so that Burn Up can KO it after six turns of burn damage without risking the activation of its Weakness Policy. Against Choice Specs Magnezone, Arcanine should use Snarl to both break Sturdy and ensure that Arcanine will survive any hit. Pokemon like Sylveon, Primarina, and Choice Band Snorlax appreciate Arcanine's ability to handle hyper offensive threats like Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, Adamant Choice Band Dracovish, and Rillaboom. In turn, these Pokemon help cover Arcanine's weakness to specially offensive threats like opposing Primarina, Hydreigon, and Kyurem. Arcanine struggles a bit when it comes to certain Encore and Taunt users like Primarina, Aromatisse, Kommo-o, and Corviknight if not running Flamethrower, so it appreciates the assistance provided by hyper offensive Pokemon like Choice Specs Porygon-Z, Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, Salazzle, and Choice Specs Gengar. In return, Arcanine helps cover their weaknesses to bulky offense and Sturdy Pokemon like Assault Vest Azumarill, non-Swords Dance Rhyperior, Magnezone, Sawk, and Avalugg.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Kadabra can fit multiple moves for its last slot on the Life Orb set thanks to the effectiveness of its three main coverage options; Psyshock is the strongest attack against some special walls like Mareanie and Roselia, securing an OHKO on both, and Energy Ball can be considered for stronger coverage against Piloswine and Water-types such as specially defensive Wartortle. Protect is also optional for scouting and safely stalling out the turns of Thwackey's Grassy Terrain and Fraxure's First Impression. Seismic Toss can be used to better weaken Steel-types, notably Ferroseed, threatening it with a 3HKO.Psychic Terrain with Expanding Force makes for a situational late-game cleaner, with Expanding Force OHKOing more targets like Tangela and providing an immunity to priority attacks from Piloswine and Gurdurr; other setters for Psychic Terrain like Slowpoke also helps. This set still struggles to sweep when facing Thwackey, Kadabra's defensive checks like Defog Vullaby, and Choice Scarf revenge killers. Choice Specs and Trick offers both more power against walls, but the Choice-lock is a heavy price to pay for a small buff compared to Life Orb's damage output.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Ferroseed and Klang are some of the best defensive answers to Kadabra thanks to their bulk and Kadabra's unthreatening coverage against them even if they lose their Eviolite. Other Steel-types like Lairon and Metang can also answer Kadabra, but are unable to repeatedly switch into Shadow Ball, particularly from Life Orb variants of Kadabra.

Special Walls: The bulkiest of special walls like Galarian Corsola, Vullaby, and Clefairy are able to take on Focus Sash Kadabra and fire back with Shadow Ball or Knock Off. However, Life Orb Kadabra is more likely to 2HKO these walls with chip damage, and Knock Off users ought to fear Counter from a healthy Focus Sash Kadabra.

Revenge Killers: Priority attackers like Thwackey and Piloswine bypass Kadabra's great Speed, and they are even switch-ins when healthy. Frailer priority users like Pikachu and Raboot as well as Choice Scarf users like Krokorok and Lampent are good offense checks when they have a safe switch into Kadabra.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
At the highest Speed tier in NFE sits Kadabra, which uses its Speed and power to threaten most of the metagame. It functions as both a special wallbreaker and cleaner, with Psychic 2HKOing most of the neutral metagame, and it is only limited due to its poor bulk, often letting priority attackers remove it in one hit. Dazzling Gleam targets Dark-types like Vullaby, Galarian Linoone, and Krokorok. Shadow Ball is effective at breaking Slowpoke and Hattrem, and it also targets opposing Kadabra. Lastly, Encore punishes targets if they lock into status or Sucker Punch while Knock Off removes the Eviolite of special walls like Klang and Ferroseed on the switch.

Kadabra cannot break through Steel-type walls like Klang and Ferroseed and instead relies on teammates like Gurdurr, Lampent, and Magmar to break them. Raboot also helps to this degree and appreciates generating momentum when pivoting out on its checks like Mareanie and Galarian Corsola to bring Kadabra in safely; additionally, defensive pivots like Vullaby and Golbat work too. For Kadabra to clean weakened teams, it needs Knock Off support from teammates like Machoke, Thwackey, and Mareanie to put targets like Tangela, Hattrem, and Galarian Linoone into OHKO range. If running Knock Off itself, Kadabra should also utilize it against switch-ins like Vullaby and Klang, helping its teammates out as well. Kadabra should avoid priority users like Thwackey and Sucker Punch Raboot, and it should have defensive switch-ins like Koffing and Gabite to deter them. Mareanie and Ferroseed act as switch-ins for sweepers like Klang and Wartortle that set up on Kadabra and sweep past it.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
The security of Focus Sash functionally doubles Kadabra's longevity, as it can afford to take an extra hit thanks to Magic Guard protecting it from entry hazards. Dazzling Gleam targets Dark-types that are immune to Psychic like Galarian Linoone and Morgrem. Encore is used for stallbreaking and deals with checks that may lock into status moves, while Shadow Ball offers strong coverage against common Ghost- and Psychic-types like Lampent and Galarian Mr. Mime. Counter in conjunction with Focus Sash lets Kadabra take down its physically offensive checks when healthy, but it is unreliable if the checks carry multi-hit attacks like Klang and Bullet Seed Ferroseed or if pivots like Raboot and Thwackey use U-turn and bring in a Ghost-type teammate.

Bring Kadabra in safely to revenge kill slower targets, and try to preserve its health so that it can utilize its Focus Sash late-game to stop opposing cleaners like Thwackey and Wartortle. Kadabra should be weary of attackers that can opt for coverage that bypasses Focus Sash, like Scale Shot Fraxure and Icicle Spear Piloswine, and should rely on walls like Galarian Corsola and Clefairy to scout. Wallbreakers like Choice Band Thwackey and Choice Specs Gastly wear down shared checks with Kadabra like Vullaby, Klang, and Ferroseed so that together they are likely to break past them. Entry hazards from Piloswine, Krokorok, and Roselia also help wear down the aforementioned checks, giving an opportunity for Kadabra to use Encore when they are forced to recover or use Defog in Vullaby's case. Pivots like Raboot, Thwackey, and Electabuzz bring Kadabra in against their checks, and they in turn rely on Kadabra for breaking bulky Pokemon like Mareanie, Golbat, and Roselia. Teleport Clefairy also pairs well with Kadabra, since it brings Kadabra in safely in order to preserve its Focus Sash throughout the course of the game.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
Thanks to its ability Magic Guard combined with its stellar Speed stat and a Focus Sash, Alakazam performs the role of a revenge killer for Psychic-type teams. It also has a high Special Attack stat, which lets it hit hard against Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn with its coverage moves. Counter in combination with Focus Sash and Magic Guard helps Alakazam beat threatening physical attackers like Sharpedo, Cinderace, and Excadrill. Expanding Force is its STAB move of choice and is boosted to crazy levels in Psychic Terrain, letting Alakazam OHKO Pokemon like Azumarill after minor chip damage. It can also 2HKO Pokemon like Scizor and Araquanid if they switch in against it. Dazzling Gleam can be used to beat Dark- and Dragon-type Pokemon like Crawdaunt and Hydreigon. Shadow Ball lets Alakazam do good damage to Pokemon weak to it like Aegislash and Alolan Raichu. Focus Blast, on the other hand, lets Alakazam threaten Ferrothorn and Tyranitar, which can stomach its other moves easily. Alakazam should not take any unnecessary damage that may result from directly switching it into opposing Pokemon, as they may leave it unable to retain its Focus Sash. Also, it should be preserved in matchups against Bug- and Dark-type teams where it is needed to take on threats like Scolipede and Sharpedo. Maximum Special Attack investment optimizes Alakazam's overall damage output. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature lets it outspeed comparably fast Pokemon such as Cinderace and Salazzle.

Alakazam's teammates appreciate its role as a revenge killer being able to take on problematic Pokemon. Teammates like Choice Specs Indeedee-M and Nasty Plot Mew can wallbreak opposing foes, making Alakazam's job easier as a revenge killer late-game. Indeedee-M is a notable teammate, as it provides it with Ghost-type immunity and Psychic Terrain support, making the team immune to threatening priority moves like Sucker Punch and Shadow Sneak from Pokemon like Bisharp, Aegislash, and Mimikyu, allowing Alakazam to deal with such threats much better. Nasty Plot Mew, meanwhile, can take care of the Steel-type matchup by taking on Pokemon like Corviknight and Ferrothorn that may be an obstacle for Alakazam late-game. Support teammates like Orbeetle and Celebi provide Sticky Web and Stealth Rock support, enabling Alakazam to outspeed faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gengar and score easier KO with Expanding Force against Azumarill under Psychic Terrain. Pokemon like Slowbro can spread paralysis and bring Alakazam onto the field safely with Teleport, acting as a defensive pivot for the team. Choice Scarf users like Gardevoir and Jirachi are good teammates, as the former can deal with weather sweepers like Kingdra, Barraskewda, and Excadrill, while the latter does a good job against Fairy- and Ice-type teams, beating Pokemon like Cloyster, which can otherwise beat Alakazam with its multi-hit moves especially after Shell Smash boost. Hatterene and Alakazam form a great core against offensive types like Dark, Dragon, and Electric where Hatterene can break teams with its defensive Calm Mind set, letting Alakazam clean up late-game.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Fairy / Fighting typing with Dazzling Gleam and Focus Blast is an option with good STAB coverage to hit Dragon- and Fighting-types, but it leaves Alakazam open to revenge killing from Extreme Speed users like Entei and Arcanine. Paired with Tapu Lele, Alakazam is threatening in Psychic Terrain with Expanding Force and Focus Blast as well as immunity to Extreme Speed. However, Psychic Terrain-based teams require a lot of support to perform well.
