Since Lapras fails to check Thunder Kyogre, teammates such as Eternatus, Blissey, and Ferrothorn can be used as secondary checks to Kyogre. Eternatus additionally checks Ho-Oh, Necrozma-DM, and Yveltal, and it is a solid status absorber. Ho-Oh can check Necrozma-DM and switch into a plethora of attackers to scout for their moves or sets. In return, it greatly appreciates Lapras's ability to check most Kyogre reliably. Offensive teammates such as Swords Dance Groudon, Choice Specs Kyogre, and Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM benefit from having a solid Kyogre and Kyurem-W check in Lapras.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: G-Max Resonance
sets.description:
• Lapras functions as a solid special tank that has the niche of being able to take on opposing Water-types like Swampert and offensive Tapu Fini, thanks to its natural bulk, ability, typing, and access to Freeze-Dry.

  • Sheer Cold allows Lapras to defeat natural checks like Porygon2 and Chansey while also doing more damage with G-Max Resonance than Freeze Dry. Thunder instead gives Lapras a powerful coverage option against Water-type Pokemon and Celesteela when Dynamaxed.

  • The last moveslot can be used for Ice Shard, which gives Lapras access to STAB priority, or for Electric-type coverage if it hasn't been included in previous moveslots.

Items

  • Weakness Policy is a great fit for G-Max Resonance, patching up Lapras's disappointing offensive stats and letting it sweep.

  • Assault Vest makes Lapras more valuable outside of Dynamax, making it a bulky abuser of Sheer Cold.

  • Light Clay increases G-Max Resonance's effects for an extra 3 turns, making Gigantamax Lapras even more difficult to break through.

vgc2021.overview: Lapras has anchored itself as a premier Dynamax candidate for many defensive teams in the metagame due to its Gigantamax form setting Aurora Veil through G-Max Resonance. Additionally, its offensive sets are strong enough to deal significant damage to several meta staples, like Garchomp, Incineroar, and Landorus-T. Bulkier Perish Song sets offer an alternative win condition if Lapras and its teammates are able to weather the three turns necessary. Lapras is reliant on Dynamax and often finds itself being insignificant on the field after it ends. Due to Lapras's relatively low base Special Attack, it sometimes struggles to pick up KOs, especially due to damage reduction through moves like Snarl and Light Screen. Lapras also dislikes taking hits before Aurora Veil goes up, as its bulk is significantly worse without it.

sets.name: Offensive Gigantamax
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump is the preferred Water-type STAB move as it helps make up for Lapras's low Special Attack, and its higher 140 Base Power Max Geyser is excellent for hitting Entei and Incineroar.

  • Blizzard is preferred on this set so that Lapras gets access to the strongest possible G-Max Resonance, notably making a difference against the likes of Dragapult and Rillaboom.

  • Thunder is used to give Lapras Max Lightning, hitting opposing Water-types like Tapu Fini and denying sleep from moves like Yawn and Spore that would otherwise disrupt it.

  • Life Orb offers an immediate power boost at the cost of Lapras's bulk, whereas Weakness Policy can be used for a larger boost without the drawbacks of recoil, but its damage output will suffer without any boosts.

  • Water Absorb lets Lapras function as a catch-all Water-type switch-in, whereas Shell Armor removes the chance of Lapras being struck by a Critical Hit. Notably this significantly reduces the damage from Urshifu-S's Wicked Blow.

sets.name: Defensive Light Clay
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump is preferred as Lapras wants the power from a 140 Base Power Max Geyser to hit Water-weak Pokemon like Incineroar.

  • Freeze-Dry gives Lapras the consistent damage needed both in and out of Dynamax. Because this set is not focused on damage the secondary effect Freeze Dry offers is preferred. Additionally, it somewhat makes up for the lack of Thunder by hitting Water-types.

  • Perish Song is an incredible endgame win condition due to the immense bulk of defensive Lapras teams under Aurora Veil.

anythinggoes.comments:
Other Options

As Transform is Ditto's only move, it has no viable other options.

Checks and Counters

Substitute Users: Substitute nullifies Imposter, so unless the Substitute is removed by the time an ally has fainted, Ditto can not come in and revenge kill. Some Substitute users to watch out for are Xerneas, Dragon Dance Zygarde, and Zekrom.

Imposter-proof Pokemon: Teams may have a sweeper unable to break through a specific Pokemon also on the team in the event that a Ditto transforms into the first Pokemon. For example, a team may have a Choice Specs Kyogre but also a Blissey or Ferrothorn to prevent an opposing Ditto from reverse sweeping. Another example is Life Orb Eternatus, Imposter-proofed by Ho-Oh and Zacian-C.

Priority Users: While not very common in the metagame, Pokemon with priority moves such as Shadow Sneak Marshadow and Extreme Speed Rayquaza may be able to OHKO or heavily damage Ditto before getting revenge killed.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Albeit hard to fit onto a team, Ditto is one of the best revenge killers in the metagame, being able to reliably revenge kill sweepers such as a chipped Xerneas, Calyrex-S, and Zacian-C. Unless it has Substitute, Zacian-C is especially vulnerable to Ditto, as a +2 Ditto can break through Zacian-C's common check in Necrozma-DM with Close Combat. Similarly, Calyrex-S fears Ditto, as it punishes Calyrex-S heavily for coming in by threatening a reverse sweep in conjunction with As One. Ditto is an amazing user of Dynamax; after copying a boosted sweeper like Calyrex-S, Groudon, or Xerneas, it can Dynamax to break the Choice lock, usually allowing it to break through a check that switches into Ditto. However, this is only recommended when Dynamax is necessary to KO a foe, when checks are weakened enough to wrap up the game, or if Ditto needs to survive a predicted priority move. It is possible for Ditto to face an opposing Ditto one-on-one, and the EVs and IVs have been chosen with this in mind. 248 HP EVs ensure that Ditto will be able to use Struggle four times before fainting, and 252 Defense EVs minimize Struggle damage from an opposing Ditto. The minimum possible Speed allows Imposter to not activate first and therefore allow Ditto to have more Transform PP.

Ditto works best on balance and stall teams that appreciate its ability to deter opposing setup attempts. Necrozma-DM and Tyranitar work well with Ditto, as they can weaken a boosted Xerneas and Life Orb Yveltal respectively before Ditto comes in and revenge kills. Xerneas and Yveltal have noticeably higher bulk than a Ditto transformed into either, so it is important for the aforementioned two checks to pressure them to Dynamax, removing their ability to reliably win against a Ditto that can Dynamax one-on-one. Moreover, Tyranitar also doubles as a mandatory check to Calyrex-S. Checks to the ever-dangerous Dragon Dance Zygarde-C, such as Lunala, and Calm Mind Kyogre, such as Blissey, Eternatus, and Ferrothorn, are essential, as Ditto is incapable of revenge killing them. Gothitelle is a rather niche option that helps to deal with passive Pokemon lacking Shed Shell, particularly non-Teleport Blissey and Eternatus. Ditto enjoys being at full or near full HP so it can survive potential priority moves and take on a healthy Xerneas, so Defoggers such as Yveltal, Ho-Oh, and Giratina are invaluable teammates for it.

sets.name: Ditto (Copycat)
sets.description: Ditto's one and only role in Ubers is to copy the opponent's Pokemon in order to function as the premier revenge killer in the metagame, able to steal the target's stat boosts on top of having a Speed boost from its Choice Scarf. It is undeniably one of the best Pokemon in the metagame for that very reason, as there are many Pokemon that can set up with ease, and Ditto is able to copy their boosts and beat most of them one-on-one. Ditto can also be useful against bulkier teams, as its PP refreshes every time it is switched out, so it can help in cases of PP wars. As Ditto is frail, you want it to be sent in safely versus offensive threats, so pairing it with the likes of Corviknight or other pivots can be a good idea. Although it is the best revenge killer the metagame has to offer, it still has its flaws in doing so against moves like Substitute and Imprison, as well as opposing Choice Scarf users and bulky setup sweepers. Also, keep in mind you cannot use Imposter on opposing Ditto that have already copied a Pokemon, and that Ditto negates the Speed reduction when it copies the opposing Pokemon while Sticky Webs are on your side.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description:
Ditto carves a niche in the OU metagame by virtue of its ability in Imposter, making it one of the best revenge killers in the tier. Choice Scarf gives Ditto the ability to outspeed any Pokemon that isn't running a Choice Scarf itself, or Pokemon like Hawlucha once Unburden has been activated. Ditto is able to duplicate the opposing Pokemon's base stats bar HP; hence, 252 HP is required in order to maximize Ditto's bulk. Against stall teams, Ditto should switch into Knock Off to get its Choice Scarf removed so it can switch moves and have effectively infinite PP as it switches out. This is especially useful against passive Pokemon with recovery like Toxapex, Mandibuzz, and Quagsire, as it can increase its longevity throughout the game.

Ditto functions best under bulky teams like stall that require support against offensive setup and opposing stall teams. Blissey appreciates Ditto's ability to break through setup sweepers like Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Venusaur, making it a great partner. In return, Blissey can pivot out slowly with Teleport to provide free switch-in opportunities. Corviknight is a fantastic partner for its ability to remove entry hazards to keep Ditto healthy throughout the game and pivot out with U-turn to bring it in safely. Trick Clefable can help cripple entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Corviknight and other Pokemon like Toxapex and Ferrothorn. Toxapex is useful for dealing with defensive Calm Mind Pokemon like Clefable, which Ditto struggles against due to its Choice Scarf. If you opt to run Toxapex, having a Regenerator core from Pokemon like Reuniclus, Amoonguss, or Tangrowth can prove useful, allowing Ditto to better PP stall defensive Pokemon. Having wallbreakers to support Ditto against stall can benefit it greatly; Pokemon like Safeguard Volcarona, Substitute Kyurem, and Block + Transform Mew can prove useful, with the latter trapping Toxapex, which Ditto struggles to remove.

uu.overview: The combination of Imposter and Choice Scarf allows Ditto to outspeed the foe, making it a strong setup deterrent and one of the best revenge killers to sweepers like Thundurus, Salamence, and Kommo-o. Ditto also has utility against stall teams, as it cannot be easily PP stalled, especially if it is able to switch into Knock Off from defensive Tangrowth, and can take advantage of transforming into opposing clerics like Umbreon and Chansey. However, Ditto can be awkward to fit onto teams, as it often cannot switch into anything safely or provide any defensive utility outside of Regenerator. Imposter also fails against Substitute, which can be problematic against certain variants of Kommo-o and Gyarados. Ditto is also unable to effectively stop bulkier setup sweepers with recovery such as Galarian Slowbro and Reuniclus due to being Choice-locked.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Ditto's value is rooted in its revenge killing capabilities, so it should never run anything besides Choice Scarf.

Checks and Counters

Substitute Users: Substitute users like Chandelure and Kommo-o can prevent Ditto from revenge killing them and proceed to wreak havoc.

Choice Scarf Users: Opposing Choice Scarf users will always Speed tie with Ditto and cannot be reliably revenge killed.

Knock Off: Ditto relies on Choice Scarf to outspeed and properly check threats, so it should avoid taking a Knock Off except when it is copying Regenerator or facing a stall team.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description:
Transform is the only move Ditto learns. The provided EVs allow Ditto to do more damage with Future Sight after transforming into a Pokemon like Reuniclus.

Ditto is able to function as a revenge killer on any archetype but is most often found on bulky balance or stall teams that are too passive to efficiently prevent Pokemon from setting up. Chansey is an excellent partner that can get Ditto in safely with Teleport to immediately pressure strong wallbreakers like Salamence and Lycanroc-D. Since Ditto is grounded before transforming, it is vulnerable to all entry hazards besides Sticky Web; entry hazard removal from Salamence and Rotom-H is valuable to keep Ditto healthy. Klefki is able to provide Spikes to wear down the opposing team to better facilitate a countersweep from Ditto. Bulky pivots such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss appreciate Ditto's ability to countersweep, since Pokemon like Salamence often use them as setup fodder. In return, Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into opposing Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude, which Speed tie with Ditto, and sponge Knock Off. Regenerator users such as the aforementioned Reuniclus, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth work well with Ditto, as they can PP stall defensive walls like Chansey together. On stall teams, Pokemon like Haze Quagsire and Spite Pyukumuku can beat bulky Calm Mind users like Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro, which Ditto is unable to revenge kill.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Ditto is a reliable revenge killer with good offensive matchups, since it's able to revenge kill Pokemon like Swords Dance Cobalion and Shell Smash Cloyster. It also has a good stall matchup because it can infinitely replenish PP and copy utility moves. Ditto's EVs just maximize its physical bulk and minimize Speed in case of the rare Ditto mirror matchup, while the Impish nature and 4 Speed IVs with a Choice Scarf allow it to outspeed Galarian Weezing, which can block Imposter by activating Neutralizing Gas. An alternative spread with 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature maximizes Ditto's chances of winning mirror matchups.

Ditto can fit on a team mainly looking for a revenge killer to deal with a range of threats that cannot be walled by a single Pokemon and could break through the team. Thus, it's a solid pick with a defensive backbone. In return, defensive teammates can switch into offensive foes for it. Ditto can also fit on offensive teams that have very little defensive backbone, revenge killing threats that could run through the team and patching up the stall matchup. Ditto in turn appreciates offensive breakers such as Toxtricity and Heracross helping its shaky matchup against balance teams. It also needs teammates that can beat Substitute users like Suicune and Volcanion; countermeasures to these Pokemon include Infiltrator Pokemon such as Toxic Crobat and Noivern. Entry hazard removers like Togekiss can also be helpful for Ditto to reliably switch into threats. Cleric support from Pokemon like Umbreon and Sylveon prevents Toxic from stopping Ditto against stall teams. Finally, Knock Off absorbers like Bewear and Cobalion can be vital, as Ditto losing its Choice Scarf means it will be unable to revenge kill offensive threats.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
This set allows Ditto to be an effective revenge killer and anti-setup sweeper. Choice Scarf gives Ditto the ability to outspeed any Pokemon it copies, bar opposing Choice Scarf users and Hawlucha after Unburden has been activated. This means that setup sweepers like Gyarados, Togekiss, and Dragapult need to be wary of setting up, or else they may be met with a devastating countersweep. The given EVs are meant to maximize Ditto's HP, which is the only stat not changed by Imposter.

Volt Switch and U-turn users such as Heliolisk allow Ditto to preserve its HP by providing opportunities for it to switch in safely. Ditto appreciates the wallbreaking capabilities of Indeedee and Diggersby due to their ability to clear out defensive Pokemon and allow Ditto to sweep late-game. Indeedee's ability in Psychic Surge prevents the use of priority attacks, which prevents Ditto from being revenge killed by priority users such as Sucker Punch Dragapult, Ice Shard Mamoswine, and Shadow Sneak Mimikyu. Ditto struggles against bulky Pokemon and therefore appreciates the power and resilience of Snorlax. Snorlax can easily switch into utility and stall Pokemon without fear of status thanks to Rest. In return, Ditto can revenge kill the powerful setup sweepers Pokemon that force Snorlax out.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Ditto is one of the best revenge killers in the tier and excellent at taking advantage of setup sweepers like Gyarados, Excadrill, and Terrakion that would be difficult to adequately cover defensively otherwise. It's a fairly straightforward Pokemon to use, as it transforms into any Pokemon you send it out against, bar a few situations, most commonly if the opposing Pokemon has a Substitute up. Due to its ability to check so many top-tier threats, Ditto can fit on all kinds of teams from offense to stall, but most commonly it finds its place on bulkier balance teams. Ditto doesn't need much support due to its nature, but it does appreciate U-turn and Volt Switch users like Corviknight, Urshifu, and Rotom-H to safely pivot it into frightening threats that it can't directly switch into otherwise, such as Keldeo and Excadrill. Ditto's ability to capitalize on setup Pokemon greatly discourages opposing teams from using setup, which gives teams with Ditto a huge advantage. Ditto is key in gaining momentum against fast and frail Pokemon without Choice Scarf, as it can force them out easily. This works for most strong wallbreakers provided you have a way to safely bring Ditto in. Additionally, Ditto can scout for coverage from opposing Pokemon such as Zeraora, Sylveon, and Rotom-H, which can be important in checking these threats.

Ditto has a few moveset options, and though it rarely gets to utilize these tools, they can be useful in a pinch. Rapid Spin or Court Change can be used to control entry hazards on the field; Rapid Spin is arguably better due to damaging the target, while Court Change can impact the entire field by shifting hazards over to the opposing team's side. Whirlwind is an especially useful tool for Ditto that can phaze Substitute users. Recover gives Ditto increased longevity in lengthy battles. Heal Bell is solid utility that can heal your team of status conditions in a pinch, while Super Fang is the best offensive option Ditto has. Perish Song, Encore, or Wish have marginal utility, but each have their own merits for teams to use. 252 Defense EVs and 0 Speed IVs with a Relaxed nature minimize damage taken from an opposing Ditto's Struggle and lower Ditto's Speed so it hopefully moves after opposing Ditto to avoid being the first to KO itself with Struggle damage.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Equipped with a Choice Scarf, Ditto is always able to outspeed any foe that it has copied unless they also hold a Choice Scarf or Ditto is undergoing Dynamax. Its ability Imposter is the reason it excels as a revenge killer. By causing it to copy all of the opponent's stats except HP, it is able to beat most sweepers such as Zacian-C, Mega Rayquaza, and non-Dynamaxed Xerneas by always hitting them first with boosted moves thanks to its Choice Scarf. A Relaxed nature, 0 Speed IVs, and maximum Defense investment are used in case Ditto is the last remaining Pokemon against another Ditto: it reduces the damage taken from Struggle and makes it as slow as possible, so that it uses Struggle last due to not copying the opposing Ditto first and therefore having more Transform PP. 248 HP EVs ensure it does not faint after four Struggles. The IV spread is optimal to have Hidden Power Fire when copying Xerneas, allowing it to potentially countersweep the opposing team with Dynamax, while maximizing the damage output of Struggle.

Ditto is one of the the best revenge killers in AG. It can make great use of Dynamax, which lets it snowball on the opposing team after having copied a boosted sweeper like Xerneas, Necrozma-DM, or Mewtwo. It is ideally sent out on the field after a teammate has fainted: Ditto can then revenge kill the foe or, if the opportunity allows it to, Dynamax to break its Choice lock and blow through the opponent's team thanks to augmented moves and doubled HP. Once its Dynamax is over, it can potentially continue to sweep with its Choice Scarf. It can also immediately copy Zacian-C and get an extra boost from Intrepid Sword that lets it break past traditional counterplay to Zacian-C such as defensive Necrozma-DM and Primal Groudon with Close Combat. Ditto is self-sufficient and fits on every playstyle, but it is typically of great value on balance teams that would otherwise be overwhelmed by the myriad of sweepers that can resort to Dynamax to bypass defensive and offensive counterplay alike. Since several Pokemon are self-Imposter-proof at varying levels, counterplay to those is highly recommended. Yveltal cannot be beaten with Ditto during any of the three Dynamax turns because it has a higher HP stat and a Life Orb, and even afterwards, Ditto can't revenge kill it without Dynamax unless Yveltal is seriously worn down, so having Tyranitar, Protect Ho-Oh, or Xerneas as a partner helps Ditto a lot. Xerneas also needs to be seriously weakened or unable to Dynamax before attempting to revenge kill it with Ditto; thus, Ho-Oh and Necrozma-DM make for good partners by forcing Xerneas to Dynamax and wasting two turns of it without much trouble. Entry hazard removal is also recommended because Ditto likes to be healthy to repeatedly check threats, so pairing it with Ho-Oh is a good idea. Ditto can struggle against defensive teams with Pokemon like Zygarde-C, Necrozma-DM, and Ho-Oh that it can do little to, so it pairs well with Pokemon like Mega Gengar and Eternatus. They provide a way to remove passive foes, while Ditto is able to check offensive threats such as Zacian-C for them.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Changing Ditto's happiness from 255 to 0 lets it beat Pokemon like Mega Altaria and Diggersby if they run Frustration, but not if they run Return. An IV spread of 30 Def / 30 SpD / 0 Spe can be used to revenge kill Pokemon like Volcarona and Thundurus-T with Hidden Power Rock on more hyper offensive Normal teams.

Checks and Counters

Normal

Defensive Sweepers: Ditto cannot properly counter defensive sweepers like Calm Mind Mega Slowbro, Suicune, and Mega Latias and CurseRest Steelix due to it only having 5 PP.

Hawlucha: Ditto cannot copy Hawlucha's Speed boost from Unburden or transform if it is behind a Substitute.

Status: Burn halves Ditto's Attack, causing it to be less effective in revenge killing physical attackers, poison lowers its longevity overtime, and paralysis prevents it from revenge killing due to its Speed drop.

Substitute: Ditto cannot transform into Pokemon behind a Substitute. Some examples of Pokemon that use Substitute are Keldeo, Blacephalon, and Magnezone.

Trick Room: Ditto has a hard time dealing with Trick Room setters like Hatterene and Stakataka, which are slower than Ditto because of its Choice Scarf.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Ditto is one of the best ways for Normal teams to handle fast threats, as Imposter mirrors opposing Pokemon's stats and Choice Scarf makes Ditto outspeed them. With Ditto in battle, Pokemon like Volcarona, Mega Altaria, and Kommo-o are pressured from setting up because it can steal stat boosts to countersweep, and Imposter means Sticky Web has no effect on it. Ditto can also exploit support Pokemon like Zapdos and Blissey to recover with Roost or Soft-Boiled and entry hazard removers like Pelipper and Coalossal to clear hazards. It can also safely switch into Mega Sableye's Knock Off to trade Speed for move freedom, and it ignores defensive Celesteela's Toxic. However, Ditto's 5 PP per move and Choice lock give it a hard time beating defensive sweepers like CurseRest Mega Steelix and Calm Mind Mega Slowbro. Choice Scarf is required for Ditto to revenge kill setup sweepers like Swords Dance Excadrill and Mega Lopunny and Speed tie with opposing Choice Scarf Pokemon like Nihilego and Landorus-T. Ditto cannot copy HP, so investing 252 EVs into HP helps it a lot, and 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature allow it to not transform and lose PP against mirrored Ditto. The mentioned IV spread allows it to have HP Fire to trap and KO Magnezone.

Defensive Pokemon like Staraptor, Blissey, and Porygon2 appreciate Ditto because it can revenge kill setup Pokemon like Dragon Dance Altaria and Bulk Up Cinderace that will try to break and setup on them. Ditto appreciates Pokemon with pivoting moves, like Teleport Blissey and Porygon2 and U-Turn Staraptor, to allow it to come in safely. Staraptor helps with Fighting-types with its part Flying typing and Intimidate, and it has Defog to clear entry hazards for when Ditto comes in. Ditto does not appreciate being statused in any form, so Blissey as a teammate can absorb status thanks to Natural Cure. Offensive Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Diggersby, Heliolisk, and Indeedee-M are appreciated, as they can remove defensive Pokemon Ditto cannot revenge kill. Mega Lopunny's Close Combat helps with Pokemon like Tyranitar and Mamoswine, and its Encore to helps with defensive sweepers like the aforementioned Steelix and Calm Mind Mega Slowbro. Diggersby helps with Electric-, Rock-, and Steel-types like Zapdos, Coalossal, and Aegislash with Earthquake and can revenge kill faster Pokemon like Zeraora and Cinderace with Quick Attack. Indeedee-M helps with Fighting- and Poison-types like Keldeo and Toxapex with Expanding Force and prevents priority moves like Mach Punch from working thanks to Psychic Terrain. Heliolisk helps with Water- and Flying-types like Celesteela, Toxapex, and Mantine with Thunderbolt and has Dry Skin to offer Water immunity for the team.

nu.overview: Thanks to its good typing, solid defenses, and great supportive tools, Vaporeon cements itself as one of the best defensive Pokemon in NU. Vaporeon's solid overall bulk allows it to check strong Pokemon such as Salazzle, Talonflame, and Blastoise. Moreover, Vaporeon has great utility options in Wish, Heal Bell, and Toxic to support its partners, and it is able to scout attacks with Protect. Unfortunately, Vaporeon faces lots of competition from Sylveon; despite Vaporeon's ability to pivot with Flip Turn, Sylveon is an overall superior defensive Pokemon that can also pass Wishes and defensively answer offensive Water-types like Starmie and Inteleon. Also, Vaporeon's passivity leaves it easily exploited by threats like Rotom-C, Vileplume, and Decidueye. Furthermore, even with a lot of investment in its bulk, Vaporeon's Defense is still lacking, which leaves it vulnerable to strong physical wallbreakers.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Haze is a great alternative over Flip Turn, as it allows Vaporeon to stop setup sweepers like Shell Smash Blastoise, but using this comes at the cost of Flip Turn's ability to grab momentum. Ice Beam can be used to hit incoming Grass- and Dragon-types like Rotom-C, Vileplume, and Flygon harder. A more specially defensive EV spread lets Vaporeon better fend off Pokemon such as Starmie and Blastoise.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Both Decidueye and Dhelmise threaten Vaporeon with their STAB options, but they have to be careful about switching into Vaporeon and getting burned by Scald. Vileplume is also annoying, as it can hit Vaporeon super effectively with Giga Drain and regain health while having the ability to poison it with Sludge Bomb.

Electric-types: Heliolisk is very annoying, as it is immune to Vaporeon's Water-type STAB moves; all Vaporeon can do is hit it with Toxic on the switch. Rotom-C is especially dangerous, as it has two STAB moves that are super effective against Vaporeon.

Dragon-types: Dragalge is very potent against Vaporeon, as it doesn't fear being whittled down by Toxic and can fish for poisons with Sludge Bomb. Goodra hits Vaporeon with strong super effective coverage, and Guzzlord weakens Vaporeon severely with Knock Off and Toxic, but it dislikes getting burned by Scald.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Set Details

Heal Bell is a great tool to keep Vaporeon and its partners healthy and helps it cure status effects, which otherwise hinder its role as a defensive Pokemon. Alternatively, Toxic wears down Mantine and Heliolisk, two Pokemon Vaporeon otherwise is helpless against, whereas Flip Turn creates momentum for Vaporeon's teammates, helps Vaporeon pass Wishes more safely, and prevents foes such as Vileplume, Rotom-C, and Dragalge from taking advantage of it. Leftovers grants Vaporeon more longevity and synergizes well with Protect. Alternatively, Heavy-Duty Boots grants Vaporeon better durability and helps it to pivot more consistently. The listed EVs allow Vaporeon to avoid a 2HKO from +4 Blastoise's Dark Pulse.

Vaporeon has great typing and bulk, and it fits well on bulkier builds such as bulky offense and balance due to its passivity. Wish and Flip Turn are excellent tools to safely bring in its partners and keep them healthy; these partners include wallbreakers like Assault Vest Copperajah, Dragalge, and Escavalier. Vaporeon dislikes strong Electric- and Grass-types such as Heliolisk, Rotom-C, Decidueye, and Dhelmise, so partners like Vileplume, Dragalge, and Goodra check them for Vaporeon; in return, Vaporeon can safely bring in these checks with Flip Turn. Ground-types such as Flygon and Mudsdale are good partners, as they check Electric-types like Heliolisk. Vaporeon is reliant on its item, so Knock Off absorbers such as itemless Vileplume make for great partners. In return, Vaporeon helps Vileplume against Pokemon like Salazzle, Talonflame, and boosted Blastoise.

lc.overview: Porygon is a threatening bulky attacker because of its boosted Tri Attack being difficult to switch into, great coverage options such as Psychic and Ice Beam, and ability to threaten prominent Pokemon like Timburr, Vullaby, and Onix. It can also run a defensive set that allows it to counter trappers like Diglett, Trapinch, and Wynaut with Trace and gain momentum with Teleport or spread paralysis with Thunder Wave. However, Porygon struggles with Fighting-type Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Mienfoo and Timburr due to these two outpacing and KOing it, while slower Mienfoo can tank a Psychic and OHKO with High Jump Kick. Additionally, Porygon cannot take on Steel-types like Ferroseed, Magnemite, and Pawniard because they can tank any of Porygon's attacks and cripple it with Thunder Wave or Knock Off. Porygon also struggles to take Knock Off as well, as losing Eviolite makes it unable to sponge attacks from Focus Sash Abra, Onix, and Ponyta, leaving it vulnerable to being KOed.
lc.comments:
Other Options

Thunderbolt can be used over Psychic to more effectively hit Pawniard while retaining coverage for Mareanie, but it is generally worse against Fighting-types. Recover can be used on Download sets to allow Porygon to stay healthy throughout the match; however, it would have to drop a coverage move or Agility. Running Thunderbolt over Thunder Wave or Tri Attack alongside Ice Beam gives it the best possible neutral coverage. A Choice Scarf Porygon set with Download can be used in order to revenge kill Mienfoo and can use Trick to hinder walls like Ferroseed.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Mienfoo and Timburr are able to take care of Porygon using their Fighting-type STAB attacks, but they should be careful about switching into Tri Attack or being heavily damaged by Psychic.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Ferroseed, Pawniard, and Magnemite can take any attack from Porygon because of their resistance to its attacks. Pawniard and Ferroseed can also use Knock Off to make Porygon easier to take care of. Ferroseed can also use Thunder Wave to cripple Porygon so it can't outpace Timburr.

Knock Off: Knock Off users like Vullaby, Pawniard, and Ferroseed hinder Porygon through removing its Eviolite, making it unable to tank attacks from Ponyta and Abra.

Priority Attacks: Priority attacks like Mienfoo's Fake Out, Pawniard's Sucker Punch, and Grookey's Grassy Glide can revenge kill Agility Porygon because of its lack of recovery.

sets.name: Download
sets.description:
Moves

Tri Attack hits targets that don't resist it hard after a Special Attack boost from Download. Psychic allows Porygon to take care of Mienfoo, Foongus, and Mareanie. Ice Beam is able to OHKO Onix, Archen, and Vullaby and is Porygon's best move against Ferroseed, as it resists Psychic and Tri Attack. Agility makes Porygon a good mid- or late-game sweeper when most of its checks are significantly weakened, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Mienfoo and Vullaby.

Set Details

Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment with a Modest nature allows Porygon to hit as hard as possible and outpace Timburr, while the remaining EVs go into Defense to help it take physical attacks.

Usage Tips

Porygon should be saved for mid- or late-game once most of its threats are weakened or KOed so it can set up with Agility and sweep. Porygon should come in on a predicted switch, Stealth Rock from Onix, or after a teammate is knocked out to keep it healthy, but it should avoid setting up on Vulpix, Dewpider, or Abra, as coming in on them will give Porygon an Attack boost from Download instead of a Special Attack boost. Porygon can also be used on slower threats to soften them up for mid- or late-game, but be careful about switching it into a powerful attack, as, if it takes too much damage, it will be unable to set up with Agility and sweep. Make sure that Steel-types are weakened or KOed; once they are, Porygon can freely use its attacks. Do not allow Porygon to be chipped by entry hazards, as this makes it easier to take care of. Be sure to not leave Porygon in against Knock Off users such as Pawniard, Vullaby, and Ferroseed, as losing its Eviolite makes it less bulky and unable to tank attacks from Spritzee, Ponyta, and Grookey.

Team Options

Porygon appreciates entry hazard support from Onix, Ferroseed, Pawniard, and Mareanie because it makes it easier for Porygon to sweep; it especially goes well with Ferroseed for its Spikes support to wear down Pokemon like opposing Ferroseed, Pawniard, and Mienfoo. Pawniard also threatens Abra, which could otherwise hinder Porygon, with Sucker Punch. Pokemon that can get rid of entry hazards such as Staryu and Vullaby are great to avoid Porygon being poisoned from Toxic Spikes and worn down from Stealth Rock and Spikes. Vullaby can also tank priority attacks from Mienfoo and Grookey. Mienfoo, Diglett, and Ponyta are also good to pair with Porygon in order to help with taking down Steel-types like Ferroseed, Pawniard, and Magnemite that resist Porygon's attacks. Pokemon like Mienfoo, Pawniard, and Ferroseed can soften up Pokemon with Knock Off to make it easier for Porygon to sweep. Mareanie and Foongus are great to pair with Porygon due to them being able to switch into Fighting-type attacks from Mienfoo and Timburr.

sets.name: Trace
sets.description:
Moves

Tri Attack is a good STAB move to use against any Pokemon that does not resist it, such as Staryu and Spritzee, with the added benefit of a small chance to inflict status. Ice Beam is used to OHKO Diglett and 2HKO Onix, Mudbray, and Vullaby. Psychic can be used for Mareanie and on a predicted switch to Mienfoo or Timburr. Recover allows Porygon to keep itself healthy throughout the game. Thunder Wave is used to hinder switch-ins like Mienfoo, Pawniard, and Vullaby. Teleport can be used over Thunder Wave to keep momentum for the team and be less passive than Mareanie, Spritzee, and Foongus, as Porygon can lure its checks such as Mienfoo, Onix, and Ferroseed and pivot into a Pokemon that can take care of them.

Set Details

Running 236 HP EVs with 76 Special Defense EVs with a Calm nature allows Porygon to take hits from special attackers like Spritzee, Wingull, and Focus Sash Abra. Using 236 HP EVs with 196 Defense EVs allows Porygon to tank physical attacks from Onix and Diglett. Trace allows Porygon to copy Regenerator from Foongus and Mienfoo, the rare Flash Fire from Ponyta, and Volt Absorb from Chinchou to block Volt Switch, as well as to counter trappers like Trapinch and Diglett.

Usage Tips

Porygon can be used early-game to use Thunder Wave against Pokemon like Mienfoo or Teleport on predicted switches into checks like Pawniard and Mienfoo to safely get in a teammate to take care of them. Teleport can also be used to allow Porygon to take an attack and bring in frail Pokemon like Abra and Carvanha safely. However, Porygon should be careful about staying in against Knock Off users like Ferroseed, Vullaby, and Mienfoo, as losing Eviolite will make it unable to withstand attacks from Ponyta, Staryu, and Abra. It should switch in on a passive attack from Mareanie or Spritzee, a predicted switch, or an attack from Ponyta or Onix. It should use Tri Attack early-game to get off decent damage against most Pokemon that do not resist it with a small chance of statusing Pokemon like Pawniard and Mienfoo that will try to switch into Porygon's attacks. Ice Beam should be used on predicted switches into Vullaby and Onix, as it will deal major damage to them; additionally, if Porygon is running Psychic, try to use it on predicted switches into Mienfoo and Mareanie, as it will do a lot of damage to them.

Team Options

Stealth Rock setters such as Pawniard and Onix are great to pair with Porygon; Pawniard is able to come in on Knock Off from Ferroseed, while Onix can safely switch into Vullaby to take Knock Off and threaten it to switch out. Bulky Pokemon like Mareanie and Foongus can come in on Fighting-type attacks from Mienfoo and Timburr. Offensive Pokemon like Abra and Wingull are also good to pair with Porygon to check the aforementioned Fighting-types. Defog and Rapid Spin users like Vullaby and Staryu are good to get rid of entry hazards that allow Pokemon like Abra, Wingull, and Grookey to beat Porygon before it can use Recover. Vullaby and Staryu are also helpful by checking Fighting-types that threaten Porygon such as Timburr and Mienfoo, and Staryu is especially helpful against Corphish and Onix. Spritzee is another great Fighting-type check that can pass Wish to Porygon to keep it healthy and also absorb Knock Off from Pokemon like Vullaby, Timburr, and Mienfoo. Fighting-types like Mienfoo and Timburr can force out Steel-types like Pawniard and Ferroseed; in return, Porygon can wall special attackers such as Wingull, Abra, and Mareanie. Setup sweepers and wallbreakers such as Tyrunt, Scraggy, and Grookey appreciate Porygon's Teleport getting them in safely.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Porygon functions as a solid wallbreaker in the NFE metagame thanks to its amazing coverage and great pair of abilities, allowing it to check walls like Mareanie, Tangela, and Vullaby. Tri Attack is Porygon's most spammable attack, used against threats like Piloswine, Hattrem, and Clefairy while having a good chance of inflicting them with status. Ice Beam enables Porygon to hit Grass- and Flying-types like Roselia, Vullaby, and Togetic, while Thunderbolt can hit Water-types like Wartortle and Brionne. Psychic allows Porygon to hit Fighting- and Poison-types like Machoke, Hakamo-o, and Mareanie and force them out. Trick can also be used to cripple walls like Galarian Corsola, Klang, and Ferroseed and gain an Eviolite in return. Shadow Ball is another option as the last move to hit Ghost-types like Galarian Corsola and Lampent. Download allows Porygon to boost its Special Attack further, while Analytic can be used to punish switch-ins and increase your chances of scoring 2HKOs against many Pokemon. A Choice Scarf can be used to outspeed threats like Choice Band Piloswine and offensive Roselia, but you do lose out on notable 2HKOs against the likes of Mareanie and Piloswine.

While Porygon has a great offensive presence, its biggest downside is its speed. Pairing Porygon with a Sticky Web setter like Charjabug is therefore encouraged to outspeed threats like Fraxure, Hakamo-o, and Adamant Raboot. Entry hazard setters like Roselia, Galarian Corsola, and Piloswine are also good partners, as their entry hazards can wear down switch-ins like Klang and Ferroseed. Porygon also appreciates slow pivots like Slowpoke and Clefairy that can safely switch it in and bait in Pokemon like Vullaby and Koffing. Clefairy can also be used as a Wish passer to prevent Porygon from being worn down. Wallbreakers that use Knock Off like Galarian Linoone, Machoke, and Thwackey are also good partners, as they can remove Eviolites from Clefairy, Mareanie, and Klang, which could otherwise stand up to Porygon. As a Normal-type, Porygon doesn't have any resistances and is vulnerable to Fighting-types like Machoke and Mienfoo, therefore physically defensive walls like Tangela and Galarian Corsola should be used to prevent these threats from KOing Porygon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Porygon can function as a specially defensive pivot, as it reliably checks threats like Lampent, Gastly, and Seadra. Shadow Ball is used to hit Ghost-types like Lampent and Galarian Corsola. Tri Attack provides general damage against most of the metagame along with a 20% chance to inflict the opposing Pokemon with status, but Psychic punishes Fighting-types that like to switch into Porygon such as Machoke. Recover is used to help Porygon's longevity against threats; it can also be used to scout moves from Choice-locked Pokemon like Hattrem and Gastly. Teleport enables Porgyon to pivot out on threats as they switch in. Trace allows Porygon to wall threats like Lampent as well as profit from other abilities like Regenerator and Magic Guard from Slowpoke and Clefairy.

Poygon provides support to its team by being able to wall special attackers like Lampent and Seadra, therefore making it a great partner to Pokemon that are weak to these threats like Raboot, Roselia, and Hattrem. Teleport should be used to gain momentum when expecting opposing special attackers like Lampent to switch out. As a defensive Pokemon, Porygon relies a lot on its Eviolite to function, so it needs to be wary of Knock Off users like Vullaby, Tangela, and Mareanie. Furthermore, Porygon can easily get pressured out by Fighting-types and physical wallbreakers like Machoke and Thwackey, so having physically defensive Pokemon to compensate for that weakness like Galarian Corsola and Tangela is encouraged. Porygon is also heavily worn down by status when Trace doesn't catch Magic Guard or Regenerator, so having a cleric like Clefairy or Lickitung can be found helpful. Frailer Pokemon like Morgrem and Kadabra can take advantage of the safe switches that Porygon's Teleport provides.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
Omastar has a niche in RU as a strong Shell Smash sweeper on both rain and hyper offense teams. However, it struggles to find setup opportunities due to its typing and poor Special Defense, and even with boosts, it still slightly struggles to break through some bulky Pokemon such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Gastrodon, and Snorlax. Meteor Beam OHKOes bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Suicune, and Volcanion after Shell Smash boosts, which otherwise check Omastar well. Surf is the preferred STAB move when Omastar is used on rain teams. Hydro Pump, on the other hand, is the better choice on hyper offense due to its higher Base Power, allowing Omastar to OHKO bulky Metagross and offensive Necrozma as well as 2HKO Registeel and Snorlax. Ice Beam OHKOes many Dragon- and Grass-types such as Noivern, Celebi, and Roserade, as well as Dragalge and Toxicroak after some chip damage. Swift Swim is the ability of choice if Omastar is used on rain teams, while Weak Armor has more use on hyper offense.

Politoed is a necessary teammate if Omastar is used on rain teams. Seismitoad and Kingdra are strong rain sweepers, which help Omastar to overwhelm bulky Pokemon such as Milotic, Registeel, and Assault Vest Reuniclus. In addition, Seismitoad also provides Stealth Rock support and an immunity to Electric-type moves. Tornadus, Raikou, Metagross, and Toxicroak are other examples that work well on rain teams and help Omastar to break through opposing teams. If Omastar is used on hyper offense, Alolan Ninetales can support it with Aurora Veil or create set up opportunities with encore. In addition, Arctozolt can be used alongside Alolan Ninetales as a strong wallbreaker, which breaks through bulky teams that Omastar struggles with. Other strong setup sweepers such as Linoone, Mimikyu, and Polteageist help Omastar overwhelm opposing teams.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description: Kabutops is a niche but potent rain attacker with access to Swords Dance that can either pivot with powerful Flip Turns or clean when rain runs out with Aqua Jet. Liquidation is stronger than Waterfall, but Waterfall can give unexpected openings through flinches. Superpower is an option to hit Gastrodon and Seismitoad neutrally, letting Kabutops break past them if they are chipped. Kabutops should always be run with Politoed on dedicated rain teams. Other rain sweepers such as Kingdra, Nasty Plot Tornadus, and Seismitoad can work in tandem with Kabutops to wear down the opposing team's defensive structure. Checks to opposing Gastrodon and defensive variants of Seismitoad, such as Tornadus and Ludicolo, are necessary, as Kabutops is completely walled by them. Other Pokemon that fit on rain teams like Klefki, Toxicroak, and Heliolisk also pair well with Kabutops.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance allows Aerodactyl to function as a dangerous setup sweeper. One boost from Dragon Dance lets Aerodactyl OHKO threats like Zarude while being faster than most Choice Scarf users, including Zarude and Mienshao. Earthquake hits Steel-types like Steelix, Stakataka, and Metagross that resist both STAB moves. Life Orb is preferred, but Heavy-Duty Boots does grant Aerodactyl Stealth Rock immunity and lacks Life Orb's recoil, which makes setting up easier. An Adamant nature lets Aerodactyl hit harder, while a Jolly nature lets it outspeed Noivern unboosted. Unnerve prevents threats like Cobalion from using their Shuca Berry and eating up an Earthquake.

Bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad eat up Aerodactyl's moves and check it, so teammates like Zarude, Roserade, and Toxtricity are appreciated. Zarude serves as a Scald switch-in that can heal itself with Jungle Healing while pivoting out on a Togekiss switch-in for Aerodactyl. Roserade provides Spikes support to wear down said Water-types as well as a super effective STAB Leaf Storm. Despite Earthquake being able to hit them, Steel-types like Doublade, Steelix, and Registeel can be problematic. Teammates like Incineroar, Milotic, and Heracross handle them with minimal fuss. A partner like Obstagoon or Choice Specs Gardevoir can wear down Steel-types to put them in OHKO range of Aerodactyl's attacks. Teammates like Dhelmise and Registeel that appreciate Aerodactyl pressuring threats like Noivern, Chandelure, and Fighting-types work as partners. Dhelmise is notable because it provides Rapid Spin support for Aerodactyl using Life Orb. Other notable entry hazard control teammates include Starmie and Volcanion to check threats like Rhyperior.

sets.name: 3 Attacks + Roost
sets.description: Aerodactyl's natural Speed and Attack stats also make it a decent choice for an anti-offense Pokemon, outspeeding common threats like Noivern and Raikou. Earthquake guarantees OHKOs on Electric-types like Xurkitree and Toxtricity while guaranteeing 2HKOs on Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka. Roost gives Aerodactyl reliable recovery to make up for Life Orb recoil and potential Stealth Rock chip if it's not carrying Heavy-Duty Boots. Teammates like Galarian Weezing and Volcanion can provide Defog support while also checking threats like Choice Scarf Mienshao and bulkier Steel-types, respectively. Dhelmise, Roserade, and Xurkitree can deal with bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad that give Aerodactyl a hard time. Dhelmise provides Rapid Spin support, while Roserade provides Spikes support to further wear down Aerodactyl's checks. Teammates like Zarude and Cobalion that can bring in Aerodactyl safely to beat Togekiss and Chandelure, respectively, are appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Xurkitree, Darmanitan, and the aforementioned Mienshao OHKO Aerodactyl. Therefore, teammates like Assault Vest Reuniclus, Milotic, and Galarian Weezing are useful to check these threats.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Flying

Mega Aerodactyl's fast Taunt can be used to stop entry hazard setters like Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Krookodile as well as prevent walls like Toxapex, Galarian Corsola, and Porygon2 from using recovery moves; however, Mega Aerodactyl values all of its moveslots and Flying-type teams have better Taunt users. Fire Fang is also an option to hit Steel-type Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Forretress harder than any move on the set. Dual Wingbeat can be used over Dragon Dance to beat Pokemon like Kommo-o, Mega Gallade, and Mega Venusaur.

Checks and Counters

Flying

Defensive Pokemon: Sturdy defensive Pokemon like Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Ferrothorn have little to fear from Mega Aerodactyl, as they can take it on even after a Dragon Dance, cripple it with status moves, and proceed to wear it down.

Status Moves: Being a physical attacker, Mega Aerodactyl fears burns from Scald and Will-O-Wisp, which leave it unable to do any significant damage. Paralysis from Thunder Wave and Discharge leaves it severely crippled, as it makes it slower and therefore a lot easier to handle.

Steel-type Pokemon: Mega Aerodactyl, in general, has trouble beating Steel-type Pokemon such as Aegislash, Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Melmetal, as, due to their good bulk, they can take any unboosted move and severely damage it back.

Priority Moves: Mega Aerodactyl is weak to common priority moves like Bullet Punch, Aqua Jet, and Ice Shard from Pokemon such as Scizor, Azumarill, and Mamoswine, which can OHKO it or severely weaken it.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-type Pokemon like Swampert, Slowbro, and Gastrodon give a hard time to Mega Aerodactyl, as it cannot hit them with super effective attacks and risk being burned by Scald.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Mega Aerodactyl's high Attack stat, stellar Speed stat, and good offensive typing make it a solid offensive Pokemon for Flying-type teams. Its great Speed also lets it outspeed and handle fast threats like Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Weavile. Its access to Dragon Dance lets Mega Aerodactyl increase its already good Attack stat to even greater levels and outspeed extremely fast Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Greninja, Regieleki, and Excadrill in the sand, making it considerably harder to revenge kill. Stealth Rock can also be used over Dragon Dance for role compression, especially when Mega Aerodactyl's teammates are not carrying it. Its high Speed stat lets it set Stealth Rock quickly against types like Flying, Dragon, and Fire and threaten their entry hazard removers. Stone Edge hits much of the metagame for good damage right off the bat, especially with Rock's good coverage. When boosted by Dragon Dance, it scores 2HKOs on Pokemon such as Slowbro and Mega Venusaur after minor chip damage. Earthquake in tandem with Stone Edge improves Mega Aerodactyl's coverage and lets it hit Pokemon such as Aegislash and Toxapex reliably. It also takes care of Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Magnezone, and Zeraora without relying on Stone Edge to hit. Tough Claws-boosted Ice Fang lets Mega Aerodactyl take care of bulky Ground- and Dragon-type Pokemon like Gliscor, Landorus, and Garchomp. Stone Edge + Ice Fang synergizes well in the Dragon matchup, as it can hit every viable Dragon-type for super effective damage. Pursuit, which is also boosted by Tough Claws, can be used over Ice Fang to handle threats to Flying-type teams such as Choice Band Victini, Mega Latias, and Latios.

Mega Aerodactyl is vulnerable to Electric-type Pokemon like Alolan Raichu in Electric Terrain and Regieleki, so teammates like Gliscor and Landorus can cover that weakness. Gliscor can provide stallbreaking support to wear down walls and absorb status for Mega Aerodactyl, while Landorus is a formidable wallbreaker to beat physical walls like Toxapex, Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Hippowdon. Additionally, both can also utilize Stealth Rock so Mega Aerodactyl can use Dragon Dance to be more threatening. Ice- and Rock-type Pokemon like Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Weavile, Nihilego, and Terrakion also threaten Mega Aerodactyl, so teammates like Corviknight, Celesteela, and Skarmory can handle them; in return, Mega Aerodactyl can deal with problematic Fire-type Pokemon like Victini and Mega Charizard Y. Corviknight can act as a great wincon with its Bulk Up set after Mega Aerodactyl has weakened the team, while Skarmory can also take on physical threats like Mega Scizor, Mega Sharpedo, and Excadrill. They both also provide Defog support to help with Mega Aerodactyl's Stealth Rock weakness. Celesteela, on the other hand, can take care of Steel-type Pokemon with Flamethrower or wear down teams for Mega Aerodactyl with Toxic + Leech Seed support and check Mega Diancie. Special attackers such as Thundurus-T and Tornadus-T can take care of Water-type Pokemon such as Swampert, Toxapex, and Urshifu-R that are problematic for Mega Aerodactyl. Mantine and Mandibuzz are also decent teammates to take on Water- and Ghost-type threats like Kingdra and Aegislash; the former provides Mega Aerodactyl with an important Water-type immunity while the latter provides pivoting with U-turn and Knock Off support. A wallbreaker like Dragonite can weaken shared checks like Toxapex for Mega Aerodactyl and appreciates Stealth Rock support for a late-game sweep.

sets.name: Curselax
sets.description:
Snorlax's overall bulk and access to Curse enable it to check Fire- and Electric-types such as Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Raikou. However, Snorlax's typing leaves it with no resistances, making it unable to switch into powerful Pokemon such as Choice Specs Toxtricity and Indeedee-M. Curse enables Snorlax to have immense sweeping potential while also letting it threaten its checks. Body Slam inflicts paralysis, making it easier for Snorlax to get boosts from Curse while helping its teammates by slowing down faster threats. Earthquake provides great coverage against Normal-resistant and -immune Pokemon like Cobalion and Alolan Marowak. Rest is Snorlax's main recovery move while also being able to remove status effects. Thick Fat enables Snorlax to reliably switch into Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion. 12 HP EVs slightly increase recovery from Leftovers. Snorlax can opt for a spread of 12 HP / 116 Atk / 204 Def / 176 SpD to OHKO Cobalion with Earthquake after a Curse and a Defense drop from Close Combat and evade a 3HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt and Volcanion's Steam Eruption. Alternatively, Snorlax can use a spread of 184 HP / 72 Def / 252 SpD to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Toxtricity's Boomburst after Stealth Rock.

Snorlax usually prefers to be on balanced and bulky offensive teams due to it checking major wallbreakers like Chandelure and its sweeping potential. Snorlax's weakness to Fighting-type attacks means it appreciates having Fairy-types teammates like Galarian Weezing, Gardevoir, and Togekiss. Galarian Weezing is particularly useful for switching into Guts Heracross, which can threaten to OHKO Snorlax even after a Curse. Cleric support from the likes of Sylveon and Umbreon is very helpful if Snorlax is forced out after using Rest. Snorlax enjoys having Toxic Spikes support from Dragalge and Galarian Weezing since it can pressure bulky Waters-types like Haze Milotic. Knock Off users like Incineroar and Obstagoon make great teammates because they are able to remove valuable items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, making it easier for Snorlax to beat its checks such as Haze Milotic and Rhyperior. Snorlax likes to have Dark-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Drapion as teammates since they are able to check Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Doublade.

sets.name: Curse Sweeper (Normal)
sets.description:
Snorlax finds a strong niche on Normal-teams as a bulky setup sweeper using Curse that can threaten types like Ice, Electric, Psychic, and Ghost after accumulating multiple boosts and serve as a strong late-game wincon. Snorlax's high Special bulk gives it setup opportunities against many common special attackers such as Dragapult and Gardevoir, and Curse's Defense boost makes it difficult to break past for many teams. Thick Fat makes Snorlax a valuable asset for Normal teams, allowing it to check Fire- and Ice-types such as Chandelure and Galarian Darmanitan, which Normal teams otherwise struggle to switch into. Rest in conjunction with Sleep Talk allow Snorlax to keep itself healthy throughout the match and heal itself of crippling status such as burn and Toxic without being entirely passive. However, Snorlax is susceptible to getting shut down by common Taunt users like Sableye, Mew, and Corviknight, as well as by Haze and Whirlwind users such as Toxapex and Hippowdon. Darkest Lariat is Snorlax's attack of choice, as it ignores opposing stat boosts from Pokemon such as Reuniclus and has no Pokemon that are completely immune to it. However, Snorlax's reliance on Curse and Darkest Lariat to pose an offensive threat means exceptionally powerful attackers that resist Dark such as Nasty Plot Hydriegon, Crawdaunt, and most Fighting-types can break through it with relatively few issues. Snorlax's HP and Defense EVs allow it to always avoid being 2HKOed by Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan's Earthquake after Stealth Rock damage. Snorlax should utilize its special bulk and Rest to switch into powerful special attackers such as Hatterene and Alolan Raichu and common status users such as Salazzle and Gastrodon.

Obstagoon serves as a great offensive partner for Snorlax, as it can switch into common Taunt users such as Mew and Sableye without fear of Will-O-Wisp and break past them, allowing Snorlax to sweep Psychic- and Ghost-type teams more easily. Ditto is a good Choice Scarf user that can dissuade opponents from using Snorlax as setup fodder thanks to Imposter allowing it to threaten to countersweep. Indeedee-M is a powerful special attacker that can pressure Fighting-types like Conkeldurr and Kommo-o as well as break past physically defensive walls such as Toxapex and Galarian Weezing using its powerful Psychic Terrain-boosted attacks. Diggersby acts as a powerful wallbreaker that can utilize its good coverage options to break past Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Corviknight, which can use Snorlax as setup fodder, as well as set Spikes to wear down teams for Snorlax to sweep more easily. Choice Scarf Braviary provides a Ground immunity to help check Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Keldeo and can Defog away entry hazards that can wear down Snorlax over the course of a match. Heliolisk acts as a check to Corviknight, as well as an offensive check to Water- and Flying-types, helping Snorlax deal with Pokemon such as Keldeo, Togekiss, and Toxapex more easily. Bewear acts as a check to physically offensive Dark-types such as Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Crawdaunt that can easily beat Snorlax while appreciating Snorlax's ability to switch into Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Chandelure thanks to Thick Fat.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Gmax Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Snorlax can use Belly Drum or Curse to raise its stats to frightening levels and break many Pokemon who would otherwise wall it.

  • Heavy Slam and Earthquake are both great coverage choices in the Crown Tundra metagame, and when using them with Gigantamax, it allows Snorlax to boost its Defense and Special Defense with their respective Max Moves.

  • Figy Berry helps Snorlax gain back significant health when dropped below half HP, and can also be restored with Gmax Replenish.

EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 212 Def / 76 SpD Careful: This spread deals with prominent Special Attack boosting foes, such as Nihilego, and helps Snorlax wall with both its physical and special bulk.

  • 212 HP / 252 Def / 52 Spe Impish: Outspeeds Toxapex to avoid getting hit by Haze following a Belly Drum.

sets.name: Yawn Support
sets.description:
• Snorlax is a solid Yawn abuser, living nearly all Max Move attacks at full HP to guarantee disruption to its foes.

  • Heavy Slam allows Snorlax to hit the relevant Ghost-types well and boosts Defense with Max Steelspike, while Earthquake hits Nihilego and Heatran well, and raises Special Defense with Max Quake.

  • Leftovers is used with Thick Fat, regular form Snorlax, and Protect, as those have the most impact when no berry is held. Figy Berry is used with Gluttony and Gigantamax in order to gain back health when in a pinch, and can also be restored with Gmax Replenish or Recycle.

sets.name: Ron (Stall)
sets.description:
This Snorlax set serves as a semi-stall Pokemon that beats many of the offensive threats in the 1v1 metagame, such as Galarian Darmanitan, Primarina, and non-Fling Choice item Haxorus. Counter deals with prominent physical attackers like offensive Rillaboom, non-Swords Dance Rhyperior, and Life Orb + three attacks Zeraora as well as Choice Band users such as Crustle and Azumarill. Amnesia utilizes Snorlax's fantastic Special Defense, which allows it to wall common Choice Specs users such as Magnezone, Sylveon, and Kyurem as well as miscellaneous specially oriented threats such as Salazzle and Volcarona. Snorlax also has access to many different coverage options that are interchangeable based on what its teammates are. Rock Tomb prevents Snorlax from being bait for Encore and Taunt users such as Primarina and Mandibuzz while also providing utility against Fire-types such as Choice item Rotom-H, Chandelure, and Volcarona. Defense Curl allows Snorlax to maximize its PP and fully commit to being a hard stall Pokemon, which helps secure the matchups against stall Kyurem and opposing non-Defense Curl Snorlax. Tackle allows it to maximize its PP while still being able to defeat other stall Pokemon such as Type: Null and Amnesia Slowbro. Double-Edge allows Snorlax to both beat certain Trick users such as Choice item Rotom-A and Choice Scarf Gardevoir while also inflicting recoil damage, which allows it to use Rest to maximize PP preservation. 252 HP and 252 Defense EVs along with an Impish nature allow Snorlax to have the best chance at taking a Choice Band-boosted Fishious Rend from Dracovish, and the extra 4 EVs are dumped into Special Defense. A Chople Berry allows Snorlax to take Fighting-type hits that would normally beat it such as a Superpower from Galarian Darmanitan or a Choice Band-boosted Close Combat from Conkeldurr.

Overall, Snorlax is a straightforward Pokemon to use. However, there are a couple interesting matchups where setting up or clicking Counter immediately isn't optimal. Primarina is a good example of where you shouldn't immediately use Amnesia turn one. For Rock Tomb variants in matchups against Primarina and other known Encore or Taunt users, it is best to click Rock Tomb until Snorlax outspeeds the foe to prevent the opponent from locking Snorlax into Amnesia with Encore or disabling its setup moves with Taunt. Snorlax often struggles with setup Pokemon like Swords Dance Haxorus, Iron Defense Kommo-o, and Belly Drum Alolan Marowak as well as non-Choice item Fighting-types or ones that have a way to survive Counter like Reversal Hawlucha and Sturdy Sawk. Because of this, it often pairs well with Fairy-types such as Aqua Jet Primarina and bulky Quick Attack Sylveon. They are also able to take care of a lot of the counters like Urshifu-R and Sawk that normally beat Snorlax. Other good partners for Snorlax would include stallbreakers like Hex Dragapult and Choice item Rotom-A, both of which are able to deal with Pokemon that can outstall Snorlax such as Corviknight and Spite Galarian Corsola.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
This set maximizes Snorlax's ability to tank hits and KO in return with its great coverage options. The 144 HP and 248 Defense investment lets Snorlax survive a Wood Hammer from Choice Band Rillaboom. The HP investment gives Snorlax ample bulk to survive Choice Scarf Porygon-Z's Hyper Beam, and the best possible odds to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Magnezone. Giga Impact OHKOes neutral targets such as non-Stall Rotom-A. Its coverage options in Heavy Slam and Superpower hit Pokemon such as Sylveon, Porygon-Z, Hydreigon, and Ferrothorn for super effective damage. Counter lets Snorlax beat Choice item physical threats like Rillaboom, Choice Scarf Dracovish and Dracozolt, and Zeraora. Earthquake can be run in order to beat Alolan Marowak and Bulk Up Zeraora. Darkest Lariat can be used to beat Alolan Marowak and Choice Specs Dragapult. An alternative spread of 144 HP / 12 Atk / 248 Def / 104 SpD and a Careful nature can be run to also survive Choice Specs Porygon-Z and Choice Band Rillaboom, but will be unable to beat Trick + Recover variants of Porygon-Z. Lastly, a spread of 88 HP / 168 Atk / 252 SpD with an Adamant nature could be run to survive Choice Specs Porygon-Z and always OHKO even defensive Trick variants with Superpower, but will fail against physical attackers like Choice Band Rillaboom.

Although Snorlax is a great physical attacker, it does lose to common physical threats such as Sawk, Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, and Conkeldurr. This makes Fairy-type teammates such as Aromatisse and Chilan Berry Primarina great partners. They also appreciate Snorlax's ability to KO Steel-types such as Excadrill and Aegislash. Snorlax also pairs well with physical walls such as Galarian Corsola, as they have excellent defensive synergy, who in return appreciate Snorlax's ability to beat down wallbreakers like Sylveon or Swords Dance Excadrill.

zu.comments:
Other Options

On stall teams, Articuno can run Haze to stop Stored Power users like Alcremie and Uxie or Heal Bell to act as a cleric. However, it struggles to find room for these options, and stall teams have access to other Heal Bell users like Clefairy, Eldegoss, and Audino. Articuno can opt for a physically offensive set with options like Triple Axel, Brave Bird, and Ice Shard, but physical walls are more common, which makes special Articuno more effective at breaking through defensive cores.

Checks and Counters

Rock-type Pokemon and Coverage: Due to its 4x weakness to Rock, any Rock-type move will at least 2HKO Articuno. This makes Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal extremely annoying for Articuno, as they can easily set up entry hazards against it. Furthermore, Pokemon like Silvally-Ground and Miltank often carry Rock-type coverage, preventing Articuno from switching into them.

Item Removal: Retaining Heavy-Duty Boots is key to maintaining Articuno's defensive capabilities, and it should avoid switching into Knock Off and Trick users like Shiftry, Gurdurr, Thwackey, and Rotom. However, if Articuno is the team's entry hazard remover and is able to consistently use Defog against the opposing Stealth Rock setter, it can afford to lose its item.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash force out Articuno with their super effective STAB move. However, they take great damage from Articuno's Flying-type STAB moves, and they dislike being crippled by Toxic.

Electric-types: Morpeko, Manectric, and Rotom formes threaten Articuno with their super effective STAB moves and generate momentum with Volt Switch. However, weaker Electric-types like Choice Scarf Rotom and defensive Rotom-S can't break through specially defensive Articuno.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Perrserker, Mawile, and Klinklang are immune to Toxic, resist Articuno's STAB moves, and take on Articuno with their super effective STAB moves. However, it should be noted that Ferroseed loses to Articuno, as it is able to PP stall Gyro Ball with Pressure.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Articuno is an amazing special wall and one of the best form of entry hazard control in ZU thanks to Pressure + Defog keeping entry hazards off the field against numerous setters such as Qwilfish, Uxie, and Clefairy, its amazing bulk, and reliable recovery in Roost. Brave Bird is the preferred STAB move to check Frosmoth. Alternatively, Freeze-Dry lets Articuno avoid Iron Barbs from Ferroseed while also threatening entry hazard setters like Qwilfish and Stunfisk, as well as Pokemon that can freely switch into its other moves like Tangela and Altaria. U-turn turns Articuno into a pivot, while Toxic wears down opposing walls such as Cramorant and entry hazard setters such as Coalossal and Rhydon, which forces Articuno out. The given EV spread lets Articuno outspeed Adamant Alolan Sandslash and chip it with U-turn. Alternatively, Articuno can run 136 Speed EVs with a Jolly nature to outspeed Flapple and Adamant Shiftry.

Specially defensive Articuno fits on almost any kind of team, ranging from stall to bulky offense. On offensive teams, it forms a VoltTurn core with partners like Silvally-Ground, Uxie, and Alolan Persian. Frail attackers such as Basculin, Cinccino, and Shiftry enjoy safely coming on the field through these VoltTurn cores and benefit from slower pivots like Articuno sponging attacks for them. Knock Off absorbers like Qwilfish, Pyukumuku, and Silvally formes are great partners that can preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots and sponge physical hits, while it handles special attackers for them. Ground-types like Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Vibrava make for excellent partners for their ability to handle Articuno's weaknesses, while they appreciate Articuno checking Frosmoth and specially offensive Basculin.

sets.name: SubRoost
sets.description:
The combination of Substitute, Roost, and Pressure lets Articuno stall out moves with low PP such as Ninetales's Fire Blast, Kabutop's Stone Edge, and Trevenant's Poltergeist. Thanks to its great Speed and bulk, Articuno is able to easily set up a Substitute against passive Pokemon such as Tangela, Audino, and Qwilfish. Toxic works well with the combination of Roost + Substitute, racking up damage on foes like Audino, Uxie, and Kangaskhan. Freeze-Dry is the preferred STAB move to cover Qwilfish, Wishiwashi, and Altaria, which can sponge Toxic.

SubRoost Articuno fits well on balance and bulky offense teams looking for a Pokemon that does well against balance teams. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian are appreciated to preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots. VoltTurn users like Basculin, Manectric, and Uxie safely bring Articuno onto the field, letting it avoid Knock Off from the likes of Tangela, Audino, and Uxie. Ground-types such as Silvally-Ground, Rhydon, and Stunfisk make for great partners, checking Steel-, Fire-, Rock-, and Ground-types such as Perrserker, Coalossal, and Rhydon. In return, Articuno checks Water- and Grass-types such as Jellicent, Appletun, and Flapple for them. Checks to Steel-types like Sawk, Rapidash, and Manectric are especially important, since Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker completely shut down SubRoost Articuno.

sets.name: Roost + 3 Attacks
sets.description:
Articuno is a great offensive pivot that is able to dish out powerful Hurricanes and Freeze-Drys. The given EV investment in conjunction with its coverage allows Articuno to outspeed and nail threats such as Thwackey, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr. Thanks to U-turn, Articuno is able to pivot from bad matchups and safely bring in partners.

Roost + 3 Attacks Articuno fits on offensive teams with VoltTurn cores, which makes Uxie, Rotom, and Wishiwashi great partners. Articuno also excels on entry hazard stacking teams, since it preys on common Defoggers such as Cramorant and Altaria and is able to generate momentum with U-turn. Physical wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Silvally formes can take advantage of Articuno inviting in and pivoting against special walls such as Audino, Clefairy, and Ferroseed. In return, Articuno can threaten physical walls such as Qwilfish, Jellicent, and Tangela for them. Ground-types like Silvally-Ground and Rhydon are great partners, checking Rock-, Fire-, Steel-, and Electric-types such as Coalossal, Klinklang, and Stunfisk. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish let Articuno keep its Heavy-Duty Boots.

ou.overview: Zapdos's unique defensive typing and ability in Static let it check and punish common offensive threats like Rillaboom, Kartana, and Tornadus-T as well as common U-turn users like Urshifu-R and Landorus-T. It also makes use of rain with its STAB moves in Thunder and Hurricane, which become 100% accurate in rain, as well as Weather Ball, which lets it hit Ground-types and Heatran much harder. This set faces competition from other rain users like Thundurus-T and Tornadus-T, which are faster and can break defensive teams more easily because of their access to Nasty Plot. However, Zapdos can check Rillaboom and Kartana better with its solid defenses and reliable recovery, which rain teams often struggle with. Unfortunately , Zapdos is incredibly prone to having its item removed by Knock Off from Pokemon it's supposed to check, like Rillaboom and Kartana, making it a much less reliable check after being chipped by Stealth Rock. Because Knock Off hampers its ability to check these Pokemon long-term, it often relies on Static to cripple offensive threats. Zapdos is also rather weak to Toxic, which is why some Pokemon like Excadrill and Melmetal opt to run it. Zapdos also faces competition from other defensive walls like Corviknight and Skarmory, which have a better defensive typing. Their neutrality to Stealth Rock also allows them to absorb Knock Off more easily.
ou.comments:
Other Options

Toxic can also used on defensive sets to punish defensive Ground-types like Garchomp, Hippowdon, and specially defensive Landorus-T that otherwise don't take much from its attacks, as well as crippling other situational switch-ins like Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Kyurem. However, it should only be used if the team has another form of entry hazard control. A set with Substitute and Pressure can be used to overwhelm common defensive cores and PP stall common checks like Heatran and Blissey. However, this set is outclassed by Pressure Kyurem and Moltres. An offensive variant with Heat Wave, Thunderbolt, and Hurricane can be a good choice, as it fits on archetypes other than rain and brings good defensive utility to a team by soft checking Pokemon like Hawlucha, Rillaboom, and Kartana, which not many other offensive Pokemon are able to do. This coverage also allows Zapdos to annoy and hit a plethora of Pokemon. However, this set faces competition from Pokemon like Tornadus-T, which also offers utility like Knock Off and has Nasty Plot.

Checks and Counters

Knock Off: Due to the abundance of Knock Off users in the tier and Zapdos's reliance on its Heavy-Duty Boots, it is an easy target for Knock Off users like Rillaboom, Kartana, and Tornadus-T, making it much easier to overwhelm offensively.

Ice-types and Ice-type coverage: Ice-types like Weavile and Kyurem can easily threaten out Zapdos with their strong STAB attacks. However, Weavile cannot switch in very easily, as it lacks reliable recovery and runs the risk of getting paralyzed by a stray Discharge or KOed by Heat Wave. Melmetal can also choose to run Ice Punch to deter Zapdos from switching in frequently or Protective Pads to ignore Static.

Rock-types and Rock-type coverage: Tyranitar is a very good check to Zapdos, as it takes minimal damage from its moves and threatens it out with Rock Blast or Stone Edge. Pokemon like Landorus-T and Hawlucha can also easily run Stone Edge to deal with Zapdos, as they would be walled by it otherwise.

Galarian Slowking: Galarian Slowking's great bulk with Assault Vest makes it a solid Zapdos check and allows it to take multiple hits from it with ease while pressuring its Substitute set with Future Sight and repeated attacks. Zapdos is also unable to use Roost against it, since it risks the chance of being poisoned by Sludge Bomb.

Toxic: Excadrill and Melmetal can use Toxic to heavily cripple Zapdos, leaving it unable to check them and other threats consistently.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Discharge spreads paralysis, making it hard for common specially defensive switch-ins like Heatran, Clefable, and Galarian Slowking to switch in safely. Volt Switch can be used over Discharge, as it lets Zapdos pivot out against the aforementioned checks and Blissey. It should be used alongside Hurricane to punish Ground-types harder as they attempt to block Volt Switch. Heat Wave can be used over Hurricane, targeting Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Scizor, Excadrill, and Magnezone at the cost of much less damage against Ground-types. Defog adds to Zapdos's utility by letting it remove entry hazards, although it's often forced to do so on free turns like forced switches, as it loses to a lot of common Stealth Rock users like Landorus-T, Hippowdon, and Clefable that are able to cripple Zapdos with either Knock Off or Toxic. Some Stealth Rock users like Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Tyranitar can also carry Rock-type coverage to pressure Zapdos. Static can punish U-turn users like Landorus-T, Urshifu-R, and Dragapult. 40 Speed EVs let Zapdos outspeed Rillaboom and the rest are invested into HP and Defense to maximize Zapdos's physical bulk.

Scizor makes a great defensive partner, as it can take pressure off of Zapdos to check Rillaboom and check Ice-types like Kyurem and Weavile. Zapdos can also pivot on some of Scizor's checks, like Galarian Slowking and Blissey, to bring it in to threaten them with Knock Off or continue the VoltTurn cycle.
