The given EV spread allows Mew to outspeed Mimikyu and Kyurem-B in order to cripple both before they can move and prevent the latter from using Dragon Dance with Taunt while also outpacing other offensive Pokemon such as Bisharp and Mamoswine.

Mew dislikes dealing with wallbreakers such as Dragapult and Keldeo. Choice Scarf users such as Indeedee and Gardevoir support Mew by revenge killing said wallbreakers, while Mew can break down defensive Pokemon like Corviknight that they struggle with. Indeedee's Normal typing also allows it to switch into Ghost-type moves such as Gengar and Dragapult's Shadow Ball. Hatterene can utilize its Magic Bounce to reflect entry hazards that wear down and cripple Mew as it switches in. Gardevoir and Hatterene are also good checks to Dark-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Weavile that Mew struggles with, while Healing Wish users such as the aforementioned Gardevoir, Indeedee-F, Celebi, and Jirachi can heal Mew if it ever gets worn down or inflicted with status. Using its good defensive typing, Celebi can take Water-type attacks such as Seismitoad and Keldeo's Hydro Pump under rain, and in return it appreciates Mew's ability to Taunt Defoggers such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Pelipper in order to keep its Stealth Rock on the field.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Mew's access to Nasty Plot and good coverage options make it a good setup sweeper capable of threatening many types like Steel, Grass, and Poison. Fire Blast is extremely important, as it allows Mew to hit Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Aegislash, and Bisharp for super effective damage, therefore making it amazing in the Steel matchup when set up. Volt Switch is used for pivoting and is particularly useful for breaking Mimikyu's Disguise under Psychic Terrain while keeping Mew healthy. A Colbur Berry allows Mew to take Bisharp's Sucker Punch while helping with other Dark-type attacks. Generally, Mew should find passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight to set up on and force out with its attacks.

As a setup sweeper, Mew appreciates support from Pokemon like Jirachi and Orbeetle. The former can set Stealth Rock for it, while the latter can set Sticky Web, both supporting Mew by chipping or slowing down foes, respectively. Steath Rock is particularily notable for securing the OHKO on Corviknight at +2 with Fire Blast, as well as breaking Focus Sash on Pokemon such as Cloyster, Dugtrio, and Polteageist that could otherwise stop Mew. Orbeetle can also set dual screens to help Mew set up. Healing Wish users such as Gardevoir, Indeedee-F, Celebi, and Jirachi also support Mew by healing it when it is chipped or statused, giving it more setup opportunities. The aforementioned offensive Pokemon like Indeedee, Hatterene, and Gardevoir make good partners for Mew by supporting it offensively. Indeedee is a strong wallbreaker that can set Psychic Terrain for Mew, protecting it from priority and boosting its Psychic, while Hatterene can keep entry hazards off the field with Magic Bounce, Gardevoir can revenge kill faster threats, and both of these Pokemon are able to take on Dark-type Pokemon for Mew. In return, these offensive Pokemon appreciate Mew's ability to set up and deal with Steel-type Pokemon like Corviknight and Aegislash reliably with Fire Blast.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Water-type defensive sets can run Volt Switch in the second slot alongside Scald for a Water / Electric typing to serve as a pivot and a Flying-resistant Pokemon, but this makes Mew vulnerable to Ground-types, as they can hit it super effectively and are immune to Volt Switch. Nasty Plot Mew can run various moves in its second slot to fit team needs, like Earth Power, Flamethrower, Scald, and many more. Outside of Earth Power variants, these sets also are dependent on Heavy-Duty Boots for more reliable longevity. Steel-type Mew can run an alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with a Careful nature to maximize its specially defensive capabilities, which allows it to check Cresselia, Tapu Lele, and Ghost / Fairy Alakazam. While maximum Special Defense investment does help it check those threats more properly, Mew fits the role of a physical wall better. Teleport is an option over U-turn for slower pivoting, though U-turn is generally preferred because it can damage foes and still works if under Taunt. Dazzling Gleam can be used as a secondary STAB option to provide Mew with a Steel / Fairy defensive typing, allowing it to check threats such as Heracross and Rillaboom. This option has some major drawbacks however; it requires Mew to run Roost in another slot and reduces its support options while gaining a weakness to Ground-type attacks. Either Scald or Flip Turn can be used for a Water / Steel typing, which grants Mew alternatives to Will-O-Wisp and U-turn, respectively.

Checks and Counters

Clefable: Unaware Clefable ignores Nasty Plot Mew's boosts and can cripple it with Knock Off and Toxic while gaining momentum with moves like Stealth Rock and Teleport. Offensive Thunderbolt Clefable resists Mew's STAB moves and can set up with Calm Mind to force Mew out.

Rillaboom: Rillaboom's Terrain-boosted Grass-type STAB moves heavily threaten bulky Water-type Mew, even Water / Flying set variants, as a Life Orb-boosted Wood Hammer cleanly 2HKOes it.

Latios: Electric-type variants of Latios such as Electric / Water and Electric / Dragon can easily switch into both Water-type and Nasty Plot Mew, resisting all of its STAB moves bar Dazzling Gleam and threatening it out with Draco Meteor, Surf, and Thunderbolt. These variants can also use Mew as setup fodder to accumulate Calm Mind boosts while healing off any chip with Recover.

Special Attackers: With Mew investing in physical bulk, strong special attackers like Latios, Porygon-Z, and Spectrier all threaten it with strong boosted attacks and can also cripple Mew with moves like Trick and Taunt.

Victini: Fire / Electric Victini is undoubtedly the best counter to Mew, as it threatens to OHKO with both of its STAB attacks while Mew's Iron Head does minimal damage against it.

Fire-types: Offensive Fire-types such as Entei, Arcanine, and Heatran make for solid checks to Mew because they threaten it with their Fire-type attacks while being resistant to Steel. Fire-types can be vulnerable to Mew's entry hazards unless running Heavy-Duty Boots, so it is important to keep them healthy against it. Additionally, these threats are immune to Mew's Will-O-Wisp, so it cannot hinder them throughout the battle.

Electric-types: Electric-types such as Latios, Clefable, Naganadel, and Magearna can threaten Mew with their STAB attacks; Clefable in particular is a solid check to Mew due to its immunity to entry hazards.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers like Latias, Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Tornadus-T are able to take advantage of Mew's passive nature to set up and heavily threaten it and its teammates. Mew is able to pivot with U-turn into checks to these threats, but it runs the risk of being greatly weakened by their attacks in the process.

sets.name: Bulky Water-type
sets.description:
Water-type Mew can select several great defensive typings that allow it to check various metagame threats and serve a valuable support role. Mew gets its Water typing from Flip Turn, which is a fairly weak move but allows it to be an effective pivot. Scald is another option that makes Mew less passive and can threaten foes with burns. In order to take on threats like Victini, Mew can run Earth Power for a Water / Ground typing to gain Electric-type immunity. This typing lets Mew resist Stealth Rock, which helps it stay healthy and check more offensive threats. Mew can opt for Dazzling Gleam so that it can take on certain Dragon-types like Garchomp and Salamence, as well as Dark / Fighting Lycanroc-D and Urshifu-S, but this opens it up to an Electric-type weakness, meaning it can't check Victini. Roost is a third option, granting Mew a Water / Flying typing to check Ground-types like Excadrill, Haxorus, and Landorus-T while still having a useful typing to resist Fighting. Mew has a plethora of support moves to choose from, and the best options are Spikes and Stealth Rock to chip the opposing team or Defog if the team needs entry hazard removal. Flying-type Mew can opt for Will-O-Wisp for its last move if not running Scald, or Volt Switch if not running Flip Turn. Leftovers are best for the Ground- and Fairy-type sets for passive recovery, while the Flying-type set needs Heavy-Duty Boots in order to come in on Stealth Rock reliably.

Setup sweepers such as Latias, Lycanroc-D, and Spectrier appreciate entry hazard support from Mew, as it allows them to break past threats more easily. Mew can also bring them in safely when pivoting with Flip Turn. Special wallbreakers like Dragapult and Spectrier appreciate Earth Power Mew's ability to pressure their checks like Unaware Clefable and Dark / Poison RegenVest Tornadus-T. Water-type Mew is highly threatened by Rillaboom's Grass-type STAB moves, so teammates like Poison / Fairy Cresselia and Steel / Flying Salamence help by easily switching into its attacks. Other Salamence variants like Dragon / Ghost can also help Mew's Fairy- and Flying-type sets by checking threats like Victini and Rillaboom.

sets.name: Bulky Steel-type
sets.description:
Bulky Steel-type Mew is a potent wall in the metagame that utilizes its Steel / Flying typing to check threats such as Cresselia and Landorus-T. Iron Head is Mew's primary STAB attack and allows it to hit Calm Mind users such as Cresselia for consistent damage. Roost provides Mew with its Flying typing and complements this solid defensive typing by providing Mew with recovery. Mew is able to utilize U-turn to pivot on switch-ins such as Victini and Hydreigon and bring in a check. Will-O-Wisp is an alternative that allows Mew to check Swords Dance users such as Lycanroc-D, Scizor, and Excadrill properly. Whirlwind can be used to phaze setup sweepers and pairs nicely with Mew's entry hazard options. For the last slot, Mew has quite a few team support options to choose from, but Spikes is the most coveted and useful option that it can utilize well to complement its solid defensive presence. Defog is another support option that can be used to remove entry hazards and dual screens. Mew can utilize Stealth Rock as an entry hazard option that can hit Levitate and Flying-type Pokemon. Leftovers increases Mew's longevity by providing passive recovery, though Rocky Helmet can be used to weaken physical attackers such as Rillaboom, Landorus-T, and Heracross.

Setup sweepers such as Latias, Lycanroc-D, and Spectrier appreciate entry hazard support from Mew, as it allows them to break past threats more easily. Fighting-types such as Lycanroc-D, Landorus-T, and Pheromosa typically require a partner that can check Cresselia, and Mew is able to fill this role. Water / Ground Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Garchomp appreciate Mew's ability to switch into Rillaboom's Grassy Glide; in return, they are able to check Victini. Mew struggles with offensive Electric-types such as Latias, Clefable, and Naganadel, so it appreciates Ground-type teammates such as Hydreigon, Garchomp, and Slowking. Fire-resistant or Fire-immune partners are a must for Mew; Heatran, Garchomp, and Salamence fill this role the best. Since Mew generally runs Spikes, Rapid Spin users such as Pheromosa and Excadrill can provide entry hazard control support without removing your own entry hazards.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Mew takes advantage of its solid bulk, offenses, and great longevity to become a threatening setup sweeper and late-game cleaner. Hurricane and Thunderbolt give Mew a great Flying / Electric typing and allow it to pressure various threats in the metagame. Hurricane has unreliable accuracy but is worth using due to its great Base Power and ability to hit threats like Landorus-T, Rillaboom, and Tornadus-T. Thunderbolt hits the Steel-types that resist Hurricane, like Magearna, opposing Mew, Reuniclus, and Scizor. Nasty Plot makes Mew extremely threatening even to specially defensive Pokemon like Blissey and RegenVest Slowking, as Mew can easily set up in front of them while healing away any damage it takes with Soft-Boiled. Soft-Boiled is chosen over Roost to prevent slower Ground-types like Hydreigon and Haxorus from hitting Mew while it has landed.

Physical attackers like Entei, Rillaboom, and Lycanroc-D appreciate Mew's ability to pressure their physically defensive checks, like Salamence, Slowbro, and Buzzwole. Both Magic Guard and Unaware Clefable have various means of punishing Mew and forcing it out, so Mew appreciates strong physical attackers like Garchomp and Heracross that threaten Clefable. These teammates can also set entry hazards to open up opportunities for Mew later. Water-types like Hydreigon and Latias are also good teammates, as they pressure bulky Ground-types like Garchomp and Heatran that resist Mew's attacks.

nationaldex.comments:
Other Options

Flare Blitz can be great for preventing Excadrill from removing hazards through Rapid Spin while also helping Mew KO itself, but its use outside of pressuring Excadrill is pretty barren, making it a worse option than Explosion overall. Skill Swap can be used over Explosion to let Mew set entry hazards against Magic Bounce users such as Mega Sableye and Mega Diancie, although it's generally an extremely fringe option due to them being very uncommon. Focus Sash can be used over Red Card to guarantee one layer of hazards.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Pokemon such as Ash-Greninja, Mega Tyranitar, Tyranitar, and Weavile can all threaten Mew with their STAB moves, either taking it out or weakening it enough to prevent it from setting up more entry hazards. Greninja and Weavile are especially dangerous; the former can Dark Pulse flinch it, preventing Mew from setting entry hazards up altogether, while the latter can outright OHKO Mew with Knock Off.

Ghost-types: Mew can be KOed by Ghost-types such as Gengar and Aegislash from their powerful STAB moves, preventing it from setting entry hazards.

Fast wallbreakers: Pokemon that are strong enough to 2HKO Mew or use it as setup fodder such as Garchomp, Kartana, and Tapu Koko can limit Mew's ability to set entry hazards for its teammates.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Mew is a very solid lead in National Dex OU due to its great Speed tier and access to Taunt and Explosion, allowing it to set up and keep up entry hazards consistently and effectively for hyper offensive teams while also preventing opposing hazard setters from setting up their own. Taunt combined with Mew's Speed tier consistently prevents Defoggers such as Corviknight and Zapdos from removing hazards and lets Mew retain a niche over Landorus-T even though Mew is generally overshadowed by it. Explosion allows Mew to take itself out in exchange for a heavy hit on a foe, generate momentum for its dangerous offensive teammates, and prevent Excadrill from removing hazards with Rapid Spin. Red Card synergizes great with Taunt to prevent setup sweepers from taking advantage of Mew and forces out strong attackers; both of these cases can provide Mew with more chances to set entry hazards. Mew typically fits on offensive teams as a suicide lead, as its ability to set up and keep up multiple layers of hazards allows its dangerous teammates to wreak havoc. Setup sweepers such as Mega Gyarados and Mega Garchomp as well as wallbreakers such as Tapu Koko and Rillaboom make great teammates as Mew's consistency in setting up hazards are very beneficial for these Pokemon.

ru.overview: Crobat's great defensive typing provides it with many notable resistances and an immunity, which enables it to check premier threats such as Zarude, Heracross, and Mienshao. Its high Speed stat and use of Heavy-Duty Boots provide it with many opportunities to clear away entry hazards with Defog and pivot out of unfavourable matchups with U-turn. Crobat also has the potential to run stallbreaking sets that can bypass Pokemon like Cobalion, Milotic, and Sylveon. Crobat depends upon Heavy-Duty Boots for most of its defensive utility and is vulnerable to Knock Off from Mienshao and Heracross. Crobat also has a tough matchup against common Stealth Rock setters like Metagross, Rhyperior, Seismitoad, and Necrozma, which prevent it from being able to consistently remove Stealth Rock. Crobat is very suspectible to Electric-types like Raikou, Xurkitree, and Heliolisk, and it faces stiff competition with Noivern, which can chip Steel-types like Steelix and Metagross with Flamethower and use Draco Meteor against prominent Electric-types and Rock-types such as Raikou, Toxtricity, and Rhyperior.
ru.comments:
Other Options

Super Fang turns Crobat into a stallbreaker that can wear down bulky Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross. Poison Fang can chip down Electric-types as well as Togekiss while having the possibility to weaken checks with Toxic. Nasty Plot can be run alongside special moves such as Sludge Bomb, Hurricane, Heat Wave, and Giga Drain to pressure checks to physical Crobat like Steelix, Zygarde-10%, Seismitoad, and Rhyperior, but Crobat's Special Attack is very mediocre, leaving it outclassed by other special sweepers like Nasty Plot Togekiss and Reuniclus.

Checks and Counters

Super Effective Attackers: Common Electric- and Rock-types such as Raikou, Xurkitree, and Rhyperior resist Brave Bird and can easily KO Crobat with their STAB moves.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf users such as Heracross, Darmanitan, and Gardevoir can easily threaten Crobat by KOing it or pivoting as it's forced out.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Metagross, Steelix, and Stakataka are only bothered by Super Fang and can use Crobat to set Stealth Rock up.

Bulky Setup Pokemon: Crobat struggles with breaking past bulky Pokemon like Galarian Slowbro, RestTalk variants of Suicune, and Snorlax, though they don’t appreciate being hit with Taunt.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: U-turn capitalizes on Crobat's high Speed stat and keeps momentum for the team. Defog helps provide Crobat's team with entry hazard control. Alternatively, Taunt can be run to shut down defensive Pokemon like Body Press Registeel and Sylveon. Toxic can be used in conjunction with Taunt at the sacrifice of U-turn to wear down Pokemon like Milotic, Seismitoad, and Umbreon. Crobat fits mainly on bulky offense and balance teams, which benefit from its natural longevity from Heavy-Duty Boots and ability to keep up momentum for its team. Wallbreakers such as Choice Band Rhyperior, Heracross, and Toxtricity can take advantage of U-turn and force out many of Crobat's checks, including Nasty Plot Togekiss, Reuniclus, and Diancie. Ground-types such as Steelix, Rhyperior, and Seismitoad prevent Electric-types such as Raikou, and Xurkitree from constantly gaining momentum with Volt Switch, while Crobat can take care of common Grass- and Fighting-types like Zarude, Mienshao, and Heracross. Crobat still struggles against bulky Steel-types like Seismic Toss Registeel, Steelix, and Metagross, so partners like the aforementioned Rhyperior as well as Water-types like Milotic and Seismitoad are beneficial. Knock Off absorbers like Colbur Berry Galarian Slowbro and Cobalion help neuter Crobat's weakness to the move. Other pivots like Zarude, Raikou, Darmanitan, and Xurkitree can form a VoltTurn core to create momentum for Crobat's team and benefit from hazards being removed so they can constantly pivot around.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Poison

Toxic is a niche option over Taunt or U-turn due to Crobat's high Speed allowing it to cripple threats like Kyurem and Landorus. However, Taunt and U-turn are almost always better.

Checks and Counters

Poison

Revenge Killers: Despite Crobat's amazing Speed tier, faster revenge killers like Choice Scarf Greninja and Mega Aerodactyl can easily take advantage of its mediocre defensive stats and KO it.

Super Effective Coverage: Crobat is susceptible to common Ice-, Psychic-, Electric-, and Rock-type Pokemon like Kyurem, Latios, Tapu Koko, and Mega Diancie, as they deal super effective damage to Crobat with their powerful STAB moves. Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Mega Diancie in particular also resist Brave Bird.

Status: Paralysis significantly hinders U-turn Crobat's ability to function as a reliable bulky and fast pivot on Poison teams and allows it to easily be outpaced by opposing threats, while burn halves the damage output of Brave Bird.

Steel-types: Most Steel-type Pokemon like Celesteela, Heatran, and Skarmory take very little damage from Brave Bird and can damage or cripple Crobat in return.

sets.name: Utility (Poison)
sets.description:
Despite facing competition from Galarian Weezing as a Defog user, Crobat's amazing Speed tier, access to U-turn and Taunt, and ability to better deal with threats like Mega Gallade and Choice Scarf Excadrill make it a great utility Pokemon for Poison teams. Brave Bird deals with major threats to Poison teams in the form of Mega Gallade and Mega Pinsir. Defog allows Crobat to remove entry hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes for its teammates, while Roost serves as reliable recovery, providing longevity for Crobat throughout the game. Taunt allows Crobat to pressure walls like Blissey and Hippowdon by blocking recovery while also preventing utility Pokemon such as Swampert and Klefki from setting up hazards and using all sorts of status moves. Taunt also ensures Toxapex's Toxic Spikes stays up against opposing Defog users like Staraptor. U-turn can be opted over Taunt, improving Crobat as a fast pivot instead. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Crobat from taking Stealth Rock damage upon entry. 192 Speed EVs along with a Jolly nature allow Crobat to outspeed key threats like Greninja, Tornadus, and Alakazam, while 48 Attack EVs ensure that it OHKOes Mega Gallade with 4 Defense EVs after Stealth Rock damage. 252 HP EVs and the remaining EVs going in Defense increase Crobat's bulk.

All of Crobat's teammates appreciate Crobat's Ground immunity Defog. Toxapex provides a great defensive switch-in against a majority of attacks directed at Crobat, notably resisting Ice. Toxapex can also provide Haze and Toxic Spikes support. Mega Venusaur is a great teammate for Crobat, dealing with Electric-type attack and Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Rotom-W that threaten it. Mega Venusaur can also act as a reliable secondary Ground-type switch-in, and, together with Toxapex, is able to provide an extremely reliable defensive core that may switch into almost any attack directed at Crobat. Drapion and Alolan Muk act as the much needed sources of Psychic immunity, additionally being able to Pursuit trap and defeat threatening Psychic-types for Crobat, like Choice Scarf Latios and Tapu Lele. They can also aid greatly in the Ghost-type matchup by safely switching into and Pursuit trapping threats like Gengar and Blacephalon. Drapion can also provide Toxic Spikes support, while Alolan Muk can opt for a Curse set which is an extremely effective late-game sweeper. Nidoking is an excellent special wallbreaker that is able to beat the Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran that wall Crobat while serving as the best source Electric immunity Poison has to offer. Nihilego is a great asset in the Flying matchup and is the best available Choice Scarf user for Poison-type teams. Lastly, Assault Vest Galarian Slowking reliably checks some key threats like Kyurem and Choice Specs Zapdos that otherwise pose a significant threat to Crobat and Poison teams more broadly.

pu.overview: Lanturn has unique utility as a bulky Water-type thanks to its splendid defensive typing and great ability. This allows it to check a myriad of Pokemon such as Heliolisk, Rotom, and Charizard. It can also act as a pivot due to Volt Switch, which allows it to serve as a damage sponge to bring stronger yet more delicate wallbreakers in such as Archeops and Toxicroak that benefit from specially defensive or Grass-type Pokemon being brought in. However, it struggles switching in against Ground-types, which other bulky Water-types like Jellicent are normally able to handle; Lanturn also has to rely on passive recovery due to its lack of a reliable recovery move, which makes it unreliable as a wall for longer games.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description: Protect is used to stall out Toxic turns and safely gain passive recovery from Leftovers. Heal Bell can be used over either Toxic or Protect to make Lanturn a cleric to assist its teammates; however, Lanturn's lack of recovery moves makes Aromatisse an overall better option for this role. The HP EVs are used to gain an extra HP from Leftovers, and the Special Defense EVs are used to never get 4HKOed by Heliolisk's Hyper Voice after stalling with Protect for Leftovers recovery. The Speed EVs let Lanturn outspeed maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 40 Pokemon such as Rhydon, and the Special Attack EVs are for Lanturn to OHKO Rhydon with Scald. Defensively, Lanturn needs support from Pokemon that can take on Grass- and Ground-type threats like Whimsicott and Sandaconda. This makes Pokemon such as Charizard, Whimsicott, and Weezing solid partners. Lanturn can also support wallbreakers such as Gourgeist-S and Lycanroc that can offensively pressure its main checks, while it supports them defensively and safely brings them in via Volt Switch.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Assault Vest allows Lanturn to switch into special attacking threats such as Heliolisk and Magmortar without sacrificing power. Hydro Pump is an option over Scald, allowing it useful rolls such as a guaranteed 2HKO on specially defensive Claydol with an accuracy and utility tradeoff. Discharge can cripple common Pokemon like Mesprit, while Dazzling Gleam 2HKOes Guzzlord without an Assault Vest and Bulk Up Scrafty. Psybeam is a niche option that allows Lanturn to OHKO Toxicroak, which is a threat that can freely switch into Scald. The Speed EVs are used for maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 50 Pokemon and lower such as Aggron and Perrserker. Pokemon like Tsareena appreciate Lanturn being able to wall their checks like Charizard, and it is also defensively supported by Pokemon such as Palossand and Aromatisse that switch in on physical threats like Aggron and non-Gunk Shot Passimian that take advantage of it. Moreover, Aromatisse can further support Lanturn with Wish.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Defog Togetic can provide its team with more utility by functioning as a cleric when using Heal Bell as its fourth move, allowing its teammates to be freed of status. Togetic can also carry Thunder Wave to cripple opposing threats and slow them down. Nasty Plot Togetic could swap Dazzling Gleam for Draining Kiss in order to recover lost health, while Psychic can also be an option instead of Psyshock to reliably OHKO Koffing.

Checks and Counters

Ice-types: Ice-types like Piloswine and Galarian Mr. Mime have no trouble breaking through Togetic through their super effective STAB attacks. Furthermore, special attackers with Ice-type coverage like Wartortle can also break Togetic down with Ice Beam.

Electric-types: Electabuzz and Pikachu have no trouble pressuring and OHKOing Togetic with Thunderbolt, Volt Switch, or, in Pikachu's case, Volt Tackle, depending on their sets. Pikachu can also remove Togetic's Eviolite with Knock Off, rendering it weaker to future attacks and leaving it Defog Togetic unreliable as a physical wall.

Poison-types: Poison-types like Golbat, Koffing, Mareanie, and Roselia can easily switch in and get rid of Defog Togetic through status and moves like Toxic and Sludge Bomb. Koffing and Mareanie can also remove Togetic's Eviolite through Corrosive Gas and Knock Off, respectively. However, these checks struggle against Nasty Plot Togetic, fearing Psychic-type coverage.

Special Attackers: Special attackers such as Choice Specs Electabuzz, Magmar, Lampent, and Duosion can easily revenge kill Togetic while enduring very little damage in return.

Toxic Users: When not carrying Heal Bell, Togetic can easily be worn down and made unreliable by Toxic users like Ferroseed, defensive Wartortle, and Metang.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Togetic functions as a physical wall and entry hazard remover in the NFE metagame. Being able to pressure out threats like Machoke, Galarian Linoone, and Thwackey allows Togetic to find use on multiple team archetypes. Defog is Togetic's primary asset, allowing it to remove entry hazards like Sticky Web and Stealth Rock from crippling its teammates. Dazzling Gleam is used to attack Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon-types like Machoke, Vullaby, and Hakamo-o, preventing the former two from using Knock Off and the latter from setting up. Flamethrower enables Togetic to hit entry hazard setters like Charjabug and Ferroseed. Toxic can also be an option to cripple walls like Galarian Corsola, Marshtomp, and Piloswine that may take advantage of Togetic's passiveness. A spread of 248 HP / 252 Def / 8 SpD paired with a Bold nature enables Togetic to reliably wall physical wallbreakers like Choice Scarf Rufflet, Thwackey, and Raboot. Togetic is still bulky enough on the special side to check threats including Choice Scarf Magmar and Drakloak.

As bulky as Togetic may be, it is also fairly passive and therefore works better on defensive builds like balance and bulky offense. Since Togetic's strongest asset is Defog, Pokemon who are weak to entry hazards like Nasty Plot Golbat and Galarian Mr. Mime amongst many benefit heavily from it. Togetic can easily be taken advantage of by set up sweepers like Klang, Wartortle, and Lampent, so having other defensive Pokemon like Machoke, Ferroseed, or and Mareanie respectively is heavily encouraged. Teammates like Gurdurr, Hattrem, and Ferroseed pair up well with Togetic due to their ability to threaten Ice- and Poison-types like Piloswine, Galarian Mr. Mime, and Roselia. Ferroseed can also serve as an entry hazard setter, while Hattrem can heal Togetic through Healing Wish.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot Togetic is a great wallbreaker in the metagame by being able to pressure and beat defensive cores like Ferroseed + Mareanie and Vullaby and Roselia through its coverage in Dazzling Gleam, Flamethrower, and Psyshock. Roost can also be used to recover lost health from entry hazards like Stealth Rock or chip damage from opposing threats. A Modest nature enables Togetic to really put a dent through the opponent's team, while maximum Speed investment allows it to outspeed all of the aforementioned walls as well as other threats like bulky Gurdurr and Hattrem.

Togetic functions best on offensive archetypes, especially Sticky Webs teams, as Sticky Web enables it to outspeed threats like Thwackey, Krokorok, and Gabite. Therefore, Charjabug makes for an ideal partner for Togetic, as it is the metagame's premier Sticky Web setter it also compensates by allowing Togetic a free switch-ins through Volt Switch. Knock Off users such as Machoke, Galarian Linoone, and Thwackey are also helpful, as they can remove Eviolites and enable Togetic to easily put in dents through the opponent's team. Other common Sticky Web abusers like Lampent, Choice Band Piloswine, and Raboot are also good wallbreaking partners. As a Flying-type, Togetic is heavily pressured by Stealth Rock and therefore likes partners that can prevent or remove them, such as Hattrem and Wartortle. Furthermore, Hattrem can also heal back Togetic's lost health or remove its potential status ailment through Healing Wish.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Togetic's unique dual defensive typing paired with an Eviolite allows it to check common Fighting-types like Throh and Falinks, Dragon-types such as Vibrava and Drakloak, and Grass-types like Tangela and Leafeon. Defog is the primary reason to use Togetic; with its decent coverage, Togetic pressures our Defiant users, Falinks and Pawniard, pretty efficiently while still defeating Stealth Rock setters like Palpitoad and Carkol. Togetic’s passive nature is mitigated by the use of Thunder Wave, as offensive Pokemon that try to take advantage of it like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, Silvally-Rock, or Stonjourner do not appreciate being slowed down. Flamethrower, with an alternative spread of 248 HP / 176 Def / 84 Spe, can be used to outspeed non-invested Mawile; paired with Serene Grace, Flamethrower has higher odds of burning the foe. Heal Bell is an option that gives your team a cleric, and an option to more freely use Defog on and defeat Stealth Rock users that run Toxic, like Palpitoad.

Togetic is passive in nature, so use it on balance or semi-stall teams, specifically which have a solid defensive backbone that can handle Ice-types like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, and Lapras, Rock-types such as Crustle and Stonjourner, and Electric-types like Raichu and Manectric. Palpitoad and Hippopotas are spectacular paired with Togetic, as they can defeat most Electric- and Rock-types that scare out Togetic. Pokemon that appreciate entry hazard removal are nice partners, especially those that can check Ice-types and appreciate the Fighting resistance and Heal Bell support that Togetic offers like Lapras and Glaceon, which pressure Pokemon that wall Togetic, like Mareanie and Roselia, respectively. Musharna and Beheeyem can weaken or KO Poison-types, giving Togetic a much easier time clicking Defog, while Togetic's Fairy typing is useful for Dark-types like Thievul, making these Pokemon have natural synergy and a strong defensive core against Fighting-types. Because Togetic despises losing its Eviolite, Knock Off absorbers are perfect teammates; these include Silvally formes, Throh, Mawile, Colbur Berry Musharna, and Dubwool. Dubwool in particular is a good partner for Togetic; it counters Pawniard trying to exploit Defog and acts as a Rock check for Togetic. Klang and Type: Null are also notable, as Klang and Type: Null can act as wincons that can check Ice-types that threaten Togetic, while Togetic handles the Fighting-types and Dubwool that Klang and Type: Null do not like dealing with.

nu.overview: Xatu derives much of its value through two tools: Magic Bounce and Teleport. Xatu is fantastic at pivoting into passive foes like defensive Flygon, Vaporeon, and Talonflame that rely on status to inflict significant damage and is a true nuisance for entry hazard setters too, including Copperajah, Mudsdale, and Bronzong. Additionally, with Teleport, Xatu can guarantee safe entry for both potent wallbreakers and setup sweepers, which has made it the staple dual screens setter on hyper offense teams and sets it apart from other dual screens setters like Espeon. Where Xatu comes short, though, is in its passivity. Despite Teleport helping it keep up momentum, its low offensive prowess still causes it to cede turns to potent wallbreakers like Starmie, Tyrantrum, and Guzzlord. Additionally, its poor defensive stats make it less effective at directly switching into coverage attacks from the likes of Sirfetch'd and Machamp and force it to use Roost very frequently to stay healthy. Xatu also struggles heavily to prevent Diancie from setting Stealth Rock, making it much less useful in certain matchups if it lacks Defog.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf sets with Trick are useful for crippling passive foes like Bronzong, Talonflame, and Mantine. Xatu can attempt boosting sets with Calm Mind and Stored Power, but because of relatively low initial damage output, they take a few turns to ramp up. On utility sets, Defog is an option if Xatu is your sole entry hazard remover; however, Magic Bounce + Heavy-Duty Boots Xatu is typically serviceable enough as a sole hazard remover.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Guzzlord, Drapion, and Zoroark all fear very little from Xatu and threaten heavy damage in return. The most Xatu can do is bring in a teammate to deal with them through Teleport or fire off a Night Shade.

Ghost-types: Pokemon like Decidueye, Golurk, and Silvally-Ghost can all easily OHKO Xatu with their STAB attacks; however, Golurk and Decidueye must be mindful of using Poltergeist against Xatu, since it may not be holding an item.

Rock-types: Diancie is the hardest Stealth Rock setter to deal with for Xatu, since Diamond Storm and Moonblast do heavy damage to it. Other Rock-types like Tyrantrum and Aerodactyl are problematic too, since they easily take Xatu out.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Xatu's bulk, even when invested in, isn't very great, so strong attackers like Machamp, Tauros, and Toxicroak can still get past it.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Set Details

Although Psychic is a more consistent attack, Xatu sometimes runs Future Sight because of its great synergy with Teleport and U-turn, letting Xatu bring in a strong wallbreaker to make use of the extra damage Future Sight provides. Night Shade is helpful to force damage onto Guzzlord and other Dark-types like Drapion; alongside Rocky Helmet, it's also enough for Xatu to beat Steel-types like Copperajah. However, Heat Wave can be used instead to take out Steel-types more quickly. The choice between Teleport and U-turn is mostly arbitrary, although it's noteworthy that Teleport has slightly better synergy with Future Sight. Xatu can also drop a STAB move entirely to run Thunder Wave, further supporting slow wallbreakers.

Rocky Helmet is the preferred item for Xatu so it can successfully stall out Copperajah and prevent it from forcing Stealth Rock. However, Xatu can instead opt for Heavy-Duty Boots to be a better pivot in case it fails to keep Stealth Rock off the field; even going itemless is a viable option if checking Poltergeist users like Golurk and Decidueye is desired. 16 Speed EVs and a Timid nature give Xatu the jump on Jolly Sirfetch'd as well as other slow wallbreakers like Adamant Tyrantrum and neutral-natured Decidueye.

Teammates that can make use of Teleport support—Sirfetch'd, Tyrantrum, and Choice Band Guzzlord, for instance—are necessary to get the most out of Xatu. Wallbreakers such as these also appreciate Xatu's Future Sight support, especially since it makes physical walls like Mudsdale and Vileplume worse at switching into them. Similarly, teammates like itemless Ninjask, Focus Sash Salazzle, and Substitute Braviary that appreciate extra security against entry hazards are prime teammates for Xatu. Dark-types like Guzzlord, Drapion, and Zoroark fear very little from Xatu and can easily switch into and threaten to KO it; this makes teammates like Sylveon, Mudsdale, and Machamp good to have, with the latter immensely benefitting from Teleport support.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
Set Details

Thanks to Teleport, Xatu is the premier dual screens setter of the tier; it can set its screens and then guarantee safe entry for a setup sweeper with Teleport. Thunder Wave provides more overall team support and prevent opposing setup sweepers from taking advantage of its passivity as easily, but Roost on Colbur Berry sets helps provide Xatu with more chances to set its screens. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature gives Xatu the best shot at setting both its screens.

This set fits exclusively on dual screens offense teams, and thus the suggested teammates are very narrow in scope. Setup sweepers such as Blastoise, Decidueye, and Salazzle are a must, with the former being a staple on hyper offense teams. Decidueye and Salazzle are also notable for their appreciation of paralysis support, and Focus Sash Salazzle really appreciates Xatu's Magic Bounce. Offensive Stealth Rock setters like Celebi and Focus Sash Aerodactyl preserve offensive momentum, and the former can also supply these teams with Healing Wish support to give setup sweepers a second chance at cleaning.

sets.name: Magic Bounce
sets.description:
Magic Bounce comes in handy for reflecting status moves such as Toxic and most importantly Stealth Rock from Pokemon such as Registeel and Steelix. Heat Wave allows Xatu to hit Steel-types like Klefki and Metagross. Giga Drain 2HKOes Seismitoad and chips away at Diancie. Teleport's negative priority allows Xatu to bring teammates in safely, but U-turn can be ran to avoid additional damage when pivoting. Rocky Helmet is a great item on Xatu because it helps to pressure Steel-type Stealth Rock setters such as Cobalion, Metagross, and Registeel. Heavy-Duty Boots is also a useful item because Xatu is not going to be able to deflect Stealth Rock from certain Stealth Rock setters, such as Stakataka and the occasional Gigalith, therefore, Heavy-Duty Boots is needed to not get chipped by their entry hazards when pivoting. Max Defense lets Xatu take two Meteor Mash from Metagross. Speed investment makes it less reliable against Metagross, but outspeeding Roserade can be useful for some teams.

Due to the great roles that Xatu provides as a defensive pivot, it can fit on balance or bulky teams. Xatu likes to have offensive pivots as teammates, such as Darmanitan and Xurkitree, which appreciate Magic Bounce keeping entry hazards off the field so they can be more reliable pivots. Fairy-type Pokemon such as Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing can be very helpful teammates since they are able to check Dark-type Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Incineroar. Meanwhile, specially defensive walls like Steelix and Porygon2 appreciate hazard prevention, since then they can check Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Toxtricity more reliably.

sets.name: Xatu (Flying)
sets.description:
With its ability in Magic Bounce deterring Stealth Rock and dual screens support for teammates, Xatu acts as a great utility support Pokemon for hyper offensive Flying-type teams. It provides threatening setup sweepers like Gyarados and Hawlucha not only with dual screen support, but also with Thunder Wave to slow down faster Pokemon and open up more room for offensive teammates to shine. U-turn allows it to switch into the desired teammate after setting up dual screens without losing much momentum for the team. Xatu should be preserved, as Magic Bounce is crucial for Flying-type teams and its Speed tier lets it repeatedly set up dual screens throughout the game. Maximum Speed investment allows Xatu to be as fast as possible to set up dual screens, while the rest of the spread improves its overall bulk to paralyze threats like Barraskewda and Togekiss for the team when behind dual screen support.

Offensive behemoths like Gyarados, Hawlucha, Braviary, and Charizard all make exceptional teammates for Xatu, as they all appreciate dual screen and Thunder Wave support to aid them in setting up. Xatu should be kept away from Knock Off users like Clefable and Whimsicott, as without its Light Clay, the number of turns its teammates can take advantage of dual screens support is reduced. Additionally, Xatu should be kept away from faster Dark-, Ice-, and Ghost-types that can outright OHKO it and instead should pivot out with U-turn on their predicted switch in.

uu.overview: Azumarill is an offensive powerhouse and effective wallbreaker when equipped with a Choice Band due to Huge Power. It can also utilize a Belly Drum set to be a scary late-game cleaner. Water / Fairy is a great offensive typing, allowing Azumarill to beat key threats like Krookodile and Keldeo. Access to great coverage moves such as Knock Off and Ice Punch lets Azumarill break past Pokemon like Volcanion and Tangrowth that would otherwise check it by resisting its STAB combination, while access to Aqua Jet allows it to also be a great revenge killer, especially against top threats like Lycanroc-D and Thundurus that have taken chip damage. Azumarill also has decent natural bulk and a great defensive typing, which allows it to blanket check some of the more dangerous threats in the metagame such as Kommo-o and Salamence. Unfortunately, Azumarill is quite slow, so it is easily forced out by faster Pokemon such as Raikou and Thundurus when it is not boosted with Belly Drum. Additionally, Rotom-W and faster Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Zarude can revenge kill Azumarill, as they can stomach a +6 Aqua Jet. Belly Drum Azumarill is restricted to only getting one setup opportunity, which usually forces it to be preserved until late-game.
uu.comments:
Other Options

An Assault Vest set can help Azumarill more comfortably switch into Keldeo, Salamence, and Galarian Moltres and KO them back and also come in and pressure neutral special attackers like Primarina. It is typically not advisable, though, as Azumarill loses out on a lot of wallbreaking power and most special attackers have the means to overwhelm it regardless. Azumarill can run a trapping set with Sap Sipper and Whirlpool, Perish Song, and Protect. This can trap passive foes like Celesteela as well as Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but the effectiveness of this set is purely restricted to punishing walls and is deadweight against a majority of the offensive threats in UU.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Faster Grass-types like Zarude and Venusaur are the biggest threats to Azumarill because even a Belly Drum Azumarill cannot OHKO them with Aqua Jet and they OHKO back. Defensive Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth can usually switch into Choice Band Azumarill and threaten it with their own STAB moves as well as scout and switch out with Regenerator.

Faster Water-resistant Pokemon: Anything faster that resists Aqua Jet is bound to pressure Azumarill. These Pokemon include Gyarados, Tentacruel, and Rotom-W. Salamence can also pressure Azumarill, but it is also pressured by Azumarill with Play Rough, so Azumarill would have to be significantly chipped for Salamence to KO it. Volcanion is immune to Aqua Jet and can threaten Azumarill with Sludge Wave.

Electric-types: An unboosted Azumarill is easy prey for Raikou and Thundurus. Without being at +6, Azumarill cannot come close to KOing them with Aqua Jet, and both will in turn OHKO Azumarill. Rotom-W resists Aqua Jet and can also outspeed and cripple Azumarill with Will-O-Wisp or pressure it with an Electric-type attack.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Play Rough is Azumarill's main attack to remove foes like Zarude, Kommo-o, and Tangrowth. Aqua Jet becomes a very powerful STAB priority move when bolstered by Huge Power and a Choice Band, allowing it to OHKO Nihilego and revenge kill Thundurus and Rotom-H after they have taken sufficient chip damage. Ice Punch allows Azumarill to break through Amoonguss by hitting it hard enough to 2HKO on the switch. Knock Off can be used to burden anything that switches in, such as Tangrowth and Tentacruel, by removing their item. A Choice Band allows Azumarill to maximize the wallbreaking potential its STAB attacks have to offer. Adamant is the preferred nature to make it as strong as possible.

Choice Band Azumarill fits best on bulky offense teams. It wants to be brought in as often as possible early-game to wallbreak, so having good pivots such as Thundurus and Jirachi is extremely useful. Azumarill wants to fire off its STAB moves frequently, but it struggles to do so against bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Nidoking, Moltres, and Salamence can remove these Pokemon and make Azumarill's job easier. Kommo-o can offensively pressure Grass-types with its mixed set and can also check Volcanion. Keeping entry hazards up is important to ease Azumarill's ability to break through Tangrowth, so partners such as Krookodile and Nihilego are essential. Tapu Bulu and Zarude threaten to revenge kill Azumarill, as they are faster and resist Aqua Jet, so partners like Salamence and Amoonguss that can comfortably switch into them are ideal. Having a good Electric-immune teammate, such as Krookodile, Seismitoad, or Nidoking, helps to deal with Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus, which are all faster than Azumarill and threaten to OHKO or significantly damage it.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
A +6 Aqua Jet will KO almost anything that doesn't resist it, so it is very hard for anything to revenge kill Azumarill. Play Rough is used to pressure slower threats after a boost, as it can OHKO anything that does not resist it, including a fully defensive Tangrowth. A boosted Knock Off will OHKO Amoonguss and defensive Celesteela. Sitrus Berry allows Azumarill to set up more reliably and puts it at a comfortable amount of HP after a Belly Drum. Adamant is the preferred nature to guarantee an OHKO on Amoonguss with Knock Off.

Belly Drum Azumarill fits best on hyper offense teams due to its nature as a late-game cleaner and need for dedicated support. Boosted Aqua Jet can still KO Water-resistant foes like Tentacruel after substantial chip damage, so a hazard setter can help chip these Pokemon to allow Azumarill to KO them later on. Krookodile and Kommo-o are good options for this, and the former also provides an Electric immunity. A teammate that can pivot, such as Cobalion or Thundurus, can help Azumarill come in safely to set up a Belly Drum and also chip foes while doing so. Once Azumarill is boosted with Belly Drum, it typically will not get another chance to do so. As such, before it can come in and sweep, it needs teammates to help eliminate its main threats, which are mostly Pokemon that resist Water, are faster, and can KO it. Good offensive teammates include Salamence and Aegislash to help take out foes like Zarude and Keldeo. Thundurus-T can also hit most of Azumarill's checks with its coverage options, and it also provides a valuable Electric immunity.

sets.name: Belly Drum (Fairy)
sets.description:
Azumarill's ability in Huge Power, coupled with a fantastic setup move in Belly Drum and powerful priority in Aqua Jet, turns it into a dangerous setup sweeper in matchups such as those against Steel and Fire teams that Fairy teams otherwise struggle with. Belly Drum alongside Aqua Jet allows Azumarill to clean through the opponent's team with its priority. Knock Off allows Azumarill to hit Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex and support the team by removing items such as Chansey's Eviolite. Substitute is used to dodge status from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Torkoal, allowing Azumarill to more securely set up Belly Drum. Play Rough hits Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Pokemon that resist Aqua Jet such as Keldeo. 4 HP EVs ensure that Azumarill can always use its Sitrus Berry after a Belly Drum. An Adamant nature allows it to threaten Ferrothorn and Toxapex after using Belly Drum. Belly Drum is most ideally set up behind the dual screens that Klefki provides, and setting up two layers of Spikes with Klefki allows Azumarill to always OHKO Ferrothorn and Toxapex after a Belly Drum by using Knock Off. Additionally, Azumarill should use Substitute whenever a slower Pokemon can only threaten it with status, such as Toxapex running Toxic.

Klefki offers mandatory support for Azumarill, as it provides dual screens for Azumarill to set up Belly Drum more easily, and its Spikes support allows Azumarill to clean more easily late-game. Klefki can also check threats such as Scizor with Foul Play. Togekiss paired with Azumarill allows Fairy teams to take on the Steel matchup, with Togekiss breaking through Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory with Fire Blast and Azumarill cleaning through the rest of the team with Belly Drum in tandem with Knock Off for Corviknight and Aqua Jet for Excadrill. Togekiss can also break through Grass-type Pokemon such as Rillaboom for Azumarill and break past stall Pokemon such as Toxapex and Mandibuzz with tools such as Nasty Plot and Thunder Wave. Hatterene can take on Poison-type Pokemon for Azumarill such as Toxapex and Galarian Weezing as well as block hazards that could add to Belly Drum's health penalty thanks to Magic Bounce. Galarian Weezing can provide fantastic support for Azumarill by setting Toxic Spikes to wear down checks such as Bewear and absorbing the opponent's Toxic Spikes. Additionally, Galarian Weezing can burn physical attackers such as Diggersby. Mimikyu and Grimmsnarl form a physical setup core with Azumarill, as they are able to use Swords Dance and Bulk Up to help Azumarill in both the Psychic and Electric matchups. Additionally, both have strong priority, making the team less dependent on Azumarill's priority to check a multitude of threats including Volcarona, Alolan Raichu, and Gengar. Lastly, Gardevoir can provide Azumarill with a second chance to sweep with Healing Wish.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Bad Bunny (Huge Power Wallbreaker)
sets.description:
• Azumarill is an uncommon but unique wallbreaker in Battle Stadium, with decent bulk, useful dual STAB coverage, and a great priority move to beat much of the metagame that doesn't resist its attacks.

  • Superpower gives Azumarill a way to beat Ferrothorn while providing Max Knuckle Attack boosts during Dynamax, whereas Bounce is used with Life Orb to help Azumarill become a surprise sweeper.

  • The given EVs allow Azumarill to have decent bulk while outspeeding uninvested Celesteela, and avoiding a Special Attack boost from Download Porygon2. The leftover 4 EVs can be put anywhere but Defense.

Items

  • Assault Vest makes Azumarill quite bulky, especially while Dynamaxed.

  • Choice Band makes Azumarill an effective hit and run attacker.

  • Life Orb, while compromising Azumarill's bulk, is the most effective wall-breaking tool for it, making Azumarill a good Dynamax attacker.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
By virtue of its stellar Water / Fairy typing and good mixed bulk, Azumarill carves a niche as an offensive tank capable of dealing with top-tier threats like Choice item Porygon-Z, non-Roseli Berry Urshifu-R, and Haxorus. STAB Play Rough and Liquidation enable it to defeat Dragon- and Fire-types such as Haxorus, Kommo-o, and Volcarona. Aqua Jet gives Azumarill a way to pick off weakened foes like Choice item Rotom-H, Sawk, and Gardevoir. Superpower is an extremely important move in order to deal with Choice item Porygon-Z. The given EV spread ensures Azumarill will survive a Hyper Beam from Modest Choice Specs Porygon-Z and tank a Poison Jab from Jolly Choice Band Haxorus and Adamant Choice Band Urshifu-S. The rest of the EVs are put into Attack to maximize damage output. Alternatively, 132 HP / 124 Atk / 252 Def EVs with an Adamant nature let Azumarill survive a Choice Band Rock Wrecker from Crustle, but you lose the special bulk necessary to handle Choice Specs Porygon-Z. Since this alternative spread only defeats Choice Scarf Porygon-Z sets, Superpower becomes less of a necessity, meaning it can be replaced with Knock Off or Bulldoze instead, allowing Azumarill to defeat Substitute + Disable Dragapult or Magnezone.

While Porygon-Z looks manageable at first glance with the help of Assault Vest, it sometimes runs a defensive Chople Berry set, utilizing Superpower's Attack drop to freely Recover and use Nasty Plot to reach +4 and OHKO Azumarill. Against Choice Band Sawk, it is best to use Aqua Jet turn one and then Play Rough, as it is likely that it is running Counter and will KO you if you use Play Rough, but there is the possibility of it using Poison Jab. Situations with the same guidelines include facing Alolan Marowak and Choice Band Crustle, if using the alternative spread. Despite being bolstered by Assault Vest, there are still special threats that Azumarill should try to avoid, like Choice Specs Primarina, Magnezone, and Porygon2. Azumarill enjoys having Kyurem as a partner, luring in threats such as Haxorus, Volcarona, and Urshifu-S, while Kyurem can deal with stall users like Slowbro, Mandibuzz, and Skarmory. Choice Specs Rotom-H also has great synergy with Azumarill, combating the likes of Chansey, Celebi, and Aegislash. In return, Azumarill can handle Dragon-types like Hydreigon and Kommo-o. Pokemon that can deal with physical wallbreakers pair well with Azumarill. Salazzle and Hawlucha are valued because of this, handling wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, Rillaboom, and Durant. In return, Azumarill can deal with Trick users like Choice item Rotom-H and Gardevoir. Due to Azumarill's mediocre Speed, it is often overwhelmed by faster Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Choice Band Diggersby. Therefore, faster Pokemon like Porygon-Z and Rillaboom pair well with it. In return, Azumarill can deal with bulky Dragon-types like Goodra, Unnerve Haxorus, and Assault Vest Kyurem.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Fairy

Azumarill can opt to run Sitrus Berry if a different teammate like Tapu Bulu runs a Z-Crystal. However, Normalium Z is the more reliable way to ensure it successfully uses Belly Drum. Azumarill can also chose to run Brick Break in lieu of Play Rough, as it better deals with Steel-type Pokemon, namely Melmetal, which otherwise withstands any of Azumarill's attacks even after Belly Drum. Substitute may be used over Play Rough in order to let Azumarill set up on Pokemon that rely on status moves to deal with it, like Torkoal and Mega Sableye, but Play Rough is generally preferred due to it hitting useful targets. Return along with a Jolly nature can be used to better deal with Galarian Weezing and Mega Venusaur, significantly improving the Poison-type matchup.

Checks and Counters

Fairy

Water-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon that resist Azumarill's Aqua Jet such as Latios and Serperior can withstand Aqua Jet even after Belly Drum and KO Azumarill with their STAB moves or super effective coverage options. Even many walls that resist Water, like Mega Venusaur, Celebi, and Rotom-W, can outspeed Azumarill and KO it with super effective STAB moves before Azumarill can use Knock Off or Play Rough.

Haze Users and Phazers: Mantine can outspeed Azumarill and remove its boosts with Haze, while Azumarill fails to reliably set up Belly Drum against Toxapex, as it removes the move's boosts with Haze and proceeds to easily deal with unboosted Azumarill. In the same vein, Azumarill fails to reliably set up against phazers like Hippowdon and Skarmory.

Status: All status conditions significantly hinder Azumarill's ability to act as a reliable offensive threat. Burn makes it significantly weaker, paralysis prevents it from outspeeding threats like Porygon2 it otherwise would, and poison puts it on a timer, wearing it down quickly in conjunction with Belly Drum's health drop.

Psychic Terrain: Due to Azumarill's below average Speed stat, it heavily relies on Aqua Jet. As a result, Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain can hamper Azumarill greatly and make it much more easily revenge killed.

sets.name: Belly Drum (Fairy)
sets.description:
An amazing Attack stat thanks to Huge Power, access to priority in Aqua Jet and Belly Drum to further take advantage of its amazing Attack stat, and a decent typing cement Azumarill as an effective physical attacker that helps greatly in matchups such as Fire, Ground, and Steel. Aqua Jet allows it to deal with faster threats like Volcarona and Mamoswine, making up for its subpar Speed stat. Knock Off hits Psychic- and Ghost-types like Jirachi and Aegislash for super effective damage, and it's able to OHKO Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Celesteela and bulky walls like Toxapex with minor or no chip damage after Belly Drum. Play Rough is a stronger STAB option that deals with Dragon- and Dark-types such as Kommo-o and Mandibuzz. Maximum Speed EVs make Azumarill as fast as possible, outspeeding threats such as Dragalge and Melmetal. Normalium Z is Azumarill's preferred item, as it nullifies chip damage taken prior to using Belly Drum while also preventing Azumarill from being crippled by Knock Off, as opposed to Sitrus Berry. The added perk of Normalium Z is that Azumarill can use Belly Drum without it to use Z-Belly Drum later, either recovering its HP back to full if it didn't switch out.

Klefki pairs up exceptionally well with Azumarill. Klefki acts as a much needed Poison immunity and provides dual screens support and Spikes support, the former allowing Azumarill to set up more easily and the latter chipping down foes for it. Tapu Koko helps greatly in the Flying- and Water-type matchups, while Mega Diancie is able to bounce off entry hazards as well as status moves directed at Azumarill. Mega Diancie can also provide Stealth Rock support, which helps it further improve the Fire- and Flying-type matchups, and aid in matchups like Poison, Steel, and Electric thanks to a wide range of coverage options in Psychic, Mystical Fire, and Earth Power. Tapu Bulu is a great asset in the Water-, Electric- and Ground-type matchups. Tapu Lele is not only a great wallbreaker when equipped with a Choice Specs, but also a great help against Poison-types such as Mega Venusaur and Galarian Weezing that threaten Azumarill. Mimikyu helps greatly in the Ghost- and Psychic-type matchups, dealing with Pokemon like Aegislash and Tapu Lele. Lastly, Togekiss synergizes well with Azumarill, as it deals with Grass-types troublesome to Azumarill, like Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn, while Azumarill in return deals with Rock-type threats to Togekiss.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
Politoed enables a powerful but matchup-reliant archetype in rain due to being the only Drizzle Pokemon in the tier. However, outside of setting rain, Politoed is a generally underwhelming Pokemon that can’t provide much help to rain teams itself and often becomes a momentum sink due to its passiveness. Encore allows it to deal with bulkier threats that would wall it otherwise and discourage Pokemon from setting up on it. Toxic can break down walls in tandem with Encore, particularly bulky Water-types that pose a threat to rain teams like Seismitoad. Hypnosis trades some effectiveness against passive builds for the potential to shut down common roadblocks to rain teams like Gastrodon and Milotic, and maintain utility against more offensive teams looking to take advantage of Politoed’s passivity. Ice Beam chips Grass-types like Celebi, 3HKOes Dragalge, and OHKOes Noivern with the Special Attack investment. Perish Song forces bulky setup sweepers out, allowing Politoed to check Pokemon like Suicune, Snorlax, and Reuniclus. Finally, Rest allows Politoed to continue setting rain when severely weakened and in long matches against passive teams. Non-Ice Beam variants can invest the 76 Special Attack EVs into Defense, as they do nothing significant with Scald. 56 Speed EVs let Politoed outrun Alolan Marowak, but 92 Speed EVs can be ran for Milotic, which Encore + Toxic variants can beat.

Politoed’s only niche is setting rain, so Pokemon that take advantage of it are necessary. Swift Swim Pokemon like Kingdra, Omastar, and Kabutops can offensively pressure the opponent and sweep once they are weakened. Seismitoad can also provide an Electric immunity and Stealth Rock. Electric-types of your own like Raikou and Heliolisk are able to run Thunder and Weather Ball as coverage and check Electric- or Water-types. Tornadus also enjoys fully accurate Hurricane and Weather Ball coverage. Toxicroak appreciates the Dry Skin recovery and can switch into Milotic with impunity. Steel-types like Metagross and Steelix can provide good defensive utility for rain teams. Finally, entry hazard setters such as Klefki and Roserade can help pressure bulkier cores that threaten rain such as Suicune + Assault Vest Reuniclus, as well as synergizing with the surprising amount of switches Politoed can force from defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
• Politoed is the strongest rain setter in the metagame thanks to its amazing supporting movepool and survivability. Politoed is usually seen alongside Kingdra, forming a solid rain core able to threaten even the strongest staples of the metagame such as Dragapult, Glastrier, and Coalossal.

  • Scald is capable of hitting metagame staples like Incineroar, Torkoal, and Landorus-T for good damage thanks to its power boost in rain. Scald can also cripple opposing physical attackers like Urshifu-S, Rillaboom, and Glastier with burns. Muddy Water is an option to ignore opposing redirection and spread accuracy drops, but its lower accuracy can be troublesome.

  • Helping Hand gives a boost to Politoed's teammates when attacking. In particular, it helps Kingdra deal with sun teams, allowing it to OHKO Torkoal and Assault Vest Landorus-T in sun with Max Geyser.

  • Perish Song can serve as a strong win condition late-game, as it can force wins on weakened teams that have only two members remaining. Perish Song can also be paired with Gothitelle, as its ability to trap foes can be extremely helpful against passive leads such as Porygon2 + Grimmsnarl. Alternatively, Icy Wind can be used to slow down faster threats such as Spectrier, Zapdos, and Garchomp.

  • Sitrus Berry extends Politoed's survivability. Wacan Berry can be used instead to help Politoed endure Regieleki's Thunderbolt or Thundurus's Max Lighting, but Sitrus Berry is usually preferred, as it can be useful in many more situations. The given EV spread lets Politoed survive Assault Vest Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and Spectrier's Max Phantasm.

anythinggoes.comments:
Other Options

Curse is useful in some situations, but Quagsire's standard moves are hard to forgo, and the omnipresence of Toxic in AG makes this set very unreliable.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Common special attackers like Kyogre, Eternatus, Calyrex-S, Xerneas, Yveltal, and Kyurem-W can threaten Quagsire and force it to switch out.

Strong Wallbreakers: Due to Quagsire's mediocre natural bulk, it fails to beat strong wallbreakers such as Life Orb Groudon, Marshadow, and Urshifu-S.

Toxic: Toxic is common in AG and seen on both passive walls and offensive Pokemon. If Quagsire is badly poisoned, it struggles to check Zacian-C.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Quagsire is a mediocre physical wall in AG that fits on stall and bulky balance builds. It is outclassed by physical walls such as defensive Zygarde-C, Groudon, Necrozma-DM, and Lunala due to its average defense stats and passive nature. However, Quagsire holds a niche as the only Zacian-C counter in AG. Additionally, it also checks Coil and Dragon Dance variants of Glare Zygarde and Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM. Earthquake allows Quagsire to directly damage Zacian-C and chip other switch-ins such as Eternatus, Kyogre, and Necrozma-DM. Scald can be used to fish for burns against Toxic-immune Pokemon such as Eternatus, Necrozma-DM, and Ferrothorn. Haze is an alternative that allows Quagsire to act as an emergency check to setup sweepers such as Geomancy Xerneas, Dragon Dance Zekrom, and Swords Dance Groudon. Recover provides longevity throughout the game. Toxic threatens and prevents strong breakers such as Kyogre, Calyrex-S, Xerneas, and Yveltal from switching in for free. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Quagsire from being chipped down by entry hazards and lets it remain fully healthy to switch into Zacian-C, while Rocky Helmet can be used on teams with strong entry hazard control to wear down and pressure Zacian-C and prevent Quagsire from being too passive.

Quagsire needs a lot of support and is vulnerable to almost every special attacker. Thus, it must be paired with solid specially defensive walls such as Eternatus, Ferrothorn, Blissey, and Kyurem-W. Due to Quagsire's poor natural bulk, checks to naturally strong physical wallbreakers such as Marshadow, Groudon, and Zekrom are also appreciated, so teammates like Lunala, Eternatus, and Zygarde-C are solid options. Offensive Pokemon like Xerneas, Kyogre, and other setup sweepers can take advantage of Quagsire's passive nature and set up on it; Ditto is an excellent teammate to punish the aforementioned Pokemon.

uu.overview: Quagsire possesses a unique niche in the UU metagame with its ability in Unaware, which lets it stop setup sweepers such as Scizor and Dragon Dance Salamence in their tracks. A Water / Ground typing allows Quagsire to act as a Volt Switch absorber while also checking Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D. As such, these attributes make Quagsire a staple on stall teams. However, Quagsire's 4x weakness to Grass makes it unable to check Pokemon such as Nihilego and Gyarados, as they commonly carry Grass-type coverage. Quagsire's bulk only goes so far, as very strong wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Azumarill can break through it with minimal effort. Finally, Quagsire's poor special bulk leaves it unable to take on special attackers well, leaving it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Thundurus-T and Keldeo.
uu.comments:
Other Options

A Curse set turns Quagsire into a bulky sweeper, but it will need many boosts before it can cause serious damage and is even more vulnerable to Grass-types. Additionally, it must drop Scald from its moveset, making Quagsire much more passive.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Moves: Grass-types resist any attack Quagsire throws at them and proceed to force it out. Amoonguss deserves a special mention, as it is immune to Toxic and can recover any lost health with Regenerator. Pokemon that can lure in Quagsire and KO it with a coverage move, such as Gyarados and Nihilego, are also threats to Quagsire.

Strong Physical Attackers: Quagsire's bulk is only decent; extremely strong attacks coming from the likes of Buzzwole and Diggersby will easily overwhelm it. Haxorus can also easily overpower Quagsire with Mold Breaker ignoring Unaware.

Special Attackers: Quagsire's mediocre special bulk makes it unable to stomach many special attacks, and as such, strong special attackers like Primarina and Azelf can easily break through it.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Scald has a good chance to burn threats such as Scizor and Tapu Bulu. Earthquake hits Pokemon such as Raikou, Jirachi, and Nihilego. Haze stops setup sweepers such as Galarian Slowbro and Reuniclus in their tracks. Toxic is an option that cripples switch-ins such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o, but it has to give up Scald or the utility of Haze to do so. Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to avoid damage from Spikes and Toxic Spikes; however, Quagsire is already resistant to Stealth Rock, and the passive recovery brought by Leftovers is generally much more appreciated. The given EV spread allows Quagsire to take on special attackers such as Rotom-W more comfortably while maximizing its physical bulk.

Quagsire fits best on stall teams, stopping setup sweepers with Unaware. Amoonguss and Tangrowth are excellent partners for Quagsire, as they check Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude. Additionally, these Pokemon are able to check wallbreakers that Quagsire struggles with, such as Conkeldurr. Chansey forms a solid defensive core with Quagsire, being able to check special attackers such as Nihilego and Thundurus-T, while Quagsire checks physical threats for it in return. Chansey's Heal Bell also allows it to cure status that easily wear down Quagsire. Other clerics such as Umbreon and Mew are also good options to pair with Quagsire. As Quagsire can be overwhelmed by strong physical wallbreakers while Spikes are in play, Pokemon that provide Defog support such as Mew and Salamence are highly recommend. Ditto can provide offensive support and deter setup sweepers like Haxorus and Crawdaunt that Quagsire can't deal with properly.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Owing to its invaluable ability Unaware and its stellar defensive typing, Quagsire is the most reliable Zacian-C check in the game, as well as being adept at checking Necrozma-DM and Swords Dance Arceus formes and capable of taking on Dragon Tail Zygarde-C. Earthquake allows Quagsire to defeat Zacian-C, 2HKOing it while also damaging Primal Groudon and Necrozma-DM. Scald can be used over Earthquake for a chance to permanently cripple the aforementioned threats barring Primal Groudon, but it is less effective at forcing them out. Haze prevents Necrozma-DM from setting up on Quagsire and breaking through it with Sunsteel Strike while also providing a win condition versus Baton Pass teams and preventing Zygarde-C from freely setting up. Toxic allows Quagsire to cripple switch-ins such as Ho-Oh and support Arceus formes while chipping away at offensive Pokemon such as Mega Rayquaza, Xerneas, and Yveltal that may try to take advantage of Quagsire's passive nature. Leftovers provides passive recovery and is important to help prevent Play Rough or Close Combat Zacian-C from breaking through Quagsire, which it can with minimal chip. Shed Shell on the other hand eases the matchup versus Mega Gengar and Gothitelle, but in general the stall teams Quagsire features on cannot handle these threats regardless.

Quagsire fits best on stall teams that in particular require an extremely reliable Zacian-C switch-ins. Due to Quagsire's low overall bulk, it is vulnerable to many wallbreakers. Lugia and support Arceus formes are good partners in order to help combat physical wallbreakers such as Primal Groudon, Mega Rayquaza,and Ultra Necrozma, whereas Chansey can check special ones such as Yveltal, Xerneas, Primal, Kyogre, Calm Mind Arceus formes, and Eternatus. Tyranitar is also a good partner, as it aids in checking Yveltal and Eternatus while potentially trapping Mega Gengar. Cleric support from the aformentioned Chansey and Diancie is also vital, as with just small amounts of chip damage, Zacian-C can break through Quagsire. Entry hazard removal is especially important, as Quagsire must be able to switch into Zacian-C reliably, and so Defoggers such as Ho-Oh, support Arceus formes, and Giratina are vital, and Magic Bounce users such as Mega Diancie and Mega Sableye are especially helpful for also countering Ferrothorn, which otherwise takes advantage of Quagsire.

sets.name: Cleric
sets.description:
Umbreon's ability to support other teammates and check strong special attackers such as Chandelure, Indeedee-M, and Necrozma gives it a significant niche in RU. Bulky Pokémon without a reliable recovery move appreciate Umbreon keeping them healthy with Wish and Heal Bell. Protect allows Umbreon to safely recover with Wish and scout opposing Choice item Pokemon. If another teammate already has Heal Bell or Aromatherapy, Umbreon can use Toxic to weaken opposing Pokémon. Foul Play is Umbreon's most reliable offensive move and helps it to better deal with physical attackers such as Metagross, Alolan Marowak, and Crobat. The given EVs coupled with a Calm nature allow Umbreon to check special attackers more effectively. Leftovers gives Umbreon passive recovery and works nicely with Protect. However, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent entry hazard damage, as this cuts into Umbreon's longevity and forces it to use Wish itself more often.

Galarian Weezing is a phenomenal partner for Umbreon because it covers Umbreon's weaknesses, checks common Fighting-types and powerful physical attackers such as Mienshao, Heracross, and Obstagoon, and removes entry hazards with Defog. In return, Umbreon covers Galarian Weezing's weakness to Psychic-type moves and, more importantly, keeps it healthy with its Wish support. Doublade is another example that has good defensive synergy with Umbreon. In general, many defensive and bulky Pokemon without reliable recovery and with susceptibility to status moves, such as Seismitoad, Diancie, and Steelix, appreciate Umbreon as a teammate. Furthermore, if Umbreon is not running Heavy-Duty Boots, a hazard remover like Noivern or Togekiss is very helpful. Since Umbreon is a very passive Pokémon, bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Suicune, Curse Snorlax and Nasty Plot Togekiss can take advantage of it. Powerful attackers like Heracross and Choice Specs Toxtricity can deal with these threats. Lastly, although Umbreon is a good special wall, some special attackers like Nasty Plot Salazzle and Choice Specs Gardevoir can overwhelm Umbreon quickly. Diancie and Registeel can deal with these threats defensively, while faster Pokemon like Crobat and Choice Scarf Flygon check them offensively.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Foul Play enables Umbreon to punish physical attackers like Metagross, Glastrier and Dragapult.

  • Snarl is used in order to reduce the damage output of special attackers such as Spectrier and Tapu Fini.

  • Moonlight allows Umbreon to stay in a match longer and, when combined with its supportive moves, can make it a solid wincon. Sun also boosts Moonlight's recovery.

  • Yawn allows Umbreon to put the opponent's team in an unfavorable position by forcing both foes to switch out or be put to sleep. Taunt allows it to prevent Trick Room attempts from Poyrgon2 or Dusclops and sleep attempts from Amoongus or Venusaur. Helping Hand's support is especially appreciated because Umbreon is frequently paired with heavy-hitters, such as Charizard and Venusaur.

  • Leftovers gives Umbreon increased longevity and Safety Goggles allows it to stand up to common sleep users in Venusaur and Amoongus.

ou.overview: Slowking's great typing, excellent ability in Regenerator, and special bulk make it one of the most reliable pivots and special walls in the metagame, and these traits with the combination of Future Sight and Teleport let it help its teammates to force progress against opposing teams. Regenerator allows Slowking to keep itself healthy, which helps it switch into threats more easily and gives it more opportunities to use Future Sight. With its great bulk and defensive typing, Slowking is able to check threatening specially offensive Pokemon such as Heatran, Nidoking, Tapu Lele, and Latios and use them as Future Sight fodders. However, Slowking is very vulnerable to physical wallbreakers like Landorus-T and Garchomp, as its physical bulk is mediocre and doesn't allow it to tank strong hits from them. Slowking's typing and mediocre physical bulk also leave it very vulnerable to Knock Off and U-turn. This is an issue, as these moves are very frequently run and often safe to use, further limiting Slowking's utility as a defensive pivot. In addition, Toxic is worrisome, as it forces Slowking to use Slack Off more often and limits its potential to consistently switch into dangerous Pokemon such as the aforementioned Heatran, Nidoking, and Tapu Lele.
ou.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower is a great option to make Slowking a lure to Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, but it comes at the opportunity cost of pressuring the opposing team with Future Sight. Thunder Wave is another good option to cripple threatening setup sweepers such as Hydreigon and Nasty Plot variants of Tornadus-T, but losing the utility of Future Sight for it is not recommended.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Common Grass-types like Rillaboom and Kartana threaten Slowking with their super effective STAB options. Ferrothorn is especially annoying, as it can use Slowking as Spikes fodder and it can dish out a strong Power Whip. However, all of them have to fear a possible burn by Scald.
