Electric-types: Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Zeraora threaten Slowking with their respective STAB moves and can easily wear it down with pivoting moves. However, Zeraora can't risk switching into a Scald.

Ghost-types: Dragapult and Aegislash threaten Slowking with their strong STAB moves, but the former has to be wary of a Scald burn if it's running Dragon Darts.

Dark-types: Both Hydreigon and Mandibuzz threaten Slowking, as the former isn't scared by Scald and can use it as setup fodder, while the latter can threaten a Knock Off to remove its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Physical Wallbreakers: Physical wallbreakers such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Melmetal can all easily overwhelm Slowking. Landorus-T can easily pivot with U-turn on it or use Knock Off, Garchomp can dish out heavy damage with its STAB moves, and Melmetal can overwhelm it with coverage options. However, they must be wary of Scald's burn chance.

Toxic: Toxic is annoying for Slowking, as it limits its utility on the field by forcing more switches and uses of Slack Off. Although Slowking can normally check it, Heatran can lure in Slowking and cripple it with a debilitating Toxic.

sets.name: Specially Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Scald is a reliable STAB move and can severely punish potential checks such as Rillaboom, Kartana, Zeraora, and Ferrothorn with a burn if they attempt to hard switch into it. Future Sight pressures opposing teams and works well with Slowking's teammates to increase their wallbreaking potential and force progress. Slack Off lets Slowking stay healthy to reliably check special wallbreakers without having to rely on Teleport or switches. Teleport is not only a solid pivoting option, but it works well in tandem with Future Sight, as Slowking can bring in a more offensive teammate safely to capitalize on the Future Sight. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Slowking pivot in more freely without getting whittled down by entry hazards and helps to maintain healing from Regenerator. 0 Speed IVs with a Sassy nature allow for it to underspeed or Speed tie with opposing Slowking and Slowbro with Teleport.

Slowking fits best on bulky offense and balance, as it is able to check dangerous Pokemon such as Heatran and Nidoking, which are threatening to those team archetypes, while being able to maintain momentum. A lot of offensive Pokemon appreciate the additional pressure of Future Sight as well as Slowking's ability to bring them in safely with Teleport. Garchomp likes having its defensive answers like Tangrowth and Landorus-T pressured by Future Sight, providing it with easier wallbreaking opportunities. Slowking is weak to strong physical attackers such as Rillaboom and Kartana, so switch-ins like Tangrowth and Mandibuzz make great partners; in return, Slowking checks problematic Pokemon such as Heatran for them. Dark- and Ghost-types such as Dragapult and Hydreigon can threaten Slowking, making Mandibuzz and Clefable effective partners. In return, Slowking can check Heatran, Tapu Lele, and Nidoking for them. Additionally, Clefable can capitalize on Dark-types such as Hydreigon and Mandibuzz that Slowking pivots against. Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora are threatening, making defensive Landorus-T and Grass-types like Ferrothorn and the aforementioned Tangrowth good partners that can help keep them at bay. When pivoted into battle via Teleport, both Landorus-T and Ferrothorn can force progress with their own Knock Off or set their respective entry hazards. Furthermore, Slowking checks Tapu Lele, Heatran, and Nidoking for them in return.

cap.comments:
Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Hydreigon and Chromera can consistently switch into Slowking, given they don't mind Scald too much, and freely set up against it. Other Dark-types like Bisharp, Weavile, and Colossoil are much riskier to directly switch into Slowking, but they threaten massive damage and can even block Future Sight if played aggressively.

Bug-types: Miasmaw can wholly prevent Slowking from recovering health thanks to Neutralizing Gas and Taunt, and it can even OHKO Slowking with First Impression. Other Bug-types like Scizor and Syclant are problematic too, since they force Slowking out and then generate momentum with U-turn. All of these Pokemon are heavily punished by Scald burns, though, and thus must be very cautious against Slowking.

Ghost-types: Pajantom can't be burned by Scald and easily removes Slowking with Choice Band Spirit Shackle, while Dragapult and Choice Specs Aegislash aren't bothered too much by burns and can also deal with Slowking with ease.

Grass-types: Rillaboom and Kartana easily OHKO Slowking but must be cautious of Scald burns. Jumbao can use Trace to copy Slowking's Regenerator for free recovery, and Life Orb variants easily OHKO it with Leaf Storm. Geomancy Necturna can very easily set up against Slowking due to its typing and great special bulk.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Set Details

Slowking defines the usage of delay moves in CAP's metagame. Thanks to Teleport, it can almost always safely bring in a devastating wallbreaker to take advantage of Future Sight. Additionally, Slowking is one of the most consistent answers to common special attackers like Heatran, Equilibra, and Tomohawk, and its impressive special bulk even lets it scout hits from strong Choice item attackers like Jumbao, Dragapult, and Kyurem that can hit it super effectively.

Always pair Slowking with wallbreakers like Garchomp, Rillaboom, and Urshifu-R; they all benefit from Slowking's Future Sight preventing physical walls like Landorus-T, Zapdos, and Tomohawk from reliably answering them and appreciate Teleport giving them safe entry onto the field. Fairy-types are also great teammates to have to help with Dark-types like Hydreigon, Chromera, and Colossoil that can block Future Sight and don't mind switching into Scald. Slowking is prone to ceding momentum to Bug-types like Scizor and Syclant and really struggles with Miasmaw denying it recovery, so Steel- and Flying-types like Corviknight and Tornadus-T are good teammates.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Depending on the team's needs, Slowking's deep movepool allows it to run various coverage moves like Ice Beam, Seismic Toss, and Foul Play in place of Dragon Tail or Future Sight. Slowking can hold Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots to allow for utility options like Slack Off and Teleport, but this leaves it unable to reliably check Choice Specs Porygon-Z and sweepers like Spectrier and Hydreigon that have boosted.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Water / Poison Latias and Water-type Mew check Slowking well, as they resist or are immune to its STAB moves. They also threaten Water / Ground Slowking with neutral damage from their Water-type STAB moves, can punish it with moves like Toxic and Knock Off, and set entry hazards against it. Fire / Ground Slowking is heavily threatened by Water-type attacks.

Item Removal: Slowking depends on its Assault Vest to better check special attackers, but Knock Off is common in the metagame, and certain special attackers like Latios and Porygon-Z can remove Slowking's Assault Vest with Trick while giving it undesirable items like Choice Scarf and Choice Specs.

Physical Attackers: Slowking's low Defense leaves it vulnerable to strong physical attackers like Garchomp, Heracross, and Lycanroc-D, which can 2HKO Slowking and force it out, using that opportunity to set up or set entry hazards.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description:
Slowking's good Special Defense combined with Assault Vest allows it to check Choice Specs users like Dragapult and Porygon-Z and Nasty Plot users like Hydreigon, Spectrier, and Tornadus-T. Water / Ground and Fire / Ground are Slowking's most useful type combinations due to their few weaknesses and useful immunities and resistances. Scald pressures opposing teams with its high burn chance and keeps Slowking from being passive. Although Slowking's Attack is below average, Earthquake gives it a useful Ground typing, allows it to 2HKO Dark / Poison Clefable, and pressures Magic Guard Clefable. Flamethrower can be used in place of Scald to better pressure Ground-immune foes like Steel / Dragon Hydreigon and Steel / Flying Mew and Salamence. Flamethrower also allows Slowking to check Fairy-type attackers like Magic Guard Clefable and Tapu Koko, both of which can pressure Water-type Slowking. Dragon Tail forces out special setup sweepers like Spectrier and Hydreigon. Future Sight pairs well with Dragon Tail, as Slowking can phaze Dark-type switch-ins and support offensive teammates.

Slowking pairs well with Electric-type attackers like Latios, Victini, and Naganadel, as they can pressure the Water- and Flying-types like Mew, Latias, and Garchomp that check it. In return, Slowking's Future Sight can create opportunities to punch holes in the opposing team. Slowking is vulnerable to physical attackers like Entei and Garchomp, so it appreciates physically defensive teammates like Salamence and Landorus-T that can check them. These physically bulky teammates can also help Slowking by absorbing Knock Off, letting Slowking keep its added bulk from Assault Vest. Entry hazards like Spikes and Toxic Spikes make it harder for Slowking to check setup sweepers like Porygon-Z, Hydreigon, and Tornadus-T, so Defoggers like Latias and Mew are helpful. Slowking struggles with Fairy-type Calm Mind users like Cresselia, which is immune to Earthquake and Dragon Tail and can cripple Slowking with Toxic, and Electric / Fairy Clefable, which can beat Slowking one-on-one and is only 3HKOed by Earthquake. Therefore, Slowking appreciates Steel-type teammates like Excadrill, Garchomp, and Hydreigon that can take on these threats.

monotype.overview:
Poison

Assault Vest Galarian Slowking is a great specially defensive wall for Poison teams that sponges special attacks from Pokemon like Latios, Kyurem, and Thundurus-T. It can also use its Psychic neutrality to switch into Psychic-type attacks from threats to Poison like Tapu Lele and Latias. It forms a Regenerator core with Toxapex and Amoonguss, making them extremely hard to break through. Its many coverage moves keep it from being setup fodder and improve a number of matchups for Poison like Flying, Dragon, and Fighting. Its lackluster physical bulk leaves it forced out by wallbreakers like Bisharp, Cinderace, Excadrill, and Zeraora.
monotype.comments:
Other Options

Psyshock is an option over Future Sight to prevent Calm Mind and Quiver Dance sweepers like Spectrier and Keldeo from setting up.

Poison

Checks and Counters

Poison

Knock Off: Losing Assault Vest to Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Clefable worsens Galarian Slowking's ability to take on special attackers.

Setup Sweepers: Galarian Slowking has a hard time dealing with many setup sweepers, especially Substitute + Calm Mind users like Jirachi, Spectrier, and Suicune.

Super Effective Attacks: Dark-types such as Crawdaunt, Krookodile, and Weavile threaten to KO Galarian Slowking with their STAB moves. Similarly, Ghost-types like Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Gengar force Galarian Slowking out, but it can often handle an attack or two from special super effective attackers. Ground-types like Excadrill, Garchomp, and Landorus-T can OHKO Galarian Slowking with Earthquake, but the latter two fear switching into Ice Beam.

Physical Attackers: Galarian Slowking is unable to withstand attacks from Pokemon like Zeraora, Dragonite, and Excadrill because of its low Defense.

Defensive Pokemon: None of Galarian Slowking's attacks can overcome walls with reliable recovery like Blissey, Gastrodon, and Mew.

sets.name: Assault Vest (Poison)
sets.description:
Future Sight in conjunction with its other attacks helps Galarian Slowking break through bulkier Pokemon like Toxapex and Cradily and targets wallbreakers like Dragapult and Zeraora. Sludge Bomb immediately damages special attackers and has a nifty chance to poison defensive Pokemon like Mantine and Zapdos, making them a lot easier to beat. Sludge Bomb is also needed to break Substitute from Kyurem, which can threaten Poison with Earth Power and Ice Beam. Earthquake helps with Poison- and Steel-types like Dragalge, Nidoking, and most importantly Heatran, which could trap and remove this set otherwise. Flamethrower with Earthquake gives Poison teams a better chance in the Steel matchup, specifically allowing Galarian Slowking to hit Ferrothorn and other Steel-types like Scizor, Skarmory, and Magnezone. Ice Beam hits Flying- and Dragon-types like Galarian Zapdos, Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, but it often needs to catch them as they switch in. A Sassy nature avoids weakening Earthquake.

All of Galarian Slowking's teammates appreciate its ability to switch in on special attacks from Pokemon like Heatran, often Psychic-types like Alakazam and Choice Scarf Latias. Nidoking can set Stealth Rock, provide an Electric immunity for Regieleki, and get rid of defensive Pokemon and physical attackers like Mantine, Aegislash, and Dragonite. Toxapex and Amoonguss form a Regenerator core alongside Galarian Slowking, making them harder to KO. Toxapex beats setup sweepers like Cinderace and Dragapult with Haze and physical attackers like Bisharp and Weavile. Amoonguss helps the team switch into Earthquake from Mold Breaker Excadrill and avert Swords Dance sweeps with Foul Play. Furthermore, it spreads status with Spore and Stun Spore and helps Galarian Slowking with physical attackers like Zeraora. Galarian Weezing gets rid of entry hazards with Defog, has Levitate for Ground-types like Garchomp and Landorus-T, and has Strange Stream to threaten Dark- and Dragon-types like Dragapult, Hydreigon, Weavile, and Zarude. While Galarian Slowking can withstand most Psychic-type moves, using Drapion prevents the team from being swept by a Calm Mind sweeper like Latias or Jirachi and gives the team Knock Off to remove items and help with Ghost-types like Spectrier and Aegislash.

ru.overview: Steelix's natural bulk, defensive typing, and multiple utility options make it an excellent Stealth Rock setter for balanced or bulky offensive teams. Its solid typing blocks Volt Switch from common Electric-types while also packing a Toxic immunity, something no other Stealth Rock user can offer. Additionally, it serves as a check to common threats like Sylveon, Xurkitree, Toxtricity, Registeel, and Metagross. However, some Electric- and Fairy-types, such as Raikou, Gardevoir, and Togekiss, commonly carry coverage moves that Steelix is vulnerable to. Steelix also struggles with common Water-types like Seismitoad, Milotic, and Volcanion, and its Grass neutrality makes it a Steel-type that cannot reliably check threats like Zarude and Roserade.
ru.comments:
Other Options

Iron Defense + Body Press can handle threats like Curse Snorlax reliably. However, another move must be sacrificed for Iron Defense, and dropping Earthquake leaves Steelix susceptible to Electric-types. Dragon Tail or Roar could be thrown in for setup sweepers like Curse Gastrodon, Reuniclus, and Suicune. Unfortunately, the moves force Steelix to move last, so it can end up getting KOed by Scald or Focus Blast.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Milotic, Seismitoad, and Suicune barely take any damage from Steelix's moves and only worry about Toxic, which Suicune can cure with Rest.

Ground-types: Rhyperior and Gastrodon offensively pressure Steelix. They don't want to be hit with Toxic, however.

Fighting-types: Mienshao and Heracross can pick off weakened Steelix with Close Combat.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Magic Guard Reuniclus, Suicune, and Snorlax don't mind switching into Toxic and freely set up on Steelix.

Fire-types: Chandelure, Volcanion, and Darmanitan force Steelix out with ease. They need to beware of Earthquake from Sturdy variants, however.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heavy Slam reliably beats Sylveon, OHKOes Gardevoir, and 2HKOes Togekiss. Toxic puts common switch-ins to Steelix, like Milotic and Seismitoad, under pressure. The last moveslot is fairly flexible. Body Press, for example, allows Steelix to 2HKO Zarude and OHKO Obstagoon. Head Smash coupled with Rock Head can catch Crobat and Noivern off guard and force them to use Roost.

Since this set focuses on checking foes, setting up Stealth Rock, and providing Toxic support for balanced or bulky offensive teams, Steelix is forced out by numerous threats, including Ground-types like Rhyperior and Gastrodon. Because of this, teammates like Zarude, Togekiss, and Milotic are appreciated. Milotic can switch into any of the Ground-types. Common Water-types like Milotic, Seismitoad, and Suicune force Steelix out or cripple it. Xurkitree, Raikou, Roserade, and the aforementioned Zarude work as answers to them. Zarude is notable because it can pivot on Fairy-types, while Roserade can provide Spikes support, put more pressure on Togekiss, and check Raikou. Xurkitree can threaten other Ground-types with Energy Ball. Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion also offensively pressure Steelix, so partners like Incineroar and Noivern are greatly appreciated. Fighting-types like Heracross and Mienshao appreciate Steelix checking Fairy-types that they struggle with. Fairy-type partners like Sylveon and Galarian Weezing are appreciated, since Sylveon can provide Wish support as well as check threats like Toxtricity if need be, while Galarian Weezing works well as a switch-in to Fighting-types as well as Zarude and can provide Defog support. A teammate like Crobat or Darmanitan can scare off Grass-types like Zarude and Roserade, which Steelix is not a reliable switch-in or check to.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Mega Steelix can opt for a Careful nature over an Impish nature for increased special bulk against threats like Latios at the cost of some physical bulk on teams that have more reliable ways to deal with Azumarill.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Steel-resistant Pokemon: Most Steel-resistant Pokemon such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn have little to no trouble switching in against Mega Steelix and can easily take advantage of Heavy Slam being its only attacking move.

Water-types: Water-type Pokemon such as Mega Slowbro, Keldeo, and Suicune can freely switch in against Mega Steelix, take very little damage from Heavy Slam, and threaten to use Mega Steelix as setup bait. Even water-types that can't set up like Kingdra can easily deal with Mega Steelix with their super effective STAB moves, especially if they're special attackers.

Special Wallbreakers: Due to its mediocre Special Defense stat, strong special attackers such as Landorus and Volcarona can OHKO Mega Steelix with ease.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Mew and Gliscor easily break through Mega Steelix, as it heavily relies on its utility moves in Curse, Rest, and Sleep Talk. Taunt from either can completely shut down Mega Steelix, while Mew can also threaten to burn it with Will-O-Wisp.

Haze and Phazers: As Mega Steelix heavily relies on Curse boosts, common Haze users such as Toxapex and Mantine and phazers such as Hippowdon and Skarmory disrupt its attempts to sweep.

sets.name: Curse (Ground)
sets.description:
An unparalleled Defense stat, a great defensive typing, and access to Curse make Mega Steelix a strong defensive setup sweeper in the Monotype metagame, easily dealing with Fairy, Normal, and Dragon teams. In conjunction with Mega Steelix's sky-high Defense stat, a single Curse boost allows it to survive attacks such as V-create from Choice Band Victini and Close Combat from +2 Mega Gallade. Heavy Slam nails Fairy-types like Tapu Bulu and Mega Diancie while dishing out large amounts of damage against neutral targets, allowing it to deal with most of the tier after a few boosts. Rest allows Mega Steelix to maintain longevity and cure any burns when against passive Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Mega Sableye, and Klefki. Sleep Talk synergizes well with Rest, allowing it to potentially further set up with Curse or fire off a powerful Heavy Slam even when asleep, preventing foes from taking advantage of Rest. Due to its already sky-high Defense stat, maximum HP and Special Defense EVs are invested to increase Mega Steelix's special bulk, allowing it to better deal with special attackers like Latios and Alolan Ninetales. An Impish nature is used to ensure Mega Steelix survives a +6 Aqua Jet from Azumarill, KOing it back with Heavy Slam.

Gastrodon and Seismitoad act as great teammates, as they both provide a much needed immunity to Water-type attacks and are able to deal with threats to Mega Steelix, such as Mega Slowbro and Mantine. Landorus synergizes well with Mega Steelix, as it comfortably deals with some of Mega Steelix's checks in Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Heatran while also acting as a great special wallbreaker. Mamoswine can deal with troublesome Ground-, Flying- and Dragon-type Pokemon such as Landorus, Zapdos, and Garchomp while also providing a form of priority thanks to Ice Shard. Nidoking works well with Mega Steelix, as it can better address the threat posed by Steel- and Flying-types that deal with Mega Steelix, such as Ferrothorn and Celesteela, by virtue of its wide coverage boosted by Sheer Force. Excadrill provides a way to check faster foes such as Cinderace and also deals with offensive threats such as Heatran while providing secondary hazard control thanks to Rapid Spin; it is also able to act as reliable wallbreaker with Swords Dance. Garchomp can form a strong physical wallbreaker core in tandem with Mega Steelix, since Swords Dance lets it break past some of Mega Steelix's checks in Mantine and Toxapex. Gliscor can cripple both offensive and defensive Pokemon thanks to Knock Off and Taunt, which Mega Steelix appreciates greatly, while also removing troublesome Spikes with Defog. Hippowdon can be a great teammate, as it sets up sand, activating Mega Steelix's Sand Force, while also providing Stealth Rock support.

zu.comments:
Other Options

A Swords Dance set can act as a terrifying stallbreaker with Qwilfish's Toxic immunity and access to Taunt. However, it lacks bulk and power, even when boosted. Qwilfish can run max Speed on its defensive set to outspeed attackers like Skuntank and Adamant Kangaskhan; however, that jeopardizes its ability to handle physical attackers. Such sets can run Destiny Bond to get an unexpected KO, but Qwilfish usually doesn't have the room for it and is required to run an inferior max Speed spread. Although weaker than Liquidation, Waterfall is an option on both sets for its flinch chance and synergy with Thunder Wave. Poison Jab is also an alternative to the STAB moves on defensive sets for its ability to damage Water-resistant attackers like Exeggutor, Basculin, and Shiftry and spread poison. However, Thunder Wave and Scald already spread status and cripple those Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Uxie: Thanks to Levitate, Uxie isn't affected by Qwilfish's entry hazards and can heavily damage it with Psychic, while Qwilfish hardly hurts Uxie with its moves. Uxie's Future Sight is also a huge threat to Qwilfish, as it prevents Qwilfish from switching into threats it is supposed to counter, such as Rapidash and Gurdurr.

Ground-immune Entry Hazard Removers: Entry hazard removers such as Rotom, Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cryogonal aren't affected by Spikes and threaten Qwilfish with their powerful special attacks. They can easily force Qwilfish out and use that opportunity to remove its entry hazards.

Special Attackers: Qwilfish's special bulk is underwhelming, meaning that special attackers such as Thievul, Rotom, and Articuno can easily OHKO it.

Ground-types: Qwilfish is weak to Ground-types and cannot handle crucial physical attackers such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Ground, even if they are 2HKOed by Qwilfish's Water-type STAB moves. Qwilfish also takes heavy damage from common Ground-type coverage from wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; the latter is noteworthy due to Inner Focus ignoring Intimidate.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Even with Intimidate, Qwilfish's bulk isn't amazing and, without any reliable recovery moves, it is quickly put in range of powerful wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Choice Band Cinccino, and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

sets.name: Defensive Spikes
sets.description:
Qwilfish is a premier physical wall that is able to set Spikes or Toxic Spikes and counter powerful physical attackers such as Basculin and Sawk. Its typing also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes from opposing Qwilfish and Cofagrigus. Thanks to Taunt, Qwilfish can prevent slower Pokémon such as Cofagrigus, Pyukumuku, and Ferroseed from setting up, recovering HP, and setting entry hazards. Thunder Wave cripples faster attackers such as Skuntank, specially offensive Basculin, and Articuno, which can otherwise freely switch into Qwilfish. Liquidation is the preferred STAB move for its ability to OHKO Rapidash and Ninetales after minimal residual damage. Scald is another option that, while significantly weaker, can cripple switch-ins with a burn. Pain Split improves Qwilfish's longevity versus bulkier teams. Rocky Helmet lets Qwilfish wear down physical attackers, punishing resisted moves like Gurdurr's Mach Punch, Alolan Sandslash's Triple Axel, and Basculin's Flip Turn. Alternatively, Black Sludge makes Qwilfish less reliant on Pain Split. The given EV spread lets Qwilfish outspeed Adamant Alolan Sandslash and maximize its physical bulk.

Qwilfish fits well on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its defensive utility and ability to set entry hazards. Special walls like Articuno, Audino, and Ferroseed make for great partners, as they are able to handle special attackers like Frosmoth, Rotom, and Frosmoth; in return, Qwilfish handles physical attackers such as Sawk and Rapidash. Ground-immune and -resistant Pokemon such as Rotom-S, Uxie, and Tangela cover Qwilfish's Ground weakness. VoltTurn cores pair well with Spikes, as they force a lot of switches. Therefore, Pokemon such as Rotom, Silvally-Ground, and Cinccino make for great partners. Spikes are appreciated by wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; Kangaskhan is a noteworthy example, as it can force switches thanks to Fake Out. Knock Off users such as Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gurdurr can remove opposing Heavy-Duty Boots, bolstering the effectiveness of Qwilfish's entry hazards.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper (Bug)
sets.description:
Thanks to its decent bulk, its access to Swords Dance, and the many resistances given by its Steel typing, Scizor can act as a threatening setup sweeper for Bug-type teams. Swords Dance allows Scizor to boost its Attack to high levels and become a dangerous setup sweeper in many matchups such as Fairy and Poison. Bullet Punch is a great priority STAB move boosted by Technician that lets Scizor pressure faster threats like Terrakion and allows it to clean late-game; in addition, Bullet Punch helps greatly in the Fairy matchup, as Scizor can take care of Pokemon like Togekiss, Belly Drum Azumarill, and Galarian Weezing, especially after a Swords Dance boost. Dual Wingbeat is a strong move boosted by Technician that greatly helps against defensive Poison-types like Toxapex and Amoonguss. Knock Off is a utility move used to punish switch-ins like Galarian Corsola and Toxapex or common defensive Normal-types like Chansey and Porygon2. Alternatively, Superpower can be used to hit Steel- and Normal-types like Excadrill, Ferrothorn, Duraludon, and Porygon2 hard, which can otherwise be hard for Bug teams to handle. Scizor should seek opportunities to set up against passive Pokemon that do not threaten it such as Bronzong, and it should be used mid- or late-game once its checks and counters like Skarmory are taken out or weakened enough. Maximum Attack investment in combination with an Adamant nature and Life Orb allows Scizor to maximize its damage output. 252 EVs in Speed allow it to outspeed faster threats like Indeedee-M and Urshifu-S when Sticky Web is up.

All of Scizor's teammates appreciate its ability to threaten weakened Pokemon with Bullet Punch. Galvantula and Araquanid are able to set Sticky Web, allowing Scizor to threaten faster Pokemon like Urshifu-S, Indeedee-M, and Drapion that are less vulnerable to Bullet Punch. Galvantula can also be used to improve the matchup against Flying- and Water-type teams and threaten most Defoggers such as Mandibuzz and Mantine. On the other hand, Araquanid can switch into Fire-type moves directed at Scizor thanks to its Water typing in combination with its ability Water Bubble; it can also use Magic Coat to bounce back very annoying Spikes against Steel, Grass, and Fairy teams. Volcarona forms a great offensive core with Scizor, as the former can cover a variety of matchups, including Electric, for Scizor and can also take care of Steel-types that check Scizor like Skarmory and Corviknight. In return, Scizor can deal with Rock- and Normal-types such as Tyranitar, Chansey, and Snorlax that Volcarona struggles against. Choice Scarf Heracross is a good partner to handle faster Fire-types like opposing Volcarona and Cinderace, and it helps Scizor against Steel and Rock teams with Close Combat. Heracross also appreciates Scizor's ability to weaken opposing teams so that it can act as a deadly sweeper late-game. Finally, Scolipede is also a good teammate, as it helps in the Fairy-type matchup and can use its coverage moves like Earthquake and Rock Slide to hit Steel- and Fire-types like Cobalion and Salazzle.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Scizor can opt for items other than Life Orb to increase its defensive capabilities at the cost of some power; Rocky Helmet can damage physical attackers such as Lycanroc-D and Rillaboom, while Leftovers provides Scizor with passive recovery. Scizor can run U-turn for a pivoting option. This option can either provide Scizor with a Steel / Bug typing, or it can maintain its Steel / Flying typing with Roost in the second moveslot at the cost of not benefiting from Technician. Defog is an option on more defensively oriented sets over Swords Dance as a Defogger with priority, though these sets are outclassed by other defensive Steel / Flying types like Mew and Salamence. Superpower can be used as a coverage option to hit Steel-type switch-ins like Magnezone and Garchomp. Another niche option is Knock Off to hit Ghost-types such as Heracross, Reuniclus, and Latias and remove opposing items. A Choice Band can provide more immediate power to Scizor's Bullet Punch and allows it to pressure its usual checks with U-turn and Knock Off at the cost of Swords Dance and Roost.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Victini, Mew, and Latias resist both of Scizor's STAB moves and are able to OHKO it. Victini and Latias in particular are especially strong checks, as they take minimal damage from Bullet Punch. Electric / Fairy Clefable is still able to OHKO Scizor, though it is more prone to its Bullet Punch. Magnezone is another particularly threatening Electric-type check, as it can trap and OHKO Scizor.

Offensive Fire-types: Offensive Fire-types like Heatran, Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Tornadus-T are solid offensive checks, as they outspeed Scizor and resist its Bullet Punch. However, they usually cannot switch into Scizor without the risk of taking massive damage from its Dual Wingbeat.

Mew: Mew is a great defensive check to Scizor with both its bulky Water- and Steel-type sets. Water-type Mew is able to check Scizor more effectively than other bulky Water-types, as it is faster than Scizor and can more properly threaten it with Scald or Will-O-Wisp. Steel-type Mew resists both of Scizor's STAB moves but is reliant on Will-O-Wisp to properly beat it.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance Scizor is a solid priority revenge killer with STAB Bullet Punch to hit faster threats such as Heracross, Pheromosa, and Spectrier. Dual Wingbeat provides Scizor with a Steel / Flying typing, which is a solid defensive typing to maximize its setup opportunities, and allows it to hit bulky Water-types like Mew, Toxapex, and Latias. Additionally, Dual Wingbeat Scizor is able to check threats such as Rillaboom and Landorus-T by threatening to OHKO them. Swords Dance allows Scizor to break past walls like Mew and Toxapex. Roost keeps Scizor healthy against its bulkier checks and allows it to properly check Fairy / Poison Cresselia. Life Orb is used to boost Scizor's power even further and works well in conjunction with Roost. Technician boosts both of Scizor's STAB attacks, which allows it to 2HKO the majority of the unresisted metagame.

Scizor is able to threaten faster threats like Pheromosa, Spectrier, and Tornadus-T, so slower Pokemon like Latias, Hydreigon, and offensive Mew appreciate its speed control. Ground-type partners like Garchomp and Hydreigon pressure some Electric-types that threaten Scizor; it should be noted though that Ground-immune Electric-types like Latias and offensive Mew require these partners to have strong secondary STAB attacks to properly beat them. Scizor is able to complement Ground-types by being a solid offensive check to Rillaboom, though it cannot switch in safely to Superpower variants. While Scizor is able to break past bulky Water-types, they are often able to threaten it out with Scald or coverage options; specially attacking Dragon-type partners like Latias, Latios, and Dragapult are able to switch into these threats without being hindered by Scald burns.

anythinggoes.comments:
Other Options

Rock Tomb is an option to lower the Speed of offensive Flying-types such as Rayquaza and Yveltal as well as other foes like Zacian-C attempting to stay in and KO Shuckle. Knock Off gets rid of items like Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Ho-Oh, Necrozma-DM, and Yveltal, making Shuckle's entry hazards more effective. However, both of these options are hard to justify over other good utility moves such as Final Gambit and Infestation due to their limited use cases.

Checks and Counters

Gothitelle: Shuckle is prohibited from switching out against Gothitelle due to Shadow Tag, making it especially susceptible to Taunt and potentially allowing the opponent to remove entry hazards freely. Gothitelle can also shrug off Shuckle's Toxic with Rest and prevent entry hazards from being set entirely if it's not running Mental Herb.

Setup Sweepers: Devastating setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Zygarde-C, Xerneas, and Zekrom can set up in front of Shuckle once Encore has been used and proceed to Dynamax and sweep without being locked into a move. Red Card also cannot phaze out Pokemon under Dynamax, making the aforementioned setup sweepers tougher to deal with.

Entry Hazard Removers: Because Shuckle is passive, it relies on Toxic or Infestation to wear down Defog users like Ho-Oh and Yveltal that can remove Sticky Web and Stealth Rock with ease. Giratina can shrug Toxic off with Rest and is immune to trapping, and Excadrill can use Rapid Spin against Shuckle and keep its Stealth Rock up. However, Encore in conjunction with offensive pressure from teammates can negate this.

sets.name: Sticky Web
sets.description:
Shuckle's access to Sticky Web and solid bulk sets itself apart from other entry hazard leads in AG, allowing it to effectively utilize its plethora of other great utility options such as Stealth Rock, Encore, Toxic, and Knock Off. Sticky Web is useful for slowing down grounded offensive foes such as Calyrex-S, Choice Scarf Kyogre, and Zacian-C for teammates. Stealth Rock also aids teammates by chipping down foes and can target certain Pokemon unaffected by Sticky Web such as Life Orb Yveltal. Encore is useful for preventing setup sweepers such as Xerneas, Nasty Plot Calyrex-S, Zekrom, and Groudon from using Shuckle as complete setup fodder, forcing them to switch out or Dynamax, while also enabling teammates to switch in freely. Final Gambit generates momentum for Shuckle's teammates by KOing itself once entry hazards have potentially been set up. Alternatively, Infestation traps and slowly damages foes like Necrozma-DM, Ferrothorn, and defensive Xerneas during the match, forcing chip damage on them as well as working with Encore to give Shuckle's teammates free switch-ins. Toxic can also be used to put a timer on Defoggers such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal. Sturdy allows Shuckle to survive attacks from powerful attackers like Kyogre, enabling it to use Mental Herb for Taunt users such as Yveltal and Grimmsnarl, guaranteeing it gets to set an entry hazard. Alternatively, Red Card forces out an abundance of threats like Zacian-C and Kyogre as well as boosted Zygarde-C and Zekrom.

Shuckle should only be used on hyper offense teams that can make full use of Sticky Web. Slower setup sweepers and wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Kyogre, Zekrom, and Groudon can all take advantage of Sticky Web while threatening common Defoggers including Ho-Oh and Yveltal. Ghost-types such as Calyrex-S and Marshadow can effectively spinblock against opposing Excadrill, preventing Shuckle's Sticky Web and Stealth Rock from being removed. Due to the importance of Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, Shuckle should generally be led with in order to immediately slow down offensive grounded threats with Sticky Web and weaken foes with Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Entry Hazards Lead (Bug)
sets.description:
Set Description

Shuckle is the primary entry hazard setter for Bug teams, with its access to Stealth Rock and Sticky Web. Since Shuckle is a utility Pokemon, Encore is used as an insurance against setup Pokemon such as Gyarados and Hawlucha, which can potentially exploit Shuckle. Toxic is used to cripple bulky Pokemon such as Hippowdon. Knock Off can be used as an alternative to cripple Pokemon such as Corviknight and Ferrothorn by removing their item. Mental Herb is used to bypass Taunt users such as Froslass and Sableye in order to allow Shuckle to at least set up either Stealth Rock or Sticky Web; otherwise, it is forced to Struggle under Taunt.

Strong wallbreakers such as Centiskorch and Durant appreciate Stealth Rock, as they can wallbreak more consistently with the chip damage. Centiskorch greatly benefits from Sticky Web, as its Speed is mediocre as well. Durant can outspeed common Choice Scarf users with Sticky Web up on the opposing side of the field, such as Dracozolt and Excadrill. Sticky Web also frees teammates like Galvantula and Vikavolt from running it, allowing them to use more offensive sets.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter (Rock)
sets.description:
Shuckle is essential for Rock-type teams because of its access to Stealth Rock and Sticky Web. By using Sticky Web, Shuckle helps its teammates greatly with outpacing threats such as Jirachi. Stealth Rock is great to help wear down Pokemon on the switch in. Knock Off helps with depriving bulky Pokemon like Hippowdon of Leftovers recovery and Duraludon of Choice items. Toxic is an option over Knock Off to put Pokemon such as Mantine, Kommo-o, and Slowbro on a timer. Encore is great to lock setup Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Scizor into Nasty Plot or Swords Dance and can also be useful against bulky Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Galarian Corsola to lock them into the first move they use, which forces them to switch out. Mental Herb is used to bypass Taunt from Pokemon like Froslass and Kommo-o once, therefore letting Shuckle set entry hazards up. Use Shuckle early-game to get Sticky Web down so its teammates can have an easier time with outpacing Pokemon or setting up. 252 HP and 252 Special Defense EVs alongside a Calm nature allow Shuckle to set up entry hazards more easily due to it being able to tank attacks.

All teammates appreciate Shuckle for its ability to use entry hazards to help them outpace or chip down the opposing Pokemon. Barbaracle is a good setup sweeper that can take care of Sand Rush Excadrill thanks to its part Water-typing and benefit from Shuckle's Sticky Web, giving it more safe setup opportunities with Shell Smash and allowing it to outpace Excadrill in sand along with Kyurem and Choice Scarf Darmanitan. Terrakion is a good Choice Scarf user for when Sticky Web has not been set up or has been removed with Defog or Rapid Spin. Terrakion's part-Fighting typing is useful in the Steel- and Dark-type matchup for dealing with Excadrill, Bisharp, and Hydreigon. Coalossal is a great Rapid Spin user because of its bulk and can stack entry hazards with Shuckle with Spikes. Tyranitar is another setup sweeper that can greatly help with the Ghost- and Psychic-type matchups because it can take advantage of Stick Web, set up with Dragon Dance, and take care of threats such as Gengar and Gardevoir. Rhyperior is a much-needed partner to give the team a way to deal with Corviknight and Skarmory via Smack Down and Earthquake, and can also use its Earthquake and Fire Punch to greatly help with taking care of Steel-types like Jirachi, Excadrill, and Bisharp.

nationaldex.comments:
Other Options

Shuckle has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Strong Wallbreakers: Shuckle, despite its good bulk, can be easily overwhelmed by a plethora of Pokemon such as Kartana, Mega Mawile, and Rillaboom.

Offensive Water-types: Offensive Water-types such as Ash-Greninja, Mega Swampert, and Manaphy can 2HKO Shuckle with their STAB moves, thus limiting it to one layer of hazards.

Substitute and Taunt: Substitute and Taunt users such as Serperior, Gengar, Tapu Fini, and Tapu Koko are very troublesome for Shuckle, as they can take advantage of it setting hazards or outright block hazards from Red Card sets; however, Shuckle can deal with them through Encore.

sets.name: Sticky Web Setter
sets.description: Shuckle finds a niche in National Dex OU as a lead on Sticky Web teams due to its great bulk and Final Gambit alongside Encore, which provide momentum to its teammates with ease after it sets entry hazards. Encore is vital because it can lock foes into Defog or a stat-boosting move, such as Corviknight, Zapdos, Rillaboom, and Mega Garchomp, allowing Shuckle to more easily set up hazards while also making it easy for its teammates to revenge kill them. Mental Herb is the item of choice for Shuckle to securely set up at least one hazard, as it is very susceptible to Taunt from Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl, Tapu Koko, and Mew; however, that can be replaced with Red Card, which can force out strong attackers and disrupt U-turn and Volt Switch from Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Rillaboom, and Landorus-T. Bisharp is an essential teammate for Shuckle, as Defiant helps it easily deter Defoggers such as Corviknight and Zapdos, and it's a very threatening wallbreaker and setup sweeper. Serperior's Contrary also pressures Defog. Shuckle's Sticky Web support heavily supports a multitude of slow yet powerful wallbreakers, such as Thundurus-T, Mega Scizor, and Mega Heracross.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Rock

Shuckle may opt to run Toxic to cripple walls like Mantine and Porygon2. However, it comes at the cost of forgoing Encore, which prevents Shuckle from being used as setup bait.

Checks and Counters

Rock

Magic Bounce: Magic Bounce users like Mega Diancie and Mega Sableye bounce off all of Shuckle's utility moves and take little to no damage whatsoever from Knock Off. While Mega Diancie needs to be wary of a full HP Final Gambit, Mega Sableye is completely immune to it, therefore always beating Shuckle.

Taunt Users: Taunt users like Hydreigon, Mew, and Gliscor prevent Shuckle from setting up any entry hazards after Mental Herb has been used. However, Shuckle in return threatens to remove Toxic Orb from Gliscor with Knock Off.

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Excadrill and Mega Scizor deal with Shuckle with ease. Excadrill in particular can get rid of any entry hazards set up by Shuckle, and it also ignores Sturdy due to Mold Breaker. However, they need to be wary of Encore when using Swords Dance.

Water-types: Water-type Pokemon like Tapu Fini and Urshifu-R can deal with Shuckle without much trouble. Tapu Fini can at least prevent Stealth Rock from going up due to Taunt, while Choice Band Urshifu-R can threaten to OHKO Shuckle with Surging Strikes, as it renders Sturdy useless. Other Water-types, like Keldeo, can easily defeat Shuckle with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Utility (Rock)
sets.description:
Shuckle plays an integral role on every Rock team due to its access to Sticky Web and the ability to reliably set it up against most Pokemon due to its access to Sturdy, paving the way for Rock's only viable playstyle, Sticky Web Offense. Sticky Web drops foes' Speed by one stage, which greatly benefits Shuckle's teammates such as Terrakion, Nihilego, and Mega Diancie and allows them to deal with faster threats such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Greninja. Stealth Rock helps wear down foes upon switch in, most notably breaking Focus Sash and Sturdy from Pokemon such as Cloyster and Skarmory. Encore prevents setup sweepers such as Mega Gallade, Azumarill, and Volcarona from using Shuckle as setup bait. It also helps deal with defensive walls like Toxapex by forcing them into using utility moves. Knock Off helps get rid of items such as Heavy-Duty Boots, Eviolite, and Choice Scarf from Pokemon like Blissey, Porygon2, and Landorus-T. Removing Heavy-Duty Boots also further improves the effectiveness of the hazards Shuckle sets. Final Gambit can be opted for over Encore, as it provides great momentum gain after hazards are set up. Mental Herb allows Shuckle to ignore Taunt from Pokemon such as Aerodactyl, Cobalion, and Tapu Fini for a single turn allowing it to reliably set up at least one entry hazard. 248 HP EVs and 252 Defense EVs along with an Impish nature maximizes Shuckle's physical bulk and minimizes damage taken by Stealth Rock. Sturdy ensures Shuckle survives a hit from full HP, allowing it to set up hazards against powerful wallbreakers like Choice Specs Aegislash.

Mega Diancie pairs well with Shuckle, bouncing off entry hazards and Taunt while also being able to make the most of Shuckle's Sticky Web and Stealth Rock support. The former helps Mega Diancie outspeed threats such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Mega Lopunny, while the latter chips threats, allowing it to successfully net more KOs. Much like Mega Diancie, Choice Scarf Terrakion appreciates Shuckle reliably setting up Sticky Web to outspeed faster threats, such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Choice Scarf Greninja. Terrakion can also run Swords Dance to make the most out of Sticky Web, as Swords Dance further improves its wallbreaking abilities and helps greatly in matchups such as Steel and Normal. Nihilego can be a threatening teammate against Fairy, Flying, and Water teams when paired with Shuckle's entry hazards thanks to a great ability in Beast Boost and a wide range of coverage options. Tyranitar can provide sand support, bolstering Shuckle's already high Special Defense stat, allowing it to take special hits better, while also improving the Psychic and Ghost matchups greatly due to its STAB-boosted Crunch and Pursuit. Alolan Golem pairs well with Shuckle thanks to an amazing ability in Magnet Pull, allowing it to deal with threats such as Mega Scizor, which it even outspeeds after Sticky Web. Shell Smash Omastar appreciates hazards set up by Shuckle, as they allow it to outspeed most threats and not worry about Sturdy and Focus Sash.

ru.overview: Guts Heracross stands as one of the most dangerous wallbreakers thanks to its freedom to choose between powerful attacks alongside its decent Speed tier, which lets it outspeed bulkier Pokemon and keep dangerous threats like Volcanion and Toxtricity in check. Heracross's typing enables it to take a hit from Zarude or Mienshao, giving it openings and expanding its defensive use. Meanwhile, Choice Scarf allows Heracross to act as a revenge killer and a potent cleaner, with Moxie allowing it to snowball after a KO. Despite Heracross's potency in wallbreaking, the Guts set cannot come onto the field easily by itself and is quickly worn down by entry hazards and its burn, mandating support and selective play. The Choice Scarf set requires the opposition to be heavily weakened to sweep and struggles with faster Choice Scarf users that can revenge kill it, especially if it lowers its defenses with Close Combat. Mienshao competes with it as a Choice Scarf Fighting-type, as it is faster, can pivot around with U-turn, and has Regenerator to combat chip damage, but Mienshao cannot snowball like Heracross can.
ru.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an alternative wallbreaking route that is able to stay healthy more easily while potentially bluffing a Choice Scarf set, but it is held back by its prediction-reliant nature in an environment with Pokemon like Togekiss, Crobat, and Alolan Marowak, which can sponge its STAB attacks.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Even though Fairy-types like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing are threatened by Facade from the Guts set, they can prove to be an annoyance if Heracross doesn't predict correctly. Galarian Weezing in particular does well if carrying Neutralizing Gas to negate Guts. Choice Scarf Heracross severely struggles with Fairy-types, as it has no direct workaround for most of them.

Faster Pokemon: Many threats such as Starmie, Obstagoon, Talonflame, and Mimikyu can outpace and threaten Guts Heracross. Choice Scarf Heracross can take a hit from certain Choice Scarf users, such as Zarude and Mienshao, but others like Darmanitan outspeed and KO it. If Heracross drops its defenses with Close Combat, more Pokemon are capable of revenge killing it even at high health.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description: Megahorn OHKOes Psychic-types like Reuniclus, Cresselia, and Necrozma, while Swords Dance can ease prediction against Fairy-types and punish Protect users trying to rack up Flame Orb chip. Stone Edge can snipe Flying-types such as Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame, which can otherwise take a hit and threaten Heracross out. Heracross puts immediate pressure on Steel-types and often zeroes in on Fairy-types such as Togekiss and Sylveon, which Zarude and Sharpedo can take advantage of. Heracross can break through most Pokemon by itself, but teammates like Starmie can prevent chip damage from entry hazards and pivots such as Thundurus and Darmanitan give Heracross openings to activate its Flame Orb, maximizing its chances to wallbreak. Certain Pokemon like Chandelure, Galarian Weezing, and Mimikyu can attempt to pivot around Heracross's attacks, racking up Flame Orb damage and punishing mispredictions, so having teammates like Darmanitan can help apply additional pressure on them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Megahorn is a strong secondary STAB attack to clean with, but Spikes can be more effective against bulkier teams. Stone Edge allows Heracross to keep Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame in check and potentially catch Togekiss attempting to switch in. The threat of a late-game sweep will require the opponent to preserve a set of Pokemon in order to handle any one move Heracross may try to clean with. Thus, partners like Obstagoon and Gardevoir can help wear down or threaten these Pokemon, which include Chandelure, Doublade, and Togekiss. Heracross's weakness to faster Choice Scarf users like Darmanitan can be mitigated by teammates like Rhyperior and Seismitoad, which can also set up Stealth Rock to chip away at the opposition. Running Spikes on Heracross not only helps its own sweeping efforts, but also assists other Pokemon like Stakataka and Necrozma, which benefit from Steel- and Water-types being worn down.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Feint is a solid option for Heracross's third moveslot that allows it to take down faster offensive threats, and even some Extreme Speed users at +2, though the lack of coverage moves makes Heracross easier to wall. A Fighting-type Heracross with Close Combat as its main STAB move is an option, with a Fighting / Dark typing being used the most. Dark / Fighting Heracross has less breaking capability than Heracross's main sets, as it doesn't have the powerful STAB Facade at its disposal. Normal / Fighting Heracross is an option as well for Fighting-type Heracross, though this set is starkly worse against Ghost-types. Spikes is a strong option on any Heracross set over Swords Dance to offer team support and chip potential switch-ins, though losing Swords Dance limits its breaking capability.

Checks and Counters

Salamence: Defensive Steel / Flying Salamence is a reliable check to Heracross's sets since it resists Facade, can tank any of Heracross' coverage moves comfortably, and generally runs Rocky Helmet to further chip Heracross. Additionally, Salamence is able to remove hazards that either Heracross or its teammates set with Defog, which can make it even more difficult for Heracross to make progress.

Buzzwole: Similarly to Salamence, a bulky Steel / Flying Buzzwole is able to wall Heracross, and Buzzwole is able to more reliably check Swords Dance sets compared to Salamence by virtue of Bulk Up.

Bulky Ghost-type Pokemon: Bulky Ghost-type Pokemon such as Ghost / Fairy Cresselia and Ghost / Fighting Slowbro are some of the best checks to some of Heracross's sets, though both of these Pokemon lose to Normal / Ghost Heracross.

Tornadus-T: Tornadus-T is a huge offensive threat to Heracross and any of its sets are able to stop Heracross from sweeping, though it cannot reliably switch into any of Heracross's moves. Even if Heracross has Sticky Web support, Flying-type Tornadus-T sets are solid offensive checks to Heracross.

Latios: Latios is another great offensive check to Heracross by virtue of its Speed tier and immunity to Sticky Web via Levitate. Every variant of Latios is able to cleanly OHKO Heracross, and Ghost-type variants of Latios are also able to switch into Heracross's Facade, though this is risky given Latios is OHKOed by the rest of Heracross's coverage.

Dragapult: Dragapult an offensive check to Heracross that fits onto many teams. It has multiple options to OHKO Heracross and gains momentum on switch-ins by pivoting out. As with other offensive checks, Dragapult cements itself as a reliable check as it can nullify Sticky Web with Clear Body.

sets.name: Guts Attacker
sets.description:
Heracross is a devastating physical attacker in the Camomons metagame that utilizes Guts and STAB Facade to 2HKO the majority of neutral metagame. Shadow Claw and Knock Off both allow Normal-type Heracross to break through Pokemon resistant or immune to Normal. STAB Shadow Claw is able to hit common defensive Ghost-types, such as Ghost / Fighting Slowbro, and a Normal / Ghost typing makes Heracross immune to Fighting- and Normal-type attacks such as Boomburst, Close Combat, and Extreme Speed, each of which is threatening to Heracross's other sets. Knock Off is the main coverage choice for Ghost-type Heracross, as it hits opposing Normal / Ghost Pokemon and offers great support by removing items. On the other hand, Close Combat is the coverage option of choice on Dark-type Heracross to hit Steel / Fairy Pokemon such as Magearna and Reuniclus, and it heavily damages Pokemon resistant to Normal that have already had their items removed. Swords Dance allows Heracross to break opposing teams much more effectively and break past walls it normally could not.

Heracross has limited defensive counterplay, but against offensive teams, it generally relies on extensive support from teammates like Latios and Dragapult, which are much faster and able to dismantle most of Heracross's offensive checks effectively. Clefable and Dragon / Fairy Necrozma can act as defensive switch-ins to Heracross's offensive checks such as Dragapult, Latios, and Fighting / Flying Tornadus-T. Additionally, Sticky Web support from Araquanid is a highly effective strategy to weaken Heracross's offensive checks considerably. For the few defensive Pokemon that give Heracross a hard time, strong special attackers such as Electric / Fairy Clefable and Fighting / Flying Tornadus-T are able to break past them. They also provide support with Stealth Rock and pivoting, respectively, both of which increase Heracross' breaking capabilities. It's important to note that, in any game, Heracross is constantly losing HP due to the effects of Flame Orb, so it's important to make the most of every turn it's on the field.

pu.overview: Sneasel is a strong offensive threat in PU thanks to its high Speed that allows it to outpace major threats such as Archeops and near-unresisted STAB move combination in Knock Off and Triple Axel, which are powerful enough to make up for Sneasel's lacking Attack stat. Sneasel can further improve its damage output with Swords Dance or Choice Band. However, even with these options, Sneasel can struggle to break through walls like Weezing and Aromatisse. Sneasel's bulk is very low, making it difficult to switch into even the most passive defensive Pokemon, such as Palossand. It also doesn't help that not running Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Sneasel extremely vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, while running it leaves Sneasel somewhat weaker and more vulnerable to status. Sneasel also faces competition from other fast revenge killers such as Archeops and Whimsicott, which have more switch-in opportunities and pivoting. Nevertheless, nothing in the tier can rival Sneasel's combination of typing, Speed, and powerful STAB combination.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Due to Sneasel's weakness to Stealth Rock and susceptibility to all other entry hazards, Heavy-Duty Boots is the primary option for its held item. However, Life Orb can be used for an easier time sweeping, and Lum Berry gives Sneasel a one-time out from being crippled by status from the likes of Weezing and Jellicent. Sneasel rarely wants to directly switch into attacks, so it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Uxie. Silvally-Fairy is also able to remove hazards, while Uxie is able to set Stealth Rock up, and both can also check Fighting-types like Passimian, which can cause trouble for Sneasel. These Fighting-types, as well as defensive threats like Weezing and Silvally-Steel, should be taken out or greatly weakened for Sneasel before it starts setting up. Wallbreakers such as Charizard and Archeops are ideal for this role. Spikes setters and Rocky Helmet users such as Qwilfish and Druddigon are also ideal for dealing chip damage to Choice Scarf users such as Passimian and Togedemaru, ideally putting them into range of Sneasel's +2 Ice Shard before it starts setting up.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band gives Sneasel a good amount of raw power to spam its STAB moves. Low Kick provides coverage for various Pokemon that would take longer for Sneasel to wear down, such as Regirock and Silvally-Steel. Similarly to its Swords Dance set, Sneasel has difficulty hard switching in and is therefore best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Lanturn and defensive Mesprit. Because full control over the entry hazard game is difficult, Sneasel will either want very effective entry hazard removers or setters. Capable entry hazard removers such as Silvally-Fairy and Whimsicott give Sneasel more chances to wallbreak and are better for teams that can bring it in more frequently. Tsareena is an effective Rapid Spin user in some matchups and also a powerful wallbreaker in its own right, capable of wearing down many defensive Pokemon such as Weezing in conjuction with Sneasel. Entry hazard setters such as Ferroseed and Qwilfish make Sneasel more devastating each time it comes in but tend to also allow Stealth Rock on Sneasel's side of the field, limiting its switch-ins. Sweepers and cleaners such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Scrafty also make for good teammates, as they appreciate Sneasel's ability to deal heavy damage to opposing walls.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Toxic may catch walls off guard like Galarian Corsola and Slowpoke, but Piloswine has a hard time giving up one of its Ice-type attacks or Stealth Rock to fit it. Curse can be used to boost Piloswine's Attack stat without locking it into a move but a lack of recovery makes it hard for Piloswine to pull off a sweep.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Piloswine has a hard time breaking through physically defensive walls like Clefairy, Hattrem, Levitate Koffing, and RestTalk Machoke, as they recover past its attacks and outstall it, although they all have to be wary of the Choice Band set.

Tanks: Gurdurr, Tangela, and Marshtomp trade hits well with Piloswine, and Gurdurr also has Defog to combat its Stealth Rock attempts. However, they struggle checking Choice Band Piloswine as effectively.

Revenge Killers: Thwackey and Raboot are some of the best revenge killers to Piloswine. Others like Surf Pikachu and Fraxure may need Piloswine chipped, and must be kept healthy to avoid being KOd by Ice Shard.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Piloswine is a great tank that exerts offensive pressure while being very hard to take down itself. It makes a great Stealth Rock user thanks to its significant bulk and ability to threaten anti-entry hazard Pokemon like Hattrem, Vullaby, and Golbat. High Horsepower is used as Piloswine's primary Ground-type STAB attack in order to hit as hard as possible when under the effects of Grassy Terrain, but Earthquake can be opted for if this is not a concern. Icicle Crash and Icicle Spear are interchangeable Ice-type attacks that threaten Grass- and Flying-type Pokemon like Thwackey, Roselia, and Togetic, although Icicle Crash is usually preferred for its consistent damage output. Ice Shard is weaker than these two, but gives Piloswine access to a decently powerful priority move that does considerable damage to faster Pokemon like Drakloak, Kadabra, and Fraxure, which lets Piloswine keep its offensive presence even if it gets worn down.

Piloswine can easily lose its defensive potential if hit by Knock Off from the likes of Pikachu and Ferroseed. If choosing to stay in against these targets, make sure that either Piloswine can afford to trade hits with them or that chipping them down is essential to the team's win condition. Piloswine should avoid setting up Stealth Rock if the opponent's Hattrem is healthy, as it can prevent Stealth Rock; instead, Piloswine should attack it with High Horsepower or switch into a wallbreaker like Lampent. Pokemon that resist Fighting like Golbat, Koffing, and Clefairy can punish Gurdurr and Machoke for Piloswine.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Piloswine can take advantage of its almost completely unresisted dual STAB attacks to be a devastating wallbreaker with Choice Band. For example, Earthquake can 2HKO common Pokemon like Clefairy, Hattrem, and Ferroseed that might not expect the boosted damage and try and switch in. Ice Shard always OHKOes Gastly as well as offensive Roselia after Stealth Rock damage. Superpower hits opposing Piloswine and Ferroseed very hard, guaranteeing a 2HKO on the former. With full Speed investment, Piloswine can outspeed and revenge kill slower targets like Marshtomp and Hattrem once they have been weakened or lost their Eviolite. High Horsepower can be used instead of Earthquake to avoid being weakened under Grassy Terrain, but the loss in damage does make it harder to secure the KO against bulkier Pokemon like Wartortle.

Piloswine cannot break most walls on its own, and relies on Knock Off support from Mareanie and Clefairy to debilitate bulkier Pokemon like Tangela and Wartortle. On the other hand, if Piloswine loses its Choice Band due to opposing Knock Off users, it will lose its own wallbreaking potential. This should be avoided by having Knock Off switch-ins like Gurdurr and Charjabug; Sticky Web support from Charjabug is also a plus for Piloswine, as it allows Piloswine to outspeed threats such as Fraxure instead of relying on Ice Shard. Stealth Rock users like Palpitoad and Galarian Corsola help provide chip damage on the opposing team so that faster threats like Roselia are put in OHKO range of Ice Shard. Being Choice-locked into Earthquake and Ice Shard can make Piloswine susceptible to being revenge killed by Thwackey and Magmar, respectively. Defensive pivots like Vullaby and Klang can help soften blows from these Pokemon while utilizing U-turn or Volt Switch to help bring Piloswine back in safely. Keeping the field clear for Piloswine with the help of anti-entry hazard Pokemon like Hattrem and Golbat helps it preserve its health for extended wallbreaking.

sets.name: Stealth Rock (Ice)
sets.description:
Piloswine performs the role of a defensive Stealth Rock setter for Ice-type teams. Its decent natural bulk not only allows it to switch into Pokemon like defensive Tyranitar and Life Orb Mimikyu, but it also lets it set up Stealth Rock efficiently. Thanks to its ability in Thick Fat and Eviolite boosting its defenses, it is able to check threatening Fire-type Pokemon like Charizard and Centiskorch for Ice-type teams. As most Fire-type attack users are specially-oriented, Piloswine becomes more useful as a specially defensive Pokemon for Ice teams. With Stealth Rock, Piloswine is able to aid offensive Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan, Cloyster, and Weavile to score easier KOs. Rock Slide allows it to beat the aforementioned Fire-type Pokemon. Ice Shard allows it to deal with Substitute Hydreigon and it can also be used to pick off weakened Pokemon. Maximum Special Defense investment along with its ability in Thick Fat lets it take Fire-type moves for the team, while Maximum HP investment is used to improve its overall bulk.

Galarian Darmanitan is a fantastic wallbreaker that appreciates Stealth Rock support to wear down defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Toxapex for it. It also loves having Piloswine as an option to pivot into with its fast U-turn against a defensive threat. With Flare Blitz, Galarian Darmanitan can beat Steel-type Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Bronzong for Piloswine. Mamoswine is able to utilize an offensive Choice Band set to wallbreak thanks to Piloswine taking up the role of a Stealth Rock setter. Piloswine, however, is susceptible to Knock Off, hence Avalugg acts as a good defensive sponge for it while also acting as a Rapid Spin user for the team. Piloswine's weakness against Water-type Pokemon can be covered by using Water Absorb Lapras with Freeze-Dry, as it can also drastically improve the team's matchup against Water-type teams. Vanilluxe can provide Aurora Veil support to further bolster Piloswine's defensive capabilities.

zu.comments:
Other Options

Toxic allows Piloswine to wear down foes like Cofagrigus, Poliwrath, Pyukumuku, and Wishiwashi. Stone Edge provides coverage against Frosmoth, Articuno, and Rotom-Frost. Superpower can be used to threaten Ferroseed, but it is generally less reliable than Piloswine's other moves.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Poliwrath, Wishiwashi, Pyukumuku, and Cramorant are able to switch into Piloswine and force it out, with Cramorant also removing Stealth Rock. Although they cannot directly switch into Piloswine, offensive Water-types like Basculin and Ludicolo can threaten to KO it.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath pressure Piloswine immensely. Pokemon that carry Fighting-type coverage like Body Press Cofagrigus also threaten Piloswine.

Grass-types: Even though they cannot switch into Piloswine and fear being revenge killed by Ice Shard if weakened, Shiftry and Ferroseed are able to threaten Piloswine; the former forces Piloswine out, while the latter weakens Piloswine with Leech Seed and Knock Off and heavily damages it with Gyro Ball. Tangela is able to tank hits from Piloswine and cripple it with Toxic and Knock Off or KO it with Leaf Storm or Giga Drain.

Residual Damage: Given Piloswine's lack of recovery, residual damage from entry hazards and status can wear it down over the course of the battle.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Piloswine's typing, huge bulk, and Thick Fat let it serve as a Stealth Rock setter that has good matchups against some Stealth Rock setters such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk. Earthquake and Icicle Crash form a formidable STAB combination, hitting relevant targets such as Skuntank, Silvally formes, and Rotom-S. Ice Shard allows Piloswine to revenge kill weakened foes such as Shiftry and Silvally-Ground. Thick Fat lets Piloswine switch into the likes of Rapidash and Aurorus.

Piloswine fits best on bulky offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take hits and consistently set Stealth Rock. Water-types such as Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant are problematic for Piloswine; checks to them such as Ferroseed and Cramorant are appreciated. Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and the aforementioned Poliwrath greatly pressure Piloswine. Partners such as Rotom-S and Qwilfish can alleviate this weakness; the former can provide VoltTurn support, while the latter can wear down problematic foes such as Cofagrigus and Jellicent with Spikes and Toxic Spikes.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Specially defensive Galarian Corsola walls most special attackers like Galarian Mr. Mime and Kadabra, and has a strong Shadow Ball to target them back. These sets may also opt for Calm Mind as a late-game sweeper. More offensive sweeping sets with Calm Mind can try Iron Defense and Weak Armor for a better chance at sweeping, but at the cost of being an ineffective wall. Another attack Galarian Corsola may entertain is Ice Beam, and with Special Attack investement it can check Substitute Rufflet.

Checks and Counters

Stallbreakers: Taunt or Substitute users like Golbat, Electabuzz, Raboot, and Rufflet prevent Galarian Corsola from recovering, and the latter two can then set up on it.

Ghost-types: If Galarian Corsola lacks Shadow Ball, then Ghost-type wallbreakers like Lampent, Gastly, and Drakloak may switch in on it and fire back with strong Ghost attacks.

Knock Off: Despite Galarian Corsola walling Gurdurr and Machoke, it comes at the price of often taking Knock Off. Without its Eviolite, Galarian Corsola becomes much less effective as a wall, and more vulnerable to the Pokemon its meant to check.

Magic Bounce: Hattrem prevents Strength Sap from healing Galarian Corsola, keeping it worn down by any chip damage it takes.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Galarian Corsola is one of the best physically defensive walls in the metagame due to high defensive stats and supportive move pool. Strength Sap helps to both cripple the physical attackers this set is meant to check and provide recovery. The following move varies on team selection; Stealth Rock is a solid choice, since Galarian Corsola's Ghost typing deters spinners like Galarian Mr. Mime. Otherwise, Haze should be used as it allows Galarian Corsola to not be setup fodder against Pokemon like Wartortle and Duosion. Whirlpool traps targets that Galarian Corsola can outstall and remove such as Piloswine, Klang, and Gurdurr.

Galarian Corsola fits on balance teams that appreciate its ability to blanket check many physical attackers and set Stealth Rock reliably. Due to its situational recovery and vulnerability to all entry hazards, Galarian Corsola works well with hazard control like Hattrem, Golbat, and Vullaby, with the latter two having particularly good defensive synergy with Galarian Corsola. Specially defensive Steel-types like Klang and Ferroseed form a defensive core and switch into Toxic for Galarian Corsola; Ferroseed also provides Spikes for hazard stacking. RestTalk Machoke, Clefairy, and Galarian Linoone help patch up Galarian Corsola's weakness to Dark- and Ghost-type attacks.

sets.name: Defensive Wall (Ghost)
sets.description:
Galarian Corsola is a physically defensive wall whose primary purpose on Ghost teams is to set up Stealth Rock and neuter physical attackers with a combination of Will-O-Wisp and Strength Sap, which also is its form of recovery. Night Shade prevents Galarian Corsola from becoming Taunt bait and enables it to chip down foes. Its EVs and Eviolite allow it to be as physically bulky as possible, allowing it to take on threats such as Gyarados. Cursed Body can make Galarian Corsola more difficult to handle, as it can disable coverage to attack it, making it harder to KO.

Jellicent and Sableye appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to form a strong defensive core with them and whittle down foes for offensive teammates. Jellicent can switch into Water-type attacks for it such as Lapras's Hydro Pump, while Sableye can cripple setup sweepers with Prankster Taunt as well as shut down a boosted Gyarados with Will-O-Wisp. All the offensive Pokemon on Ghost teams appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to set up Stealth Rock as it makes it easier to break through opposing Pokemon. In return, Galarian Corsola specifically appreciates Mimikyu's ability to take on Dark-type Pokemon that threaten it such as Hydreigon. Thanks to its ability to set Spikes, Froslass forms a good entry hazard stacking core with Galarian Corsola.

sets.name: Stall
sets.description:
Rest is used to recover HP after boosting and in order to remove status. It also is Galarian Corsola's primary tool for PP stalling. Amnesia is used to defend against special attackers lacking boosting moves like Kyurem and Weakness Policy Aegislash. Strength Sap doubles as both a recovery move and an Attack-lowering move, used to beat Pokemon like Dracovish, Choice item Excadrill, and Galarian Darmanitan. It should be used constantly against non-Trick Choice item Pokemon in order to heal off damage and fish for Cursed Body activations or stall until they can no longer deal significant damage. Night Shade is useful against Trick users, notably Rotom-H without much HP investment, which can be 3HKOed. It also is used to end a battle quickly, in order to avoid potential critical hits or secondary effects that stall often falls prey to. Will-O-Wisp can be used to shut down setup Pokemon like Crustle. Spite can be run in order to PP stall opposing PP stall Pokemon, like Meowstic and opposing non-Spite Galarian Corsola. The Defense investment and a Bold nature let Galarian Corsola take a Choice Band-boosted Fishious Rend from Adamant Dracovish, allowing Galarian Corsola to heal back up with Strength Sap. The rest of the EVs are dumped into Special Defense, which helps with rolls against Pokemon like Weakness Policy Aegislash. Galarian Corsola has many other benchmarks for its bulk: maximum HP and Defense maximizes Galarian Corsola's chance to beat Adamant Choice Band Dracozolt and rare four attacks Alolan Marowak. 252 HP and 148 Defense with a Bold nature can be run for Jolly Choice Band Dracozolt, while improving the Aegislash matchup further. 252 HP and 124 Special Defense is exactly what is needed to beat Aegislash, while 252 HP and 104 Special Defense with a Calm nature guarantees Galarian Corsola beats Dragapult. Generally, Galarian Corsola should set up with the respective defensive stat, heal off damage with Strength Sap or Rest, and then use Night Shade or Will-O-Wisp until the foe falls.

Galarian Corsola struggles against Taunt users with significant damage output, like Life Orb Zeraora, and Taunt users with recovery, like Corviknight and Mandibuzz. Therefore, Taunt users like Whimsicott and Chople Berry Terrakion that can beat them serve as great partners. In return, Galarian Corsola can handle hyper offensive threats such as Galarian Darmanitan, Sawk, and Choice Item Excadrill. Dark-types, particularly Bisharp, non-Choice Scarf Hydreigon, Incineroar, and Mandibuzz are also particularly threatening against Galarian Corsola, as they can hit it super effectively and often carry Knock Off, Taunt, or setup options. To aid against then, Pokemon like Choice Band Crustle, Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, and Primarina can all be used to beat the metagame's relevant Dark-types. Galarian Corsola can beat back threats like Arcanine and opposing Primarina in return. Lastly, certain Trick users like Gardevoir, Malamar, and heavily HP-invested Rotom-W can present a problem for Galarian Corsola, so Pokemon that do not mind being Tricked and can avoid the move altogether, like Excadrill and Whimsicott, can be good partners. In return, Galarian Corsola can handle Pokemon like Steelix, Galarian Darmanitan, and Choice item Haxorus for them.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Haze can be run in order to discourage setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Mega Latias from setting up on Galarian Corsola with ease. However, it is extremely hard to use over other useful moves like Will-O-Wisp or Strength Sap.

Checks and Counters

Ghost

Super Effective Coverage: Dark- and Ghost-types such as Hydreigon, Gengar, and Aegislash threaten Galarian Corsola by heavily damaging it with their super effective moves.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Bulk Up Zarude, Gliscor, and Kommo-o completely shut down Galarian Corsola by disabling its status moves and denying recovery, forcing it out or making it forced to use Night Shade.

Magic Bounce: Magic Bounce users such as Mega Diancie, Mega Sableye, and Hatterene shut down Galarian Corsola by reflecting its status moves, preventing it from recovering with Strength Sap or crippling foes with Will-O-Wisp.

Powerful Wallbreakers: While Galarian Corsola's bulk is impressive, it is nailed by very powerful wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Kyurem and Mega Charizard Y.

Knock Off: Knock Off users such as Zeraora, Pelipper, and Mamoswine can threaten Galarian Corsola by removing its Eviolite, making it significantly easier to deal with.

Poison: Toxic from Pokemon such as Zapdos, Celesteela, and Gastrodon can significantly wear down Galarian Corsola during a match, limiting its ability to check foes consistently.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ghost)
sets.description:
Galarian Corsola serves as one of Ghost's primary walls due to its excellent Eviolite-boosted bulk and great utility moves in Night Shade, Will-O-Wisp, and Strength Sap, letting it handle threatening physical attackers such as Excadrill, Mega Lopunny, and Garchomp. Additionally, it compresses the role of a valuable entry hazard setter with Stealth Rock. Night Shade prevents Galarian Corsola from being completely passive, breaking Substitute from foes like Zapdos and Calm Mind Keldeo while wearing down foes like Excadrill and Garchomp much more quickly. Will-O-Wisp inflicts burns on physical attackers like Mega Swampert, Dragonite, and Mega Aerodactyl, making it much easier to deal with them. Strength Sap also cripples the aforementioned physical attackers while providing Galarian Corsola with a source of recovery. Cursed Body can be potentially useful in order to disable strong attacks that may defeat Galarian Corsola. Maximum HP and Defense investment with a Bold nature is needed in order to handle the likes of Choice Band Excadrill, Galarian Darmanitan, and Terrakion better. Galarian Corsola is extremely vulnerable to Knock Off, so it should be wary of switching into users that carry it like Zeraora, Mega Gallade, and Landorus-T.

All teammates appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to take on dangerous physical attackers while setting Stealth Rock. Mega Sableye forms a great defensive core with Galarian Corsola, as it provides a useful Dark neutrality, absorbs Knock Off, and prevents entry hazards like Spikes and Toxic Spikes from being set with Magic Bounce. Additionally, it deals with foes like Nidoking, Blacephalon, and SubToxic Aegislash.
