Ditto patches Blissey's general vulnerability to setup sweepers like Dragonite and Cloyster by KOing them after it gets brought into the field via Teleport. It also helps Blissey massively against walls that beat it one-on-one like Celesteela and Toxic Toxapex. Mega Lopunny can threaten Ghost-types like Mega Sableye with its access to Scrappy, and Mega Pidgeot beats most Fighting-types that threaten Blissey such as Mega Gallade. Both Mega Pokemon can also form a pivoting core with Blissey due to their fast U-turns and moves to threaten Steel-types like Ferrothorn. Wallbreakers like Diggersby and Heliolisk all appreciate Blissey bringing them safely into the field with Teleport and weakening their targets with its Stealth Rock or Toxic support. In the same vein, Porygon-Z can more easily pull off a sweep with Blissey's aforementioned perks.

ru.overview: Raikou is an amazing pivot and sweeper in the RU tier, being one of the fastest Pokemon and having great power and coverage. It can pivot easily with Volt Switch while pressuring many Electric-immune Pokemon that may try to block it. Its decent bulk lets it take some hits to offensively check foes or set up more easily. Its typing and movepool also make it a good offensive check to most Flying- and Water-types as well as some Electric-types, including Togekiss, Suicune, Milotic, and Xurkitree. Raikou has to compete with other Electric-type Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Toxtricity as both a pivot and a wallbreaker, however. It has no moves to hit Seismitoad and Gastrodon, and it has a hard time breaking through some Electric-resistant Pokemon such as Roserade and Dragalge. It also struggles to beat bulky special walls such as Umbreon and Registeel, and it lacks the power to KO most threats without boosts or some prior damage.
ru.comments:
Other Options

Extrasensory can be used to hit Poison-types that wall Raikou otherwise, such as Dragalge, Roserade, Toxtricity, and Vileplume, and it does more damage to Fighting-types like Mienshao and Heracross. Raikou can use Choice Specs or Choice Scarf to act more as a wallbreaker or a revenge killer; however, Heavy-Duty Boots is generally better, as it allows Raikou to switch its moves and keep itself healthy more easily throughout the match. Raikou can be used on rain teams alongside Politoed as a good Electric-type check, and it can use Thunder as its main STAB move and Weather Ball over Scald on these teams.

Checks and Counters

Seismitoad and Gastrodon: Raikou doesn't have any coverage to threaten Water / Ground types such as Seismitoad and Gastrodon, although they have to be careful with Toxic, especially Seismitoad, as it lacks any form of reliable recovery.

Special Walls: Special walls such as Umbreon, Porygon2, and Registeel don't fear much from Raikou, as they take little damage from its moves, but they have to be careful of Volt Switch constantly chipping them throughout the match. Porygon2 is also susceptible to Toxic and can be used as setup fodder by Calm Mind + Substitute Raikou.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types such as Regidrago and Dragalge tank Raikou's attacks easily and can deal a lot of damage in return with their STAB moves, though Dragalge has to be careful of potential Extrasensory.

Poison-types: Some Poison-types, such as Vileplume and Roserade, take little damage from Raikou, as they have good Special Defense, resist most of its coverage, and are immune to Toxic. Toxtricity also resists most of Raikou's attacks, and it has sound moves to bypass a potential Substitute, but it takes much more damage from Raikou due to its mediocre defensive stats. The uncommon Extrasensory Raikou can do more damage to them.

Faster Revenge Killers: Despite Raikou's high Speed and overall good bulk, some revenge killers can outspeed and beat it. Choice Scarf Darmanitan and Choice Scarf Tyrantrum can OHKO Raikou, whereas Choice Scarf Mienshao and Choice Scarf Heracross can OHKO it after little damage. They have to be careful with Substitute, although Mienshao and Darmanitan can use U-turn to break it. Noivern with Draco Meteor can revenge kill a weakened Raikou, even through Substitute thanks to Infiltrator, and it can take a hit from Raikou if needed.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Volt Switch is used to pivot, whereas Thunderbolt is used when Raikou needs more damage. Aura Sphere does more damage to most Steel-types while also 2HKOing Zarude and KOing Tyrantrum after some damage. Toxic punishes Electric immunities like Gastrodon and Seismitoad. Scald can be used over Toxic to hit some Ground- and Fire-types, most notably 2HKOing Rhyperior and Alolan Marowak. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Raikou to pivot as much as possible. This set pairs well with Pokemon that can force out special walls that often switch into Raikou such as Registeel, Porygon2, and Umbreon. Some examples are Heracross, Mienshao, and Cobalion. Other physical wallbreakers like Zarude and Darmanitan can also help pressure Raikou's switch-ins. Noivern can form a great VoltTurn core with Raikou on offensive teams, as the pair provides some defensive utility and counterplay to faster threats, with Noivern also pressuring some of Raikou's best checks in Seismitoad, Roserade, and Dragalge. Klefki, Heracross, and Roserade can use Spikes to help Raikou weaken foes through pivoting, and Raikou can pressure most entry hazard control options in return.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Aura Sphere hits Dark-, Normal-, and Steel-types like Zarude, Umbreon, Porygon2, and Stakataka. Scald hits Alolan Marowak and Rhyperior, which easily stop Raikou otherwise. Substitute lets Raikou punish Pokemon that can't do much against it, especially after boosts, such as Porygon2, Milotic, and Togekiss, letting it find more setup opportunities or better pressure opposing teams. Leftovers gives Raikou passive recovery, allowing it to set up more easily after taking damage or using Substitute. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used with three attacks to give Raikou an easier time acting as a wallbreaker and revenge killer throughout the match. Raikou can potentially stall out attacking moves with Pressure, especially if using Substitute. This set goes well with other special wallbreakers, such as Starmie and Choice Specs Sylveon, which can help Raikou pressure and weaken bulkier special walls such as Registeel and Umbreon. Other wallbreakers such as Heracross and Mienshao can pressure Raikou's checks; in return, Raikou can check bulkier Flying- and Water-types that give them trouble. Spikes support from the likes of Roserade, Klefki, and Heracross helps Raikou weaken its checks. Grass-types such as Zarude and the aforementioned Roserade can help deal with Seismitoad and Gastrodon, which are some of the best checks to this set.

uu.overview: With its solid Special Attack, a Speed stat that outpaces nearly the entire metagame, and good special bulk, Raikou is able to make a name for itself as a solid offensive pivot that can check tier staples like Lycanroc-D, Thundurus, and Keldeo. Access to Aura Sphere and Scald along with its STAB Thunderbolt gives Raikou near-perfect coverage against the entire metagame. This coverage, along with its stats and access to Volt Switch, makes Raikou a solid choice for an offensive pivot. Raikou struggles to deal with defensive staples, however, notably Amoonguss and Chansey. It also lacks a form of reliable recovery, which forces it to function mainly as a revenge killer and makes it overly reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots. Raikou also faces strong competition as a fast Electric-type by Thundurus, which has stronger coverage moves, can use U-turn as a pivoting move to prevent being blocked by Ground-types, and can use Knock Off to cripple Pokemon like Assault Vest Tangrowth that Raikou greatly struggles with, though it does have worse special bulk and a worse Speed tier than Raikou. Raikou's subpar physical bulk means that it is easily threatened by several physical attackers it cannot OHKO, like Krookodile and Mamoswine.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Substitute and Calm Mind can be used to give Raikou some extra breaking power with either Aura Sphere or Scald, preferably the latter to hit Zarude while still being to hit Rhyperior, as the coverage move, but in a metagame infested with Assault Vest Tangrowth, it is very hard to make this set work.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Tangrowth only takes neutral damage from Aura Sphere, and can take those well due to commonly running Assault Vest. Amoonguss resists all of Raikou's coverage moves, walling it with ease. Zarude can easily wall most of Raikou's attacks and, if holding a Choice Scarf, easily pivot out on it with U-Turn, though it does have to watch out for Aura Sphere. The former two Pokemon also have Regenerator, which means that they are not punished as hard by Raikou's Volt Switch.

Ground-types: Choice Scarf Krookodile, Choice Scarf Diggersby, and Zygarde-10% can all outspeed or Speed tie Raikou and use their super effective moves to OHKO it. Rhyperior can also serve as a major threat and can scare Raikou out if its HP is high enough; however, it does have to be extremely wary of Scald. Gastrodon and Seismitoad are able to completely wall Raikou with ease, though they do fear Toxic.

Kommo-o: Kommo-o either resists or is immune to all of Raikou's attacking moves and can easily turn it into setup fodder if it is running a Clangorous Soul set, although physical and mixed sets do have to worry about being burned by Scald. It also has no reliable recovery, and thus gets worn down easily by multiple Volt Switches as well as Toxic.

Specially Defensive Walls: Chansey's enormous special bulk allows it to wall Raikou, even if it has Aura Sphere. However, Chansey does not like switching into Volt Switch, especially when hazards are up. Assault Vest Reuniclus and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can also sponge Raikou's attacks easily, though the former does have to watch out for Toxic.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Thunderbolt is Raikou's main method of pressuring Pokemon like Thundurus and Aegislash. Volt Switch turns Raikou into a fast offensive pivot, allowing it to make progress and bring its teammates onto the field. Aura Sphere is especially useful, as it allows Raikou to hit Zarude, which completely walls it otherwise. Scald allows Raikou to hit Nidoking, another Pokemon that completely walls it otherwise. It can also be used to hit Rhyperior for more damage and spread status to checks like Tangrowth, and it is Raikou's best move against Thundurus-T. Toxic allows Raikou to cripple switch-ins like Tangrowth and Kommo-o that resist both Thunderbolt and Scald, as well as crippling Rhyperior in the absence of Scald. Heavy-Duty Boots prevent Raikou from taking entry hazard damage, increasing its pivoting capabilities.

This Raikou set works best on VoltTurn and bulky offense teams that appreciate Raikou's high Speed tier and its ability to check Thundurus and Lycanroc-D. Flying-types like Salamence, Noivern, and Moltres are excellent partners for this set. Powerful wallbreakers, like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Mamoswine, appreciate Raikou bringing them in safely against its checks, such as Chansey and Amoonguss, which they can then pressure. Keldeo is an especially good partner for Raikou, as together they can overwhelm their shared checks, such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Pokemon that can pivot into Ground-types, particularly Rhyperior, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon, are greatly appreciated, especially if Raikou is not running Scald. Grass-types, such as Zarude and Tangrowth, are especially good at dealing with these Pokemon. Raikou greatly appreciates entry hazard support from Pokemon like Kommo-o, which allows it to wear down its checks like Tangrowth in combination with Volt Switch.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Raikou's great Speed stat and shockingly good coverage make it a good choice for Calm Mind sweeping.

  • Substitute pairs very well with Pressure for PP stalling, punishes more flimsy checks, and also protects Raikou from status.

  • Rest with Chesto Berry is a reasonable alternative for giving Raikou more chances to set up Calm Mind.

  • Volt Switch lets Raikou function as a pivot when needed. Extrasensory is mainly for hitting Naganadel as hard as possible.

  • Shadow Ball does good damage to Dragapult, and Aura Sphere can be used if your team has issues with Ferrothorn.

Items

  • Leftovers pairs the best with Calm Mind and Substitute.

  • Life Orb turns Raikou into a more immediate sweeper, and works especially well when Raikou Dynamaxes.

  • Always hold Chesto Berry when using Rest, as Raikou can't afford spending time asleep.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Raikou's ability to pivot with Volt Switch, combined with its good Speed stat and coverage, make Choice Specs a reasonable option for it.

  • Extrasensory is Raikou's best attack against Naganadel, while Shadow Ball hits Dragapult hard. Aura Sphere lets Raikou deal a good amount of damage to Ferrothorn, who otherwise walls Raikou.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Entei is a strong wallbreaker that can also act as a good revenge killer and a decent late-game cleaner thanks to its strong priority move. Sacred Fire is Entei's best STAB move due to its great Base Power, no drawback unlike Flare Blitz, and especially high burn chance. Extreme Speed allows Entei to revenge kill weakened faster threats such as Raikou, Starmie, and Sharpedo. Stone Edge deals heavy damage to Fire-types such as Chandelure, Incineroar, and Volcanion, which take Entei's STAB moves well. It is also Entei's best move for Water-types and OHKOes Noivern. The slightly higher Base Power of Flare Blitz allows Entei to OHKO Registeel and Raikou as well as consistently 2HKO Reuniclus and specially defensive Porygon2. Stomping Tantrum can be used over Flare Blitz to 2HKO Dragalge, Tyrantrum, and Diancie as well as hitting Rhyperior for more damage. A Jolly nature is necessary to outspeed Obstagoon, Darmanitan, Indeedee, and Mimikyu. Inner Focus prevents Incineroar from lowering Entei's Attack stat with Intimidate.

Entei's best counters are bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad. As a result, a strong Grass-type or Electric-type like Dhelmise, Roserade, Toxtricity, or Xurkitree is extremely important as a teammate. These four examples are also able to threaten or wear down bulky Rock-types like Diancie and Gigalith, which are huge threats to Entei too, especially if Entei lacks Stomping Tantrum. In return, Entei can threaten their counters such as Registeel for Roserade's case or Crobat for Dhelmise. A Fighting-type such as Cobalion or Mienshao can help Entei with bulky Rock-types as well as Curse Snorlax. These two can also bring Entei safely on the field via U-Turn or Volt Switch. In general, Entei appreciates VoltTurn support a lot. Entei is easily revenge killed by other Pokemon once it's locked into a move, so a defensive backbone provided by bulky Pokémon like Seismitoad, Stakataka, and Assault Vest Reuniclus is helpful. An entry hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, and Starmie is crucial due to Entei's weakness to Stealth Rock. Speaking of hazards, Entei appreciates Spikes or Toxic Spikes setters such as Roserade, Golisopod, Galarian Weezing and Dragalge alongside the usual Stealth Rock, because they support Entei in wearing down its counters as well as general wallbreaking. Lastly, although Entei is a decent late-game cleaner due to its strong Extreme Speed, a more reliable one like Choice Scarf Heracross, Calm Mind Raikou, or Shift Gear Toxtricity is a solid partner too.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Entei is a good supporting Pokemon that cannot flinch or be weakened by opposing Intimidate due to its ability Inner Focus.

  • Sacred Fire is a strong STAB move with 50% burn chance that can heavily cripple physical attackers, such as Metagross and Dragapult, by halving their Attack.

  • Extreme Speed is a strong priority move that can finish off weakened foes such as Focus Sash Regieleki and Whimsicott.

  • Snarl is useful to soften damage taken by opposing special threats such as Venusaur, Tapu Fini, and Galarian Moltres.

  • Bulldoze can provide speed control and trigger the Weakness Policy of Entei's allies, and it is great combined with Metagross and its ability Clear Body that prevents its Speed from dropping.

  • Stone Edge is a useful coverage option that hits Flying-types such as Zapdos and Charizard while also being helpful to hit Incineroar.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Silk Scarf boosts the power of Extreme Speed and prevents Entei from being Choice locked. Flare Blitz has more power than Sacred Fire and has perfect accuracy, but the recoil and lower burn chance make it a more risky option. Double-Edge can be used for immediate power, although the recoil is a downside that reduces Entei's already poor longevity. Stomping Tantrum is an option, either as a coverage move or a STAB attack to provide a Normal / Ground typing, that allows Entei to hit checks with Flash Fire such as Heatran, although this option is significantly weaker than Sacred Fire. Facade is a stronger option than Double-Edge if Entei is statused, but it otherwise lacks immediate power.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Slowbro, Mew, Galarian Slowking, and Toxapex are the most widespread check to Entei, as they resist Entei's strongest STAB attack, comfortably tank Extreme Speed, and threaten to KO back.

Salamence: Despite Entei's Intimidate immunity, Salamence is still a solid check to it with Dragon / Ghost and Water / Ground typings; however, Entei's Howl sets can be problematic for Dragon / Ghost Salamence.

Hippowdon: Rock-type Hippowdon is one of the most reliable switch-ins to Entei in the metagame, although it doesn't appreciate being inflicted with status through Sacred Fire and especially Toxic.

Flash Fire Steel-types: Flash Fire users such as Heatran and Coalossal are solid check to Entei thanks to their resistance to Normal and immunity to Fire-type attacks. These two threats typically run a Ground / Steel typing or coverage moves to KO Entei.

sets.name: Extreme Speed
sets.description:
Entei is a powerful attacker that utilizes STAB Extreme Speed to threaten a large portion of offensive Pokemon. Sacred Fire is Entei's secondary STAB attack and allows it to hit Steel-types such as Mew, Reuniclus, and Magearna. Additionally, Sacred Fire's high burn chance can hinder switch-ins and deter physical attackers from directly switching in. Crunch helps against Fire-resistant Ghost-types such as Slowbro, Galarian Slowking, and Salamence. Stone Edge is useful coverage that hits Fire-types like Latias, Arcanine, and Volcarona, although its low accuracy can be a hindrance. Alternatively, Toxic can be used as the last slot on Choice Band sets, as it allows Entei to inflict poison on foes such as Slowbro, Mew, and Salamence. Choice Band is prefered for immediate power, although Entei can also run Heavy-Duty Boots in conjunction with Howl to act as a setup sweeper. Inner Focus grants Entei an immunity to Intimidate, allowing it to deal normal damage to Landorus-T and Salamence.

Latios, Tornadus-T, and Hydreigon appreciate Entei's ability to pressure specially defensive walls like Unaware Clefable and Blissey; in return, they are able to pressure physical walls such as Mew and Toxapex. Spectrier in particular is a great partner to Entei, as it heavily pressures Entei's Ghost-type checks. Rillaboom, Volcarona, and Zarude can utilize their Grass typing to break past bulky Water-types that threaten Entei, particularly Mew, Galarian Slowking, and Salamence. Entei is vulnerable to Stealth Rock, so it is important to have some form of entry hazard control; offensive Defoggers such as Tornadus-T and Landorus-T are some of the best options to fill this role.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Subtitute + Calm Mind Suicune relies on Pressure to wage a war of attrition on a number of Pokemon that can wall it such as Seismitoad, Gastrodon, and Mantine. Calm Mind makes it very hard for special attackers to break Suicune's Substitute and makes Scald much harder to switch into. Substitute provides Suicune with a way to protect itself from status effects, which will cripple sets lacking Rest, and is especially effective for PP stalling Pokemon unable to break its substitute in one hit. Note that Suicune must still be cautious not to switch into status moves like Toxic and Thunder Wave from the likes of Registeel, Togekiss, and Klefki. Protect enables Suicune to scout Choice item users, stall out low PP moves, and gain additional Leftovers recovery. Ice Beam can be used to hit the likes of Zarude and Seismitoad after boosting, which are otherwise major threats. Roar is another option that allows Suicune to phaze out other setup sweepers and rack up entry hazard damage. The EV spread allows Suicune to outpace base 80 Speed Pokemon like Chandelure and Togekiss, while giving it an 81% chance that Seismitoad's Earthquake will not break its Substitute. An alternative spread with maximum Speed will allow Suicune to Speed tie with Heracross, but lowers its chances of its Substitute surviving Seismitoad's Earthquake to about 56%. This set lacks recovery other than Leftovers, so Suicune must be careful not to take Knock Off from Pokemon like Incineroar and Obstagoon without a Substitute up. Suicune must also be careful not to get hit by Trick from the likes of Darmanitan and Gardevoir, as it completely cripples this set.

Suicune's natural bulk and typing make it a great choice for teams looking to check threats like Darmanitan, Alolan Marowak, and Metagross. Suicune's best check is Zarude, which can use Jungle Healing to remove any Scald burns and threaten Suicune with Power Whip. Therefore, it pairs well with Zarude checks like Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, and Togekiss. Cobalion has the added bonus of being an excellent Knock Off absorber thanks to Justified, while Galarian Weezing and Togekiss check other threats to Suicune like certain Guts Fighting-types such as Machamp and Heracross. The aforementioned Guts users, along with Obstagoon, pose a notable threat to Suicune because they are powerful enough to threaten Suicune and unafraid of burns from Scald. Sylveon or Togekiss notably can provide Heal Bell support to remedy this set's weakness to status effects. Suicune is also threatened by Electric-types like Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Raikou, so it should be used alongside Electric-type checks such as Roserade, Assault Vest Reuniclus, Zarude, and Vileplume. Finally, Suicune lacking Roar is unable to beat certain Calm Mind sweepers with Psyshock like Reuniclus and Sigilyph, so it is wise to pair it with checks to them like Obstagoon and Chandelure.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
This Suicune set is capable of sweeping given the right conditions. Rest allows this set to be extremely resilient to status and provides it with reliable recovery. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being passive while using Rest. Roar can be used over Sleep Talk in order to more reliably defeat other Calm Mind sweepers like Reuniclus and rack up entry hazard damage. This set runs enough Speed EVs to outpace Adamant Golurk and Jolly Alolan Marowak, then invests the rest in Defense and HP to be as hard to break through as possible. This, along with reliable recovery in Rest, makes it a much better answer to the likes of Darmanitan, Sharpedo, Cobalion, and Stakataka.

Rest renders this set much less vulnerable to status effects and Knock Off, but it still has one major nemesis in the meta: Zarude. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to easily remove Scald burns, and this set lacks the safety net of Substitute to allow moves like Ice Beam to be effective. Checks to Zarude include Pokemon like Cobalion, Incineroar, Crobat, Noivern, and Togekiss. This set has difficulty setting up Calm Mind against offensive Electric-types like Xurkitree, Raikou, Heliolisk, and Toxtricity, so checks like Roserade, Zarude, Celebi, and Porgyon2 work well with it. Heliolisk has the added danger of Dry Skin causing Water-type moves to heal it, so Suicune must be played particularly carefully against it. If running Roar, Suicune can phaze foes into Spikes provided by Roserade, making it a particularly notable partner.

uu.overview: Despite its average movepool, Suicune is a decent setup sweeper due to its astounding bulk and valuable defensive typing that allow it to check distinguished threats such as Rhyperior. With Pressure, Calm Mind, and its superb bulk, Suicune is able to stall out threatening walls such as Aegislash and Chansey. However, Suicune is held back by the prevalence of Water-resistant Pokemon in the tier such as Keldeo, Mantine, and especially Zarude; Keldeo can simply ignore Suicune's Special Defense boosts with Secret Sword, Suicune struggles to make headway against Gastrodon and Mantine, and Zarude especially can use Jungle Healing to cure itself of burns and Power Whip to deal significant damage. In addition, Suicune lacks reliable recovery, forcing it to rely on Leftovers and Rest in order to regain HP. This makes Suicune susceptible to Knock Off, as losing Leftovers would require Suicune to use Rest more often. In addition, its overreliance on Sleep Talk isn't great either, as you rely on RNG to choose the ideal move. Furthermore, Suicune's weakness to Grass- and Electric-type moves is easily exploitable by the common Power Whip Tangrowth, Zarude, Thundurus, and Thundurus-T.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind is another option, as it allows Suicune to PP stall would-be checks such as Quagsire; Ice Beam can also be used over Protect to prevent it from getting walled by Grass-types. However, it makes Suicune extremely vulnerable to passive damage and status and thus less reliable than CroCune. In addition, it is unable to sponge hits from foes like Rhyperior and Mamoswine, effectively taking up the teamslot of a Water-type without offering very much defensive utility. Toxic can be used to subdue Water-immune Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Mantine, and Seismitoad. However, Suicune often doesn't have room to run Toxic due to it suffering from four-moveslot syndrome. If you were to run Toxic, it would likely replace Sleep Talk on CroCune. A set with Calm Mind / Roar / Scald / Rest allows Suicune to be used as a dedicated phazer and stop foes like Calm Mind + Psyshock Galarian Slowbro from setting up; however, this would waste Suicune's sweeping capabilities and requires entry hazard support to be effective.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Raikou and Thundurus-T can easily severely damage Suicune with Thunderbolt, even after a Calm Mind boost.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude pose an immense threat to Suicune with Horn Leech and Power Whip due to Suicune's lackluster Defense and poor Speed. Heavy-Duty Boots variants of Zarude, in particular, completely counter Suicune, as they can switch into Scald without fear due to Jungle Healing.

Water-immune Pokemon: As Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, it can't damage Water-immune foes such as Mantine and Gastrodon; Suicune struggles with Gastrodon especially, as it can force Suicune to use Rest more often due to Toxic. Despite this, Suicune can still annoy both through Pressure stalling.

Knock Off and Trick Users: Knock Off removes Leftovers, preventing Suicune from regaining passive recovery over the course of a battle and forcing it to use Rest more often. Trick users such as Jirachi and Rotom-W can force Suicune into being Choice-locked.

Haze Users: Moves such as Clear Smog and Haze make it difficult for Suicune to set up for a late-game sweep, as they reset all of Suicune's stat boosts. Notable examples of foes that are able to do this are Gastrodon and Mantine.

sets.name: CroCune
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to become a threatening bulky sweeper. Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, which it can use to spread burns and sweep. Rest allows Suicune to easily recover HP while also curing any status conditions. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being too passive during sleep turns either by letting it continue to boost its special stats or attack foes. Suicune's Speed investment allows it to outspeed Aegislash and Incineroar.

As Suicune is a sweeper, it fits best on balance teams. Pokemon such as Kommo-o and Salamence are essential teammates for Suicune, as they threaten Grass-types like Zarude that pose a tremendous threat to Suicune. Salamence can also provide Defog support for Suicune and its teammates, which they appreciate. Suicune also appreciates Electric-immune teammates such as Nidoqueen and Rhyperior, with the former having the ability to set up Toxic Spikes to help Suicune stall opposing Pokemon like Seismitoad, and the latter providing counterplay to foes such as Nasty Plot Togekiss as well as Stealth Rock support. However, Nidoqueen cannot switch into Thundurus and Thundurus-T after a Nasty Plot boost. Suicune also appreciates teammates like Assault Vest Tangrowth and Amoonguss, which can help check threats like Keldeo; Tangrowth can also help check Thundurus and Thundurus-T, while Amoonguss can provide sleep support with Spore. Pokemon that can sponge Knock Off such as Buzzwole and Heavy-Duty Boots Zarude are also treasured on Suicune's team, as Suicune despises losing its Leftovers. Zarude is especially appreciated, as it can also threaten KOs on Water-resistant foes such as Gastrodon, Milotic, and Seismitoad, which would otherwise completely wall Suicune.

monotype.overview:
Water

Sporting great defensive stats, amazing defensive typing, and decent natural Speed, Suicune is able to wall and stall many Pokemon in Monotype such as Slowking and Tapu Lele. Thanks to its ability in Pressure, Calm Mind, and its natural bulk, Suicune can stall out menacing walls such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Toxapex one-on-one. It is also able to effectively stall out menacing attacks like Tapu Bulu's Horn Leech with Pressure. Due to its lack of reliable recovery, Suicune is extremely vulnerable to entry hazards,status, and other chip damage leaving it unable to reliably switch into attacks. In addition, having Scald as its only offensive move makes it vulnerable to Water-immune Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Mantine. Furthermore, Suicune's heavy reliance on Leftovers makes it extremely vulnerable to Knock Off.
monotype.comments:
Other Options

Water

Rest and Sleep Talk can be used over Protect + Substitute in order to fully recover HP, but that leaves Suicune as setup bait and relies on RNG to select the ideal moves. This set also makes Suicune worse at PP stalling.

Checks and Counters

Water

Water-types: Specially defensive Water-type Pokemon easily wall Scald and force Suicune to switch. Toxapex is particularly a threat due to its access to Haze and reliable recovery.

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can spam Thunderbolt and Rising Voltage against Suicune, but it can threaten them from behind a Substitute, especially if it has used Calm Mind.

Chip Damage: Any chip damage, like from damaging entry hazards and status conditions, reduces Suicune's ability to wall its foes. Toxic Spikes deserves a special mention, as it automatically puts Suicune on a timer.

Grass-types: Grass-types resisting Scald makes them extremely hard to break past. Tapu Bulu deserves a special mention for its ability to set up a Substitute and proceed to use Suicune as setup fodder. Rillaboom's Grassy Glide will not only OHKO Suicune but decimate any Water team. However, both Rillaboom and Tapu Bulu fear Scald burns, making opponents reluctant to switch them in.

Haze Users and Phazing: Moves such as Haze and Whirlwind make it difficult for Suicune to set up for a late-game sweep.

Stallbreakers: Common Taunt users like Cobalion and Keldeo can lock Suicune into Scald, which is only threatening after it has used Calm Mind. Suicune is also vulnerable to Encore, which allows opposing physical attackers to come in and revenge kill it without the risk of being burned by Scald.

Water-immune Pokemon: Due to Scald being its only offensive move, Suicune is unable to damage Water-immune pokemon such as Cradily and Mantine. However, Suicune is able to annoy them through Pressure stalling.

sets.name: Calm Mind + Substitute (Water)
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to both sweep and take on special attackers like Tornadus-T while being able to fire back with Scald; Scald allows Suicune to spread burns, which threaten opposing physical attackers such as Dragonite and Scizor coming in. Protect adds passive recovery via Leftovers and works with Substitute and Pressure to PP stall foes; Protect also allows Suicune to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Rillaboom, Tapu Lele, and Latios. Substitute can also be used to block status conditions such as poison and burn that would nullify Suicune's passive recovery and therefore prevent it from effectively PP stalling. It can create a Substitute for free on Pokemon like defensive Celesteela. Suicune's HP investment allows it to form a Substitute with 101 HP, which doesn't break after one Night Shade or Seismic Toss from Galarian Corsola or Blissey.

Toxapex is able to provide Toxic Spikes support, which helps Suicune stall out its foes. In addition, it can stop setup sweepers like Bisharp with Haze. Swampert provides an Electric immunity to the team and phazes setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Dragapult with Roar. Furthermore, Swampert can set Stealth Rock, which helps Suicune wear down opposing teams. Urshifu-R is good to break past many potential checks to Suicune, such as Water-immune Pokemon such as Cradily, Seismitoad, and Mantine, with Close Combat and Thunder Punch. Tapu Fini provides a Dragon immunity while also setting up Misty Terrain, which prevents Suicune from becoming statused, and threatening Suicune's Dragon-type checks like Latios and Hydreigon. In turn, Suicune can assist Tapu Fini by spreading burns and PP stalling its checks such as Skuntank. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini also helps to weaken foes with Trick and Knock Off. Mantine not only removes hazards like Toxic Spikes, but also offers a Ground immunity. In addition, it provides a key neutrality to Grass Mantine also has Haze to stifle setup Pokemon like Belly Drum Azumarill and Volcarona. Slowking assists Suicune and the team by filling the role of a specially defensive pivot, bringing in Suicune with ease and countering Pokemon it struggles against such as Toxapex and Toxicroak. Teammates with Heal Bell like Vaporeon help with Suicune's vulnerability to status chip damage.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Suicune has some trouble competing with Tapu Fini as a bulky Water-type, but access to tools such as Pressure and a unique movepool give it some niches over the more common Pokemon.

  • Ice Beam is Suicune's most reliable coverage against Dragon-types such as Salamence and Dragapult. Sheer Cold isn't very reliable, but it does give Suicune a 20% chance to OHKO extremely bulky Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Cresselia, and still gives Suicune a powerful Max Hailstorm.

  • Icy Wind deserves mention for giving Suicune a decent option for Speed control.

  • Air Slash gives Suicune access to Max Airstream, a rare tool for bulky Water-types.

  • Substitute saves Suicune from status moves such as Yawn and Leech Seed, letting it set up on certain passive Pokemon such as Swampert and defensive Celesteela.

  • When paired with Chesto Berry, Rest gives Suicune one chance to recover all its health without much consequence, something Tapu Fini is unable to do.

  • Roar lets Suicune win Calm Mind wars against any Pokemon that lacks Taunt, in addition to phazing set-up sweepers in general before they Dynamax.

  • Protect pairs well with Pressure and Leftovers, letting Suicune scout common choice locked Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Regieleki.

Items

  • Leftovers gives Suicune the most sticking power for its more defensive variants, and pairs well with Substitute and Protect.

  • Sitrus Berry gives Suicune a more immediate burst of health, useful for more offensive variants.

  • Chesto Berry lets Suicune wake up from Rest without wasting a turn.

  • Weakness Policy is an unusual option that lets Calm Mind Suicune take advantage of common checks while Dynamaxed, such as Tapu Koko and Regieleki.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 100 Def / 156 Spe with Bold: This EV spreads outspeeds up to Timid Celesteela, while giving Suicune good physical bulk.

  • 100 HP / 252 SpA / 156 Spe with Modest: This is a more offensive take on Suicune that still outspeeds Timid Celesteela.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Bold: This EV spread maximizes Suicune's physical bulk.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest or Timid: This is a far more offensive approach to Suicune, maximizing its power and Speed to take advantage of Max Airstream. Modest gives Suicune some extra fire power and outspeeds up to Timid Tapu Koko after a Max Airstream, while Timid outspeeds Dragapult.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Suicune's great bulk and supporting options allow it to be a great help to its team with moves like Tailwind and Helping Hand. Additionally, it is a nuisance to the opposition with its damage-reducing moves such as Snarl and Scald.

  • Scald is Suicune's Water-type move of choice, as it can severely cripple physical threats such as Glastrier and Metagross with its burn chance.

  • Tailwind allows Suicune's teammates to outspeed fast threats such as Dragapult and Venusaur in sun. Tailwind works especially with Suicune because of its ability Inner Focus, preventing it from getting flinched.

  • Snarl allows Suicune to neuter the damage of special attackers such as Spectrier, Charizard, and Tapu Fini.

  • Ice Beam can hit Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Garchomp for massive damage, as well as Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Whimsicott that Suicune would otherwise struggle with. However, Suicune can also run Helping Hand to increase the damage output of its teammates.

ou.overview: Tyranitar's unique defensive typing and solid bulk under sand allow it to check prominent special attackers in the tier like Dragapult, Heatran, Tornadus-T, and Volcarona. Alternatively, Tyranitar can use its great Attack stat, amazing offensive typing, strong coverage options, and Choice Band to become a fearsome wallbreaker. Sand Stream allows Tyranitar to support sand sweepers like Excadrill, Dracozolt, and Sand Veil Garchomp. However, Tyranitar's typing leaves it vulnerable to common Pokemon in the metagame such as Landorus-T, Rillaboom, and Tapu Lele. Tyranitar's lack of reliable recovery makes it easy to wear down and hurts its ability to check Pokemon repeatedly throughout the game. Additionally, Tyranitar's low Speed leaves it susceptible to faster foes like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Rillaboom. Finally, many Pokemon that Tyranitar is supposed to check like Tornadus-T and Kyurem run super effective coverage moves to overwhelm it.
ou.comments:
Other Options

The specially defensive set can run Ice Beam to serve as a lure to Landorus-T and Garchomp, dealing a ton of damage on the switch, but it has limited uses outside of that, and running Thunder Wave is more useful to permanently cripple Pokemon like Corviknight and Clefable. Chople Berry allows Tyranitar to survive Fighting-type moves from the likes of Tornadus-T and Kyurem and KO them back with its Rock-type STAB move or cripple them with status conditions; however, it is a single-use item and Tyranitar prefers the longevity provided by Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots. A Dragon Dance set with Weakness Policy alongside dual screens support could be used on hyper offense teams, as dual screens allow Tyranitar to survive strong super effective moves like Garchomp's Earthquake and Tapu Lele's Moonblast while setting up. However, it has a mediocre Speed tier even after a boost, and it is outsped by threats like Zeraora, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Kartana, which can revenge kill it easily after some chip damage. The Choice Band set can use an EV spread of 40 HP / 252 Atk / 48 SpD / 168 Spe to withstand a Moonblast from Choice Specs Tapu Lele while still outspeeding Azumarill and Skarmory. Choice Band Tyranitar can also use Superpower to almost OHKO Ferrothorn if rain weakens Fire Punch while also OHKOing Heatran. Nevertheless, Tyranitar doesn't have enough room for it in this set, and it is also forced out by the stat drop, which can give free turns to dangerous threats.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Offensive Ground-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Excadrill threaten to KO Tyranitar with their strong STAB Earthquakes. They can set up Stealth Rock or boost with Swords Dance as Tyranitar is scared out. However, they are worn down quickly if they switch into Choice Band Tyranitar's attacks. Albeit uncommon, physically defensive Hippowdon can take on any Tyranitar set lacking Toxic and set up Stealth Rock or hit it with its STAB Earthquake.

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types like Rillaboom and Kartana can OHKO Tyranitar with their Grass-type STAB moves. However, they dislike being paralyzed by Thunder Wave, and they don't take hits from Choice Band Tyranitar very well. Tangrowth's great bulk coupled with Regenerator allows it to switch into Tyranitar with relative ease. However, it can be crippled by Thunder Wave or Toxic from the specially defensive set. Ferrothorn can switch into the specially defensive set almost unharmed, and it can set Spikes or cripple Tyranitar with Leech Seed. However, it must be wary of Fire Punch from the Choice Band set.

Water-types: Urshifu-R and Barraskewda threaten Tyranitar with their STAB attacks. Also, they can gain momentum with U-turn or Flip Turn. However, they hate being hit with Thunder Wave or Toxic. Bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Swampert can tank a hit and threaten it with a Scald burn or just pivot out.

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Though they must be wary of Thunder Wave, strong Fighting-types like Urshifu-R and Galarian Zapdos force out Tyranitar with their STAB moves, and they can gain momentum with U-turn as Tyranitar switches out. Pokemon that Tyranitar is supposed to check such as Tornadus-T, Kyurem, and Reuniclus usually run Fighting-type coverage to break past it.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Clefable and Tapu Fini can take on the specially defensive set fairly well, and they can chip at Tyranitar's health with their STAB moves. Nevertheless, they can't switch into Choice Band Tyranitar reliably. Offensive Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko can threaten Tyranitar with their STAB moves. None of them can switch into Choice Band attacks though, as they lack the bulk to do so.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Tyranitar's ability to pressure common forms of entry hazard removal such as Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Mandibuzz makes it a great Stealth Rock user. Rock Blast is the STAB move of choice, as it has higher PP and accuracy than Stone Edge. Also, it helps against Substitute users like Kyurem. Earthquake OHKOes Heatran while dealing good damage to Toxapex, Bisharp, and opposing Tyranitar. Thunder Wave cripples defensive switch-ins like Corviknight and Clefable, while Toxic can be used to put Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Hippowdon on a timer. Leftovers provide passive recovery, increasing Tyranitar's longevity; on the other hand, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent Tyranitar from being worn down by entry hazards.

Flying-types like Corviknight and Skarmory can deal with Grass- and Ground-types like Rillaboom, Kartana, Landorus-T, and Garchomp for Tyranitar, and both of them enjoy Tyranitar checking Heatran and Volcarona. Corviknight provides Defog support to prevent Tyranitar from being worn down by entry hazards, while Skarmory can set Spikes to form a hazard-stacking core with great defensive synergy. Nasty Plot Tornadus-T is noteworthy, as it can lure in Zapdos and smack it with a Rock-type Weather Ball under sand, which helps Tyranitar to keep Stealth Rock on the field. Slowbro can deal with Ground-, Water-, and Fighting-types that plague Tyranitar, such as Landorus-T, Barraskewda, and Urshifu-R, and it can bring Tyranitar in safely via Teleport. Similarly, Slowking can check some threats that Tyranitar can't such as Tapu Lele and Clefable while providing a secondary check to Heatran. Both Slowbro and Slowking enjoy Tyranitar's ability to check Dragapult and Volcarona. Moreover, they can bring in sand wallbreakers like Excadrill and especially Dracozolt safely with Teleport, and also both of them can use Future Sight, which is great to wear down opposing Pokemon for said wallbreakers. Tangrowth checks Ground-, Grass-, and Water-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, Rillaboom, and Barraskewda, and it lures in Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Zapdos, which Tyranitar can set Stealth Rock on or cripple with status effects. Sand sweepers like Excadrill, Dracozolt, and Sand Veil Garchomp appreciate Tyranitar's sand and Stealth Rock support to wear down their checks for a late-game sweep. Excadrill also provides Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards and boost its own Speed simultaneously.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Tyranitar's high Attack stat further supported with Choice Band and solid coverage options makes it a great wallbreaker. Additionally, its fantastic special bulk under sand gives it defensive utility and allows it to check certain Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Fire Punch allows Tyranitar to hit Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Kartana and Scizor, threatening them with an OHKO, while also providing another option to 2HKO Corviknight and Skarmory if Stone Edge PPs or its accuracy is a concern. Ice Punch nails Landorus-T and Garchomp on the switch while hitting Hippowdon for decent damage. Heavy Slam can be used to OHKO Clefable.

Choice Band Tyranitar pairs well with pivots like Slowbro, Slowking, Tornadus-T, and Corviknight that can give it free switches to attack. Slowbro checks Ground- and Water-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Urshifu-R, while Slowking can check Tapu Lele and Clefable. Both of them offer Teleport to bring in Tyranitar safely and also provide Future Sight support, which makes Tyranitar far harder to switch into. Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Corviknight can deal with Grass- and Ground-types such as Rillaboom, Kartana, and Landorus-T, and they can bring Tyranitar in safely with U-turn against their own checks such as Zapdos and Heatran. Bulk Up Corviknight is a great teammate, as it appreciates Tyranitar's ability to deal with its checks such as Zapdos, Heatran, and Volcarona for a late-game sweep. Sand sweepers like Excadrill, Dracozolt, and Sand Veil Garchomp enjoy Tyranitar's sand and ability to weaken their checks such as Landorus-T and Corviknight, allowing them to clean late-game. Outside of sand teams, Pokemon such as Zeraora, Swords Dance Scizor, and Swords Dance Landorus-T benefit from Tyranitar weakening opposing Landorus-T and Corviknight, which gives them more opportunities to set up and break through opposing defensive cores or clean late-game.

anythinggoes.comments:
Other Options

Roar is a decent option in place of Foul Play or Thunder Wave, as it wears down foes due to Stealth Rock and sand while providing amazing support against Baton Pass Calyrex-S teams, a strategy with very limited counterplay. Not having a Dark-type STAB move or Thunder Wave does, however, let Zacian-C, Choice Scarf Kyogre, and other wallbreakers switch in far more freely. Crunch can also be used over Foul Play to pressure Eternatus with more damage and potential Defense drops, but it doesn't have the same utility as many other options Tyranitar has access to.

Checks and Counters

Super Effective STAB Attacks: Tyranitar's typing leaves it with multiple weaknesses, so STAB attacks from multiple common Pokemon such as Marshadow, Necrozma-DM, and Xerneas can easily break through its bulk, and they don't take much damage from Tyranitar's attacks back.

Ground-types: Groudon and Zygarde's high natural Defense, Rock resistance, and immunity to Thunder Wave make them stone walls for Tyranitar. Groudon can switch in multiple times and use it to set up Stealth Rock or a more dangerous Swords Dance, and Zygarde-C can likewise freely set up with Dragon Dance or Coil, although Foul Play deters Swords Dance and Dragon Dance.

Water-types: All the major Water-types in the metagame can threaten Tyranitar, as none of them are largely bothered by the attacks it can throw out. Kyogre changes the weather and threatens an OHKO with its offensive sets, and defensive sets can set up on it with Calm Mind and use Rest to negate Thunder Wave, the only potentially troubling attack to Kyogre. Palkia and Dracovish hit it for massive damage if not an OHKO, and Tyranitar has no meaningful way to threaten Gastrodon or Quagsire. Offensive Kyogre, Palkia, and Dracovish must, however, switch in safely due to Thunder Wave.

Zacian-C: Zacian-C has multiple ways to OHKO Tyranitar, and it easily takes advantage of the turns spent clicking Rest or Stealth Rock by forcing Tyranitar out and potentially getting setup turns. It doesn't appreciate being worn down by Foul Play or being paralyzed by Thunder Wave, however, limiting its switch-in opportunities.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
While facing stiff competition from Yveltal, Tyranitar is able to hold its own due to its fantastic sand-boosted special bulk and typing, which let it switch reliably into Calyrex-S, Yveltal lacking Focus Blast, Ho-Oh, Eternatus, and Lunala, while being a valuable entry hazard setter with Stealth Rock. Rock Blast is chosen over other Rock-type STAB moves to beat SubSeed Calyrex-S while still forcing Yveltal out. Foul Play deters some physical attackers such as Zacian-C, Marshadow, and Groudon from switching in or setting up on Tyranitar. Thunder Wave is similarly useful, but it trades the ability to deter Zygarde or Groudon from setting up for the ability to cripple Kyogre and Xerneas. Tyranitar lacks reliable recovery, so it has to use Rest to heal from the continuous attacks it will likely be taking, but this does let it absorb status from the likes of Toxic Ho-Oh, Toxic Eternatus, and Giratina. Leftovers makes Tyranitar need to use Rest less often, but Heavy-Duty Boots is another solid option to increase its longevity. Maximum Special Defense and HP investment gives it the best chances of beating Calyrex-S over a longer game, which is generally its most important role, and is overall helpful for most special attackers that can't immediately threaten it such as Eternatus and specially offensive Yveltal.

Tyranitar's best fit is on balance teams that appreciate its ability to check Calyrex-S, Yveltal, and Eternatus while also providing Stealth Rock support. This Stealth Rock support also gives teammates the moveset freedom to exert more pressure, like Necrozma-DM running more offensive Dragon Dance sets. Tyranitar can be overwhelmed by a number of offensive Pokemon in the metagame such as Zacian-C, Kyogre, Xerneas, and Groudon. Teammates that can deal with these threats such as Necrozma-DM, Eternatus, Ferrothorn, and Lunala, respectively, are all useful. Eternatus can additionally outspeed threats like Marshadow and Zygarde-C and deal with them with Dynamax Cannon while limiting opposing Necrozma-DM due to its good bulk and Pressure. Ferrothorn also switches into Kyogre reliably. Zacian-C can pressure Xerneas and revenge kill offensive Pokemon like weakened Groudon. It also appreciates sand weakening Necrozma-DM's recovery and Stealth Rock powering up Assurance, which makes Necrozma-DM lacking Heavy-Duty Boots struggles to switch into Zacian-C. Quagsire is a more reliable of way of dealing with Zacian-C than Necrozma-DM when paired with Tyranitar, as its recovery is not hindered by sand, but it can only find a place on bulky balance and stall teams. Offensive Excadrill requires Tyranitar as a teammate to work reliably, although Tyranitar does not require it.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Dark)
sets.description:
With its respectable bulk, Tyranitar is the primary Stealth Rock user for Dark-type teams. The combination of Fire Blast and Stone Edge deals with most lead Pokemon, such as Ferrothorn, Xatu, and Ribombee. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple some of the problematic setup sweepers that can easily exploit Tyranitar, such as Hawlucha and Gyarados, on the switch. A specially defensive EV spread along with Sand Stream is used to benefit from Tyranitar's special bulk as much as possible against foes like Charizard and Togekiss. Sand Stream can be also used as a tool to reset opposing weathers, giving Dark-type teams some space in unfavorable matchups such as against rain Water.

Offensive Dark-type Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl and Hydreigon appreciate the presence of Tyranitar, as its Stealth Rock paired with sand allows them to break the opposing team more easily. Hydreigon also benefits heavily from Tyranitar's Thunder Wave, which allows it to outspeed some of the fastest Pokemon in the metagame such as Dragapult and Hawlucha. Sableye and Mandibuzz make good defensive partners to Tyranitar with their capability of handling Bug- and Fighting-type moves. Mandibuzz can also take on Ground-type attacks for Tyranitar.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Dark)
sets.description:
Tyranitar can become a powerful setup sweeper for Dark teams thanks to its access to Dragon Dance and amazing coverage options, allowing it to threaten types such as Fire, Electric, and Poison. Stone Edge breaks past Pokemon such as Blissey, Pelipper, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is mainly used for Toxapex and Steel-types like Aegislash, Heatproof Bronzong, and Klefki. Heavy Slam deals with Fairy-types like Hatterene and Galarian Weezing, while Fire Punch is particularly useful to hit Ferrothorn reliably. Substitute is also an option to set up more easily on weaker Pokemon like Torkoal, Toxapex, and Galarian Weezing, and Leftovers is used along with it to gain passive recovery. Lum Berry prevents Tyranitar from being crippled by the likes of Toxapex, Slowking, and Salazzle. Tyranitar should use its good bulk paired with Sand Stream to set up easily on special attackers like Dragalge and Rotom-H as well as passive Pokemon like Amoonguss. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed Alolan Ninetales and Choice Specs Gengar after a Dragon Dance boost.

Dragon Dance Tyranitar primarily fits on hyper offense teams and can take on threats like Togekiss and Volcarona, which its teammates appreciate. Krookodile is the premier option for setting Stealth Rock while also providing utility in Knock Off and Taunt to dismantle threats like Porygon2, Gastrodon, and Corviknight. Taunt can also prevent entry hazards from slower leads such as Skarmory, which helps Tyranitar stay healthy. Hydreigon can weaken physically defensive Pokemon like Bewear, Corviknight, and Hippowdon for Tyranitar, making it an important wallbreaker. Mandibuzz can use Defog to get rid of hazards like Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes, which would otherwise make Tyranitar easier to revenge kill. It also deals with Fighting- and Ground-types like Choice Scarf Cobalion, Excadrill, and Hawlucha while providing U-turn support. Urshifu-S can threaten Steel teams for Tyranitar with its powerful STAB move combination and pick off faster threats such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Jirachi with Sucker Punch. Grimmsnarl provides useful dual screens for Tyranitar, which allows it to set up on Pokemon like Charizard and Kyurem more safely throughout the match. Drapion and Bisharp are able to help against problematic Fairy-types like Primarina, Grimmsnarl, Galarian Weezing, and Mimikyu so Tyranitar can forego Heavy Slam. Additionally, Drapion can spread status with Toxic Spikes, which is useful for preventing Electric teams from switching in freely.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Dynamax Attacker
sets.description:
• Tyranitar's incredible special bulk, when combined with Dynamax, allows it to check key special threats, such as Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, and Naganadel. It also has a wide variety of coverage options that can be customized to fit your team's needs.

  • Stone Edge is Tyranitar's most powerful Rock-type STAB. Rock Blast is still a good option to consider, however, being able to break through Disguise and Focus Sash, and having much higher PP.

  • Crunch provides good neutral coverage, and allows Tyranitar to deal massive damage to Cresselia and Metagross.

  • Earthquake gives Tyranitar a useful Special Defense boost when Dynamaxed, OHKOes Dynamaxed Nihilego, and is Tyranitar's best option against Naganadel and Toxapex.

  • Ice Punch is Tyranitar's best option against Landorus-T and Garchomp, dealing massive damage to them both.

  • Iron Head gives Tyranitar a key Defense raise with Max Steelspike, giving it a much better shot of defeating Mimikyu.

  • Superpower lets Tyranitar boost its attack while Dynamaxed with Max Knuckle, and deals insane damage to opposing Tyranitar.

  • Fire Punch allows Tyranitar to roast Ferrothorn, and when Dynamaxed, Max Flare is Tyranitar's most powerful attack against Celesteela.

Items

  • Weakness Policy takes advantage of Tyranitar's large amount of weaknesses, letting it win one-on-one against a wide variety of Pokemon once it gets an Attack boost.

  • Assualt Vest enhances Tyranitar's ability to check special attackers, most notably making Tyranitar an excellent check to Naganadel.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This spread maximizes Tyranitar's power and bulk.

  • 244 HP / 52 Atk / 212 Def with Adamant: This EV spread allows +1 Defense Dynamax Tyranitar to avoid a 2HKO from +2 Life Orb Mimikyu's Play Rough, and also lets Dynamax Tyranitar survive Life Orb Cinderace's Max Knuckle.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With Dragon Dance, Tyranitar patches up its poor Speed stat, allowing it to be a competent and bulky sweeper with a variety of coverage options.

  • Stone Edge is Tyranitar's most powerful STAB with good neutral coverage, but Rock Blast should be considered as well for breaking through Disguise and Focus Sash.

  • Iron Head gives Tyranitar the valuable Max Steelspike when Dynamaxed, which is extremely useful against Mimikyu.

  • Earthquake gives Tyranitar the useful Max Quake for boosting its Special Defense while Dynamaxed, and is also Tyranitar's best option against threats such as Nihilego, Naganadel, and Heatran.

  • Crunch offers good netural coverage and lets Tyranitar break past Cresselia, and when combined with Iron Head, lets +1 Dynamax Tyranitar potentially beat Dynamax Metagross via Weakness Policy boosts.

  • Ice Punch is Tyranitar's best option against Landorus-T, and deals plenty of damage to Hippowdon while Dynamaxed as well.

  • Fire Punch, when Dynamaxed, deals more damage to Celesteela and Ferrothorn than any other attack as Max Flare.

Items

  • Weakness Policy pairs well with Max Steelspike and Max Quake, and takes advantage of Tyranitar's great bulk while Dynamaxed.

  • Lum Berry protects Tyranitar against status moves such as Yawn and Will-O-Wisp, potentially surprising more passive way to stop a Tyranitar sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 68 Atk / 188 Spe with Jolly: This allows +1 Tyranitar to outspeed up to Adamant Cinderace and Timid Nihilego, while retaining a lot of bulk.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread maximizes Tyranitar's Speed and bulk.

  • 84 HP / 204 Atk / 28 Def / 4 SpD / 188 Spe with Jolly: This is a far more offensive approach to the set. The EVs allow Tyranitar to survive a Life Orb Play Rough + Shadow Sneak from Mimikyu, and outspeed Timid Nihilego and Adamant Cinderace after a Dragon Dance.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• With great defensive stats and movepool, Tyranitar makes a good choice for a Stealth Rock setter.

  • Rock Tomb may be weak, but its Speed control is invaluable.

  • Foul Play gets around Tyranitar's potential lack of Attack investment, and notably OHKOs +2 offensive Mimikyu.

  • Taunt lets Tyranitar punish passive Pokemon, such as slower Stealth Rock setters and Porygon2.

  • Earthquake is Tyranitar's best attack against foes such as Heatran, Naganadel, and Nihilego.

  • Thunder Wave provides a more extreme Speed control option, that effectively punishes fast set up sweepers such as Naganadel.

Items

  • Leftovers allows Tyranitar to stick around for a long time, and works particularly well with Taunt.

  • Focus Sash lets Tyranitar get away with a more offensive EV spread, and potentially punish foes that are otherwise safe against it with status such as Cinderace and Urshifu-S.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: This spread makes Tyranitar as specially bulky as possible, good for special threats such as Zapdos.

  • 84 HP / 140 Atk / 28 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread is perfect for Focus Sash Tyranitar, maximizing its Speed to take advantage of Speed control, while ensuring that Tyranitar survives Play Rough + Shadow Sneak from Life Orb Mimikyu.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Tyranitar makes an excellent Weakness Policy user thanks to its high Attack and weaknesses to common attacking types like Ground and Steel.

  • Rock Side is a reliable spread move with a respectable damage output. It becomes the base move for Tyranitar's powerful Max Rockfall, easily destroying the likes of Thundurus, Zapdos, and Glastrier.

  • Lash Out is great for punishing opposing Intimidate, as it doubles in power if Tyranitar's stats are lowered. Crunch works just as well if Tyranitar is paired with Intimidate deterrents like Thundurus. In general, teams appreciate Dark-type coverage to threaten Spectrier, Dragapult, and Indeedee-F.

  • Superpower is Tyranitar's preferred filler move, notably allowing it to hit Urshifu-S and opposing Tyranitar for super effective damage while also boosting its Attack with Max Knuckle.

  • Maximum HP investment allows it to consistently beat a variety of common threats including Charizard, Zapdos, and Spectrier.

sets.name: Focus Sash Lead
sets.description:
• Fast Tyranitar is an excellent aggressive lead. It is very effective for spreading paralysis and launching powerful hits early-game.

  • Rock Slide lets Tyranitar hit for consistent spread damage and can potentially land crucial flinches.

  • Jolly Tyranitar is a great Assurance user, as it is often paired with faster teammates like Thundurus and Dracovish, allowing Assurance to hit for double damage. Foul Play is also a strong choice against powerful physical attackers like Landorus-T and Defiant-boosted Thundurus.

  • Thunder Wave can ruin unsuspecting enemy lead Pokemon, which is especially great if it can catch a foe as it Dynamaxes. This opens the door for Tyranitar's teammates to gain momentum and clean up late-game.

  • Taunt works well to shut down attempts to cripple Tyranitar and its partners such as status spreading or Trick Room. Superpower is useful for hitting Kartana and opposing Tyranitar.

  • 252 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature give Tyranitar the best possible chances of crippling its desired target, while maximum Attack investment ensures it can still pack a punch. Focus Sash makes up for the lack of bulk investment.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Tyranitar's great bulk and unique defensive typing let it check a bunch of scary threats such as Yveltal, Ho-Oh, Mega Gengar, Eternatus, and Mewtwo. Pursuit allows Tyranitar to trap Pokemon that it forces out, such as Mega Gengar, Mewtwo, and Choice item variants of Mega Rayquaza, as well as break Lunala's Shadow Shield if it tries to switch out. A Rock-type move is recommended in order to check Yveltal properly and to force out Ho-Oh; Rock Tomb is chosen for its Speed-lowering effect, which neutralizes Max Airstream users like Yveltal, Mewtwo, and Thundurus-T and preserves momentum against faster threats like Zacian-C and Eternatus. Foul Play deals major damage to Zacian-C and offensive Primal Kyogre, deterring them from switching in freely, as well as threats Tyranitar is supposed to check like Mega Gengar, Mewtwo, and, if running Shuca Berry, Mega Rayquaza and Ultra Necrozma. Alternatively, Stealth Rock is a decent option due to Tyranitar's good matchup against common Defoggers like Ho-Oh and Lunala. Rest gives Tyranitar a source of recovery and lets it shrug off status ailments like Toxic poison from Ho-Oh, Eternatus, and Lunala. Roar allows Tyranitar to phaze non-Dynamaxed setup sweepers like Vivillon, prevents Geomancy Xerneas from setting up on it, and racks up entry hazard damage. Leftovers reduces the need for Tyranitar to use Rest by giving it passive recovery, which is helpful because it's very prone to chip damage from entry hazards and status ailments. Alternatively, Tyranitarite is a decent option if none of Tyranitar's teammates are using a Mega Stone, as it gives Tyranitar significantly more bulk and power at the cost of being unable to Dynamax. Chople Berry reduces the damage taken from Fighting-type attacks such as Focus Blast from Mega Gengar and Yveltal. Shuca Berry allows Tyranitar to survive a boosted hit from physical attackers such as Mega Rayquaza, Ultra Necrozma, and Extreme Killer Arceus; this item should be used alongside Foul Play. The EV spread maximizes special bulk for threats such as Yveltal, Mega Gengar, and Eternatus. Shuca Berry can optionally be used with a physically defensive spread to take on the aforementioned physical attackers better.

Tyranitar is a good fit on balanced teams that can accommodate its many weaknesses. Defensive Necrozma-DM is an excellent partner, as it is able to handle Zacian-C and check Xerneas, and it appreciates Tyranitar's ability to deal with Yveltal, Ho-Oh, and Eternatus in return. Note that sand limits Morning Sun's recovery, however. Arceus-Ground is able to check Primal Groudon and Zygarde-C well, while Tyranitar can deal with Ho-Oh and Yveltal. Ferrothorn and Primal Groudon are able to check Primal Kyogre; Ferrothorn in particular provides Spikes support, allowing Tyranitar to rack up more damage on the opposing team with Roar, and can use Knock Off on Ho-Oh, letting Tyranitar pressure said foe with Stealth Rock. Primal Groudon can run Stealth Rock, freeing up a moveslot on Tyranitar. Ditto is a great partner that makes up for Tyranitar's lackluster matchup versus offense, while wallbreakers such as Xerneas, Yveltal, Zacian-C, and Primal Kyogre can help to pressure bulky teams that Tyranitar struggles to dent.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Rock Blast can be used over Rock Slide to break Substitute from Kyurem and Zapdos and prevents PP stalling. Toxic and Protect can be used to spread status and wear down foes such as Porygon2 and Mantine.

Checks and Counters

Dark

Super Effective Attacks: Despite having boosted Special Defense in sand, Tyranitar can easily get overwhelmed by super effective attacks. Fighting-type attacks particularly will take down Tyranitar with ease, thus it is forced to switch out to a teammate such as Mega Sableye.

Status: Tyranitar can easily get worn down by poison, taken advantage of if its paralyzed, or have its Leftovers cancelled out by being burned.

Rock-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Excadrill, Melmetal, and Gastrodon resist Tyranitar's main STAB attacks and force it out.

Physical Walls: Hippowdon, Porygon2, and Mega Venusaur take little damage from Tyranitar's STAB attacks and threaten to cripple or KO it, leaving Tyranitar vulnerable.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Dark)
sets.description:
Tyranitar plays a pivotal role for Dark teams by acting as the primary Stealth Rock setter, helping break Focus Sash and Sturdy for its teammates and being able to tank most special attacks thanks to having a boosted Special Defense in sand. Rock Slide lets it take care of many threats to Dark teams such as Volcarona, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y. Heavy Slam gives Tyranitar the ability to take on Tapu Lele and Hatterene, while Fire Blast hits most Steel-type physical walls such as Ferrothorn, Skarmory, and Mega Scizor that would otherwise wall Tyranitar. Tyranitar can cripple faster foes that don't get OHKOed by Rock Slide with Thunder Wave such as Latios and Dragonite. Leftovers gives Tyranitar some passive recovery that increases its longevity. Maximum HP and Special Defense gives Tyranitar as much special bulk as possible, allowing it to tank almost any unboosted special attack in sand. Sassy nature is preferred if Fire Blast is chosen over Heavy Slam.

All of Tyranitar's teammates appreciate Stealth Rock and Thunder Wave support. Hydreigon especially helps in the Poison and Steel matchups as a Substitute + Nasty Plot sweeper or a faster teammate for an edge in the Dragon matchup. Mega Sableye is a great choice as a Mega Evolution and can act in tandem with Tyranitar, since it is immune to Fighting and can keep entry hazards off your side of the field while spreading burns with Will-O-Wisp. Greninja can be geared to help in any matchup and runs a variety of different sets including Choice Specs, Choice Scarf, Grassium-Z, Icium-Z or Expert Belt. Choice Specs is particularly helpful in the Dragon and Flying matchups, while Grassium-Z is great in the Water and Ground matchups. Icium-Z helps break defensive Celesteela after an Ice Beam, and Extrasensory with Expert Belt can break through Toxapex and Mega Venusaur, which give Tyranitar a lot of trouble. Choice Scarf Greninja can revenge kill opposing Choice Scarf users such as Latios, Latias, and Landorus-T as well as Mega Aerodactyl. Toxic Spikes can be fitted into any of these sets to support entry hazard stacking. Mandibuzz can help check physical setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Mega Scizor, and is also able to clear entry hazards with Defog. Alolan Muk is extremely helpful with taking on pesky Fairy-types and can take advantage of Fairy teams' passive Pokemon such as Klefki to set up with Curse. Zarude is another great teammate that gives an edge in the Water and Ground matchups since it becomes very dangerous after one or two Bulk Ups, and Weavile could be helpful versus Flying with its hard hitting STAB Ice-type attacks. Bisharp is a strong physical attacker that can set up with Swords Dance and provides great priority in Sucker Punch.

ubers.overview: Lugia possesses some of the greatest bulk in the metagame backed up by one of the best defensive abilities in Multiscale. Its access to reliable recovery, a great Speed tier, and an extensive support movepool ensures that it can keep itself healthy with relative ease and effectively check various threats such as Zygarde, Groudon, and Rayquaza. Its walling capabilities, however, are entirely dependent on Multiscale, which makes Lugia very hard to utilize considering it must be kept at full health or else risk being taken down by the multitude of fast and strong wallbreakers in the metagame. Lugia also despises all status ailments and must avoid them at all costs, making cleric support with Lugia important and making it a natural fit on stall teams. While Heavy-Duty Boots is a godsend to rid Lugia of its weakness to Stealth Rock, it also means it lacks passive recovery and can't switch in on certain Pokemon it would otherwise beat, such as Landorus, in fear of Knock Off. Lugia's defensive typing also leaves much to be desired, giving it weaknesses to the extremely common Ghost- and Dark-type attacks. It also cannot deal with the best offensive and defensive threats in the metagame, being completely outclassed by Necrozma-DM and Lunala, both of which share Lugia's Psychic-type but have a much better secondary typing in Steel and Ghost, respectively. On more dedicated stall builds, Giratina is bulkier and can provide more for its team.
ubers.comments:
Other Options

Defog allows Lugia to remove entry hazards so that it can free up a moveslot for another teammate, but since Necrozma-DM, the best Stealth Rock setter in the metagame, doesn't really care about Lugia, it's not advised.

Checks and Counters

Yveltal: Yveltal can often outspeed Lugia and shut it down via Knock Off, Toxic, or Taunt. It doesn't want to switch in on a status move, however.

Ghost-types: Calyrex-S can consistently 2HKO Lugia even through Multiscale, takes little damage from Ice Beam, and can cure itself of status with Aromatherapy. Marshadow can break through Lugia's defenses as well. Giratina can status Lugia with either Will-O-Wisp or Toxic, while Giratina-O can opt for a strong Ghost-type STAB move to deal a ton of damage.

Necrozma-DM: Necrozma-DM can hit through Multiscale thanks to Sunsteel Strike, set up Stealth Rock in front of Lugia without fear of much, remove Lugia's Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, or cripple Lugia with Thunder Wave or the rare Toxic. Offensive variants can set up with Dragon Dance in front of Lugia and chunk it with a boosted attack.

Steel-types:Ferrothorn, Skarmory, and Magearna can come in on Lugia and utilize their utility moves for free, whether that's setting up entry hazards, removing them, or providing cleric support, respectively. The former two can even threaten to status Lugia.

Residual Damage: Multiscale is the only reason Lugia is even remotely viable, so any way to consistently break it effectively cripples Lugia. Tyranitar's Sand Stream or damage from status conditions makes Lugia way less bulky.

sets.name: Great Wall (Defensive)
sets.description:
Roost is Lugia's most important move, ridding it of its Flying typing and thus its pesky weakness to Ice-, Electric-, and Rock-type attacks while also providing reliable recovery. Whirlwind allows Lugia to phaze out foes like Zygarde that are trying to set up. Ice Beam hits Ground- and Dragon-type foes for a considerable amount of damage, OHKOing Rayquaza after Stealth Rock and 3HKOing Zygarde-C while Lugia shrugs off their attacks. Toxic is Lugia's main way of dealing with the majority of the metagame; it should be used liberally against foes that are not Steel- or Poison-type to whittle them down and stall them out with Lugia's fantastic bulk. Thunder Wave is an option to incapacitate wallbreakers that try to switch in on Lugia, such as Calyrex-S and Urshifu-S, or the aforementioned Steel- and Poison-types, like Necrozma-DM and Eternatus. 96 Speed EVs are utilized so that Lugia can outspeed maximum Speed neutral-natured base 90s like Kyogre and Groudon, as well as maximum Speed Necrozma-DM.

Lugia requires heavy team support, as it is extremely passive and is only seen on more stall-oriented builds. A switch-in to Yveltal is paramount, as it outspeeds Lugia and can cripple it with Knock Off, Taunt, or Toxic. Defensive Xerneas and Eternatus are great teammates, able to deal with anything Yveltal throws their way while also acting as consistent answers to Marshadow, a wallbreaker that Lugia cannot deal with. Ghost-types in general are a problem for Lugia, especially Calyrex-S. As such, Yveltal acts as a good answer to them. Lugia struggles against the premier Steel-types of the metagame in Necrozma-DM and Ferrothorn, so teammates that can beat them are appreciated. Physically defensive Eternatus can use Flamethrower to beat them both, shrugging off their hits and PP stalling them with Pressure. Ho-Oh can threaten them with Sacred Fire and can also remove entry hazards for Lugia with Defog if Lugia's Heavy-Duty Boots are removed. It also serves as a switch-in to Calyrex-S and Marshadow, scouting their sets. In return, Lugia can deal with Zygarde and Rayquaza, both of which give Ho-Oh trouble. Cleric support is necessary in case Lugia gets statused, so Blissey and Chansey make perfect teammates, removing status and acting as emergency switch-ins to Ghost-type attacks. Status absorbers such as Rest Zygarde and Giratina also work.

sets.name: Defensive Wall
sets.description:
Owing to Lugia's high natural bulk, decent defensive typing, and invaluable ability in Multiscale, it serves as a potent blanket check and emergency switchin to some of AG's most potent threats, including Mega Rayquaza, Zacian-C, and Ultra Necrozma. Access to valuable support moves such as Whirlwind and Toxic and Thunder Wave allows it to accrue chip damage or cripple the aforementioned threats, allowing them to be more easily handled. Roost is chosen over Recover in order to have a better matchup against Swords Dance Primal Groudon and a paralyzed Zacian-C by negating super effective damage from their coverage moves and Wild Charge. Whirlwind is vital in shutting down setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Primal Groudon, Mega Rayquaza, Zacian-C, Xerneas, and Swords Dance Arceus formes, which may take advantage of Lugia's relative passiveness, while also allowing Lugia to rack up chip damage alongside entry hazards. However, it cannot be relied on to phaze some threats such as Dragon Tail Zygarde-C and Dynamax users. Thunder Wave allows Lugia to outspeed offensive threats and freely use Roost on them in order to have Multiscale up versus their attacks, making them much easier to deal with. In particular, it punishes Zacian-C, Mega Rayquaza, and Eternatus. Toxic allows Lugia to cripple switch-ins such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal while chipping away at offensive Pokemon such as Mega Rayquaza and Primal Groudon.
