A Choice Scarf set allows Mamoswine to outspeed its typical fast checks like Raikou and Lycanroc-D, but this set faces a lot of competition from Diggersby, which also has access to U-turn to pivot out of unfavourable matchups.

Checks and Counters

Buzzwole: Mamoswine struggles to break through bulkier variants of Buzzwole that can stomach multiple Icicle Crashes and recover any lost health with Roost. Buzzwole also threatens to OHKO back with Close Combat or Drain Punch. Offensive variants of Buzzwole do need to be careful though, as Mamoswine could potentially KO it with two Icicle Crashes after Stealth Rock.

Rotom-H and Rotom-W: Both Rotom-W and Rotom-H are immune to Earthquake and resist Ice, making it difficult for Mamoswine to break through them. Additionally, both of these Pokemon can typically force Mamoswine out with STAB attacks or status moves, though they need to be wary of Knock Off on the switch.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: UU has many threats like Keldeo, Gyarados, and Lycanroc-D that are faster than Mamoswine and threaten to KO it with super effective attacks. Mamoswine is also weak to multiple priority attacks, allowing Azumarill and Conkeldurr to KO it after minimal chip.

Residual Damage: Since Mamoswine typically needs Life Orb to be effective, it will get worn down quickly, especially if it has to switch into Stealth Rock or Spikes.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Ice Shard can threaten many faster threats like Galarian Moltres, Thundurus, and Zarude, and it can also OHKO offensive Salamence and Zygarde-10%. Knock Off is used to punish and cripple a switch-in such as Rotom-H or Rotom-W, allowing Mamoswine or another teammate to break past it more easily later. Thick Fat offers better protection against Rotom-H and ensures it can take a Fire Blast from Moltres. Stone Edge can be used alongside Thick Fat to nail the aforementioned Pokemon harder. Oblivious is also an option, as it blocks Intimidate to allow Mamoswine to retain its wallbreaking potential against Pokemon like Salamence and Incineroar. Life Orb is preferred, as it allows Mamoswine to safely 2HKO almost anything in the tier, including Celesteela and Chansey. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed unboosted Galarian Moltres and Timid Volcanion, but the loss in power significantly limits Mamoswine's breaking potential.

After Mamoswine breaks down the enemy team early-game, a cleaner like Gyarados or Nihilego can finish it off for a late-game sweep. A pivot like Thundurus or Rotom-W can lure in Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Amoonguss and then pivot to Mamoswine for a more favorable matchup. Teaming Mamoswine up with a special wallbreaker like Thundurus-T, Keldeo, or Salamence will help the team break past Pokemon like Buzzwole, Rotom-H, and Rotom-W, all of which Mamoswine struggles against. Mamoswine is vulnerable to priority moves from Conkeldurr, Crawdaunt, and Azumarill; Amoonguss and Buzzwole can switch into most of these. Since Mamoswine is slow, it will need a teammate like Thundurus or Starmie to help deal with fast threats like Keldeo and Lycanroc-D.

sets.name: Wallbreaker (Ground)
sets.description:
Mamoswine is an efficient Choice Band wallbreaker with almost unresisted coverage, barring some Rotom formes and Araquanid. Icicle Crash breaks Flying-, Dragon-, and Grass-types for Ground-type teams. Ice Shard lets Mamoswine pick off weakened foes. Superpower deals with Normal- and Ice-type Pokemon. The given spread enhances Mamoswine's offensive presence as much as possible. Thick Fat provides Ground-type teams an offensive Ice-resistant Pokemon.

Since Mamoswine is used best as a wallbreaker, late-game sweepers such as Excadrill and revenge killers such as Dugtrio appreciate Mamoswine as a teammate. Mamoswine doesn't have the best bulk and being Choice-locked lets other offensive Pokemon such as Hawlucha take advantage of it. Hippowdon and Claydol make good teammates for Mamoswine, as Hippowdon can switch into physical attacks while Claydol takes on special attackers. Hippowdon can also set Stealth Rock and Sandstorm to further aid Mamoswine with effective wallbreaking. Claydol can be also used for Rapid Spin to prevent Mamoswine from taking extra damage from entry hazards. Seismitoad makes a good partner, as it can absorb Water-type attacks for Mamoswine.

sets.name: Choice Band (Ice)
sets.description:
Mamoswine has a great Attack stat, average Speed, a Ground typing that makes it a great Electric immunity, and a good movepool that makes it a powerful wallbreaker. Earthquake allows it to hit Poison- and Steel-types such as Toxapex and Bisharp. Ice Shard is a great priority move to get KOs on weakened Pokemon or get some chip damage if Mamoswine is low on health. Superpower makes Mamoswine able to heavily damage Ferrothorn. Mamoswine is a great wallbreaker that can be used at the beginning of the game to pressure common leads such as Ferrothorn and Hippowdon and force switches. Mamoswine is also useful for the endgame to pick up KOs on weakened Pokemon with Ice Shard. However, Mamoswine does not have the best bulk, so it is best to get in Mamoswine on a weak attack, on a predicted switch, or after a teammate has fainted.

Thanks to Mamoswine's Ground typing, it is able to take care of threatening Steel- and Rock-type Pokemon, which its teammates appreciate. Piloswine makes a great partner to set Stealth Rock, which makes it easier for Mamoswine to get KOs. Alolan Ninetales is great for being able to set up Aurora Veil, which helps Mamoswine wallbreak more freely. Choice Scarf Galarian Mr. Mime or Avalugg to help keep hazards from the field for the whole team with Rapid Spin. Cloyster and Kyurem-B loves Mamoswine due to it being able to take down threats such as Ferrothorn and Dragapult before Cloyster or Kyurem-B sets up. However, Mamoswine struggles to take Water-type attacks from Pokemon such as Dracovish and Seismitoad, so Lapras makes a great partner thanks to its Water Absorb and ability to do major damage to them with Freeze-Dry. Mamoswine also forms a good wallbreaking core with Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan against Steel-type teams due to the latter's access to Flare Blitz, Superpower, and Earthquake, ability to bring Mamoswine in safely with U-turn, and ability to provide speed control for the team and outpace threats such as Choice Scarf Excadrill.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Setter
sets.description:
• Mamoswine is an effective early game setter of Stealth Rock with Focus Sash, thanks to its good coverage and access to priority in Ice Shard.

  • Icicle Spear is the prefered Ice-type STAB, since it breaks through Focus Sash and Mimikyu's Disguise.

  • Oblivious blocks the effects of Intimidate and Taunt, making it Mamoswine's best ability.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Mamoswine is one of the most threatening Pokemon in the metagame. Between its sky-high Attack stat, great offensive typing, and immunity to Intimidate because of Oblivious, it can blow massive holes in opposing teams.

  • High Horsepower is the chosen Ground-type STAB move and is used over Earthquake as it doesn't hit Mamoswine's teammates. It hits Fire-types such as Incineroar and Entei, as well as Steel-types such as Heatran and Metagross, which would otherwise resist its Ice-type attacks. High Horsepower also turns into Max Quake if you choose to Dynamax Mamoswine, providing useful Special Defense buffs.

  • Icicle Crash is chosen over Icicle Spear because of its consistency. It hit a variety of Pokemon for super effective damage, such as Zapdos, Landorus-T, and Dragapult.

  • Ice Shard is very useful to pick off fast Focus Sash users such as Whimsicott and Regieleki.

  • Mamoswine can run Life Orb to boost its already massive Attack, but it can also run Focus Sash to survive a hit against Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Venusaur.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Ground

A Jolly nature allows Mamoswine to outspeed offensive Heatran, but it doesn't outspeed anything else significant because Mamoswine can already KO foes like Nidoking with Ice Shard, and it has less breaking power without Adamant. Choice Scarf turns Mamoswine into a decent revenge killer that can outspeed the likes of Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Barraskewda without rain, but it loses a ton of extra damage output without Choice Band, making it more difficult to wallbreak.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive walls such as Mega Slowbro, Skarmory, and Swampert are able to take attacks from Mamoswine and wear it down with Scald, Body Press, or Flip Turn, respectively. However, Swampert's lack of reliable recovery means that it can easily be pressured by Mamoswine's teammates.

Status: Burn significantly reduces Mamoswine's damage output, leaving it unable to function as a wallbreaker. Toxic consistently wears Mamoswine down, making it difficult for it to stay in the field for a long time.

Water-types: Offensive Water-types such as Mega Swampert, Urshifu-R, and Mega Gyarados can outspeed Mamoswine and KO it with their STAB moves. Bulky Water-types such as Tapu Fini, Slowbro, Swampert, and Suicune are able to tank attacks from Mamoswine and 2HKO it with Scald, with Tapu Fini and Suicune outspeeding Mamoswine as well.

Rotom-W: Rotom-W is one of the most consistent checks to Mamoswine, being immune to its Earthquake due to Levitate and resisting its Icicle Crash. Rotom-W is able to either KO Mamoswine with a powerful Hydro Pump or cripple it or another teammate with Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Heracross, Mega Gallade, Terrakion, and Kommo-o after a boost can all outspeed Mamoswine and KO it with their STAB moves.

Revenge Killers: Mamoswine sits at a mediocre Speed tier for an offensive Pokemon, making it outsped and KOed by a myriad of powerful revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Keldeo, Tapu Lele, Blacephalon, and Rillaboom due to Grassy Glide.

sets.name: Choice Band (Ground)
sets.description:
Mamoswine's good Attack stat and daunting STAB combination make it an excellent wallbreaker that can help against types like Flying and Dragon, which are otherwise poor matchups for Ground teams. Icicle Crash allows it to get rid of Mandibuzz, Tapu Bulu, and Dragonite. Ice Shard provides useful priority for fast threats like Landorus, Hydreigon, Latias, and Latios, especially if they are weakened. Superpower is a useful move for targeting Ferrothorn and Porygon2; however, Knock Off gets rid of items like Eviolite, Leftovers, and Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Galarian Corsola, Porygon2, Celesteela, and Blissey. An Adamant nature paired with a Choice Band maximizes Mamoswine's damage output, letting it pick off weakened threats with Ice Shard better and have a better chance of KOing a weakened Celesteela or Corviknight. Thick Fat is the preferred ability to give Ground teams a useful resistance to Ice-type attacks. Generally, Mamoswine should be used to wallbreak types like Flying, Poison, and Dragon early-game, and it can clean weakened teams with Ice Shard late-game.

Hippowdon is a great partner, as it tanks hits for Mamoswine due to its good bulk, can phaze out threatening foes like Mega Scizor and Mega Gallade with Whirlwind, and provide Stealth Rock and Sand Stream support, which gives Mamoswine an easier time sweeping late-game by racking chip damage on foes. Landorus is an essential wallbreaker, as it can not only break through physically defensive foes like Slowbro and Mega Sableye for Mamoswine, but utilize Gravity in order to make Mamoswine's Earthquake useful against threats like Celesteela, Rotom-W, and Corviknight. Gastrodon and Seismitoad can absorb Water-type attacks for Mamoswine; Gastrodon has access to reliable recovery, and Seismitoad can outspeed and threaten Azumarill as well as use its higher physical bulk to take attacks from Pokemon like Barraskewda more easily. Excadrill is a dangerous sweeper under Hippowdon's sand due to Sand Rush, which allows it to outspeed fast threats like Mega Lopunny and Terrakion for Mamoswine, and it provides Rapid Spin support while breaking past physically defensive foes like Mega Sableye, Porygon2, and Avalugg with Steelium Z and Swords Dance. Garchomp can break through most walls due to Swords Dance and Dragonium Z while weakening Celesteela with Fire Fang and providing a useful neutrality to Water- and Grass-type attacks. Mega Garchomp can destroy foes like Celesteela and Ferrothorn with Fire Blast while living an Aqua Jet from +6 Azumarill and threatening it back with a Sand Force-boosted Earthquake. Mega Steelix is a powerful bulky sweeper with Curse that can also live a hit from +6 Azumarill's Aqua Jet and threaten it back with Heavy Slam, and it also threatens other foes like Tapu Bulu and Rillaboom.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Although outclassed in power and defensive utility by Toxtricity, Porygon-Z's Speed tier and powerful Tri Attack give it a small niche in RU as a revenge killer and stallbreaker. Shadow Ball hits Ghost-types and lets Porygon-Z consistently revenge kill Mimikyu, but Adaptability-boosted Tri Attack hits just as hard as Shadow Ball against most Steel- and Rock-types. Trick cripples Pokemon like Registeel and Steelix if Porygon-Z's Choice Scarf is no longer needed, and allows it to set up with Nasty Plot to break through slower teams. Porygon-Z should be paired with Pokemon like Necrozma, Darmanitan, and Obstagoon that can help it pressure bulky Steel- and Rock-types. Alternatively, Seismitoad, Milotic, and Suicune are good defensive answers to the likes of Metagross, Stakataka, and Steelix. Snorlax and Assault Vest Reuniclus easily shrug off Tri Attack, so checks to them like Heracross, Incineroar, and the aforementioned Obstagoon also make for good partners.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Special Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Porygon-Z's high base Special Attack coupled with Adaptability and great coverage allows it to break down or outright sweep a variety of slower opposing team compositions.

  • Tri Attack or Uproar can be used as an alternative STAB options to Hyper Beam that do not have cooldown, whereas Thunderbolt provides solid coverage against the likes of Celesteela and Water-types such as Tapu Fini and Gyarados.

  • Nasty Plot allows Porygon-Z to boost its Special Attack to nearly unwallable levels, whereas Trick allows it to cripple passive walls and regain move flexibility.

Items

  • Chopple Berry lets Porygon-Z survive Fighting-type Attacks while Dynamaxed, particularly useful against Cinderace and Urshifu-R.

  • Life Orb lets Porygon-Z deal massive damage even without a Nasty Plot boost.

  • Choice Scarf patches up Porygon-Z's Speed stat, letting it outspeed key threats such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Dracovish.

sets.name: Dynamax Attacker
sets.description:
• Porygon-Z makes use of its amazing Special Attack paired with Adaptability to threaten almost the entire metagame. While its attacking potential is one of the best, its low bulk, average Speed, and need to Dynamax to perform well are often a burden; therefore, it needs to be supported by a redirector such as Clefairy or Togekiss.

  • Hyper Beam lets Porygon-Z unleash a 300 Base Power Max Strike, capable of shredding even bulky foes like Tapu Fini, Incineroar, and Grimmsnarl. Moreover, Max Strike lowers the foe's Speed, allowing Porygon-Z to outspeed Urshifu-R, Garchomp, and Galarian Moltres.

  • Dark Pulse hits Ghost-types such as Spectrier and Dragapult that are immune to Hyper Beam while also lowering their Special Defense when Dynamaxed.

  • Trick Room allows Porygon-Z to function on mixed archetypes that feature slow Pokemon such as Glastrier and Torkoal. Nasty Plot can be used as an alternative to boost Porygon-Z's Special Attack, but it isn't usually needed, as its immediate power is more than enough to threaten the majority of the metagame, and using Nasty Plot would require even more redirection support to function well.

sets.name: Chople Berry
sets.description:
This Porygon-Z set functions as a menacing wallbreaker due to Nasty Plot and a terrifying Adaptability-boosted STAB move in Hyper Beam. Nasty Plot boosts Porygon-Z's Special Attack to astronomical levels, letting it power through walls like Arcanine, Chansey, Corviknight, and Slowbro. Hyper Beam is Porygon-Z's strongest STAB move and can OHKO certain Pokemon without a boost, such as non-Unnerve Haxorus and Rillaboom. Eerie Impulse, when used with Recover, allows Porygon-Z to break through Primarina and Choice Specs Magnezone. 132 EVs in HP and 252 EVs in Defense alongside Chople Berry allow Porygon-Z to survive a Close Combat from Choice Band Urshifu-R, with Bold beating Adamant variants and Modest only beating Jolly variants, as well as an Outrage from Choice Band Mold Breaker Haxorus. 72 EVs in Speed are run to outspeed non-Jolly Corviknight as well as Pokemon like Choice Specs Modest Magnezone and bulky Rillaboom. The rest is put into Special Attack to maximize damage output. Alternatively, Porygon-Z can run Electroweb instead of Eerie Impulse and a spread of 92 HP / 252 Def / 28 SpA / 136 Spe to beat Choice Band Sawk and Avalugg while outspeeding Choice Band Adamant Dracovish. Another spread it can use is 184 HP / 248 Def / 32 SpA / 44 Spe with Speed Swap and Uproar replacing Eerie Impulse and Recover to reliably defeat Zeraora, stall Rotom-A, and Substitute users like Whimsicott.

You want to think carefully when using this Porygon-Z set, as it has many matchups requiring specific play. Against Primarina, Porygon-Z should always use Eerie Impulse immediately to survive the possible Choice Specs Hydro Cannon. If it is an Assault Vest or Chilan Berry variant, Porygon-Z only needs to use Eerie Impulse until it's at -4, heal off damage taken shortly afterwards, Nasty Plot till at least +4, and OHKO with Hyper Beam. To figure out whether the Primarina is Choice Specs or not, if -2 Hydro Cannon deals 58% of damage or more against the standard EV spread, that indicates that it is using Choice Specs, so you can end the battle after one use of Nasty Plot instead of two. Against Choice Specs Magnezone, the same process comes into play; however, you do not need to set up with Nasty Plot, as Hyper Beam 2HKOes. Against stall Arcanine, use Nasty Plot once, as +1 Hyper Beam OHKOes even if they use Snarl. Usually, you will use Hyper Beam first against particular Pokemon that aren't naturally specially defensive, such as Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan and non-Unnerve Choice Band Haxorus. Porygon-Z appreciates Chilan Berry Primarina as a partner, which handles wallbreakers like opposing Choice item Porygon-Z, Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, and Shell Smash Crustle. In return, Porygon-Z can deal with specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Slowbro, and Goodra. Porygon-Z is relatively frail even with this set's bulkier spread and cannot take many hits; thus, bulkier partners such as Magnezone and Arcanine are appreciated. Having partners that can take on Ghost-types like Dragapult, Galarian Corsola, and Gengar is imperative, as Porygon-Z has no moves capable of hitting them. Dark-types like Mandibuzz and Taunt Incineroar help alleviate this weakness. In return, Porygon-Z can handle one of their biggest issues: Urshifu-R.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Porygon-Z is an extremely strong special attacker due to its high Special Attack and Adaptability, and when paired with Choice Specs, this makes it one of the biggest offensive threats in the metagame. Hyper Beam OHKOes threats like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Arcanine. Trick is mainly used against typical stall-oriented Pokemon such as Torment Skarmory, Chansey, and Galarian Corsola to lock them into one move, allowing Porygon-Z to set up with Nasty Plot and KO them once boosted, barring Galarian Corsola which will be PP stalled because Porygon-Z cannot touch it without Dark Pulse. Dark Pulse is able to defeat Alolan Marowak and non-Focus Blast Choice Scarf Gengar, Dark Pulse can also hit Ghost-types, which Hyper Beam can't touch, in specific Galarian Corsola and Alolan Marowak. Uproar can be used over Dark Pulse on lower Special Attack set's to 2HKO non-Mirror Coat Magnezone and Whimsicott. The given EVs allow Porygon-Z to survive Grassy Glide from Choice Band Rillaboom and outspeed non-Choice Scarf Dracozolt and Dracovish, as well as OHKO Alolan-Marowak. An alternative EV spread of 144 HP / 60 Def / 72 SpA / 232 Spe with a Modest nature can be run in order to survive Choice Scarf Chandelure and Modest Scarf Draco Meteor from Hydreigon. However, the drop in Special Attacker makes the Alolan-Marowak match up unreliable, and can hurt with rolls against particularly bulky threats, like uninvested Snorlax. Another EV spread of 4 HP / 200 Def / 72 SpA / 232 Spe can be used to beat Life Orb Rillaboom. Lastly, Porygon-Z can use a spread of 144 HP / 60 Def / 96 SpA / 208 Spe or 148 Def / 152 SpA / 208 Spe with the nature Timid to out speed Adamant Haxorus and Urshifu, alongside doing all that you did before, depending on which one you use. Choice Specs Porygon-Z in general can sacrifice investment in either bulk, power, or speed to beat or get close to beating specific threats, like Excadrill, or fully invest in Speed to speed tie other non-Choice Scarf Porygon-Z. Generally, due to the power Choice Specs gives to Porygon-Z, it has a lot more room to invest in either overwhelming offense or bulk.

Trick should be used immediately against Pokemon such as Skarmory, Chansey, Galarian Corsola, and Crustle. Against Skarmory, simply rotate between Hyper Beam and Recover if they're running a damaging move; if you lock them into a status move, simply click Hyper Beam twice. Against Chansey, use Trick followed by Nasty Plot twice to get to +4 and then OHKO with Hyper Beam. Against Galarian Corsola, simply Trick and PP stall it, as it won't have any moves that can deal damage to Porygon-Z. Similarly to Galarian Corsola, Porygon-Z needs to PP stall Crustle. Regardless of what item you receive back, spam Recover until the foe runs out of PP. Due to the multi-hit nature of Rock Blast, the matchup is more favorable for Crustle but is not guaranteed If Crustle goes for Shell Smash on your Trick, simply click Hyper Beam twice, as they will be Choice-locked and unable to attack. Porygon-Z struggles against Fighting-type Pokemon and Pokemon with Fighting-type coverage such as Urshifu-R, Sawk, Hawlucha, and Haxorus. Fairy-type Pokemon, specifically Primarina and Sylveon, go well with Porygon-Z, since they can cover the Fighting-type weakness whilst simultaneously appreciating Porygon-Z's ability to deal with their threats such as Chansey, Rillaboom, Rotom-H as well as Poison-types such as Toxtricity and Venusaur. Porygon-Z needs to be wary of common Chilan Berry and Assault Vest users, mainly Primarina, so consider teammates such as Zeraora and Rillaboom.

nationaldex.comments:
Other Options

Bulk Up and Drain Punch may seem appealing to offer some form of recovery, but they fail to break through Corviknight in the same manner as Swords Dance. Shadow Sneak also seems nice, as it gives Mega Gallade a priority move, but it has no relevant targets and is simply not better than any of the listed options.

Checks and Counters

Strong Priority: Rillaboom's Grassy Glide, Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, Aegislash's Shadow Sneak, and Mega Mawile and Bisharp's Sucker Punch bypass Mega Gallade's solid Speed tier and threaten to deal heavy damage to it.

Revenge Killers: Faster revenge killers such as Tapu Koko, Ash-Greninja, and Mega Lopunny all scare Mega Gallade out. None of these Pokemon can switch into it though, nor can they check a full health Mega Gallade due to its solid bulk.

Status: Being burned severely impedes Mega Gallade's ability to break through bulkier cores, and being Paralyzed ruins its solid Speed tier, leaving it vulnerable to slower foes such as Tapu Lele, Tapu Fini, and Zapdos.

Fairy-type Pokemon: Fairy-types such as Mega Mawile, Clefable, and Tapu Lele can stomach a hit from Mega Gallade, and threaten it back with their STAB moves.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
As a Psychic / Fighting wallbreaker, Mega Gallade often draws comparison to Mega Medicham. Although Mega Medicham has more immediate power, Mega Gallade's access to Swords Dance, a higher Speed tier, and Knock Off differentiate it enough to give it a niche. Swords Dance allows Mega Gallade to clean up easier in the late game, when checks such as defensive Landorus-T are weakened into Zen Headbutt range. Knock Off can be used to threaten Slowbro, Reuniclus, and Slowking and cripple Pokemon that rely on their item, such as Volcarona, Zapdos, and Moltres. Ice Punch can be used to revenge kill Garchomp as well as nailing Gliscor, Mega Latias, and Landorus-T. It is important to note that upon Mega Evolving, Mega Gallade gains Inner Focus, protecting it from Landorus-T's Intimidate. Justified is the chosen ability prior to Mega Evolving to get an Attack boost by absorbing a weak Knock Off from Tangrowth or Toxapex. Maximum Speed investment and a Jolly nature allow Mega Gallade to outspeed Kartana and Garchomp as well as Speed tying Mega Latias and threatening the aforementioned Pokemon with an OHKO.

Quite possibly the best partner for Mega Gallade is Tapu Lele, as it appreciate Mega Gallade's ability to break through Corviknight, Slowking, and Heatran, and it provides Psychic Terrain to boost the power of Mega Gallade's Zen Headbutt, allowing it to break through Clefable. Other teammates that appreciate Mega Gallade's ability to pressure Corviknight, Slowbro, and Heatran include Garchomp, Volcarona, and Serperior. Additionally, solid checks to Fairy-types are appreciated, such as Ferrothorn and Jirachi. Jirachi is an especially great teammate, as its Healing Wish gives Mega Gallade a second opportunity to sweep. Solid entry hazard removal is also mandatory to give Mega Gallade more longevity, so Defoggers such as Corviknight, Zapdos, and Rotom-W pair well. Mega Gallade also appreciates Tyranitar and Weavile's ability to threaten Zapdos and trap Psychic-types.

pu.overview: Gallade makes for a potent wallbreaker with its raw strength, coverage, and decent Speed tier. It does a great job at dismantling slower teams, as it can threaten balance staples with its STAB moves, such as Regirock and Weezing. Gallade is able to distinguish itself from other Fighting-types like Passimian and Sawk with its immediate power, secondary STAB, and ability to boost with Swords Dance. However, its Speed tier still leaves much to be desired, as it can easily be pressured by offensive Pokemon like Archeops and Charizard. Gallade finds itself competing with other Fighting-type wallbreakers like Scrafty that are weaker initially but have more defensive utility.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Gallade is able to bolster its naturally high Attack with Life Orb to easily muscle past Pokemon like Gigalith without the need for hazards. Swords Dance elevates its power even further, helping net OHKOs on bulky Pokemon like Weezing once boosted, while generally being harder to switch into. It also provides the necessary strength to get past Palossand and Aromatisse. Lum Berry provides more setup opportunities against status users, such as Gigalith and Regirock. Sticky Web support from Pokemon like Ribombee, Galvantula, and Vikavolt allows Gallade to outspeed Pokemon like Silvally-Steel and Lycanroc. These Sticky Web setters are also able to pivot Gallade into Pokemon such as Gigalith and Togedemaru. Gallade's middling Speed tier makes it rather easy for it to be checked by common Pokemon like Charizard and Silvally-Fairy, so Gallade appreciates having a defensive backbone with Pokemon like Druddigon and Sandaconda to fall back on. Gallade's average bulk can be mitigated with pivots like Togedemaru and Whimsicott to get it in safely on Pokemon like Weezing.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Mega Gallade can opt to run Bulk Up and Drain Punch in lieu of Swords Dance and Close Combat; Drain Punch acts as a form of passive recovery, while Bulk Up makes Mega Gallade even tougher for physical attackers to deal with. However, the immediate damage output from Swords Dance and Close Combat is generally preferred. Substitute may be used to help Mega Gallade set up against passive Pokemon like Toxapex while avoiding status conditions from foes like Mega Sableye and Rotom-W, and it is opted for on Bulk Up sets, but it forces Mega Gallade to give up Knock Off or Shadow Sneak which are preferred in most cases.

Checks and Counters

Psychic

Fairy-types: Fairy-type Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Mimikyu can threaten to OHKO Mega Gallade with their powerful STAB moves. However, Mega Diancie needs to be wary of Mega Gallade winning the speed tie, while Mimikyu is easily threatened if Disguise is broken. Bulky Fairy-types like Hatterene can also check Mega Gallade effectively.

Ghost-types: Ghost-type Pokemon such as Gengar and Choice Scarf Blacephalon can outspeed and OHKO Mega Gallade with their Ghost-type STAB moves. However, they need to be wary of Shadow Sneak.

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive walls such as Mega Slowbro and Mega Sableye can easily switch in against Mega Gallade and proceed to burn it with Scald or Will-O-Wisp, respectively. Mega Sableye in particular is immune to both of Mega Gallade's STAB options and takes reduced damage from Knock Off, completely walling Mega Gallade.

Revenge Killers: Faster revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Zeraora, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Latios can all threaten to KO Mega Gallade after very little chip damage. However, Pokemon weak to Shadow Sneak like Latios need to watch out for it.

Status: All forms of status can cripple Mega Gallade greatly. Poison puts Mega Gallade on a timer, limiting its ability to act as a reliable wallbreaker. Paralysis allows Mega Gallade to easily be revenge killed. Burn greatly weakens it as a wallbreaker.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Psychic)
sets.description:
An excellent Speed tier, a sky-high Attack stat, and a great secondary type in Fighting that aids greatly against Steel and Dark teams make Mega Gallade an amazing physical wallbreaker on Psychic teams. Swords Dance allows Mega Gallade to further increase its already high Attack stat, allowing it to easily break through a majority of teams and walls like Celesteela. Close Combat is Mega Gallade's primary STAB option, dealing with troublesome Steel-, Dark-, Normal-, and Rock-types like Bisharp, Zarude, Porygon2, and Tyranitar. Zen Headbutt allows it to deal with Poison- and Fighting-types like Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Keldeo. Psycho Cut can be used in lieu of Zen Headbutt at the cost of some Base Power as a more accurate option that also avoids damage from Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin, as well as Poison from Toxapex's Baneful Bunker. Knock Off helps against opposing Psychic-types like Slowbro and Victini that resist both of Mega Gallade's STAB options while also helping with Ghost-types like Galarian Corsola and Aegislash. Knock Off also gets rid of items like Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots, crippling the foe as a result. Shadow Sneak can be used instead of Knock Off as a form of priority that also helps against fast Psychic- and Ghost-types like Latios and Choice Scarf Blacephalon. However, Knock Off is generally preferred for the increased power against bulky Psychic- and Ghost-types like Slowbro and Galarian Corsola, and Shadow Sneak proves to be counter-productive when paired with Tapu Lele. Justified, prior to Mega Evolution, allows Gallade to switch into weak Dark-type moves like Mega Sableye's Knock Off and gain an Attack boost. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature makes Mega Gallade outspeed threats like Choice Specs Blacephalon, Keldeo, and Landorus.

All of Mega Gallade's teammates appreciate its ability to deal with Dark-types like Hydreigon and Mega Tyranitar. Steel-types like Jirachi and Metagross pair up well with Mega Gallade, as they deal with Fairy-types like Mega Diancie and Clefable that threaten it, and they can better handle Dragon-type attacks like Draco Meteor from Latios and Latias while also being able to provide Stealth Rock support. Victini and Mega Gallade form a formidable physical wallbreaking core while also synergizing well against Steel teams, as Victini deals with threats like Celesteela, while Mega Gallade in return takes care of Heatran reliably. Latios and Latias act as the most reliable Choice Scarf users on Psychic-type teams and can provide Defog support. Latias in particular can provide Healing Wish support for Mega Gallade, which it appreciates greatly. Fairy-types like Hatterene and Tapu Lele further improve the Dark matchup while also dealing with Dragon-type threats like Mega Altaria and Dragonite. Slowbro provides a reliable defensive pivot, can act as a reliable Fire-resistant Pokemon against Pokemon like Cinderace, and is also able to bring Mega Gallade safely into the field thanks to Teleport. Celebi is a great teammate, as it reliably deals with Water- and Ground-types that threaten Mega Gallade such as Mega Swampert and Excadrill. Deoxys-S breaks through Flying-type teams thanks to its BoltBeam coverage in conjunction with Nasty Plot. Albeit not common, Meloetta can provide a reliable switch-in against Ghost-type attacks directed at Mega Gallade from the likes of Gengar and Blacephalon.

pu.overview: Froslass makes for a capable wallbreaker thanks to its usable Attack and great Speed tier combined with its unique typing. It also has access to utility moves such as Trick and Spikes, allowing it to cripple and overwhelm its answers; it can even run a dedicated Spikes set, although it becomes much weaker without a boosting item. However, its below average Attack often leaves it over-reliant on its own Spikes to get past defensive behemoths like Regirock, while its typing and bulk leave it easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Togedemaru, and Sneasel as well as priority moves like Sucker Punch and Accelrock.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Triple Axel is a strong, albeit unreliable, STAB move. Icicle Crash is an option, as it's more reliable despite being weaker; it also avoids Rough Skin and Flame Body from the likes of Druddigon and Coalossal. Trick allows Froslass to cripple its answers such as Scrafty and Aromatisse, while Ice Shard allows it to revenge kill foes like Ribombee. Despite seeming odd on a set using a Choice item, Spikes lets Froslass take advantage of the many Pokemon it forces out. Froslass's subpar bulk means it appreciates being brought in via partners like Galarian Articuno and Passimian; Both can also act as a Defog deterrent, and they both appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Charizard have an easier time cleaning late-game after Froslass has weakened down walls such as Regirock, Aromatisse, and Silvally-Steel.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description: Froslass's great Speed and typing make it a potent Spikes setter, as it's capable of pressuring common spinners such as Tsareena. Taunt prevents Pokemon like Miltank from recovering and also allows Froslass to keep its Spikes on the field against Defog users like Silvally-Fairy. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Archeops greatly appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets, as it gives them an easier time breaking through Gigalith and Regirock, respectively. They can also both pressure common Defog users that Froslass struggles against like Silvally-Steel and Charizard. Pokemon like Regirock, Weezing, and Lanturn can switch into threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Passimian, and Togedemaru that force out Froslass, respectively.

ubers.overview: Froslass is one of the premier entry hazard setters and dedicated leads in the tier. By virtue of its base 110 Speed and access to useful utility moves like Spikes, Taunt, and Destiny Bond, Froslass distinguishes itself as a more viable option than other Spikes setters like Mew and Cloyster. Icy Wind also allows it to slow down faster threats and prevent them from using Defog via Taunt or potentially trade with them via Destiny Bond. However, Froslass’s rather low bulk leaves it vulnerable to being easily KOed. Additionally, Froslass has difficulty defeating common Sticky Web setters on hyper offense teams like Slurpuff and Mental Herb Shuckle. Furthermore, although base 110 Speed is adequate, faster threats like Calyrex-S and Zacian can use Substitute in front of Froslass and proceed to cause problems to the hyper offense teams it is commonly utilized on.
ubers.comments:
Other Options

Other status moves like Thunder Wave and Will-O-Wisp can be run over Destiny Bond or Icy Wind if a particular team benefits from it. However in most cases, this is suboptimal. Poltergeist can be used over Icy Wind or Shadow Ball as an option for a stronger attacking move. In this case, a Jolly Nature should be utilized instead.

Checks and Counters

Faster Offensive Threats: Faster offensive threats like Calyrex-S and Zacian can take advantage of Froslass to use Substitute and potentially sweep hyper offense teams it is commonly featured on.

Ho-Oh: Thanks to Sacred Fire, Ho-Oh has a 50% chance of burning Froslass, negating its ability to potentially trade via Destiny Bond, and proceed to remove the entry hazards Froslass has set up with Defog.

Status Moves: Status moves like Toxic and Will-O-Wisp can bypass Focus Sash and make Froslass susceptible to being KOed before it gets to lay more than one layer of Spikes. Alternatively, Thunder Wave greatly reduces Froslass's overall effectiveness at setting up entry hazards and trading with a problematic foe.

Anti-Entry Hazard Pokemon: Faster users of Taunt such as Aerodactyl can completely prevent Froslass from setting up Spikes. Magic Coat leads like Slurpuff force mind games and can potentially bounce back Froslass's entry hazards and Taunt, putting its teammates in an extremely disadvantageous position. Furthermore, Magic Bounce users like Xatu can prevent Froslass from setting up Spikes, although it can 2HKO Xatu with Icy Wind.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
Taunt prevents slower Defoggers from removing Spikes, while Destiny Bond is used in conjunction with Taunt to potentially force a trade with an opposing threat. Finally, the attacking move of choice comes down to personal preference. In most cases, the speed control that Icy Wind provides offers more benefit and utility to the hyper offense teams that Froslass is commonly run on. However, Shadow Ball can be used over Icy Wind if Magic Bounce users like Xatu are a concern or if Substitute variants of Calyrex-S pose an issue to the team Froslass is being utilized on. Cursed Body could prove situationally useful, especially when facing Choice-locked foes. Maximum Speed EVs and a Timid nature are utilized to guarantee that Froslass outspeeds as many threats as possible while almost always setting up at least one layer of Spikes

As Froslass is commonly featured on hyper offense teams, potential team options include offensive threats like Zacian and Zekrom, which pressure and overwhelm the Defoggers commonly found in the tier. Yveltal is another great partner to pair with Froslass, as it has access to Taunt, which can prevent slower Defoggers from removing any entry hazards Froslass set up. Additionally, Froslass can be paired with another entry hazard setter like Slurpuff or a screens setter like Grimmsnarl or Regieleki to form a utility core that allows a variety of setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, Geomancy Xerneas, Swords Dance Zacian, Dragon Dance Zekrom, and Double Dance Groudon to sweep more easily. Air Balloon can be run on any of the aforementioned sweepers if the matchup against Sticky Web teams is a concern. Furthermore, it should be noted that Froslass struggles against leads on Sticky Web teams such as Slurpuff and Mental Herb Shuckle. Thus, pairing Froslass with a fast Rapid Spin user like Pheromosa or Regieleki would greatly benefit the removal of entry hazards and facilitate a potential sweep from one of Froslass's teammates.

sets.name: Suicide Lead (Ghost)
sets.description:
Froslass is a premier suicide lead Spikes setter on Ghost-teams. A high base 110 Speed stat alongside access to Taunt also allows Froslass to prevent opposing entry hazards from the likes of Ferrothorn and Bronzong and to prevent Defog from Pokemon such as Mandibuzz. Icy Wind is used to slow down faster Pokemon such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Excadrill, allowing Froslass to potentially take them out the next turn with Destiny Bond. However, Will-O-Wisp can be used over Destiny Bond to cripple physical attackers such as Grimmsnarl. Focus Sash allows Froslass to survive any one hit and set one layer of Spikes.

Froslass is mainly used on hyper offensive Ghost teams; Pokemon such as Polteageist, Mimikyu, Dragapult, Gengar, and Aegislash all take advantage of Spikes support, as they appreciate chip damage racking up on opposing Pokemon. Froslass can also form an entry hazard setting core with Stealth Rock users such as Runerigus to further stack hazards. Watch out for priority users such as Mimikyu and Aegislash, as they can OHKO Froslass if Focus Sash is not intact; faster threats such as Weavile and Dragapult also outspeed and OHKO Froslass. Faster hazard setters such as Ribombee can freely set up Sticky Web before Froslass is able to use Taunt on them.

sets.name: Suicide Lead (Ice)
sets.description:
Froslass is able to make a great suicide lead thanks to its high Speed stat and is great for its access to entry hazards, Taunt, and Destiny Bond. Spikes are great to pressure switch-ins and get chip damage on the opponent's Pokemon. Taunt enable Froslass to shut down other Pokemon from getting up Stealth Rock, Toxic Spikes, or Spikes. Destiny Bond can be used to take down a Pokemon with it. Shadow Ball allows Froslass to 2HKO Hatterene that would otherwise bounce Spikes back. Froslass should be used as a lead most of the time to get up Spikes and try to take a Pokemon down with it with Destiny Bond. It can also be saved for later in the game to stop common Rapid Spin users such as Excadrill from getting rid of Spikes thanks to its Ghost typing.

Stealth Rock setters such as Mamoswine and Piloswine work great with Froslass to form an entry hazard-stacking duo to pressure Pokemon from being able to switch in and out, as well as making it easier for Cloyster and Weavile to sweep. Wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Mamoswine, Kyurem-B and Cloyster appreciate Froslass's Spikes to chip down the opposing team and make them easier to get rid of. However, Froslass will struggle to set up Spikes later in the game if there are entry hazards down that can break its Focus Sash, so partners such as Avalugg and Galarian Mr. Mime go well with it. Froslass also struggles against Pokemon that can attack and KO it with priority moves like Aegislash, so partners such as Galarian Darmanitan and Lapras are needed, as they can take care of it.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
A fierce special wallbreaker, Rotom's Electric / Ghost typing offers STAB attacks that deal at least neutral damage against a majority of the metagame. Moreover, its Speed sets it apart from other special attackers, as beyond targeting physical walls like Cofagrigus and Wishiwashi, it also revenge kills wallbreakers like Decidueye, Golurk, and Sawk. Volt Switch is particularly deadly, as it lets Rotom chip and switch out on forced switches and attackers it cannot OHKO at first like Skuntank, Abomasnow, and Malamar. It is also useful for pivoting out on walls like Clefairy and Ferroseed, although Trick immediately debilitates them and other Pokemon that are immune to Volt Switch like Galarian Stunfisk and Lanturn.

The downsides of Rotom's coverage are the relevant resistances and immunities that opposing targets can take advantage of if Rotom is Choice locked into an unfavorable attack. Faster Dark-types like Silvally-Dark, Liepard, and Alolan Persian revenge kill Rotom, so it requires support from Fighting-types such as Sawk, Toxicroak, and Gurdurr; Sawk and Toxicroak scare these checks out with their Choice Scarf sets, while Gurdurr and Toxicroak have threatening priority sets for them. These teammates also target Normal-types like Miltank and Kangaskhan so that Rotom can spam Shadow Ball without fearing immunities. Grass- and Water-type wallbreakers like Decidueye, Abomasnow, and Basculin target Volt Switch-immune walls like Sandaconda and Piloswine, as well as Lanturn in the case of the first two, which helps Rotom pivot freely once they are eliminated. Rotom's resistances are vital for checking Toxicroak and Ninjask late-game, so keep Stealth Rock off your side of the field with the support from Eldegoss, Silvally-Dark, and Cramorant. Physical cleaners like Silvally-Dragon and Togedemaru pick up the pace for Rotom and appreciate it eliminating their checks like Cofagrigus, Garbodor, and Qwilfish.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Rotom capitalizes on its good Speed tier with the boost from Choice Scarf, allowing it to revenge kill unboosted targets such as Silvally-Ghost, Gourgeist-S, Basculin, and Froslass. Beyond revenge killing, Rotom has enough firepower to also threaten notable physical walls like Cofagrigus, Weezing, and Avalugg, although its frailty makes it lack opportunities to switch in. Its fast pivoting with Volt Switch is a great way to threaten Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf Toxicroak, as it can chip them into range of being cleaned up with Thunderbolt. Trick targets walls like Clefairy and Miltank and lets Rotom take advantage of its coverage for when its natural Speed suffices.

The Speed and coverage Rotom provides make it best used on balance builds. Wallbreakers like Sawk, Golurk, and Abomasnow target walls like Galarain Stunfisk, Ferroseed, and Pilowsine for Rotom, while Rotom in return checks their revenge killers like Gourgeist-S and Silvally-Ghost. An offensive pivoting core can be formed with the likes of Liepard and Ninjask, which rely on Rotom to punish physical walls like Cofagrigus and Qwilfish. Grass-types like Eldegoss, Gourgiest-S, and Tangela are reliable partners that can switch into Electric-immune targets like Sandaconda and Lanturn. After it uses Trick, Rotom becomes vulnerable to Froslass and Liepard, so it should have defensive support from walls like Miltank, Weezing, Tangela, and Gurdurr. Even when retaining Choice Scarf, these walls also help stomach attacks from faster sweepers untouchable by Rotom like Choice Scarf Basculin and Flame Charge Silvally formes.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Utilizing Rotom's apt defensive typing and offensive pressure lets it function as a worthwhile entry hazard remover. This is thanks in part to Levitate giving it an edge against Ground-type Stealth Rock users and its STAB coverage nailing setters like Golurk, Qwilfish, and Drednaw. However, Defog comes at the cost of losing momentum when Rotom could use Volt Switch instead, and it opens an opportunity for its checks to switch in safely. Will-O-Wisp threatens hazard setters and slower physical attackers such as Pilowsine, Garbodor, and Galarian Stunfisk. It also synergizes well with Hex, helping Rotom break through the aforementioned walls. Alternatively, Shadow Ball is immediately more threatening to some targets like Sandaconda and Decidueye. Heavy-Duty Boots secures Rotom's HP when switching into Stealth Rock, while Colbur Berry forgoes said security for an edge against attackers with strong Dark-type coverage like Gurdurr and Toxicroak. Sitrus Berry is a third option for general recovery that particularly gives Rotom an upper hand against Sandaconda and Piloswine.

Pair Rotom with additional offensive pivots like Ninjask, Silvally-Dark, and Basculin that appreciate having entry hazards cleared for them and pressure Rotom's faster checks. They also help in tandem with it to bring in wallbreakers, and Pokemon like Decidueye, Abomasnow, and Golurk cover Rotom's Ground- and Electric-type checks. Steel-types like Togedemaru and Klinklang deal with special walls like Clefairy and Alcremie for Rotom, and they appreciate its Ground- and Fighting-type immunities. Unless Rotom is holding Colbur Berry, it should avoid Knock Off at all costs and instead switch into a defensive teammate like Rocky Helmet Weezing or Garbodor that punishes users like Gurdurr and Liepard. Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Toxicroak target Rotom's faster checks like Alolan Persian, Gougeist-S, and Froslass and can clean with their Fighting-type coverage after Rotom deals with defensive Ghost- and Poison-types.

pu.overview: Rotom is a quite versatile Pokemon thanks to its solid typing both offensively and defensively, great Speed, and decent movepool. These traits allow it to perform well as either a Choice Scarf user or a Defogger. Electric / Ghost is a near unresisted typing, bar some exceptions such as Drampa and Shiftry, all of which can be pivoted out against with Volt Switch. Defensively, Rotom resists or is immune to various common attacks from Pokemon such as Scyther and Passimian, although has to watch out for common coverage moves such as Knock Off. Rotom's Speed allows it to outspeed threatening breakers such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Magmortar and for its Choice Scarf set to outspeed other common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. There are other Electric- and Ghost-types that give it competition as a Choice Scarf user, such as Togedemaru with its higher Speed and valuable Steel typing, and Haunter with its higher Speed and Special Attack alongside support moves such as Destiny Bond. However, Rotom's unique type combination and access to both Trick and Volt Switch make it a great option over the other two.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf allows Rotom to utilize its solid Speed to outspeed various other Choice Scarf users, such as Passimian and Mesprit, as well as gain momentum with Volt Switch. While Trick is run to cripple specially defensive Pokemon that may try to switch in on Rotom, such as Lanturn and Gigalith, it can also be used to potentially put a stop to bulky setup Pokemon such as Scrafty and Aromatisse. Rotom is best used as a revenge killer or brought in by slow pivots such as defensive Mesprit and defensive Silvally-Fairy, which furthermore form a solid VoltTurn core with it. Wallbreakers such as Tsareena and Magmortar benefit from being brought in through Rotom's Volt Switch.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Rotom can serve as a solid Defog user with its good matchup against various entry hazard setters such as Mesprit and Palossand. Furthermore, it is able to cripple various other hazard setters such as Gigalith and Druddigon with Will-O-Wisp. Will-O-Wisp also powers up Hex, which should only be run alongside it. Thunderbolt is an option for the last slot if you want to give Rotom more of an offensive presence, although Pain Split is an option to increase Rotom's longevity that pairs well with its low HP stat. Colbur Berry allows for Rotom to better check Fighting-types and other Knock Off users, such as Passimian and Scyther, but Heavy-Duty Boots is a secondary option so it can take no damage from Stealth Rock. While Rotom does have a nice defensive typing, it is recommended to not switch it into attacks too many times, as it is easily worn down with its only okay bulk, especially without Pain Split. Pokemon that are easily worn down by entry hazards, such as Silvally-Steel and Passimian, appreciate Rotom's hazard removal.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: A very good offensive typing in tandem with Nasty Plot makes Rotom-H a good wallbreaker, as it is easily able to break through common defensive Pokemon like Clefable, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight. It is mostly used on balance and bulky offensive teams looking for a reliable progress maker or Togekiss check. Clefable and Blissey are particularly good partners, as they are often able to deal with common threats to Rotom-H, such as Dragapult and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Substitute + Nasty Plot (Electric)
sets.description:
Rotom-H is a good option on Electric teams because of its ability to hit Grass- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Celebi, Vileplume, and Ferrothorn for super effective damage with Overheat. Being able to take down Steel-type Pokemon is especially important, as Overheat in the Steel matchup can be otherwise hard due to its defensive core as well as revenge killers in Excadrill. Nasty Plot and Substitute in conjunction with its good Special Attack and decent Speed allows Rotom-H to serve as a setup sweeper and wallbreaker, being great against Steel teams as well as other types like Grass, Ice, and Psychic. Nasty Plot helps Rotom-H break past bulkier Pokemon such as Mew, Galarian Corsola, and Celebi as well as OHKO offensive Pokemon such as Gardevoir, Hatterene, and Kyurem-B with a boosted Overheat. Substitute allows Rotom-H to set up on more passive defensive Pokemon, mainly Ferrothorn, Celebi and Appletun, or forced switches. Against Steel, Rotom-H should look to set up Substitute against Ferrothorn in order to beat more Pokemon with Overheat. Substitute is also good because it enables Rotom-H to set up in front of Bisharp's Sucker Punch and force Aegislash to change to Blade forme to take it on, allowing Rotom-H to deal with these Pokemon more consistently especially against Steel teams. Thunderbolt hits Pokemon such as Toxapex and Corviknight for super effective damage while OHKOing Pokemon such as Indeedee and Gengar after a Nasty Plot boost without having to rely on Overheat along with its Special Attack drops. Maximum Speed combined with a Timid nature allows Rotom-H to outspeed Pokemon like Indeedee-F, Mamoswine, and Diggersby as well as other Pokemon like Choice Scarf Duraludon if Sticky Web is set.

The entirety of Electric teams appreciates Rotom-H's ability to beat Steel teams effectively. Galvantula and Vikavolt set Sticky Web for Rotom-H, allowing it to outspeed Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Duraludon, Choice Scarf Gardevoir, and Salazzle. Alolan Raichu is a good revenge killer under Electric Terrain, being able to take on Pokemon such as Seismitoad, Terrakion, and Choice Scarf Excadrill, which check Rotom-H. The latter is extremely important, as it can beat Rotom-H with Earthquake if it is not behind a Substitute. Pincurchin sets Spikes and Toxic Spikes, wearing down the opposing team for Rotom-H, and can slow down Pokemon like Gengar with Thunder Wave and give Rotom-H setup opportunities with Memento. Zeraora is a great physical wallbreaker, being able to take on special walls like Snorlax and Tyranitar with its high Attack paired with Choice Band as well as Dragon-type Pokemon like Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Dracovish with Play Rough. In return, Rotom-H can break past a lot of the Pokemon Zeroara struggles with such as Galarian Corsola, Torkoal, and Vileplume with Nasty Plot. Toxtricity is another special sweeper with Shift Gear that works together with Rotom-H to take on types like Psychic, Grass, Fairy, Ice, and Poison. Morpeko can break dual screens using Psychic Fangs to help Rotom-H wallbreak and bring Rotom-H in safely using Parting Shot. It can also beat Pokemon like Gastrodon and Seismitoad with Seed Bomb for Rotom-H.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Choice
sets.description:
• Rotom-H sports a fantastic defensive typing, and serves as a premier offensive pivot with good defensive upside.

  • Rotom-H often choses Trick and Will-O-Wisp as defensive move options to cripple defensive walls or physical Dynamax sweepers at the expensive of offensive coverage

  • Alternatively, Rotom-H can also opt between Thunderbolt or Dark Pulse as offensive move selections over Will-O-Wisp, which can be somewhat awkward with choice lock. Thunderbolt gives Rotom-H a repeatable Electric-type STAB that doesn't force it to switch, and Dark Pulse helps it get important coverage against various Pokemon that resist both of its STAB types, such as Dragapult.

Items

  • Choice Scarf allows Rotom-H to outspeed major threats, such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Dracovish. It also punishes defensive Pokemon more with Trick.

  • Choice Specs gives Rotom-H much more power.

EV spreads

  • 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe Timid: This spread maximizes speed and power for Choice Scarf.

  • 68 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 12 SpD / 172 Spe Modest: This spread gives Rotom-H some bulk while maximizing Special Attack and outspeeding Adamant Choice Band Dracovish and slower variants of Zapdos.

sets.name: Bulky Baking Oven
sets.description:
• Rotom-H without a choice item can seamlessly play both a potent Dynamax role and a useful supporting role in one set.

  • Nasty Plot in combination with Electric STAB options allow it to check all variants of Zapdos, but can be replaced by Volt Switch if equipping an Assault Vest.

  • For the last slot, Rotom-H can use Dark Pulse to hit many targets that resist its dual STAB, and can also gain access to Max Darkness, dropping foes' Special Defense. It can also opt for running Will-O-Wisp to gain the upper hand against physical attackers.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry gives Rotom-H a quick burst of recovery that can turn potential 2HKOs into 3HKOs, with th most notable one being turning Zapdos's Life Orb Max Lightning into a 3HKO after Stealth Rock against maximum HP Rotom-H.

  • Assault Vest gives Rotom-H plenty of special bulk to better check special threats, and it works particulary well with Dynamax.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD Modest: This spread forgoes Speed investment to maximize Rotom-H's HP.

  • 68 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 12 SpD / 172 Spe Modest: This spread gives Rotom-H bulk, maximizes Special Attack, and outspeeds Adamant Choice Band Dracovish and slower variants of Zapdos.

vgc2021.overview: Rotom-H shines more than ever with the amount of Steel- and Grass-types in the current metagame, such as Rillaboom, Kartana, and Celesteela, all of which it can check. Its amazing defensive typing also lets it take on Glastrier, Metagross and Venusaur with relative ease. In addition, it becomes a threatening Pokemon under Dynamax after a Nasty Plot or two. However, it struggles against Pokemon such as Assault Vest Landorus-T, as well as against damage reductions such as Grimmsnarl's Light Screen and Incineroar's Snarl. Further, it relies on Nasty Plot to boost its comparatively meager Special Attack stat, meaning it often has matchups where it is unable to set up and simply dead weight.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Overheat allows Rotom-H to hit Steel- and Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Kartana. It is also able to change the weather as Max Flare during Dynamax.

  • Nasty Plot is used to offset Overheat’s Special Attack drop as well as increase Rotom-H's damage output. Rotom-H is typically able to set up easily thanks to its typing.

  • Safety Goggles is used to block sleep moves from Venusaur and Amoonguss, as well as Rage Powder from the latter. Sitrus Berry can be used instead to increase Rotom-H’s longevity.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
This set is designed to check important threats in the metagame, namely Zeraora, Ferrothorn, and Sylveon. The Speed EVs allow for Rotom-H to outpace maximum Speed neutral natured Aegislash, while maintaining as much special bulk as possible. The rest of the EVs maximize Rotom-H's special bulk to better check Sylveon. Lava Plume is Rotom-H's main STAB attack, and the 30% chance to burn targets can come in handy; Blue Flare can be used for extra damage output, but generally Lava Plume’s extra PP and higher chance to burn is more desirable. Volt Switch is an important tool for Rotom-H that allows it to pivot and scout for switches. Roost is Rotom-H's main recovery move and increases its longevity immensely. Toxic allows Rotom-H to beat defensive Sylveon properly and allows for it to hinder other switch-ins as well. Defog is a great tool to remove entry hazards and dual screens, while Freeze-Dry's increased coverage is great for would-be switch-ins such as Seismitoad and Rotom-Wash. Will-O-Wisp, Nuzzle, and Aromatherapy are all worth considering as support options, as well as many other niche options. Due to Rotom-H's weakness to Stealth Rock, Heavy-Duty-Boots is the preferred item on this set to eliminate this weakness, but Leftovers is an acceptable choice as well.

Rotom-H's best partners are typically Pokemon that appreciate its slow pivoting. In particular, Obstagoon can use Rotom-H’s pivoting to activate its Guts with Flame Orb safely, while Rotom-H can solidly check some of Obstagoon's checks in Corviknight Ferrothorn, Magearna, and Hippowdon. Kyurem is a good partner, as Rotom-H is one of the best switch-ins in the metagame to one of Kyurem's most prevalent checks, Sylveon, given Rotom-H has Toxic. Sylveon can possibly hinder Rotom-H as well if it has Toxic as well, however, so be careful. Some of Rotom-H's most common switchins are Water-type Pokemon such as Seismitoad and Rotom-W if it is not running Freeze-Dry, so a partner such as Seismitoad or Ferrothorn that can switch into Water-type Pokemon relatively safely is great, and both of the aforementioned partners can form a core that compresses both entry hazard roles with Rotom-H. Some of the strongest checks in the metagame to Rotom-H are Dragon-type Pokemon such as Kommo-o and Hydreigon, which take minimal damage from Freeze-Dry and do a ton of damage back. Rotom-H is a great partner for Water-type Pokemon such as Keldeo, Azumarill and Gyarados, which can struggle to get past Ferrothorn and other physically bulky Pokemon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Rotom-H's role in the metagame is to be a powerful special attacker while also being a great stallbreaker withTrick. Overheat hits Steel- and Grass-types such as Aegislash, Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Celebi. Thunderbolt hits Flying- and Water-types, such as Mandibuzz, Primarina, Milotic, and Toxapex. Trick is used to Choice-lock stall Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Type: Null into setup moves so that they can't touch Rotom-H. Rest is used to recover HP against Pokemon that got Choice-locked into attacks like Galarian Corsola with Night Shade. The EVs allow Rotom-H to outspeed maximum Speed neutral-natured base 60s, like Incineroar, survive three Night Shades or Seismic Tosses from Galarian Corsola or Chansey, and stall it out with Rest after crippling it with Trick, and 2HKO Incineroar and Arcanine. Alternatively, a spread of 240 HP / 80 Def / 140 SpA / 48 Spe with a Bold Nature can be run, in order to always beat Urshifu-S, while still outspeeding base 60s. This will make the Primarina matchup much less reliable, however.

Due to Rotom-H being a slow Fire-type, it is easily taken out by Rock-types and fast Water-types, such as Rhyperior, Tyranitar, Crustle, Keldeo, and Blastoise. Bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon and Pyukumuku can deal with this weakness. Rotom-H helps these Pokemon in return by being able to OHKO Grass-types like Ferrothorn, Venusaur, Rotom-C, and Celebi. Due to Rotom-H's attacks being Fire- and Electric-type, Dragon-types such as Haxorus, Hydreigon, and Dracovish can tank Rotom-H's attacks and KO it in return. Fighting-types such as Choice Specs Keldeo and bulky Choice Band Sawk can deal with these Dragon-types. In return, Rotom-H provides a check to both Flying- and Grass-types and also resists Electric-type attacks from Zeraora, Rotom-C, and Togedemaru.

uu.overview: Rotom-W's typing and Levitate allow it to be an effective pivot that comes in against notable threats such as Mamoswine, Moltres, Pelipper, and Celesteela. Rotom-W can act as an effective entry hazard remover due to its great matchup against common entry hazard setters like Rhyperior and Krookodile. Other utility options like Pain Split and Will-O-Wisp allow it to make progress even when the opponent switches to its checks and counters. Sadly, Rotom-W's poor HP stat in conjunction with its reliance on Leftovers and Pain Split for recovery holds back its ability to act as a reliable pivot and exacerbates its vulnerability to poison, burn, and Stealth Rock damage. While Rotom-W does have some useful resistances, it needs to be healthy or used with prediction to pivot against foes that can potentially dent it greatly, such as Ground-types that have a strong secondary STAB move like Nidoking and Diggersby.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Rocky Helmet has the benefit of punishing the likes of Jirachi for spamming U-turn or contact moves, though losing the passive recovery from Leftovers is not ideal. Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature makes Rotom-W a more effective pivot against Keldeo and Mamoswine, but the loss in Speed hampers it against foes like Nidoking and Chandelure. Choice Scarf is an option to revenge kill Keldeo and Lycanroc-D, with the set being able to run Trick to cripple the likes of Gastrodon, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth. However, Choice Scarf Rotom-W can no longer act as a switch-in to Mamoswine and Krookodile, fearing Knock Off, and being Choice-locked lets Ground-types punish Volt Switch much more strongly. Nasty Plot + Pain Split turns Rotom-W into a wallbreaker, but it still has immense problems with Grass-types. This set also sacrifices Volt Switch in favor of Thunderbolt or Discharge, which makes the matchup against Grass-types even worse. Rindo Berry can be used if the team is too weak to Dragon Dance Gyarados, as it can prevent an OHKO from +2 Adamant Power Whip and provide a safety net against Tapu Bulu if Will-O-Wisp misses.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Rotom-W cannot deal any significant damage to the likes of Tangrowth and Amoonguss aside from burning them. Though Tapu Bulu dislikes Will-O-Wisp, it can still threaten Rotom-W with Horn Leech to restore health. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to disregard status completely. However, all of them lose momentum to Volt Switch as they switch in. Rotom-W also must watch out for Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o only dislikes status from Rotom-W and is able to freely set up with Clangorous Soul. Zygarde-10%'s Thousand Arrows ignores Levitate, meaning it heavily punishes teams that solely rely on Rotom-W to deal with Ground-types.

Seismitoad and Gastrodon Seismitoad and Gastrodon shut down Rotom-W nearly completely if it is not carrying Toxic. Seismitoad can cripple Rotom-W with Toxic and is the only Stealth Rock setter that is immune to both Hydro Pump and Volt Switch, and Gastrodon does not care much about Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch is required so Rotom-W can gain momentum against Grass- and Dragon-types such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o while bringing in teammates like Chandelure and Primarina to threaten them. Hydro Pump destroys common entry hazard setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile. Pain Split is Rotom-W's only recovery move and gives Rotom-W more utility against bulkier teams, though it can be easy to play around. Will-O-Wisp cripples Amoonguss, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Tangrowth. Other status moves can be used over Will-O-Wisp; Toxic limits Seismitoad and Gastrodon's longevity better, whereas Thunder Wave cripples Noivern and Kommo-o. Defog is an alternative option because Rotom-W has several opportunities to remove hazards, such as when facing Celesteela and Jirachi, while having a good matchup against many of the entry hazard setters. Leftovers is Rotom-W's primary way of standing up to repeated U-turn and Stealth Rock damage. Maximum Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed and OHKO Nidoking as well as potentially cripple offensive Kommo-o with Will-O-Wisp.

Rotom-W fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate its ability to check Mamoswine and Moltres. U-turn users such as Zarude and Moltres form VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W that can be difficult to stop, as Rotom-W threatens their checks such as Rotom-H and Rhyperior. Rotom-W appreciates Moltres's ability to pressure Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Wallbreakers such as Buzzwole, Entei, and Nidoking appreciate Rotom-W's Volt Switch allowing them to pressure defensive cores relying on Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth. Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude can help remove Seismitoad and Gastrodon and patch any weaknesses against Zygarde-10%. Zarude also forms a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W and appreciates Rotom-W sponging Krookodile's Knock Off if its item is still required, this being particularly important for Choice Scarf variants.

ou.overview: Rotom-W is a premier defensive pivot in OU because of its Water typing and ability Levitate, giving it staying power against Ground-types and differentiating it from other Electric-type pivots like Tapu Koko and Zeraora. Along with its arsenal of threatening status moves, these factors make it an amazing support option for bulky offense teams, where it is able to easily grab momentum and pivot into threatening offensive teammates while heavily punishing Ground-types attempting to block its Volt Switch. It also has unique defensive utility in checking, most notably, Heatran and Tornadus-T, but also Ground-types like Excadrill and Landorus-T. However, Rotom-W lacks reliable recovery, and it is dependent on Pain Split and Leftovers to consistently pivot and check offensive threats throughout a game, letting it be easily overwhelmed by repeated hits from Pokemon like Landorus-T and Heatran. This problem worsens after a Knock Off from one of the Pokemon it most commonly checks, like Landorus-T or Tornadus-T, or when it is statused by Heatran or Excadrill. Rotom-W faces competition from Slowking as a defensive pivot because of Slowking's reliable recovery with Slack Off and Regenerator, useful guaranteed slow pivoting with Teleport, and access to Future Sight, an invaluable tool for offensive teammates. Swampert is also able to set Stealth Rock, spam its unblockable Flip Turn, and check Electric-types like Tapu Koko and Zeraora better while still checking Heatran.
ou.comments:
Other Options

Rotom-W can run a Choice Scarf set with Trick to lure in and cripple common specially defensive walls like Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Galarian Slowking for its teammates while serving as a revenge killer. However, forgoing defensive investment means that it loses most of its defensive use. It also faces competition from Tapu Fini as a Choice Scarf + Trick user that has much more defensive utility, courtesy of its base stats and defensive typing, and can lure in walls like Toxapex better.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types like Rillaboom and Kartana can outspeed and OHKO Rotom-W easily if switched in safely, but direct switches let Rotom-W pivot on or cripple them. Ferrothorn and Tangrowth are pressured by Will-O-Wisp and prone to Rotom-W pivoting into a threatening wallbreaker like Kyurem or Heatran. However, they can easily switch into Rotom-W and punish its forced switch with Spikes, Knock Off, or Sleep Powder.

Chip Damage: Rotom-W's lack of reliable recovery makes it susceptible to Knock Off and Toxic from common Pokemon it checks, like Landorus-T and Tornadus-T, removing or negating its only consistent recovery in Leftovers. Switching into U-turn from either of these Pokemon can also steadily whittle it down, especially alongside chip damage from entry hazards.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Specially defensive walls like Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Galarian Slowking can switch into Rotom-W easily, but the latter two are pressured by Will-O-Wisp, and all three can be taken advantage of with a predictive Volt Switch into a wallbreaker.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch is extremely useful on Rotom-W in order to grab momentum for wallbreaking teammates, especially when armed with Hydro Pump and several status conditions to threaten incoming Ground-types intending to block Volt Switch. Thunder Wave lets it cripple offensive Dragon-types like Dragapult and Kyurem more than a burn would while crippling walls like Clefable and Heatran. Will-O-Wisp is also common to pressure Garchomp, Tapu Koko, and Zeraora, and it can provide amazing utility against Leftovers-reliant walls like Ferrothorn. Both status moves can also deter and heavily punish switch-ins from offensive Grass-types like Rillaboom and Kartana. Pain Split and Leftovers let Rotom-W check offensive threats while pivoting through chip damage from entry hazards or status conditions for longer. 88 Speed EVs let it outspeed Adamant maximum Speed Scizor. Rotom-W can use Defog because of its unique ability to relatively safely use Defog on Heatran, one of the most threatening Stealth Rock setters in the tier, as well as other extremely common Ground-type entry hazard setters like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Hippowdon. However, forgoing Pain Split recovery makes it a less consistent answer to most offensive threats. Defense investment is an option to take care of miscellaneous physical attackers like Hawlucha, Weavile, and Melmetal more easily at the cost of reduced special bulk.

Rotom-W fits best on bulky offense teams because it keeps up momentum consistently, enables its offensive teammates, and provides defensive flexibility. It gives opportunities to wallbreakers like Bisharp, Kartana, and Heatran after pivoting out on passive specially defensive walls like Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Galarian Slowking. Other defensive pivots like Landorus-T and Corviknight can help keep up momentum while respectively checking offensive Electric-types, like Tapu Koko and Zeraora, and Grass-types, like Rillaboom and Kartana, for Rotom-W. Scizor is also a fantastic partner because of its defensive synergy with Rotom-W. In addition to forming a potent momentum-based core, Scizor is a decent check to offensive Grass-type threats and can check strong wallbreakers, like Tapu Lele and Kyurem, that would otherwise blow back Rotom-W. Rotom-W can help check opposing Skarmory and Heatran in return. Tapu Lele and Tornadus-T enjoy Rotom-W's ability to check Heatran and force damage on Steel-types with Volt Switch or Will-O-Wisp, enabling them offensively.

sets.name: Status Utility (Electric)
sets.description:
Rotom-W serves as the primary defensive Pokemon on Electric-type teams, taking advantage of its part Water typing to take on threatening Pokemon like Barraskewda and Galarian Darmanitan. In addition, its ability Levitate enables Rotom-W to act as the primary check to Ground-types. Will-O-Wisp is good for burning physical attackers such as Bisharp and Mimikyu while Toxic is important for allowing Rotom-W to beat Pokemon such as Seismitoad and Gastrodon that would wall it otherwise, making it even better against Ground teams. Volt Switch enables Rotom-W to act as a slow pivot for the team in order to bring in teammates safely.

Due to Levitate and Volt Switch, nearly every Electric-type Pokemon greatly benefits from Rotom-W's presence on a team. Specifically, Toxtricity and Zeraora greatly appreciate Rotom-W's ability to serve as a defensive pivot by using Volt Switch to bring them in safely. Rotom-W also pairs well with Vikavolt, which provides a secondary Ground-type immunity. Heliolisk can also pair well with Rotom-W due to its immunity to Water-type attacks, which also relieves the pressure from Rotom-W to deal with strong Water-type Pokemon. In addition, Heliolisk's coverage moves also helps deal with Ground-types, further relieving pressure from Rotom-W.

sets.name: Nasty Plot + Substitute (Water)
sets.description:
Rotom-W is a decent setup sweeper on Water teams thanks to its access to Nasty Plot in tandem with Substitute. Substitute allows Rotom-W to set up on more passive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Pelipper, Mandibuzz, and Jellicent, posing a huge threat to types such as Water, Ghost, and Dark. Thunderbolt and Hydro Pump are Rotom-W's STAB moves, with Hydro Pump being especially strong under rain. Thunderbolt hits everything on Water bar Seismitoad and the uncommon Gastrodon, and Hydro Pump beats them both if they are Swift Swim and Sticky Hold, respectively. Dark Pulse is an alternative option over Hydro Pump in order to hit Pokemon such as Celebi, Seismitoad, and Ferrothorn. Generally, Rotom-W should try to look for opportunities to punch holes in the opposition early- to mid-game for other sweepers like Barraskewda and Seismitoad to sweep late-game, since Rotom-W won't be sweeping by itself most of the time. A Timid nature along with maximum Speed investment is used to outspeed Pokemon such as Gyarados and Togekiss that can be problematic to deal with otherwise.

Pelipper's Drizzle is great for boosting Rotom-W's Hydro Pump, and Pelipper can bring in Rotom-W safely with U-turn. Keldeo primarily is an amazing partner for Rotom-W because it can beat Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Hydreigon that would otherwise be problematic, while Keldeo appreciates Rotom-W's ability to beat Flying-type Pokemon such as Togekiss and Corviknight for it. Other offensive Pokemon like Seismitoad, Barraskewda, and Choice Scarf Dracovish appreciate Rotom-W's role as a early- to mid-game wallbreaker in order to sweep teams late-game. Rotom-W also appreciates said Pokemon to beat Pokemon that it can't, such as Ferrothorn, while outspeeding faster Pokemon such as Indeedee, Hydreigon, and Dragapult. Toxapex is a good partner for Rotom-W because of its access to Toxic Spikes, which helps with types such as Normal, Psychic, and Fairy.
