As a result of deadly Adaptability-boosted STAB moves, great Speed tier, and unpredictability between special and physical sets, Basculin is a premier special wallbreaker. However, it's incredibly frail, so it has to be cautious of revenge killers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Gourgeist-S. Flip Turn allows Basculin to chip switch-ins and checks like Audino and Wishiwashi while keeping momentum. Ice Beam deals with some Water-resistant foes like Tangela and Altaria. Toxic cripples foes like Jellicent and Wishiwashi.

Basculin typically fits on offensive and balance teams looking for an immediate special wallbreaker with a solid Speed tier. Choice Specs Basculin provides great support for physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Sawk that have trouble with physical walls. In return, they can deal with special walls like Wishiwashi and Audino, which Basculin struggles to break through. Defensive pivots such as Uxie and Articuno can take hits for Basculin and bring it safely on the field with U-turn, while Basculin helps them with its pivoting. This works very well in tandem with entry hazard support from the likes of Ferroseed and Alolan Sandslash, as it allows Basculin to OHKO targets like Cofagrigus and Gurdurr. Partners like Ninetales and Frosmoth cover Grass-types like Tangela, while teammates like Thwackey and Rotom handle Water-types like Wishiwashi and Cramorant.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Basculin takes advantage of its respectable Speed tier and Adaptability to tear through Pokemon that normally absorb its special attacks, like Audino and Articuno. Flip Turn chips checks such as Altaria, Ferroseed, and Tangela while keeping momentum. Aqua Jet helps Basculin revenge kill weakened, faster foes such as Cinccino and Ninetales. Superpower allows Basculin to break through Ferroseed, which can sponge the rest of its attacks well. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs can be used to provide coverage against Qwilfish and Poliwrath, which can similarly handle the rest of Basculin's attacks well.

Basculin pairs well with special attackers such as Alcremie, Frosmoth, Ninetales, and Rotom, as it can take down special walls like Audino and Clefairy that its teammates struggle with and also lure in physical walls and use Flip Turn. Defensive pivots like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Articuno let Basculin safely enter the field and can take hits for it. Offensive pivots such as Silvally-Ground, and Cinccino similarly allow Basculin to safely enter the field by threatening or KOing foes. Basculin pairs nicely with Pokemon that can threaten Water-types such as Rotom, Thwackey, and Manectric. Frosmoth, Rapidash, and Ninetales take care of Grass-types, with Frosmoth notably also checking one of the biggest threats to Basculin in Altaria.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Basculin is a great choice for teams that want a very hard hitting revenge killer and pivot. Flip Turn chips switch-ins such as Ferroseed and Clefairy while providing momentum. Ice Beam is great coverage against Pokemon like Altaria and Tangela, which can normally switch into its Water-type attacks. Toxic cripples checks like Jellicent and Wishiwashi.

Choice Scarf Basculin is usually found on offense and balance teams looking for a revenge killer. VoltTurn cores love having Basculin on their team, as it enables these cores with Flip Turn while bulkier pivots like Alolan Persian and Uxie can help Basculin switch in easily. Teammates such as Articuno and Skuntank serve as answers to bulky Grass-types like Tangela and Appletun. Thwackey and Rotom check Water-types that sponge Basculin's attacks and are additional offensive pivots that keep momentum. Lastly, entry hazard removers like Altaria and Rotom-S clear entry hazards that wear down Basculin as it pivots.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Krokorok can also carry Toxic on its sets to better wear down switch-ins like Tangela and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Gurdurr: Gurdurr counters both Krokorok set by being able to switch in repeatedly and OHKOing it with STAB attacks. Furthermore, Gurdurr can remove Stealth Rock through Defog.

Grass-types: Thwackey and Tangela have no trouble switching into Krokorok and OHKOing it with their STAB attacks.

Physical Walls: Clefairy, Machoke, and Charjabug can usually switch into Krokorok multiple times and block its progress.

Special Wallbreakers: Lead Krokorok relies on Intimidate and its moderate Speed to secure Stealth Rock, so faster special attackers like Galarian Mr. Mime, Focus Blast Electabuzz, and Magmar can take it out. However, none can switch into Krokorok and greatly fear the Choice Scarf set.

Revenge Killers: Pokemon like Choice Scarf Raboot and Shell Smash Wartortle are able to revenge kill Krokorok with strong coverage.

sets.name: KrokoRocks (Stealth Rock Lead)
sets.description:
Krokorok provides Stealth Rock and early momentum as a lead. Hattrem is ineffective as a form of entry hazard prevention due to it fearing a STAB Knock Off, while Taunt targets Defog users like Vullaby and Togetic. Taunt also prevents opposing entry hazards such as Stealth Rock from Galarian Corsola and Piloswine, Sticky Web from Charjabug, Toxic Spikes from Koffing, and Spikes from Ferroseed. Intimidate along with Krokorok's defensive investment allows it to survive an attack followed by priority when up against Piloswine and Machoke. The remaining Speed investment and a Jolly nature let Krokorok outspeed Modest Roselia along with other slower attackers like Lampent and Marshtomp.

Use Krokorok as a lead and supplement it with offensive teammates that preserve the momentum it gains early-game. Sweepers like Thwackey and Lampent appreciate Stealth Rock pressuring Flying-types like Vullaby and Golbat, as well as Knock Off both weakening Marshtomp, Piloswine, and Galarian Corsola. Roselia is particularly potent as a partner, not only for providing additional entry hazard pressure with Spikes, but also for checking threats to Krokorok like Thwackey, Tangela, Wartortle, and Galarian Mr. Mime. Faster attackers like Kadabra and Raboot revenge kill Krokorok and are immune to entry hazard damage with Magic Guard and Heavy-Duty Boots, respectively. It is best then to pair Krokorok with cleaners like Klang, Wartortle, and Fraxure to deal with them, as well as forms of speed control such as Hattrem and Charjabug. To help preserve Krokorok, pick teammates that resist Ice or are immune to Fighting like Klang, Galarian Corsola, and Lampent; the two Ghost-types are additionally compatible as spinblockers.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Krokorok differentiates itself from other offensive Ground-types like Piloswine by being the only one with enough Speed to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame with Choice Scarf. It's a good revenge killer and lead on offensive teams that checks Raboot, Electabuzz, and Metang with Earthquake and sets up Stealth Rock when they switch out. Knock Off removes Eviolite from Earthquake switch-ins like Tangela, Clefairy, and Gurdurr. Stone Edge hits Flying-type and Defog users like Vullaby, Togetic, and Golbat, which usually can sustain Knock Off.

Choice Scarf Krokorok can fulfill different roles depending on what is needed, whether it is to sweep, revenge kill, or set entry hazards. Krokorok will, however, find itself commonly forced out by locking itself in the wrong move or by being unable to get through common physical walls like Golbat, Tangela, and Gurdurr, making special wallbreakers such as Galarian Mr. Mime, Magmar, and Nasty Plot Togetic great partners. Krokorok is also quite frail, making pivots like Thwackey and Electabuzz great partners, and they can also force out Water-types like Wartortle and encourage Steel-types like Klang or Metang to switch in. These partners are also checked by Grass-types, so having Flying- and Fire-types like Golbat, Raboot, and Lampent is greatly appreciated. Krokorok is also greatly pressured by priority users like Piloswine, making physically defensive walls like Tangela, Machoke, and Galarian Corsola pivotal.

uu.overview: Krookodile's high Attack, respectable Speed, and amazing offensive typing make it one of the best offensive checks to Pokemon like Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro. Few Pokemon resist the combination of Earthquake and Knock Off, which dents even neutral targets such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Amoonguss. Intimidate lets Krookodile switch into resisted and neutral hits such as Lycanroc-D's Stone Edge without getting too worn down. It also helps prevent late-game sweeps from Pokemon like Salamence. Moves like Stealth Rock and Taunt let Krookodile compress utility roles, and its ability to run a plethora of items, like Life Orb, Leftovers, Choice Scarf, Choice Band, and resist Berries, makes for a key factor in its unpredictability and versatility. It's one of the best Choice Scarf users in UU, capable of revenge killing threats like Nihilego and Thundurus. With Choice Band, it can remove common answers to it like Amoonguss more easily. However, Krookodile is threatened by physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10% even after Intimidate, and its special bulk leaves it vulnerable to special attackers like Nidoking and Aegislash. Weaknesses to common types like Grass, Water, and Fighting hinder its defensive utility and leave it helpless against common Pokemon like Keldeo, Rotom-W, and Tangrowth. Coverage from Electric-types like Raikou's Scald and Thundurus-T's Focus Blast prevents Krookodile from checking them despite its Electric immunity. Buzzwole and physically defensive Tangrowth wall Krookodile indefinitely.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Passho Berry gives Krookodile a chance to eliminate threats like Crawdaunt, Rotom-W, and Raikou. Krookodile can opt for a more offensive Choice Scarf set with Moxie, letting it accumulate Attack boosts as it KOes enemies. However, the utility that Intimidate offers is more worth it to weaken Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, and Krookodile can't break past Grass-types and Buzzwole without enough boosts. High Horsepower should be used in place of Earthquake if Tapu Bulu is on Krookodile's team, as Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake. Choice Band Aerial Ace hits Buzzwole very hard, but that's it. Choice Band Assurance can nail Pokemon like Amoonguss as they switch in, but it requires specific conditions and good prediction

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tangrowth check Krookodile very well and are only bothered by Knock Off. Both cause big damage with Giga Drain and incapacitate a team member with Spore or Sleep Powder. However, Amoonguss has to wary of Choice Band Earthquake, as it is 2HKOed after Stealth Rock damage. Zarude and Tapu Bulu switch into Krookodile's STAB moves and can recover with Jungle Healing or Horn Leech.

Water-types: Rotom-W and Gyarados are immune to Ground and can take advantage of Krookodile being Choice-locked into Earthquake. The former can remove Stealth Rock with Defog, while the latter can get a free turn of setup. Krookodile also can't take any Water-type hits from Crawdaunt, Azumarill, Primarina, and Keldeo, but they don't like to switch in directly into its moves. Crawdaunt is also easier to switch around, since only one of its STAB types threatens Krookodile.

Fighting-types: Buzzwole walls any Krookodile set. It resists both of Krookodile's STAB moves, can tank any hit, has reliable recovery in Roost, and can threaten Krookodile back with its own STAB moves. Kommo-o, Mienshao, Keldeo and Cobalion also threaten Krookodile greatly. The former has enough bulk to take non-Choice Band attacks and KO back, while the latter three outspeed non-Choice Scarf sets, with Choice Scarf Mienshao outspeeding even those. However, Mienshao and Cobalion should scout for Chople Berry and Choice Scarf sets.

Strong Wallbreakers: Despite its ability and good defensive typing, Krookodile has subpar bulk and lacks reliable recovery, meaning it gets worn down quite quickly switching into Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10%. Pokemon like Aegislash and Nidoking hurt it very badly with even resisted special STAB moves due to its bad special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Krookodile's role compression and item versatility let it perform on both hyper offense teams and on more defensive ones, like balance and bulky offense. With Life Orb, this set fits on hyper offense teams as a great lead. If running Leftovers or a Berry, this set fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate Krookodile's utility and resistances. Knock Off is useful for checks like Amoonguss, Rotom-W, and Celesteela, crippling them for Krookodile's teammates. Stealth Rock wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Tangrowth for teammates like Aegislash and Choice Specs Primarina. Toxic allows Krookodile to cripple checks such as Tangrowth and Buzzwole. Taunt prevents Stealth Rock and Defog from Pokemon like Rhyperior, Seismitoad, Rotom-W, and Moltres. Chople Berry lets Krookodile take Lycanroc-D's Close Combat and KO back with Earthquake. It also helps Krookodile take Thundurus formes' Focus Blast to then weaken or KO them. Alternatively, Life Orb lets Krookodile pressure Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Rotom-W more easily, while Leftovers offsets entry hazard damage and gives Krookodile longevity to keep threats like Nihilego and Aegislash in check more easily. Rindo Berry is another option to survive +1 Nihilego's Grass Knot and OHKO back with Earthquake.

Setup sweepers such as Kommo-o and Salamence work well with Krookodile, as it can set Stealth Rock up and weaken their checks such as Primarina and Diancie. Special attackers like Thundurus, Starmie, and Nihilego appreciate Krookodile denting and crippling their checks in Chansey and Celesteela with Knock Off, paving their way to sweep. In return, they compensate for Krookodile's lower Speed tier and remove Pokemon like Buzzwole, Zarude, and Keldeo. Amoonguss can check Pokemonn like Primarina, Keldeo, and Zarude for Krookodile, and together they can keep Lycanroc-D in check. Salamence forms a double Intimidate core with Krookodile, weakening Pokemon like Zarude and stopping setup sweepers like Gyarados from getting out of control. Krookodile is vulnerable against Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Togekiss so partners like Aegislash, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel are valuable.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Knock Off pressures walls that rely on their items, like Celesteela and Chansey, and discourages Pokemon like Rotom-H and Salamence from switching in. Stone Edge threatens Pokemon immune to Ground like Gyarados, Moltres, and Rotom-H. Close Combat lets Krookodile hit targets such as Zarude, Chansey, and opposing Krookodile harder. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Buzzwole and Tangrowth, but since others like Amoonguss and Jungle Healing Zarude are immune or resilient to it, it's quite matchup reliant. Darkest Lariat is useful to hit Pokemon like Rotom-W harder after they've had their items removed. Lash Out serves as a good way to punish Intimidate from opposing Krookodile and Salamence and also punishes Defog from the latter, but it has no use outside of that because Krookodile outspeeds the Rotom-H formes and Moltres, the only other relevant Defoggers. Stealth Rock can be used to take advantage of Krookodile's ability to force switches against Pokemon such as Azelf and Nihilego, but it should only be used when the role compression is necessary, and it requires very good prediction. Choice Scarf turns Krookodile into an amazing revenge killer, outspeeding key Pokemon and sweepers such as Lycanroc-D, Nihilego, Thundurus, and +1 Jolly Kommo-o.

This set fits well on offense, bulky offense, and balance teams that need a fast revenge killer. These kinds of teams appreciate Krookodile's defensive utility in its two immunities and Intimidate. Even though Intimidate allows Krookodile to take on physical attacks a bit better, it shouldn't be relied on, so teammates like Aegislash and Tangrowth help it against wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D. Assault Vest Tangrowth takes on threatening Water-types such as Primarina, Rotom-W, and Keldeo well. Strong wallbreakers such as Primarina and Entei can get past Krookodile's checks such as Buzzwole and Tapu Bulu, allowing it to spam its STAB moves more freely. Krookodile is helpless against Grass-types, so partners that can pressure them like Nihilego and Mamoswine are great. Rotom-H is another good teammate that can scare away Grass-types and brings Krookodile in on checks like Nihilego. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Kommo-o and Jirachi is key to weaken checks like Rotom-W and opposing Kommo-o. Salamence, Aegislash, and Moltres ensure Buzzwole is not given free turns to wallbreak, as it can freely come into Krookodile.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Earthquake and Knock Off threaten a large portion of the metagame and together have almost unresisted coverage, hitting even Amoonguss hard thanks to Choice Band. Stone Edge hits Pokemon immune to Ground like Salamence, Moltres, and Galarian Moltres. Close Combat hits Zarude and Chansey harder. Toxic cripples common switch-ins, such as Buzzwole and Tapu Bulu. Lash Out punishes Intimidate Salamence and Krookodile for switching in and Salamence for using Defog. Darkest Lariat hits Rotom-W and Tangrowth harder after Knock Off. Stealth Rock capitalizes on Krookodile's ability to force switches, but it requires near-perfect predictions and should be used only if the role compression is needed. Choice Band gives Krookodile extra power to break through would-be checks like Amoonguss and defensive Kommo-o, notably 2HKOing the former with Earthquake.

Krookodile fits on bulky offense and balance teams, where it acts as a potent wallbreaker and clears the way for late-game sweepers like Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina and Thundurus by removing threats like Amoonguss and Chansey. Due to its frailty, Krookodile loves VoltTurn support from teammates like Jirachi and Mienshao, which can bring it in safely against Pokemon such as Aegislash and Tentacruel to start wreaking havoc. Rotom-H is an especially great teammate, since it can bring in Krookodile with Volt Switch and scares out switch-ins like Tangrowth, Zarude, and Buzzwole. Entry hazard support from allies like Nihilego and Kommo-o is greatly appreciated to weaken checks like Tangrowth. Late-game cleaners like Lycanroc-D and Dragon Dance Salamence appreciate Krookodile weakening checks like Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Buzzwole. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth make great teammates, as they sponge Water-, and Grass-type hits from Pokemon like Keldeo and Zarude, while Krookodile can scare out Salamence and Moltres for them. Krookodile easily beating Galarian Slowbro is appreciated by teammates like Keldeo, Primarina, and Amoonguss, as Assault Vest sets are a major roadblock for them and they can become setup fodder for Calm Mind sets if Choice-locked.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Lead (Dark)
sets.description:
Krookodile is a valuable lead for hyper offensive Dark teams thanks to the massive utility options it has to offer for its teammates, notably Stealth Rock and Taunt. Taunt is used to shut down Defoggers such as Mandibuzz and Mantine as well as slower entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Hippowdon, Toxapex, and Skarmory. Knock Off has the benefit of removing items from bulky threats such as Porygon2, Mandibuzz, and Blissey, making them easier to deal with. Earthquake lets it threaten Pokemon such as Torkoal, Klefki, and Cobalion. It also discourages fast sweepers like Volcarona and Scolipede from safely setting up on it and beating the majority of the team. Intimidate is a fantastic ability, as it weakens problematic foes like Terrakion and Zeraora, which can handle Dark-type teams easily with their STAB and coverage moves. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed slower foes such as Lucario, Kommo-o, and Rotom-C. Focus Sash lets Krookodile set Stealth Rock without getting OHKOed by powerful attacks such as Moonblast from Jirachi or Focus Blast from Alakazam. It's recommended to lead with Krookodile at the start of match, so it can set up Stealth Rock more efficiently with its Focus Sash intact. Magic Bounce users such as Xatu and Hatterene should also be dealt with before attempting to set up Stealth Rock.

Setup sweepers and wallbreakers such as Dragon Dance Tyranitar, Bulk Up Urshifu-S, Hydreigon, and Bisharp appreciate Krookodile's entry hazard support to wear down the opposing team and its ability Intimidate. Taunt is especially useful because it prevents most Pokemon from setting up entry hazards and defensive threats like Toxapex and Corviknight from fully recovering their health. Bisharp can also handle a huge threat in Hatterene, which deflects Stealth Rock with Magic Bounce. Urshifu-S appreciates Stealth Rock damage on opponents, since it can specifically OHKO Zeraora with Sucker Punch and Hatterene with Wicked Blow after a Bulk Up boost. Drapion's part-Poison typing is very useful, as it can set Toxic Spikes and form a hazard-stacking core with Krookodile. Zarude is helpful against troublesome Water-types such as Keldeo and Primarina, as they are both able to use Substitute and force Krookodile to damage them. Krookodile cannot prevent faster leads such as Ribombee, Galvantula, and Cobalion from setting up entry hazards, so Mandibuzz getting rid of them with Defog is appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: With one of the highest Attack stats in LC combined with Hustle, Galarian Darumaka can make a potent Choice Scarf wallbreaker, although Hustle's inaccuracy can make it a double-edged blade. This set capitalizes on its good movepool; Ice Punch is its main STAB move, hitting Flying-types like Vullaby. Superpower OHKOes Munchlax, while Zen Headbutt 2HKOes Mareanie after Stealth Rock. U-turn can put pressure on the opponent and helps maintain momentum. This EV spread allows Galarian Darumaka to hit its maximum Attack; combined with a Choice Scarf, this allows Darumaka to put on pressure right away. Teams that struggle with defensive walls like Ferroseed and Munchlax benefit from Galarian Darumaka's presence, as its power and speed with a Choice Scarf allow it to punch through and pressure defensive teams. However, it takes a hefty amount from Timburr's Mach Punch and can't outspeed Choice Scarf Galarian Farfetch'd. Because of this, teammates that can deal with Fighting-types are useful, like Spritzee and Oddish. Since Darumaka is weak to Stealth Rock, it also appreciates entry hazard control from Pokemon like Vullaby and Drilbur.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description:
The combination of overwhelming strength, Heavy-Duty Boots, and U-turn makes Darmanitan a powerful wallbreaker and reliable pivot in RU. Earthquake hits Fire- and Rock-types like Chandelure, Incineroar, and Diancie in one slot. Rock Slide can be used instead of Earthquake to better deal with Flying-types like Noivern. Toxic allows Darmanitan to wear down bulky Pokemon more easily, especially its common switch-ins like Milotic, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon. Heavy-Duty Boots turns Darmanitan into a hard to wear down pivot, as it doesn't have to worry about entry hazards.

Pokemon such as Cobalion that struggle against bulky Water-types like Seismistoad, Milotic, and Gastrodon appreciate Darmanitan's ability to put them on a timer with Toxic. Powerful wallbreakers like Obstagoon and Toxtricity, on the other hand, appreciate Darmanitan's U-turn support. Other U-turn or Volt Switch users such as Mienshao, Xurkitree, and Raikou are good teammates because they form a potent VoltTurn core with it. These Pokemon can also take advantage of bulky Water- and Rock-types that Darmanitan usually baits onto the battlefield. Metagross, Necrozma, and Roserade can support Darmanitan with their entry hazards to better chip down its typical switch-ins, which may need to continually switch in as Darmanitan comes in and out. Bulky Pokemon like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Milotic give Darmanitan a reliable defensive backbone, as Darmanitan is easily revenge killed by faster threats like Noivern and Mienshao.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Darmanitan is a strong revenge killer and a huge threat in general to offensive teams or teams without a reliable bulky Water- or Rock-type. U-turn allows Darmanitan to keep up momentum, pivot out of disadvantageous matchups, and get a teammate safely onto the field. Sheer Force-boosted Rock Slide deals heavy damage to Flying- and Fire-types such as Noivern, Chandelure, and Incineroar that resist Flare Blitz. Trick allows Darmanitan to cripple a bulky threat or a dangerous bulky setup sweeper like Milotic, Calm Mind Reuniclus, Suicune, or Curse Snorlax if needed. Alternatively, Earthquake can be used to 2HKO Diancie, Tyrantrum, and Dragalge. Superpower hits Snorlax and Rock-types in one slot, but outside of this it does not have very much use.

Xurkitree and Raikou are fantastic partners for Darmanitan, as they form a good VoltTurn core with it, and Darmanitan can also bait bulky Water-types onto the battlefield for them. Strong wallbreakers like Toxtricity, Obstagoon, and Tyrantrum appreciate Darmanitan's ability to get them safely into the battle with U-turn. In return, Darmanitan appreciates their ability to weaken bulky threats for it to clean safely. These Pokemon are also able to beat Curse Snorlax, which is a huge threat to Darmanitan. Strong Fighting-types like Cobalion, Mienshao, and Heracross can beat Snorlax too as well as weaken sturdy Rock-types. Next, because entry hazards punish switches that Darmanitan usually forces, teammates like Metagross, Roserade, and Golisopod are crucial. On the other side, a hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, or Starmie is very crucial too because entry hazards limit Darmanitan's pivoting, and they wear it down too quickly alongside Flare Blitz recoil. A defensive backbone is also important, as Darmanitan can be easily revenge killed by a faster Choice Scarf user like Mienshao and Flygon.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
Life Orb Darmanitan solidifies itself as a huge offensive threat in the metagame thanks to its great ability in Sheer Force and high base Attack stat. Flare Blitz is Darmanitan's strongest physical STAB and Sheer Force-boosted move used to defeat prevalent Pokemon like Aegislash and Corviknight. Will-O-Wisp is crucial for allowing Darmanitan to defeat Pokemon with the ability Sturdy, such as Steelix and Choice Band Avalugg. Taunt helps Darmanitan break stall-oriented Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Type: Null while solidifying its matchup with Yawn Sylveon. Superpower helps Darmanitan deal with Normal- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Porygon-Z and Tyranitar. 8 HP and 52 Defense EVs allow Darmanitan to survive a Adamant Choice Band Steelix's Earthquake after a burn. A Jolly nature with 216 Speed EVs allows Darmanitan to outspeed maximum Speed Choice Specs Porygon-Z. The remaining EVs are invested in Attack to maximize Darmanitan's damage.

Darmanitan's Fire typing leaves it vulnerable to common Water-type Pokemon like Primarina and Rotom-W. As such, teammates with strong Grass-type coverage like Celebi and Rillaboom serve as great teammates for it. Darmanitan in return helps deal with Fairy-type Pokemon the previously listed Pokemon would have trouble with, such as Sylveon and Hatterene. Similarily, Dragon-type Pokemon like Kyurem and Kommo-o also make for great teammates, as they can also counter Water-type Pokemon like Rotom-W and Gastrodon and also appreciate Darmanitan's ability to beat most Fairy-type Pokemon. Fairy-type Pokemon themselves like Gardevoir and Sylveon also value Darmanitan's Fire-type coverage for defeating Steel-type threats like Aegislash and Corviknight. These Fairy-type Pokemon offer Darmanitan support in dealing with Dragon-type Pokemon that Darmanitan would otherwise be vulnerable to, like Dragapult and Kommo-o.

anythinggoes.comments:
Other Options

Galarian Darmanitan can also use a devastatingly strong Choice Band set, limiting its switch-ins to an extremely small handful of Pokemon, but the loss in Speed is very noticeable. Superpower is a decent coverage option to hit Ferrothorn hard without the recoil as well as giving the option of Max Knuckle, but the drops in Attack and Defense make it more committal and less consistent than other options.

Checks and Counters

Kyogre: Defensive Kyogre resists both Icicle Crash and Flare Blitz while not taking much damage from any other coverage move. Repeated U-turns can easily chip it down, and healing damage with Rest leaves it vulnerable, but it is still one of the sturdiest walls to Galarian Darmanitan.

Necrozma-DM: While it doesn't appreciate Flare Blitz, Necrozma-DM can shrug off any other hit and even has a chance to live two Choice Scarf Flare Blitzes. It also accumulates chip damage by switching in with Rocky Helmet.

Chip Damage: Rocky Helmet on Necrozma-DM and Skarmory, Stealth Rock, other hazards, and Flare Blitz recoil can very easily wear down Galarian Darmanitan, especially because it can't stick around for long without switching.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf Calyrex-S as well as Geomancy-boosted Xerneas can outspeed and OHKO Galarian Darmanitan, while priority from Pokemon such as Marshadow and Yveltal exploit its low defensive stats to threaten it.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan is a solidly fast and incredibly strong revenge killer in AG. Icicle Crash can take out neutral Pokemon such as Marshadow and Calyrex-S when chipped while also threatening Eternatus, Zygarde, and Yveltal. U-turn is an easy to spam pivoting option that lets Galarian Darmanitan chip down walls that resist its main coverage, like Kyogre and Necrozma-DM, while creating a more favorable position for its team. Flare Blitz OHKOes Zacian-C, a prime target, while also dealing solid damage to Ferrothorn, Necrozma-DM, and Skarmory. Rock Slide OHKOes defensive Ho-Oh, which can pivot into Galarian Darmanitan and scout what it's locked into otherwise. Earthquake nails Pokemon like Necrozma-DM, Zacian-C, and Eternatus in one move while also hitting Steel-types without the recoil drawback of Flare Blitz. A Jolly nature with maximum Speed and its Choice Scarf allow Galarian Darmanitan to outrun and revenge kill Pokemon such as Zacian-C, +1 Zekrom and Reshiram, and Calyrex-S.

With Galarian Darmanitan's ability to bait in and pressure Necrozma-DM, force out Ground- and Dragon-types, and pivot with U-turn, it is an excellent offensive partner for Zacian-C. Similarly, Zacian-C helps Galarian Darmanitan by pressuring checks to it such as defensive Kyogre and Toxapex with Wild Charge. Zekrom also threatens defensive Water-types and can take advantage of U-turn switch-ins to set up a Dragon Dance. Since Galarian Darmanitan also lacks any kind of defensive utility, common walls such as specially defensive Yveltal, Eternatus, and Zygarde-C also help by switching into wallbreakers it can't OHKO. Specially defensive Yveltal can also safely bring in Galarian Darmanitan with U-turn and provide Defog support, mitigating its weakness to entry hazards. Defensive Necrozma-DM is able to switch into and threaten out Xerneas and Zacian-C, Pokemon that Galarian Darmanitan can't switch into and can only pressure when locked into the right move.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ice)
sets.description:
Galarian Darmanitan's tremendous Attack stat bolstered by its ability Gorilla Tactics, along with its decent Speed and coverage options, allows it to serve as an effective sweeper and revenge killer. Icicle Crash allows it to beat Ground- and Dragon-types like Hippowdon and Dragapult. Flare Blitz provides great coverage for Bug- and Steel-types like Frosmoth and Corviknight. U-turn is a solid option for safely bringing in a teammate on a predicted switch. Superpower allows Galarian Darmanitan to OHKO defensive Pokemon like Tyranitar and Snorlax. However, Earthquake serves as great coverage for Aegislash, Toxapex, and Chandelure. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Galarian Darmanitan to Speed tie with opposing Choice Scarf users like Drapion.

With its great Speed tier and offensive presence, Galarian Darmanitan has the flexibility to function as a late-game sweeper or wallbreaker while also being able to provide its team momentum with U-turn. Entry hazard removers such as Avalugg and Galarian Mr. Mime serve as helpful teammates for keeping Galarian Darmanitan healthy throughout a match. Vanilluxe offers Aurora Veil support to bolster Galarian Darmanitan's survivability, especially against Choice Scarf users that outspeed it such as Gengar as well as priority users like Bisharp and Aegislash, while also being able to break through defensive Water-types like Rotom-W and Toxapex with Freeze-Dry. Piloswine and Mamoswine support Galarian Darmanitan with Stealth Rock, allowing defensive checks such as Galarian Corsola and Rotom-W to be slowly worn down into KO range.

sets.name: Choice Band (Ice)
sets.description:
By virtue of the stacked boosts from Choice Band and Gorilla Tactics onto its already amazing Attack stat, Galarian Darmanitan is an obscenely powerful wallbreaker. Icicle Crash is able to destroy walls that don't resist it, like Clefable, and even frailer Ice-resistant Pokemon on the switch-in, such as Crawdaunt. Fire Punch and Flare Blitz serve as coverage to nail Steel- and Ice-types that resist Icicle Crash; the former one is preferred, as it already OHKOes Corviknight and Ferrothorn without recoil damage. However, the latter scores KOs versus Levitate Bronzong, +1 Corviknight, Mamoswine, and Aegislash after contact with King's Shield. Earthquake nails Toxapex and Torkoal and is Galarian Darmanitan's best way to damage Snorlax. U-turn takes advantage of the number of switches Galarian Darmanitan forces, generating momentum for the team while hitting reasonably hard. A Jolly nature is vital to outrun Kommo-o and tie with other base 95 Speed Pokemon such as Indeedee.

Because this Galarian Darmanitan forgoes the Speed boost from Choice Scarf, it becomes vulnerable to faster Pokemon like Hydreigon and Dragapult. Other Choice Scarf revenge killers that can beat them, like Weavile and Galarian Mr. Mime, are, thus, great partners. Entry hazards are also an issue for Galarian Darmanitan, since they reduce its lifespan greatly, especially if it's running Flare Blitz; therefore, Rapid Spin users such as the aforementioned Galarian Mr. Mime and Avalugg are mandatory teammates. Alolan Ninetales provides Aurora Veil support for Galarian Darmanitan, making it more useful against offensive teams by taking hits better and KOing faster, frailer enemies back. Swords Dance Weavile and Cloyster appreciate Galarian Darmanitan's capability to break walls for a late-game sweep. Froslass, Mamoswine, and Piloswine can lay down Spikes and Stealth Rock, respectively, softening defensive Pokemon like Toxapex for Galarian Darmanitan.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Gorilla Tactics
sets.description:
• Galarian Darmanitan has the highest Attack stat in the format after accounting for Gorilla Tactics, allowing it to hit incredibly hard with relatively high speed without taking an additional penalty from a Choice item.

  • Earthquake is highly recommended, as it's Galarian Darmanitan's best attack against Tapu Fini.

  • U-turn allows Galarian Darmanitan to do substantial chip damage while not locking itself into an attack. Superpower is Galarian Darmanitan's best attack against Rotom-W.

Items

  • Choice Scarf makes Galarian Darmanitan into a good revenge killer, outspeeding prominent foes such as Dragapult and Landorus-T with a Jolly nature.

  • Choice Band makes Galarian Darmanitan more effecitve as a wall breaker, making Earthquake deal over 50% to Bold Tapu Fini.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Galarian Darmanitan is a great wallbreaker with its excellent Attack, ability Gorilla Tactics, good Speed, and wide movepool. Icicle Crash allows Galarian Darmanitan to take care of Dragon- and Flying-type Pokemon such as Goodra and Mandibuzz. Flare Blitz makes Galarian Darmanitan able to take on Corviknight, Chople Berry Ferrothorn, and non-Occa Berry Whimsicott, while Earthquake OHKOes Alolan Marowak, Choice Specs Chandelure, and Aegislash, more reliably than Flare Blitz. Superpower is used to OHKO Chansey, non-Chople Berry variants of Incineroar, Tyranitar, and Snorlax, as well as Steel-types like bulky Choice Specs Duraludon. Giga Impact can be used as a powerful neutral move to beat Sylveon, Dracovish, Gastrodon, and non-Chilan Berry Primarina. Lastly, Stone Edge can be used over Earthquake to be able to OHKO stall Rotom-H. An alternative spread of 8 HP / 96 Atk / 168 Def / 236 Spe can be run in order to survive a Choice Band Rillaboom's Grassy Glide in Grassy Terrain, while still outspeeding base 80 Pokemon, like Mamoswine, at the cost of rolls against Pokemon like Gastrodon. 48 HP / 16 Atk / 244 Def / 200 Spe with a Jolly nature lets you tank a Choice Scarf Iron Head from Excadrill, while outspeeding non-Choice Scarf variants.

Galarian Darmanitan struggles with fast Fire- and Steel-types such as Volcarona and Durant, so Rhyperior, Crustle, and Choice Specs Dragapult make great partners for it. In return, Galarian Damanitan can take care of Corviknight and Aegislash for them. Galarian Darmanitan also struggles with Choice Scarf Dragon-types such as Dracovish and Haxorus, so partners such as Primarina, Galarian Weezing, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon are good to have. In return, Galarian Darmanitan can take on certain stall threats like Type: Null and Snorlax for them. Galarian Darmanitan also needs partners like Galarian Corsola and Conkeldurr that can take on Crustle and Sawk. In return, Galarian Darmanitan beats Pokemon such as Togekiss and Whimsicott.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Galarian Darmanitan is one of the best physical attackers and Choice Scarf users due to its great ability in Gorilla Tactics, great Attack stat, above average Speed stat, and wide movepool. Icicle Crash allows Galarian Darmanitan to beat Dragapult, non-Yache Berry Whimsicott, and Choice Band Haxorus. Flare Blitz allows Galarian Darmanitan to take on Steel-types like Excadrill and Ferrothorn. Superpower lets Galarian Darmanitan beat Tyranitar, while Earthquake allows it to secure the OHKO against most Fire-types such as Chandelure and Alolan Marowak, most of the time. Stone Edge can be used over either Superpower or Earthquake in order to beat Rotom-H while still hitting the aforementioned Fire-types, but its shaky accuracy makes using Earthquake better in general. 8 HP and 180 Defense allows for Galarian Darmanitan to survive a Fishious Rend from non-Adamant Choice Band Dracovish, as well as a Grassy Glide from Choice Band Rillaboom, and an Iron Head from uninvested Corviknight after Flare Blitz recoil, while 224 Speed EVs allows it to outpace Timid or Modest Choice Scarf Porygon-Z, depending on Galarian Darmanitan's chosen nature. Adamant can help out with rolls against bulkier Pokemon like Mandibuzz. An alternative spread of maximum Attack and Speed can be run in order to speed tie other base 95s, while ensuring the best possible rolls against Pokemon like Mandibuzz.

Galarian Darmanitan has trouble with Sturdy users such as Crustle, Avalugg, and Sawk, so partners such as Aromatisse and Choice Band Haxorus pair well with it. In return, Galarian Darmanitan can take on troubling Pokemon such as Dragapult, opposing Choice Band Haxorus, and Whimsicott for them. Galarian Darmanitan also struggles with bulky Pokemon such as King's Shield Aegislash, Corviknight, and Galarian Corsola, so partners such as Choice Specs Hydreigon and Volcarona help with these Pokemon. In return, Galarian Darmanitan can take on Dragapult, Whimsicott, and Excadrill. Galarian Darmanitan also has trouble with faster Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Haxorus and Hydreigon, so having partners such as Togekiss and Conkeludurr can be beneficial. In return, Galarian Darmanitan helps deal with threatening Pokemon like Corviknight.

sets.name: Zen Mode
sets.description:
Endure allows Galarian Darmanitan to reliably activate Zen Mode and its Salac Berry, giving it massive boosts in Speed and Attack as well as a newfound partial Fire typing, notably allowing it to consistently beat other Galarian Darmanitan variants, Hydreigon, Durant, and Haxorus. Icicle Crash and Flare Blitz are Galarian Darmanitan-Z's strongest STAB options and hit threats such as Haxorus, Goodra, Hydreigon, and Dragapult, as well as Ferrothorn, Excadrill, and Durant respectively. The two moves also provide good neutral coverage, as the combination of them is only resisted by Fire- and Water-types, many of which Choiced Galarian Darmanitan struggles with anyway. The last moveslot has a couple of different options: Encore can shut down stallers like Galarian Corsola and physically defensive Corviknight, Reversal can potentially provide a 200-Base Power coverage move to blow away threats like Choice Band Snorlax and Dracovish, Substitute gives Galarian Darmanitan-Z the chance to beat Aegislash, and Earthquake provides a more reliable way to hit Chandelure. 180 Speed EVs ensure that Galarian Darmanitan-Z will outspeed Choice Scarf Gengar, Choice Scarf Durant, and everything slower after transforming into its Zen Mode forme and activating its Salac Berry. 116 Special Defense EVs ensure that Galarian Darmanitan-Z always tanks Choice Scarf Dragapult's Fire Blast. The remaining EVs are placed into Attack with an Adamant nature to maximize Galarian Darmanitan-Z's damage output.

Since this set's main use is as a lure for opposing fast Choice Scarf users such as opposing Galarian Darmanitan, Gengar, and Haxorus, Pokemon that can lure in these threats, like Togekiss, make good partners for Galarian Darmanitan-Z. While Galarian Darmanitan-Z can beat Haxorus and opposing Galarian Darmanitan for Togekiss, Togekiss can in return beat Fighting-types like non-Choice Scarf Sawk and Conkeldurr and walls such as Galarian Corsola. Since Galarian Darmanitan-Z struggles heavily with Sturdy users like Sawk and Crustle, Primarina makes for a good partner; in return, Galarian Darmanitan-Z can beat threats like Venusaur, Diggersby, and Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan. Mandibuzz also acts as a good partner, as it lures in opposing Galarian Darmanitan while beating slower defensive threats that Galarian Darmanitan-Z struggles with, like Steelix, Taunt Whimsicott, and Galarian Corsola. Galarian Darmanitan-Z can cover opposing Galarian Darmanitan as well as Hyper Voice Togekiss in return.

nationaldexmonotype.comments:
Other Options

Ice

Galarian Darmanitan has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Ice

Physically Defensive Walls: While Galarian Darmanitan has amazing damage output, it struggles to get past extremely bulky physical walls such as Galarian Corsola, Mega Slowbro, and Porygon2, especially if it's running Choice Scarf. As a result, they are able to wear it down with their status or attacking moves. However, Choice Band variants of Galarian Darmanitan can 2HKO these walls.

Rotom-W: Rotom-W is an extremely effective check to Galarian Darmanitan; it resists both Icicle Crash and Flare Blitz, is immune to Earthquake due to Levitate, and threatens to wear it down with Hydro Pump or cripple it with Will-O-Wisp.

Status: Burn greatly hinders Galarian Darmanitan's wallbreaking. Paralysis leaves it more easily revenge killed, and Toxic puts it on a timer; both problems are worsened by its fragility and vulnerability to entry hazards.

Priority Moves: Offensive Pokemon carrying priority moves like Rillaboom, Bisharp, and Dragonite can take advantage of Galarian Darmanitan's middling bulk. However, Pokemon carrying weaker priority moves like Zygarde-10% need it to be heavily chipped before attempting to KO it.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan can be promptly OHKOed by faster Choice Scarf users like Blacephalon, Terrakion, Latias, and Nihilego. Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan is outsped and OHKOed by a plethora of offensive threats like Tapu Koko, Mega Lopunny, Mega Aerodactyl, and Hydreigon, so it must be extremely wary of them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ice)
sets.description:
Galarian Darmanitan is one of the best revenge killers on Ice teams due to its amazing coverage moves and generally high Attack stat boosted by Gorilla Tactics, which make it a decent wallbreaker as well. Flare Blitz lets Galarian Darmanitan KO Steel-types such as Celesteela, Aegislash, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight, which are massive threats to Ice teams. Earthquake provides good coverage against Toxapex, Heatran, and Torkoal, which otherwise completely wall Galarian Darmanitan. Earthquake is also useful for SubToxic Aegislash, as it doesn't activate King's Shield, unlike Flare Blitz. U-turn safely brings in a teammate to deal with a check to Galarian Darmanitan like Rotom-W or Galarian Corsola. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature allows Galarian Darmanitan to outspeed foes like Mega Aerodactyl, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Choice Scarf Excadrill. Galarian Darmanitan should be used to clean weakened teams late-game once bulky walls such as Porygon2 and Swampert are severely weakened or removed. Due to its poor bulk and vulnerability to entry hazards, notably Stealth Rock, it should avoid switching in excessively.

Alolan Ninetales is useful in order to deal with bulky Water-types that pressure Galarian Darmanitan such as Tapu Fini, Rotom-W, and Mega Slowbro with Freeze-Dry, as well as Fighting-types like Keldeo. Additionally, it provides valuable support with Aurora Veil. Avalugg is an extremely useful defensive teammate to deal with physical threats that outspeed Galarian Darmanitan such as Choice Scarf Weavile, Mega Swampert in rain, and Barraskewda in rain. It also removes entry hazards for it with Rapid Spin. Defensive Cloyster can also remove entry hazards and provides Spikes and Toxic Spikes support. Choice Specs Kyurem deals with physically defensive walls such as Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Swampert for Galarian Darmanitan due to its power and amazing coverage. Mamoswine is a good offensive partner with Galarian Darmanitan, crippling its usual checks like Galarian Corsola and Porygon2 with Knock Off while acting as a secondary way to deal with Steel teams. It also appreciates Galarian Darmanitan forcing out Steel-types like Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, which Mamoswine needs chip damage on to successfully KO. Piloswine can be used instead as a great wall to deal with Fire-types like Choice Scarf Blacephalon and Volcarona thanks to the combination of Thick Fat and Eviolite. It also provides Stealth Rock support for Galarian Darmanitan while dealing with other special attackers like Tapu Koko, Nihilego, and Alolan Raichu. Choice Scarf Weavile can greatly help in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, dealing with faster Choice Scarf users like Latias, Jirachi, and Blacephalon.

sets.name: Choice Band (Ice)
sets.description:
Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan is one of the most lethal wallbreakers on Ice teams due to its Gorilla Tactics-boosted Attack, allowing it to easily break through types with defensive cores such as Dark, Normal, and Poison. Flare Blitz OHKOes troublesome Steel-types like Celesteela, Aegislash, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory after Stealth Rock damage. Earthquake lets Galarian Darmanitan deal with key targets such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Torkoal. U-turn is useful to bring in teammates safely while maintaining offensive momentum. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature lets Galarian Darmanitan outspeed foes such as Mega Garchomp, Nidoking, and unboosted Kommo-o. Galarian Darmanitan should be used as an early-game wallbreaker to take advantage of types with defensive Pokemon, like Dark, Normal, Poison, and punch holes in the opposing team.

Alolan Ninetales is a great teammate to deal with troublesome Fighting-types such as Mega Gallade, Keldeo, and Urshifu-R for Galarian Darmanitan, as well as Dark-types that outspeed it such as Hydreigon and Choice Scarf Weavile, while providing Aurora Veil support. Avalugg is an amazing defensive partner, as it deals with physical attackers that outspeed and KO Galarian Darmanitan like Zeraora, Mega Aerodactyl, and Mega Swampert while also providing Rapid Spin support. Piloswine is an excellent specially defensive wall that can deal with special Fire-types like Volcarona and Blacephalon due to Thick Fat and Eviolite. It also provides Stealth Rock support and deals with additional special attackers that outspeed and threaten Galarian Darmanitan like Latios, Hydreigon, and Thundurus-T. Choice Specs Kyurem can defeat extremely bulky physical walls for Galarian Darmanitan like Galarian Corsola and Porygon2, easing pressure off of it. It also breaks through bulky Water-types like Swampert, Mega Slowbro, and Rotom-W with Freeze-Dry. Choice Scarf Weavile deals with threatening Ghost- and Psychic-types like Gengar, Latias, and Latios.

lc.overview: With access to Stealth Rock and Spikes, along with the ability to beat the tier's most common Defogger, Dwebble is one of the leading entry hazard stackers in the tier. Shell Smash coupled with a decent Attack stat also allows it to become a dangerous sweeper; these two sets require significantly different counterplay, which can trip an unprepared opponent up. Sturdy gives Dwebble opportunities to set entry hazards or use Shell Smash. However, its mediocre defensive typing gives it very few resistances, and its reliance on its item leaves it susceptible to Knock Off. Additionally, it faces competition from Ferroseed, which can also set the same entry hazards while offering more defensive utility, although it lacks the offensive presence that Dwebble's Shell Smash set provides. It also faces competition from Onix, which is faster and has a better offensive typing. Onix can run Sturdy sets too, though it tends not to, leaving Dwebble as the tier's best Sturdy user.
lc.comments:
Other Options

A Weak Armor set can be run with a spread of 36 HP / 156 Atk / 76 Def / 236 Spe alongside a Jolly nature and Eviolite. This functions similarly to the suicide lead set, but it finds it easier to set hazards against Knock Off users while being able to check Vullaby. Dwebble can choose to run a Bug-type STAB move; this offers no meaningful coverage, however. The Shell Smash set can run Aerial Ace to hit Timburr and Mienfoo, but this still doesn't KO them at +2 and generally isn’t worthwhile.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: While Timburr and Mienfoo don't like getting hit by Knock Off, they can counter all Dwebble sets - Eviolite sets survive any move from Dwebble even at +2. Timburr is particularly threatening, as it can heal back up with Drain Punch, remove entry hazards with Defog, and KO Dwebble with priority Mach Punch. Mienfoo can break its Sturdy with Fake Out and then KO Dwebble with High Jump Kick.

Water-types: Staryu is able to remove Dwebble's entry hazards with Rapid Spin, gaining a Speed boost while doing so, while taking any hit from the Shell Smash set and OHKO it in return. Corphish has access to Knock Off and Aqua Jet, allowing it to easily beat Dwebble one-on-one.

Multi-hit moves: Multi-hit moves hinder all Dwebble sets, as they can break through Sturdy and potentially OHKO it. Onix with Rock Blast is particularly threatening, as it outspeeds Dwebble and hits it super effectively.

Ground-types: Ground-types are threatening, since Dwebble lacks the coverage to hit them super effectively. Mudbray is particularly threatening because it gains Defense boosts from each hit.

Ferroseed: Ferroseed can take any hit from the Shell Smash set, even at +2, and use Knock Off and Thunder Wave to hinder both Dwebble sets.

Grookey: While it is unable to switch directly into Dwebble, Grookey can revenge kill Dwebble with Grassy Glide.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
Moves

Stealth Rock damages and wears down every Pokemon in the metagame. Spikes is useful to damage all grounded foes. Knock Off allows Dwebble to remove the foe's item to help its teammates. Counter can be used to OHKO a physical foe such as Timburr if it chooses to attack. Rock Blast is a terrifying multi-hit STAB attack, threatening to OHKO foes like Berry Juice Vullaby and frail threats like Abra and Dewpider that have a Focus Sash. Alternatively, Earthquake can be used to deal more damage to Rock-resistant foes.

Set Details

Maximum EVs and a Speed-boosting nature are used to get out as many entry hazards as possible before being KOed. Maximum Attack is used because Dwebble relies on Sturdy and Berry Juice for longevity, meaning it has no need for defensive investment. There are enough remaining EVs to increase its HP stat, but this is avoided so that Berry Juice is guaranteed to fully restore its health and reactivate Sturdy. Sturdy guarantees that Dwebble can take a hit from full HP, giving it an extra turn to set entry hazards. Another option is to run a Hasty nature with 0 Defense IVs, which allows Dwebble to OHKO Timburr and offensive Mienfoo with Counter if they use Knock Off.

Usage Tips

As the name of this set indicates, Dwebble is used as a lead. The main objective of this set is to put up multiple entry hazards before being KOed. However, preserving Dwebble can be advantageous in some situations where it can be sacrificed later in the game to provide offensive momentum. Typically, Dwebble will rarely be using its offensive moves, since the utility of stacking entry hazards is preferable to the utility of Knock Off or other offensive moves.

Team Options

Offensive teams benefit most from Dwebble, as they can pressure the opponent and make it difficult for them to find an opportunity to remove entry hazards. Setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Scraggy and Nasty Plot Vullaby appreciate entry hazards breaking Sturdy on their foes and wearing down their checks. Pawniard can punish Defog with Defiant and therefore makes for a good partner. Frillish is immune to Rapid Spin and is able to switch in against the most prominent user of the move, Staryu, making it a good pick on entry hazard-stacking teams. Having a Rapid Spin user on the team is useful for removing entry hazards from your side of the field. Offensive threats such as Grookey, Abra, and Choice Scarf Mienfoo appreciate hazard support, as it helps to put their checks in range of an OHKO.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

Shell Smash raises Dwebble's Attack and Speed by 2 stages, drastically increasing its power and allowing it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. Rock Blast is generally the preferred STAB move, as it is the most accurate Rock-type move with good power and will often hit at least as hard as Rock Slide due to Little Cup's low HP totals. It also breaks through Focus Sash and Sturdy users. Alternatively, Stone Edge can be chosen for more consistent damage, if it hits, and to bypass Berry Juice on foes like Weak Armor Vullaby. Earthquake is Dwebble's best coverage move, hitting the Rock-resistant Pawniard and Onix super effectively, and it gets a neutral hit against other foes like Timburr and Mudbray. Knock Off provides good neutral coverage, with the utility of removing the foe's Eviolite and weakening them. Counter and Stealth Rock are niche alternative moves.

Set Details

Maximum Attack EVs and an Attack-boosting nature are used to optimize Dwebble's sweeping power. Maximum Speed EVs allow Dwebble to outspeed the entire metagame after a Shell Smash boost, only tying with the rare Choice Scarf Diglett. There is no HP investment to ensure that Berry Juice reactivates Sturdy. Sturdy guarantees that Dwebbles survives one hit when at full health, allowing it to take a hit while setting up. Berry Juice restores its HP to full, which reduces Dwebble’s susceptibility to being picked off by weak priority moves.

Usage Tips

Try to avoid switching Dwebble into entry hazards at all costs, since this will stop Sturdy from activating and will prevent a safe setup with Shell Smash. Avoid being hit by Knock Off as well, since Dwebble's item is important to give it setup opportunities. Dwebble should be used as a late-game sweeper, setting up when its checks are sufficiently weakened. Try to bring Dwebble in on a free switch, such as after a Pokemon has fainted or via a slow U-turn, so it doesn't lose its Berry Juice early by switching into an attack. Weaken or remove bulky Pokemon like Mudbray, Spritzee, and Timburr before attempting to sweep with Dwebble, because they can take even a boosted hit and retaliate for lots of damage. Try to remove priority move users, as they can easily pick off Dwebble after its defenses are lowered by Shell Smash. With Sturdy intact, Dwebble can also act as a countermeasure for opposing sweepers that don't have multi-hit moves.

Team Options

Entry hazards from Pokemon like Ferroseed and Pawniard wear down opposing Pokemon, allowing Dwebble to KO more foes. A teammate that provides entry hazard removal such as Staryu, Defog Timburr, or Vullaby, is essential for helping to preserve Dwebble's Sturdy. Pokemon that can bring Dwebble in safely like U-turn Mienfoo and Vullaby are good partners. Pokemon like Giga Drain Ferroseed and Staryu that deal with bulky Ground-types are helpful. Mareanie and Spritzee are good team choices as well because they can deal with Timburr. Trappers such as Diglett and Wynaut help Dwebble by removing or weakening its defensive checks. Knock Off support from Pokemon like Timburr and Mareanie is appreciated, since very few Pokemon will be able to take Dwebble's boosted moves without an Eviolite.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Rock Tomb over Stone Edge with a Jolly nature is beneficial for getting an edge against faster Taunt users like Golbat and Electabuzz, as Dwebble chips them down and outspeeds afterwards, but it comes at the cost of losing a strong STAB attack. Weak Armor with Focus Sash provides more Speed so that Dwebble has a better matchup against some leads like Raboot and Fake Out Pikachu, but the lack of an Eviolite combined with the Defense drop makes Dwebble less reliable for setting entry hazards against Pokemon like Clefairy and Piloswine.

Checks and Counters

Gurdurr: By resisting both of Dwebble's attacks, using Defog to clear entry hazards, and stopping Shell Smash sweeps with Mach Punch, Gurdurr is a consistent counter to Dwebble. Dwebble's best bet is to be paired with sweepers that require Gurdurr's Eviolite removed to sweep, or else it will be squandered versus it.

Special Attackers: Dwebble's special bulk is unsalvageable, and practically any offensive special attacker can 2HKO it. However, thanks to Sturdy, frailer attackers like Galarian Mr. Mime and Magmar fear Shell Smash and Stone Edge.

Water-types: Wartortle stomachs Dwebble's attacks while hitting back hard, and after Sturdy activates, it uses Rapid Spin to remove any entry hazards. Mareanie and Marshtomp threaten with Scald, but they may lose their Eviolite in the process.

Bulky Leads: Bulkier Pokemon like Tangela and Gabite are able to take on Dwebble, although they could be annoyed by Knock Off and are unable to prevent Dwebble's first entry hazard attempt. Piloswine and Thwackey apply here as well, and they also have strong priority to punish Shell Smash.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description:
Dwebble can set entry hazards and apply pressure against Defog users and Magic Bounce Pokemon, namely Vullaby, Golbat, and Hattrem. It can set both Stealth Rock and Spikes for early-game pressure against other common leads like Piloswine, Clefairy, and Charjabug. Shell Smash gives Dwebble an opportunity to put a large dent into the opposing team while outspeeding faster special attackers like Electabuzz and Gastly.

Use Dwebble as a lead to set entry hazards immediately or boost with Shell Smash for early momentum. Entry hazards are usually more worthwhile when Dwebble faces Electabuzz, as its strong Volt Switch into a priority user like Gurdurr or Thwackey would invalidate its wallbreaking attempts. Spinblockers like Drakloak and Lampent are good teammates for Dwebble, since they can prevent its entry hazards from being removed, while Pokemon like Electabuzz and Taunt Golbat pressure Defog users. Setup sweepers like Klang and Fraxure appreciate the chip damage to wear down their checks. Other offensive Pokemon such as Raboot, Thwackey, and Magmar pair well with Dwebble, since they can provide momentum after entry hazards have been set down, while Dwebble can weaken walls such as Galarian Corsola, Tangela, and Ferroseed.

sets.name: Shell Smash Offense
sets.description:
Crustle serves as one of the best Sturdy users in the 1v1 metagame. Crustle's access to the offensively strong Rock typing, alongside a powerful move in Rock Wrecker and utility options in Rock Blast and Shell Smash, gives it the potential to be one of the most powerful setup attackers in the metagame, utterly destroying nearly anything that does not resist Rock Wrecker, like Hydreigon, Aromatisse, and Snorlax, after a Shell Smash. Counter is incredibly useful for some physical attackers as well; Choice Scarf Dracovish and Dracozolt will beat Crustle if it uses Shell Smash, but will fall after being hit by Counter, as Crustle will always survive their attacks. Golisopod can also sometimes survive a Rock Wrecker from Crustle and is unsafe to set up against, but Crustle will still win by using Counter turn one by either KOing Golisopod or putting it in range of a Rock Wrecker. Crustle runs 128 HP and 20 Defense EVs in order to survive a Choice Band Iron Tail from Haxorus, as well as maximizing HP in order to get Choice Band Snorlax into Rock Wrecker range after a Counter. 164 Speed is run in order to outspeed Rock Tomb Dracovish after a Shell Smash. Lum Berry can be used to threaten Yawn Sylveon and Stall Rotom-A, whereas Mental Herb is very helpful against Taunt users like Haxorus and Whimsicott, both ensuring Crustle can set up with Shell Smash and threaten offensively.

Crustle works well with frailer threats that need Sturdy support in order to beat the Pokemon they cannot threaten offensively. Pokemon like Dracovish, Dragapult, Galarian Darmanitan, and Dracozolt all appreciate Crustle's ability to tank hits from offensive threats like Choice Scarf Haxorus, non-Quick Attack Sylveon, and all of their ditto matchups. In return, these offensive powerhouses generally have a good matchup against the bulky stall Pokemon that can beat Crustle, like Corviknight and Arcanine. Crustle appreciates Pokemon that can also beat Steel-type Pokemon, that can generally survive any one attack Crustle can go for, even after a Shell Smash—Pokemon like Aegislash, Duraladon, Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Bisharp can usually handle Crustle, although the physical Steel-types need to watch out for Counter. Therefore, Fire- and Fighting-types like Arcanine, Sawk, and Conkeldurr will be great partners for Crustle, as they can generally handle these Steel-type threats.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Crustle earns its place as one of the best threats in the 1v1 tier, being able to always beat non-Substitute Primarina, Zeraora, and Porygon-Z with its powerful Choice Band-boosted Rock Wrecker. Rock Blast, though relying on rolls for some of its matchups, will always take down Volcarona and FEAR Togedemaru, and can potentially take down opposing Shell Smash Crustle. Earthquake helps Crustle against non-Air Balloon Aegislash and Choice Band Steelix. Counter allows Crustle to take down Choice item threats like Urshifu-S, Dracovish, and Conkeldurr that would normally 2HKO Crustle and take one of its hits. Heavy Slam alternatively helps Crustle beat non-Babiri Berry Sylveon and Whimsicott more reliably. The given spread allows for Crustle to always survive the rare Choice Band-boosted Iron Tail from Mold Breaker Haxorus and KO them back with Rock Wrecker. 29 Speed IVs and a Brave nature allow Crustle to underspeed Aegislash and OHKO non-Air Balloon Blade forme variants. The rest of the EVs are invested into Attack to maximize Crustle's damage output, which helps it get the best roll against Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Dracovish, and Aromatisse.

Stall Arcanine is an exception to the Fire-type Pokemon that Crustle can normally beat, since it can use Burn Up to lose its Fire typing and then stall you out with the combination of Will-O-Wisp and Morning Sun. Life Orb Salazzle is another exception due to it being able to bypass Sturdy with Fake Out and then almost always OHKO Crustle with Overheat. Pixie Plate Sylveon is an exceptional partner for Crustle due to it being able to break through a lot of Pokemon that Crustle normally can't beat, like stall and Sturdy users, while also generally beating a lot of Pokemon that resist Crustle's attacks. Pokemon that Sylveon can cover for Crustle include Dragapult, Urshifu-R, stall Azumarill, Rotom-W, Galarian Corsola, and Sawk, among other threats. Assault Vest Primarina is another Fairy-type that can be used as a teammate, able to take out threats such as Arcanine, Salazzle, and Skarmory, though it is more prone to stall Pokemon. Crustle in return can defeat Pokemon that Primarina and Sylveon struggle against such as Galarian Darmanitan, Zeraora, and Dracozolt.

lc.overview: With a diverse movepool, a decent stat spread, and a great offensive typing, Scraggy is a strong offensive threat in LC. Its unique typing gives it access to STAB on strong moves such as High Jump Kick, Knock Off, and Drain Punch. Its access to Knock Off also allows it to support other teammates by removing items from opposing Pokemon and helps it sweep with powerful moves such as High Jump Kick, while coverage moves help it break through its checks. Its solid bulk gives it opportunities to set up with Dragon Dance and be a potent sweeper. Scraggy also has the option of two abilities to help it sweep: Moxie allows it to become stronger every time it KOes a foe, while Shed Skin allows it to set up on status inducers. Unfortunately, Scraggy's typing leaves it very weak to Fairy-types and common Flying- and Fighting-types. Additionally, Scraggy must pick between its potential coverage moves, leaving it walled by one of its checks. Lastly, Scraggy lacks immediate power and needs support to break through its checks despite its coverage options.
lc.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Scarf set can be run with Moxie to form a potent sweeper, but it struggles to break through its checks due to its lack of immediate damage. Poison Jab can be used to hit Morelull and Cottonee harder, but the flinches from Iron Head are generally more useful. An Intimidate support set can be run to set up on physical attackers, particularly Onix, but it misses out on the sweeping potential that Scraggy has. Alternatively, Bulk Up can be run in tandem with Dragon Dance and Drain Punch to form a bulky sweeper with decent recovery.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Spritzee resists both of Scraggy's STAB moves and OHKOes it in return. Nasty Plot Spritzee sets can be broken through more easily, however. It should also be wary of Iron Head and Poison Jab.

Poison-types: Oddish and Mareanie resist Scraggy's Fighting STAB attacks and do not take much damage from Knock Off. Oddish uses Strength Sap to prevent Scraggy setting up, and Mareanie can cripple it with Scald burns. Both should be wary of Zen Headbutt.

Fighting-types: Croagunk, Timburr, and Galarian Farfetch'd can take an attack from Scraggy and OHKO in return with a Fighting-type STAB move. Croagunk and Timburr also have strong priority in Vacuum Wave and Mach Punch, respectively.

Faster Choice Scarf Users: Faster Choice Scarf users such as Galarian Farfetch'd outspeed and KO Scraggy.

sets.name: Dragon Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

Dragon Dance allows Scraggy to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, reaching 21 Speed, and break through foes it wouldn't be able to otherwise. High Jump Kick is a powerful STAB attack used for breaking through neutral targets. For example, +1 High Jump Kick OHKOes most Berry Juice Vullaby sets after Stealth Rock damage. However, Drain Punch can be used for its recovery and to avoid taking damage from misses. Knock Off hits Ghost- and Psychic-types that resist Scraggy's Fighting STAB attack, with the extra utility of removing the target's item. Iron Head is used for hitting Fairy-types like Spritzee, while Zen Headbutt is an option for hitting Fighting- and Poison-types such as Croagunk, Oddish, and Mareanie.

Set Details

This set has Speed and Attack maximized to help its sweeping ability, with an Adamant ability to improve the damage rolls on defensive foes such as Eviolite Spritzee. Berry Juice helps Scraggy set up on defensive Pokemon that lack the ability to OHKO it, such as Mareanie and Ferroseed. Alternatively, Eviolite can be used so that Scraggy can set up on more offensive foes such as Pawniard and Onix. If you're running Berry Juice, the remaining EVs should be invested in HP for extra mixed bulk; they should be invested in Defense or Special Defense if using Eviolite so that the benefit of Eviolite can be maximized. Moxie is preferred as the ability for its greater sweeping potential, with the drawback being that it gives Scraggy a harder time setting up compared to Shed Skin. Alternatively, Shed Skin allows Scraggy to absorb status ailments, most notably burns, giving it a good chance of shaking the status off while setting up on Pokemon such as Mareanie and Ponyta.

Usage Tips

Scraggy is best used as a late-game sweeper and should set up when its checks are suitably weakened. It should try to set up on Dark-types such as Pawniard, Rock-types such as Onix, or Steel-types such as Ferroseed. These are all threatened by Scraggy's Fighting STAB moves and struggle to OHKO it even without Eviolite. If Shed Skin is being used, set up on status users such as Mareanie and Ferroseed. Try to use Knock Off early- and mid-game on Scraggy's checks to make a late-game sweep easier to achieve. Avoid letting Scraggy accrue too much damage prior to setting up so that it is less vulnerable to priority moves. Scraggy will struggle to sweep if its checks are insufficiently worn down. Spritzee and Timburr are particularly threatening, since Scraggy struggles to break through the former even with Iron Head, while the latter threatens it with Mach Punch.

Team Options

Knock Off users such as Vullaby make good partners by making opposing Pokemon easier for Scraggy to break when set up. Dual screens users like Natu can give Scraggy multiple setup opportunities in the same match and also leave it less susceptible to priority moves. Scraggy can be used in a core stacking Fighting-types with Timburr or Galarian Farfetch'd, since they have access to Knock Off and useful coverage moves for wearing down their shared checks. Pivots such as Vullaby and Chinchou provide good support by safely bringing Scraggy in, either by slow pivoting or by using their pivot move on a predicted switch. Entry hazard removers such as Timburr and Vullaby are useful, since Scraggy struggles to sweep with Sticky Web present, and removing layers of Spikes helps keep Scraggy out of range of priority attacks. Diglett can use Memento to give Scraggy a good setup opportunity while also being able to trap key threats. Pokemon that can pressure Spritzee and Timburr, such as Mareanie and Oddish, also make great teammates.

pu.overview: Scrafty can be run as an either bulky or fast setup sweeper, sporting both Bulk Up and Dragon Dance. Its solid bulk and defensive typing give it various opportunities to switch in against and set up on Pokemon such as Weezing and Palossand. However, this same typing also gives it weaknesses to common types such as Fairy and Fighting, which are often run as coverage on Pokemon Scrafty wants to check such as Mesprit and Absol. Scrafty's typing also has its ups and downs offensively, as it is able to hit most of the tier neutrally, but Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy completely wall it if it is not running coverage. While Scrafty's defenses are good, its Attack is underwhelming without boosts and its Speed is very mediocre, with it still being outsped even at +1 by Pokemon such as Ribombee and Whimsicott.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: This set allows Scrafty to serve as a special sponge that can soft check special attackers such as Rotom, which it can use as setup fodder. This pairs well with Bulk Up because, after setting up, Scrafty can take both physical and special hits, ideally allowing it to slowly break through the opponent's remaining Pokemon. This is furthered by its combination of Rest and Shed Skin, which makes Scrafty harder to wear down and cripple with status conditions, although Shed Skin can be unreliable at times. Drain Punch also helps keep Scrafty healthy, while Knock Off does decent damage while crippling Pokemon that may depend on their items such as Ribombee and Choice Scarf Passimian. Scrafty prefers to start setting up after threats to it such as Passimian and Aromatisse have been taken out, so Pokemon that can help against those such as Uxie, Togedemaru, and Rotom make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance gives Scrafty a greater offensive presence, with Moxie giving it an easier time sweeping and maximum Speed with a Jolly nature allowing it to outspeed base 110 Speed Pokemon after one Dragon Dance. Close Combat serves as its powerful STAB move, although High Jump Kick is slightly more powerful and has no defense drops in exchange for considerably more risk. Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse. Lum Berry gives Scrafty one-time protection from status conditions that would otherwise make it much harder to sweep, but Chople Berry can instead be used to take moves such as Close Combat from Choice Scarf Passimian, which still outspeeds +1 Scrafty, and Hitmontop's Mach Punch. Shed Skin can be run if using a Chople Berry so Scrafty can still set up against status inflicting Pokemon like Jellicent. Good teammates are Pokemon that can help against faster threats such as Ribombee and the previously mentioned Choice Scarf Passimian. Both Silvally-Fairy and Silvally-Steel make for good teammates, as they can check these threats and bring Scrafty onto the field with Parting Shot. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Vikavolt can weaken bulky Pokemon such as Weezing and Aromatisse, making it easier for Scrafty to clean up the match.

sets.name: Life Orb Attacker
sets.description:
With its decent Speed and movepool options, Sigilyph is able to be used as either an offensive Calm Mind wallbreaker or Defogger that is able to exert offensive pressure. Additionally, with its Magic Guard ability, it isn't hindered by status such as poison and burn, which improves its capability to break through bulky Pokemon that utilize status moves such as Milotic and Registeel. Heat Wave allows Sigilyph to hit Steel-types such as Steelix, Registeel, and Metagross that would wall Sigilyph otherwise. Calm Mind allows Sigilyph to leverage its offensive presence and break through bulkier opposition. Defog, on the other hand, can be utilized on teams that have sufficient wallbreaking power but are weak to entry hazards, leveraging its good matchup versus common hazard setters in the tier such as Steelix and Roserade. Air Slash is an alternative that can be considered over Psychic to hit Incineroar, which walls this entire set otherwise. However, this would miss out on hitting key targets such as Diancie, Raikou, and Toxtricity. If running Calm Mind, Psyshock can be used over Psychic to have the edge in Calm Mind wars against Suicune. When running Defog, Energy Ball can be opted for over Heat Wave, which gives it a better matchup against Diancie and Seismitoad, although it would miss out on hitting Steel-types.

Sigilyph fits best on offensive and balanced team structures. Wallbreakers like Bewear and Sharpedo that are able to beat out or heavily weaken specially defensive Pokemon such as Umbreon, Snorlax, and Incineroar complement Sigilyph nicely. In return, Sigilyph is able to help weaken bulky Pokemon, such as Milotic and Togekiss without Thunder Wave, that check said wallbreakers. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Snorlax and Ground-types such as Seismitoad, Steelix, and Flygon can all be good partners, as they help answer threatening Electric-types such as Raikou and Xurkitree. Sigilyph's ability to repeatedly beat down and keep entry hazards off the field against Steel-types such as Steelix and Registeel is valued by offensive Pokemon such as Calm Mind Raikou, Choice Scarf Gardevoir, and Xurkitree, as well as defensive Pokemon like Porygon2 and Snorlax.

pu.overview: Cofagrigus sets itself apart from other Ghost-types through its useful supportive and defensive capabilities. Because of its access to Toxic Spikes, Cofagrigus can aid its teammates by wearing down their checks while doing the same to its own checks, such as Palossand and Jellicent. Its Ghost typing and bulk are useful for denying Rapid Spin from Pokemon such as Tsareena and Hitmontop, and Iron Defense + Body Press pressures Defoggers such as Silvally-Steel. This combination of moves is also useful late-game once Cofagrigus's checks have been worn down, making it a valuable asset throughout a game. However, Cofagrigus has a serious lack of reliable recovery and is forced to rely on Rest, rendering it setup fodder for Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee. It also has lackluster Special Defense, which lets wallbreakers such as Vikavolt and Magmortar easily pierce through it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Shadow Ball is an interesting alternative over Toxic Spikes to hit Ghost-types, which otherwise wall Cofagrigus. Notably, this includes Rotom, Heavy-Duty Boots Froslass, and opposing Cofagrigus, which are not heavily impacted by Toxic Spikes. However, the supportive capabilities of Toxic Spikes are generally preferred due to these Pokemon being uncommon, and Toxic Spikes is more useful during the early- and mid-game stages. Despite Chesto Berry usually being run to give Cofagrigus a one-time instant recovery option alongside Rest, running no item makes it harder to pressure with Poltergeist and Knock Off users such as Froslass, Gourgeist-S, and Passimian. The Speed investment lets it outspeed Galarian Stunfisk, and the remaining EVs combined with a Bold nature bolster Cofagrigus's physical bulk, which improves its durability and the damage output of Body Press. Alternatively, a specially defensive spread of 248 HP / 240 SpD / 20 Spe with a Calm nature allows it to take special hits better at the cost of its physical bulk and attacking power.
