Chandelure beats Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and some variants pressure Chansey for Primarina. Thundurus hits Water-types such as Tentacruel and Volcanion, can bring it in safely with U-turn, and potentially remove key items like Assault Vest from Tangrowth and Eviolite from Chansey. Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Krookodile handle Electric-types like Thundurus-T and set Stealth Rock up to help Primarina wallbreak. Chansey walls Primarina effortlessly, so Fighting-types such as Buzzwole and Kommo-o can be used to threaten it. Primarina can be easily worn down by entry hazards, so a Wish passer like Jirachi can help it stay in the match for longer. In the same vein, entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H extend Primarina's longevity.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
Thanks to its bulk, Primarina continuously checks threats such as Keldeo and Salamence by healing itself with Rest while taking advantage of its excellent STAB combination with Sleep Talk. Rest allows it to not be ruined by status such as Toxic from Aegislash and Buzzwole. Moonblast is great neutral coverage while also proving super effective damage on Kommo-o and Galarian Moltres. Scald allows Primarina to get a burn on switch-ins like Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Tentacruel, negating the recovery from Leftovers and Black Sludge. 124 Special Defense EVs and Leftovers allow Primarina avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball and 3HKO from Salamence's Hurricane from full HP without Stealth Rock, with the rest put into Defense to take on Dragon Dance Salamence and Keldeo's Secret Sword better. Leftovers is great, as it synergizes well with Rest + Sleep Talk, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to negate damage from entry hazards if the team has unreliable or no hazard removal.

RestTalk Primarina is mainly used on bulky teams that appreciate a status sponge and value the defensive qualities its typing provides. Necrozma is an excellent partner, as it can threaten Amoonguss and Tentacruel, that would otherwise counter Primarina. Zarude checks Rotom-W and Chansey while appreciating Primarina checking Keldeo and Kommo-o. Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Moltres can help check Grass-types such as Zarude and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and provide momentum with Volt Switch and U-turn. Hazard control is important for Primarina to not be chipped down easily and forced to use Rest if it is running Leftovers. Salamence removes entry hazards with Defog and checks Zarude well. Kommo-o, Rhyperior, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all form solid defensive cores with Primarina, as they are able to check Pokemon such as Volcanion, Thundurus, and Rotom-W nicely, while Primarina checks Salamence, Keldeo, and Moltres in return.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Substitute lets Primarina avoid sleep- and poison-inducing moves, which would otherwise cripple it and prevent it from sweeping with Calm Mind. Common checks like Amoonguss can't deal with Primarina if it uses Substitute as they come in, as Primarina is faster and can set up with Calm Mind. Substitute also eases prediction when forcing switches from Pokemon like Salamence and Kommo-o. Draining Kiss aids Primarina in recovering HP, allowing it to take more hits and use Substitute if needed. However, Draining Kiss is a very weak move and will only pose a threat to many Pokemon if Primarina has accumulated enough boosts. Moonblast, on the other hand, is powerful from the start and lets Primarina not rely too much on Calm Mind boosts to threaten Water-resistant Pokemon like Tangrowth and Rotom-W. Scald is a reliable Water-type move, capable of burning Pokemon trying to check it, like Tentacruel, Assault Vest Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Leftovers compensates the 25% loss in HP from Substitute. With the given EV spread Primarina is able to beat Amoonguss one-on-one, as it ensures Amoonguss can't break Primarina's Substitute after a Calm Mind. A faster spread with 136 Speed EVs can be used to outspeed Conkeldurr but it will require two Calm Mind's for Amoonguss to not break its Substitute, leading to Spore mindgames.

Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as its ability to come in on moves like Draco Meteor from Salamence is greatly appreciated by other teammates. By switching on these moves, Primarina can either get a Substitute up or set up with Calm Mind if its checks have been eliminated or weakened. Strong wallbreakers like Mamoswine, Nidoking, and Aegislash can get past bulky Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Electric-types such as Raikou and Thundurus force Primarina out of the field if it doesn't have a Substitute up, so Pokemon like Rhyperior and Seismitoad take care of them. They can also set Stealth Rock to aid Primarina in its sweep. Amoonguss and Buzzwole can take on strong physical attackers such as Diggersby and Mamoswine for Primarina. Chansey is extremely annoying, as it can take boosted hits with ease and threaten Primarina back with Toxic and Seismic Toss. Conkeldurr, Lycanroc-D, and Swords Dance Diggersby are powerful wallbreakers that can muscle through Chansey and remove it for Primarina.

sets.name: Defensive Calm Mind (Water)
sets.description:
Primarina performs the role of a bulky sweeper with Calm Mind for Water-type teams. Its Fairy typing is fantastic defensively, as it allows it to take on Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-type Pokemon for the team. With Calm Mind increasing its Special Attack and Special Defense, Primarina can threaten and steamroll through opposing teams late-game while also improving the team's matchup against the aforementioned types. Calm Mind also lets it take hits from Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Duraludon, and Dragapult better. Rest is Primarina's main form of recovery and also cures it of any status condition like Toxic that may hamper its sweep. Sleep Talk is used to ensure that Primarina is not completely passive during Rest turns. Moonblast lets Primarina deal with Dragon-, Dark-, and Fighting-type Pokemon like Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Keldeo by hitting them for super effective damage and allows Primarina to perform well against matchups like Psychic-, and Ice-type teams. Primarina should prioritize attacking more to weaken the team early-game, as such types cannot take repeated Moonblast from Primarina very well. Against types like Normal and Ice, Primarina should set up against Pokemon like Bewear and Avalugg. Maximum HP and Defense investment along with a Bold nature makes Primarina as bulky as possible, allowing it to tank unboosted attacks from Pokemon like Bisharp and Grimmsnarl.

Water-types like Toxapex appreciate Primarina taking on troublesome Dragon-type Pokemon like Hydreigon and Dragapult for the team. In return, Toxapex provides Primarina with a defensive pivot against Grass-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Virizion. Toxapex can not only spread Scald burns, which makes it easier for Primarina to set up on and beat Pokemon like Drapion and Kyurem-B, but also provide Toxic or Toxic Spikes support to wear down teams, which lets Primarina be a more effective wincon in general. Seismitoad provides an essential immunity against Electric-type attacks and provides Stealth Rock support for Primarina to score easier KOs after setting up. Gastrodon can also be used as a bulkier teammate and for an additional Electric-type immunity. Keldeo does a great job of handling Ice- and Steel-type teams, beating Pokemon such as Kyurem and Ferrothorn. Crawdaunt and Barraskewda can also wallbreak and beat Jirachi and Toxapex for Primarina. Pokemon like Cloyster and Pelipper can take care of the Grass-type matchup , with the former additionally aiding Primarina to pressure Dragon-type teams even more and the latter breaking Pokemon like Toxapex and Ferrothorn with Choice Specs-boosted Hurricane.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Primarina is usually severely overshadowed by Tapu Fini, but Primarina does offer some small advantages, such as a much higher Special Attack stat, Grass-type coverage, and being able to pick off Focus Sash Pokemon with Aqua Jet.

Items

  • Assault Vest is the most common item on offensive Primarina to take advantage of its good special bulk.

  • Choice Specs is still viable for offering a lot of firepower, especially compared to Tapu Fini.

  • Focus Sash lets Primarina take advantage of Torrent more easily, and lets it deal massive damage to Pokemon it'd normally be KOed by.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 28 Def / 228 SpA: This spread maximizes special attack and bulk, and always takes a Choice Band Urshifu Thunder Punch.

  • 4 Atk / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: This spread is viable with more offensive items, especially Focus Sash.

  • 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 SpA: This spread gives Primarina the ability to always survive Max Lightning from Urshifu formes.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Primarina's solid defensive stats paired with an Assault Vest allow it to take hits from even the strongest special attackers in the 1v1 tier, such as Porygon-Z, Sylveon, and offensive Rotom-H. Moonblast hits Dragon-types like Dragapult and Haxorus, Fighting-types like Kommo-o and Urshifu-S, non-Roseli Berry and Assault Vest variants of Urshifu-R, and most neutral targets such as Porygon-Z. Sparkling Aria deals with Fire-types such as Rotom-H, Salazzle, and non-Passho Berry Volcarona. Aqua Jet is used to finish off Sturdy users like Shell Smash Crustle and Sawk while also being generally useful for weakened foes such as Togekiss to avoid being hit with flinches from Air Slash. Hydro Cannon is useful for KOs that Sparkling Aria just can't quite reach, like Assault Vest Rhyperior. Energy Ball is useful against Pokemon with a 4x weakness to Grass such as non-Rindo Berry Gastrodon as well as opposing Primarina. 248 HP EVs and 148 Defense EVs allow Primarina to always survive a Choice Band-boosted Poison Jab from Haxorus, while 248 HP EVs along with 64 Special Defense EVs allow Primarina to survive a Choice Specs Hyper Beam from Porygon-Z; the rest of the EVs are dumped into Special Attack. An alternative spread of 248 HP / 80 Def / 40 SpA / 140 SpD with a Calm nature can also be run, which gives Primarina less defensive capabilities, only now living a Fishious Rend from Choice Band Dracovish, but now lets Primarina beat rare Uproar variants of offensive Choice Specs Porygon-Z. Torrent is the preferred ability, as it provides Primarina with situational boosts to its Water-type moves.

Primarina will have issues with specially defensive walls such as Galarian Corsola and Snorlax, as using Assault Vest instead of a damage-boosting item prevents it from breaking down these threats due to their great natural bulk. Thus, Primarina appreciates teammates with stallbreaking capabilities, including Taunt users such as Skarmory, Haxorus, and Urshifu-S. Primarina threatens special attackers and faster Taunt users for Skarmory, bulky Dragon-types for Haxorus, and Fighting- and Fairy-types for Urshifu-S. Primarina also struggles with strong physical moves from many physical attackers in the metagame like Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan and Choice Band Crustle. Bear in mind that Choice Band Rhyperior often runs Speed investment, because it can afford to do so, which will allow it to beat Primarina. Physical walls like Avalugg, defensive Rotom-W, and Grassy Seed Rillaboom deals with the aforementioned threats, while Primarina handles threatening Dragon-types like Dragapult and Kommo-o for these Pokemon in return. Despite its type advantage, Primarina can't break through threats such as defensive Arcanine and Kyurem, as Arcanine utilizes Burn Up to rid itself of its Water-type weakness and follows up with Snarl and Morning Sun, while Kyurem can simply PP stall Primarina with the combination of Noble Roar and Roost. Teammates that handle these threats include options such as Urshifu-R and Fling + Swords Dance Haxorus.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Primarina's great Special Attack and Special Defense, along with the wide variety of moves available to it and its decent defensive typing of Water / Fairy, allow it to be a potent threat in the metagame. Hydro Cannon, boosted with Choice Specs, can OHKO many threats such as Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, physically defensive Corviknight, Incineroar, and Arcanine. Sparkling Aria is a less powerful alternate to Hydro Cannon, with its main upsides being that it doesn't have a recharge turn and can go through Substitutes. Sparkling Aria can take down the likes of Aegislash for Primarina. Moonblast is Primarina's most powerful Fairy-type move and is used to cover Dragon-types like non-Disable Dragapult, Dracovish, Haxorus, and Hydreigon. Energy Ball is a coverage move for Primarina which allows it to take on opposing Water-types for Primarina, such as non-Choice Specs Primarina, non-Thunderbolt stall Rotom-W, and Gastrodon. 248 HP and 148 Defense EVs allow Primarina to take an Poison Jab from Choice Band Haxorus and Choice Band Urshifu, while the 64 Special Defense combined with the aforementioned HP gives Primarina the bulk to take a Hyper Beam from Choice Scarf Porygon-Z. Alternatively, running 96 HP and 196 Special Defense alongside 156 Special Attack with a Modest Nature allows Choice Specs Primarina to beat Porygon-Z, even if their Choice Specs is removed through Trick. A spread of 252 HP / 232 Def / 20 SpA / 4 SpD with a Bold Nature can be run in order to survive a Rock Wrecker from Choice Band Crustle.

Bulky Pokemon with Mirror Coat like Milotic and Avalugg take out Primarina with ease, so teammates that can counteract those Pokemon like Sylveon and Taunt Whimsicott make good partners for Primarina. In return for these teammates, Primarina can take down Steel-types that these are weak to like Corviknight and Excadrill. Primarina is also stopped in its tracks by Grass-types like Celebi, Ferrothorn, Rillaboom, Venusaur, and Whimsicott, so Fire-types like Arcanine and Salazzle can make good partners for Primarina, also allowing there to be a potential Fire / Water / Grass core. In return, Primarina can take out Water-types with its Energy Ball, such as Blastoise, non-Choice Specs Primarina, and Gastrodon. Primarina also loses Electric-types like Zeraora, Dracozolt, and Toxtricity, so Ground-types like Rhyperior and Choice Scarf Diggersby and Pokemon with Ground-type coverage like Conkeldurr and Choice Scarf Haxorus make good teammates for Primarina. In return, Primarina can take on Pokemon for the Ground-types like Blastoise, non-Choice Specs Primarina, Gastrodon, and Galarian Darmanitan. Stall Pokemon that can take advantage of Primarina like Galarian Corsola and Type: Null pose a threat to it, so wallbreakers like Taunt Corviknight and Incineroar are good teammates for Primarina. In return, Primarina can take down Choice Band Dracovish, Choice Scarf Rotom-H, and Keldeo for these teammates.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

X-Scissor is a more accurate Bug-type attack compared to Skitter Smack at the cost of no utility against special attackers. Charjabug can also use Light Screen to support its team, but cannot afford to sacrifice its bulk to use Light Clay and typically finds more use out of Thunder Wave or Toxic than from the limited turns of Light Screen.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Raboot, Carkol, Magmar, and Lampent pose a huge threat to Charjabug, especially the latter two with their Choice Specs variants OHKOing it.

Hattrem: Magic Bounce Hattrem denies any Sticky Web attempt from Charjabug and can hit it hard with Mystical Fire, but must be careful not to switch into Skitter Smack, as Charjabug is able to win in a one-on-one scenario at the cost of the majority of its health.

Stallbreakers: Taunt users like Golbat and Electabuzz prevent Sticky Web attempts, while offensive stallbreakers like Shift Gear Klang and Bulk Up Rufflet can abuse Charjabug's passivity.

Entry Hazards: As much as Charjabug wants to function as a slow pivot throughout the game, it struggles to remain healthy with its entry hazard vulnerability, particularly its crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Sticky Web
sets.description:
Charjabug is the premier Sticky Web user in the metagame thanks to its solid Bug / Electric typing letting it threaten Hattrem and pivot out of common Defog users with Volt Switch. It's also blessed with a solid Defense stat and a resistance to Fighting, which lets it switch into Gurdurr and Machoke with relative ease. Skitter Smack is Charjabug's primary attack due to its ability to cripple special attackers that may switch in such as Magmar and Hattrem while also being powerful enough to 2HKO Choice Specs variants of the latter. Volt Switch lets Charjabug generate momentum and safely switch out of setup sweepers such as Combusken, Klang, and Fraxure, which all would otherwise use it as setup fodder. Lastly, Toxic allows Charjabug to cripple Defog users like Vullaby and Gurdurr in addition to opposing hazard setters like Galarian Corsola and Piloswine. Alternatively, Thunder Wave allows Charjabug to cripple Golbat, and can lower the Speed of Pokemon that are unaffected by Sticky Web such as Drakloak and Klang.

Charjabug should aim to set up Sticky Web as early in the game as possible, although it should be wary of Magic Bounce if Hattrem is present on the opponent's team. After Sticky Web has been set, Charjabug can freely spread status and use Volt Switch to pivot into strong breakers to take advantage. Wallbreakers like Machoke, Rufflet, and Gastly make great use of the speed control that Charjabug provides and benefit greatly from its ability to bring them in safely with a slow Volt Switch, the latter also being an offensive spinblocker. Charjabug has no reliable recovery and is very prone to being worn down, so pairing it with Wish users like Clefairy and Togetic can increase its longevity; the aforementioned Fairy-types also function as great physically defensive walls and can alleviate some pressure from Charjabug. Charjabug's weakness to entry hazards limits the number of times it is able to switch in, so Rapid Spin users like Wartortle and Galarian Mr. Mime can be beneficial. Spikes users such as Carkol, Roselia, and Ferroseed not only form solid entry hazard-stacking cores but can act as specially defensive walls covering Charjabug's mediocre special bulk.

pu.overview: Vikavolt is a wallbreaking powerhouse, sporting a massive base 145 Special Attack stat, powerful STAB attacks, Volt Switch, and decent coverage to boot. It can also switch into threats like Palossand and Passimian thanks to its passable bulk, typing, and access to recovery. However, Vikavolt is very slow for a wallbreaker, and its Bug typing can be a hindrance, as it leaves Vikavolt unable to switch into Pokemon like Regirock that it can otherwise easily pressure. It is often outclassed by Ribombee and Galvantula as a Sticky Web setter, as their Speed tier is much more suited for the aggressive playstyle, with Galvantula also sporting the same typing and Volt Switch. Similarly, Agility sets suffer from competition from Quiver Dance Ribombee.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: This set takes advantage of Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential, forcing out most Pokemon slower than it such as Sandaconda and Jellicent. Although Thunderbolt is a great reliable STAB move for Vikavolt, Sticky Web can be used on more offensive teams as speed control, giving Vikavolt a few more opportunities to outspeed and pressure opposing Pokemon such as Aggron and Adamant Absol but mostly serving to support its teammates. Bug Buzz is primarily used on Vikavolt as a reliable way to hit Pokemon that Electric-type moves cannot hit as well, such as Druddigon and Tsareena. However, Energy Ball is a useful alterative to hit Ground-types harder, such as Palossand and Rhydon, that may attempt to block Volt Switch. A good partner for this set is Passimian, which can assist in offensively checking common switch-ins such as Gigalith and Regirock and deter the opponent from using Defog thanks to Defiant. It can also form a solid VoltTurn core with Vikavolt. Other wallbreakers that appreciate the Sticky Web support like Magmortar and Silvally-Steel make for solid partners. The former appreciates Vikavolt taking on Water-types such as Lanturn, while the latter can pressure defensive behemoths like Gigalith for Vikavolt.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description: This set uses Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential and transforms it into a late-game sweeper, using Agility to make it faster than the entirety of the unboosted metagame. Vikavolt's natural bulk and typing let it use Agility against Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Passimian and Togedemaru as well as more defensive Pokemon that struggle to damage it such as Uxie and Claydol. Energy Ball is used to defeat Pokemon that resist its primary attacks, such as Palossand and Galarian Stunfisk. Roost, however, can give Vikavolt more longevity, allowing it to recover on more defensive threats to make it harder to revenge kill. This set pairs well with entry hazards setters such as Spikes Froslass and Qwilfish, as these help Vikavolt force its way past difficult-to-break Pokemon such as Gigalith and specially defensive Togedemaru. It also defensively pairs well with Ground-types such as Palossand and Sandaconda that resist Rock-type attacks from Pokemon such as Lycanroc and Regirock, since these Pokemon often stop Vikavolt from sweeping.

pu.overview: Ribombee makes for an incredibly versatile threat due to its blistering Speed, good typing, and solid movepool. These traits render it capable of fulfilling multiple roles, ranging from an offensive pivot able to support its teammates with Sticky Web to a capable wallbreaker and cleaner with Choice Specs and Quiver Dance, respectively. It can also revenge kill various threats like Sneasel and Archeops. However, Ribombee struggles a lot against Steel- and Fire-types as well as specially defensive walls like Silvally-Steel, Magmortar, and Gigalith due to its average Special Attack and relative lack of coverage options.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Thanks to its decent coverage and great Speed, Ribombee makes for a fairly threatening setup sweeper. Roost allows Ribombee to use walls like non-Toxic Palossand as setup fodder and makes Ribombee a far more reliable answer to Scrafty. Bug Buzz hits Psychic- and Grass-types like Mesprit and Tsareena without needing a boost, while U-turn gives Ribombee more utility early- and mid-game when its checks are still healthy. Wallbreakers like Passimian and Trevenant are vital partners; they soften up Pokemon like Gigalith, Silvally-Steel, and Charizard, making Ribombee much more of a nuisance. Due to its poor bulk, teammates that can bring Ribombee in safely like Lanturn and Togedemaru make for stellar partners; the former can also switch into Fire-types such as Charizard. Lastly, other cleaners like Scrafty, Hitmonlee, and Silvally-Steel can set up on Ribombee's answers, and vice versa.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Ribombee's coverage and Speed make it a potent wallbreaker and revenge killer when wielding a Choice Specs. Sticky Web is an option over U-turn for Ribombee to support its teammates, while Switcheroo lets it cripple answers like Gigalith and Togedemaru. However, U-turn is the preferred option due to it easing prediction. Cleaners like Sneasel and Gourgeist-Small appreciate Ribombee weakening walls like Weezing and Silvally-Steel for them. Scrafty is another great teammate, as it can also take advantage of some of the various walls that Ribombee finds itself unable to break, such as specially defensive Togedemaru. Stealth Rock and other entry hazards are a huge nuisance to this particular set; they heavily dent Ribombee and make it easier to pick off with a priority move, meaning it has a harder time revenge killing Pokemon like Sneasel and Absol. This makes entry hazard control absolutely vital, with Charizard and Tsareena standing out as great options because they also deal with threats Ribombee struggles against.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description: This set makes Ribombee a capable offensive pivot capable of supporting its teammates with Sticky Web. Stun Spore allows Ribombee to cripple threats it struggles against, like Charizard, while Psychic allows it to hit Poison-types, notably Weezing. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Ribombee forces and allows it to bring it teammates against the Pokemon it invites in. Pokemon like Passimian, Magmortar, and Silvally-Steel make for fantastic partners; not only do they greatly appreciate Ribombee's Sticky Web, but they can also easily take on threats Ribombee has a hard time against such as Togedemaru and Gigalith, with Passimian also deterring the opponent from removing Sticky Web with Defog. Due to Ribombee's unimpressive damage output, it appreciates Spikes from partners like Froslass, which can pressure Steel-types for Ribombee and also enjoys Ribombee being able to revenge kill or cripple faster threats like Sneasel. Froslass can also switch into Rapid Spin users like Hitmontop trying to get rid of Ribombee's Sticky Web.

sets.name: Sticky Web Lead (Fairy)
sets.description:
Due to Ribombee's great natural Speed, it can reliably set up Sticky Web for Fairy teams. STAB Moonblast and Bug Buzz allow Ribombee to avoid becoming passive. Stun Spore slows down foes further by halving their Speed, allowing teammates such as Togekiss to set up against faster threats such as Dragapult. Skill Swap allows Ribombee to set Sticky Webs against Magic Bounce users such as Hatterene, although this is fairly useless outside of matches with Magic Bounce users. Ribombee's EV spread alongside its Timid nature will enable it to hit as fast as possible. Its Focus Sash ensures it can always lead and set up Sticky Web.

All of Ribombee's teammates appreciate its ability to set Sticky Web. Choice Scarf Gardevoir especially appreciates this, as it becomes even harder to stop with foes slowed down. Togekiss becomes faster than all unboosted grounded Pokemon, which allows it to easily set up Nasty Plot. Togekiss can also break past Steel-type Pokemon such as Aegislash and Ferrothorn that wall Ribombee. Since Ribombee's main niche is setting Sticky Web and Mimikyu can block Rapid Spin, the two make good teammates. Mimikyu appreciates Sticky Web as well, as it becomes less reliant on Shadow Sneak to hit threats such as Durant and Dragapult. Grimmsnarl can also pick off weakened airborne threats such as Gyarados with Sucker Punch, which are immune to the effect of Sticky Web.

pu.overview: Thanks to its amazing Speed, great Attack, and coverage, Lycanroc has established itself as a terrifying offensive threat capable of revenge killing multiple tier staples such as Charizard and Ribombee, which gives it an important niche over Archeops. While it does have a great Attack and movepool, it can struggle to get past physically defensive walls that aren't weak to its attacks like Tangela, Quagsire, and Sandaconda.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: With this set, Lycanroc makes for a great revenge killer. Close Combat targets Pokemon like Gigalith, Togedemaru, and Regirock. If running Psychic Fangs, Lycanroc is going to find itself unable to break through Palossand and Claydol; partners that can take them on like Whimsicott and Tsareena are therefore appreciated. They can also weaken other walls such as Weezing in order for Lycanroc to clean. In exchange, they enjoy Lycanroc pressuring Pokemon like Charizard and Sneasel for them. If running Crunch, Lycanroc struggles against Fighting-types such as Hitmontop and Passimian, which makes teammates like Jellicent and Aromatisse appreciated. While Life Orb makes Lycanroc less prediction reliant, Choice Band makes it hit considerably harder while also not getting chipped down by Life Orb.

sets.name: Sand Sweeper
sets.description:
Lycanroc has a small niche in RU as a sweeper on sand teams. However, on non-sand teams, Aerodactyl, Tyrantrum, and Stakataka are better options because of their typings, utility, and offensive pressure. Close Combat hits Rock-resistant foes such as Cobalion, Steelix, and Stakataka, while Crunch hits Golurk, Metagross, and Doublade. Adamant is used on Lycanroc when it's on sand teams, allowing it to OHKO Milotic and Steelix with a Swords Dance-boosted attack with one layer of Spikes up. However, Jolly can be used over Adamant so that Lycanroc is not easily revenge killed by Cobalion, Celebi, and Life Orb Mienshao when sand runs out.

Since Lycanroc is a weather-reliant Pokemon, it only fits on sand-oriented teams. Thus, Gigalith is a necessary partner for Lycanroc, as it sets up sand for Lycanroc to be a deadly late-game cleaner and revenge killer; Gigalith also provides Stealth Rock. Spikes support from Klefki and Golisopod is helpful to wear down Lycanroc's checks throughout the match such as Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Steelix. Lycanroc cannot handle Grass-types such as Dhelmise, Vileplume, and Celebi while unboosted, so teammates such as Incineroar and Noivern are needed. Noivern also provides pivot support to bring Lycanroc in safely; in return, Lycanroc is able to threaten Fairy-types such as Togekiss and Sylveon for Noivern. Lycanroc also struggles against bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon and Milotic, so a Water-resistant or Water-immune teammate like Dhelmise, Virizion, or Toxicroak is mandatory. Dhelmise is also able to remove entry hazards for Lycanroc; in return, Lycanroc is able to threaten Flying-types such as Togekiss, Noivern, and Crobat. Lycanroc can be easily revenge killed by Pokemon such as Cobalion, Choice Scarf Mienshao, and Flygon when sand runs out, so Noivern and Choice Scarf Gardevoir are also great options.

uu.overview: Lycanroc-D is a potent revenge killer due to its strong Tough Claws-boosted priority move in Accelerock, which enables it to revenge kill weakened Dragon Dance Salamence and +2 Speed Galarian Moltres, and high Speed, which lets it outspeed Keldeo. Access to strong coverage moves, such as Close Combat to break past Krookodile, Crunch to deal with Aegislash, and Psychic Fangs to break past Kommo-o makes Lycanroc-D one of the toughest Pokemon to wall in the tier. However, Lycanroc-D struggles to break through teams that run physically bulky threats such as Tangrowth and Buzzwole. Its poor bulk also means it cannot come in on almost anything, so it requires moves such as U-turn and Volt Switch to come in safely as well as occasional aggressive prediction on expected switches.
uu.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance is an option that allows Lycanroc-D to OHKO foes like Amoonguss and Tangrowth at +2; however, it can struggle to find many opportunities to set up safely. Drill Run is nice to give Lycanroc-D excellent Rock- and Ground-type neutral coverage, but the only notable Pokemon it hits super effectively is Colbur Berry Galarian Slowbro. A Focus Sash lead Lycanroc-D is able to use Endeavor while setting up Stealth Rock, but this is generally not worth it in comparison to its other, much more dynamic sets.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu do not switch into Stone Edge well, but they resist Close Combat and threaten Lycanroc-D after switching in; the former also runs Rocky Helmet often, which punishes Lycanroc-D. Tangrowth is the biggest offender, since unboosted Close Combat damage is restored nearly completely by Regenerator, it commonly uses Rocky Helmet, and it can freely threaten Lycanroc-D's team in multiple ways after it comes in. Choice Scarf Zarude takes Accelrock well and can OHKO it with Power Whip.

Steel-types: Choice Scarf Jirachi resists Lycanroc-D's Accelrock and can revenge kill it with Iron Head, only having to fear the rare Sucker Punch. Unless carrying the necessary coverage, Aegislash can safely pivot into Lycanroc-D multiple times and threaten to OHKO with either of its STAB moves. Aegislash can also remove Swords Dance Lycanroc-D if weakened into Shadow Sneak Range.

Water-types: Foes like Suicune and Gastrodon that don't fall to one hit and are capable of firing back with super effective attacks pose problems for Lycanroc-D, which has to be kept in reserve while its teammates wear them down. Starmie naturally outspeeds and can threaten Lycanroc-D, though it must be wary of its health to avoid being taken out by Accelrock. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can take an Accelrock from Lycanroc-D unless they are severely weakened and revenge kill it with Aqua Jet in return.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf users that are not in range of its priority are able to revenge kill Lycanroc-D due to its frailty; Mienshao, Diggersby, and Krookodile are all notable for their resistance to Accelerock and ability to OHKO Lycanroc-D with their STAB moves. Raikou has to mind its HP when around Lycanroc-D, but so does Lycanroc-D, as its bulk makes it take heavy damage from Scald.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Stone Edge is a very spammable STAB move that can OHKO Rotom-H and Salamence while dealing heavy damage to neutral targets like Primarina. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs is an option that inflicts heavy damage on the likes of Amoonguss, Tentacruel, and offensive Buzzwole. Close Combat is a powerful coverage option that nails many Rock resistant Pokemon such as Keldeo, Krookodile, and Kommo-o. Crunch hits Aegislash, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro harder. Accelerock is useful against offense teams, specifically keeping threats such Agility-boosted Galarian Moltres and Dragon Dance Salamence in check. It also makes Lycanroc-D more difficult to revenge kill with faster threats such as Venusaur in sun and Starmie. Sucker Punch can be used to deal more damage than Accelerock against neutral targets; however, it is only really useful for a better matchup against Choice Scarf Jirachi. A Life Orb is used to guarantee feats such as 2HKOing defensive Celesteela with Close Combat and Amoonguss with Stone Edge on the switch with Stealth Rock up. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is needed to make Lycanroc-D outspeed and threaten as many foes as it can, particularly Keldeo.

Lycanroc-D fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to revenge kill common offensive threats such as Salamence without sacrificing its teammates' wallbreaking capabilities. As Lycanroc-D is unable to switch in on mostly anything, pivots are appreciated to give it opportunities to punch holes as often as possible and gain momentum; Moltres and Rotom-H are efficient at this and help pressure Buzzwole and bulky Grass-types, which usually give Lycanroc-D grief. Entry hazards allow Lycanroc-D to leave greater dents in otherwise solid answers such as Buzzwole and Tangrowth, although residual damage from its foes' Rocky Helmet and its own Life Orb will noticeably sting. Krookodile is a great Stealth Rock setter that draws out Buzzwole and Amoonguss to remove their Rocky Helmets with Knock Off. Special attackers such as Moltres and Primarina appreciate Lycanroc-D's ability to break through Chansey, and in return they can help wear down common physically defensive threats such as Buzzwole for it. The Grass-types of the tier like Tangrowth and Zarude are excellent partners to handle threats such as Azumarill. Additionally, they also check faster Pokemon Lycanroc-D cannot threaten as much with its priority, such as Raikou and Zygarde-10%.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
• Lycanroc-D is a decent and unique Focus Sash lead due to its access to all of Counter, Endeavor, Stealth Rock, and a unique STAB priority move.

  • Counter, when combined with Accelerock, allows Lycanroc-D to defeat promiment physical Dynamax sweepers such as Cinderace. This set almost requires Focus Sash to remain intact, so be wary of Lycanroc-D taking residual damage if the opponent still has physical sweepers in play.

  • Close Combat allows Lycanroc-D to hit Ferrothorn and many other Steel-types harder than its STAB coverage, and gets a Tough Claws boost, unlike many of its higher-Base Power STAB moves.

  • Stealth Rock allows Lycanroc-D to support sweepers on its team, helping break opposing Focus Sash and weakening opposing Galarian Moltres and Glastrier.

  • Endeavor allows Lycanroc-D to also defeat many special attackers one-on-one, but be wary of Dynamaxed foes, which will only go to half health if Lycanroc is put to 1 HP.

  • Swords Dance allows Lycanroc-D to become less passive and punishes opponents that try to play around its somewhat predictable Focus Sash strategies.

  • Rock Tomb can be used to provide speed control for incoming sweepers, allowing the likes of Cinderace and Urshifu-R to outspeed many threats to their sweep.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Lycanroc-D can increase its damage output by running Iron Tail instead of Iron Head, but this has the cost of having unreliable accuracy. Drill Run is another coverage option that allows Lycanroc-D to hit defensive Steel- and Fire-types, but it is not as useful in a metagame where Flying-types and Levitate are common. A Rock-type Lycanroc-D with Accelerock provides alternate Tough Claws-boosted priority that can hit foes more reliably than Sucker Punch, but its power is much weaker and it leaves Lycanroc-D running Stone Edge, which isn't boosted by its ability and has shaky accuracy. Psychic Fangs allows Lycanroc-D to hit Poison-type walls like Cresselia and Latias reliably, but the prevalence of Dark-types in the metagame makes using this move harder to justify.

Checks and Counters

Physically Defensive Poison-types: Bulky Poison-type Pokemon like Toxapex, Latias, and Cresselia each have methods of checking and stalling Lycanroc-D thanks to their access to recovery, useful abilities, and status-inflicting moves like Scald from Toxapex and Toxic from each.

Passive Damage: With Life Orb being its best item, Lycanroc-D is constantly chipping its own health. Outside of Steel-type variants, Lycanroc-D is open to chip damage from every entry hazard, and running contact moves to take advantage of Tough Claws means Rocky Helmet effectively punishes it. Too much chip damage over a battle can severely limit Lycanroc-D's opportunities to cause damage.

Extreme Speed: Although Steel-type Lycanroc-D resists Extreme Speed, all other variants take neutral damage from it and are easily 2HKOed by unboosted hits. +1 or Choice Band-boosted Extreme Speed from Adamant Entei or Lucario can OHKO Lycanroc-D with a favorable roll or after minor chip damage.

sets.name: Physical Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Lycanroc-D's good Attack is boosted even further by its great ability in Tough Claws. Combine this with its nice Speed, a plethora of strong physical contact moves, and access to priority, setup, and Stealth Rock, and it becomes one of the scariest wallbreakers in the metagame. Crunch grants Lycanroc-D a Dark typing and STAB on Sucker Punch. Iron Head notably covers the Fairy-types aiming to wall Dark-type moves while Play Rough covers the Dark- and Fighting-types hoping to check Dark-type attacks. Close Combat is a third option for the secondary STAB move that provides a much higher Base Power and hits Normal- and Steel-types even harder, but it leaves Lycanroc-D unable to hit Pokemon with Fairy and Poison typings, like Cresselia, as easily. Sucker Punch provides Lycanroc-D with powerful priority to take on faster offensive threats like Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Naganadel. Lycanroc-D is a great Stealth Rock setter thanks to its breaking potential forcing the opponent to switch often. Swords Dance is another option that quickly makes Lycanroc-D even more threatening and can potentially lead to sweeps with a stronger Sucker Punch. Life Orb provides Lycanroc-D with the most immediate power, but it wears it down over longer battles and can put it in range of even resisted hits like Extreme Speed due to its poor bulk. Focus Sash is an option, particularly if you're running Lycanroc-D as a lead, to allow it to use Stealth Rock or Swords Dance safely. A Jolly nature is needed to outspeed threats like Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Terrakion and Speed tie with Latios and Latias.

While Lycanroc-D has various methods of breaking through walls, team support is very important to optimize its damage output and opportunities to come in. Lycanroc-D's most common typings are able to hit most defensive typings at least neutrally, but they can struggle to break past certain combinations like Water / Poison, Dark / Poison, and certain Fairy and Flying typings. Strong special attackers like Dragon / Electric Latios and Ground / Steel Hydreigon can help Lycanroc-D pressure threats like Toxapex, Latias, and Cresselia. Lycanroc-D is able to target certain faster threats with Sucker Punch, but it is unable to take on most Extreme Speed users, since its defenses are frail. Bulky Normal-type checks like Ghost / Dragon Salamence and Ghost / Fighting Slowbro can take on Extreme Speeds aimed at Lycanroc-D and chip their users with Rocky Helmet. Lycanroc-D also appreciates teammates like Tornadus-T and Dark-type Heracross that can remove opposing Rocky Helmets and, in Tornadus-T's case, remove entry hazards with Defog to cut down on the residual damage Lycanroc-D takes.

zu.comments:
Other Options

Wishiwashi can opt for a physically defensive spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold or Impish nature to better handle physical attackers such as Silvally-Ground and Rapidash at the cost of losing the ability to reliably check special attackers such as Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types such as Flapple and Gourgeist-S are able to OHKO Wishiwashi, while Thwackey and Shiftry can KO Wishiwashi with a bit of prior chip. However, these Pokemon, particularly Shiftry, must be careful of switching into U-turn. Defensive Grass-types such as Appletun and Tangela can deal with Wishiwashi and do not take much from its attacks, but they must be wary of Toxic.

Electric-types: The Rotom formes and Manectric threaten Wishiwashi out with their STAB attacks, with the former also being able to cripple it with Trick.

Residual Damage: Entry hazards limit the number of times Wishiwashi can safely switch in and wear it down to Solo Form much faster. Altaria, Audino, and Cryogonal can also cripple non-RestTalk Wishiwashi variants with Toxic.

Knock Off: Wishiwashi is reliant on Leftovers as its means of recovery, so Knock Off users such as Gurdurr, Alolan Persian, and Clefairy can reduce Wishiwashi's longevity.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
With access to a slow U-turn and naturally high defenses, Wishiwashi makes for an excellent slow pivot and mixed wall, checking the likes of Rapidash and Basculin. Scald can burn physical attackers such as Gourgeist-S and Flapple that attempt to switch in, while Liquidation is a guaranteed OHKO on Fire-types such as Ninetales. Toxic cripples bulkier foes like Appletun and Tangela, as well as dissuading setup sweepers like Frosmoth and Swoobat from switching in. Protect synergizes well with Toxic and lets Wishiwashi scout attacks from Choiced-locked Pokemon such as Rotom, Cinccino, and Sawk. Additionally, Protect lets Wishiwashi acquire more Leftovers recovery, which is essential for staying above Schooling's deactivation threshold. Alternatively, Wishiwashi can give up some utility and opt for Rest for some much needed instant recovery. Sleep Talk should be used in conjunction with Rest in order to avoid being overly passive when asleep. Rest Wishiwashi is also a great status absorber, making it a more reliable pivot against stall teams.

The best use of Wishiwashi's slow U-turn is to pair it with offensive threats such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry that typically struggle to switch into attacks. Pivots such as the Rotom formes and Uxie make for great Wishiwashi partners, as they can form a VoltTurn core to keep momentum while wearing down foes. Wishiwashi's lack of reliable recovery means it is very vulnerable to being worn down by entry hazards; Defog users such as Rotom-S and Articuno help to alleviate this issue. Ground-types like Silvally-Ground, Alolan Dugtrio, and Galarian Stunfisk appreciate Wishiwashi's slow U-turn, and in return, they can deal with Electric-types such as Rotom, Rotom-S, and Morepeko. Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Ninetales and Skuntank are good Pokemon to pair with Wishiwashi, as they can switch into Pokemon like Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S that threaten Wishiwashi out.

sets.name: Wall
sets.description:
Mareanie has great bulk, recovery, and a good typing in Poison / Water that allow it to come into Fighting- and Fairy-types such as Timburr and Spritzee repeatedly. Sludge Bomb makes it able to take care of Fairy-types such as Spritzee and Cottonee. Toxic Spikes is great to help cripple Pokemon that do not have any form of recovery for the rest of the game. Using Iron Defense allows Mareanie to become a great physical wall to take on Swords Dance users such as Pawniard and Galarian Farfetch'd and trappers such as Trapinch and Diglett. The EV spread allows Mareanie to take on Spritzee's Psychic and an unboosted Munchlax's Earthquake. An alternative EV spread of 116 HP / 180 Def / 12 SpA / 180 SpD enables Mareanie to be able to take physical attacks from Galarian Farfetch'd and Corphish a bit better at the cost of not recovering as much from Regenerator.

Pokemon that are weak to Fighting- and Fairy-type attacks such as Pawniard, Munchlax, and Timburr appreciate the fact that Mareanie can repeatedly come in on these attacks. All of its teammates love the pressure that Toxic Spikes put on grounded Pokemon, as Pokemon without recovery will be crippled for the rest of the game. However, Mareanie struggles with Ground-types such as Mudbray and Trapinch, so partners like Vullaby and Wingull make great partners, as they are immune to Earthquake. Mareanie also likes to be paired with trappers such as Trapinch and Diglett in order to take care of Poison-types to make Toxic Spikes more threatening. Mareanie also struggles with Galarian Ponyta, so Pawniard and Munchlax are good to pair with Mareanie to take care of it.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

Toxic over Toxic Spikes punishes targets like Marshtomp and Tangela immediately rather than relying on an entry hazard to status them. Sludge Bomb damages and also spreads status on targets like Vullaby and Thwackey to prevent them from switching in as easily, but Knock Off is usually better for the general utility. As a physical wall, Mareanie is more reliable at checking Pokemon like Gurdurr and Raboot. However, specially defensive sets already check these attackers and are overall more effective.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types: Mareanie usually fails as a special wall when up against Galarian Mr. Mime, Kadabra, and Hattrem, as they target its Psychic weakness and have either immunities or Magic Bounce to work around Toxic Spikes.

Ground-types: Especially without Scald, Ground-types like Piloswine, Marshtomp, and Krokorok are switch-ins to Mareanie that hit hard with Earthquake.

Wallbreakers: Many of the meta’s strongest attackers like Pikachu, Choice Specs Electabuzz, and Choice Band Thwackey break through Mareanie with their STAB attacks.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Mareanie functions as a great special wall thanks to its multiple recovery options and supportive coverage. Recover gives Mareanie the opportunity to regain its HP immediately, while its ability Regenerator can help Mareanie regain HP when pivoting. Scald can burn physical attackers like Piloswine and Thwackey, while Toxic Spikes offers an opportunity to spread status against vulnerable teams once opposing Poison-types are eliminated. Knock Off debilitates walls like Vullaby and Galarian Corsola and also threatens special wallbreakers like Kadabra and Galarian Corsola. Haze prevents some sweepers such as Shell Smash Wartortle, RestTalk Klang, and Calm Mind Lampent from setting up and breaking past Mareanie.

Mareanie should be played as defensive pivot that switches into attackers like Lampent and Raboot in order to force them out. Try pairing Mareanie with physically defensive Pokemon like Galarian Corsola, Clefairy, and Tangela to help deal with attackers like Thwackey, Pikachu, and Machoke. Clefairy and Galarian Corsola also form a great entry hazard-stacking core with Toxic Spikes Mareanie, with the former luring in Hattrem for a Knock Off, and the latter trapping and removing Hattrem with Whirlpool to let Mareanie spam its status moves far more freely. Other bulky Pokemon like Gurdurr and Klang appreciate Mareanie scouting stronger attacks for them, as it can easily switch into Moonblast and Flamethrower from Clefairy and Lampent, respectively. While Mareanie has a weakness to Earthquake, it could be worthwhile to stay in and use Knock Off on tanks that use Earthquake, such as Piloswine and Marshtomp, if removing their Eviolite is essential for the team’s win condition; in these cases, pair Mareanie with offensive sweepers like Kadabra and Raboot. Otherwise, Ground-type checks such as Thwackey and Galarian Corsola can help. Late-game, it could be beneficial to sack Mareanie by spamming Haze in the face of Shell Smash Wartortle or Dragon Dance Fraxure so that they do not sweep and remain slow enough to be revenge killed by offensive teammates like Kadabra and Galarian Mr. Mime.

ou.overview: Toxapex is one of the best defensive Pokemon in the OU metagame. With its amazing defenses, great defensive typing, wide support movepool, reliable recovery, and Regenerator, Toxapex is both very hard to wear down and able to check common metagame threats such as Melmetal and Scizor. Thanks to these qualities, Toxapex is able to fit on numerous balance and stall teams as a defensive pivot. Its high number of utility options allow Toxapex to wear down and cripple many of the metagame's top threats such as Mandibuzz, Ferrothorn, and Heatran, making it a hard Pokemon to switch into despite being a defensive Pokemon. Toxapex unfortunately has trouble exerting offensive pressure due to its underwhelming offensive stats; therefore, its only ways of making progress will be spreading status such as poison and burn and removing items with Knock Off.
ou.comments:
Other Options

Poison Jab allows Toxapex to hit Tapu Fini for consistent damage, which would potentially beat Toxapex with a Calm Mind set otherwise. Shed Shell can be used to prevent being trapped by Magma Storm Heatran, which would otherwise beat Toxapex due to the combination of Magma Storm, Earth Power, and Taunt. Block can be used alongside Spite to both trap PP stall opposing Toxapex, crippling them significantly throughout the course of the game. Toxapex can use an alternative spread of 252 HP / 144 Def / 112 SpD to take hits from Tornadus-T much better while avoiding the OHKO from Timid Nidoking's Earth Power. It can use a Relaxed nature in order if it's using both Scald and Knock Off on the same set.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types: Latios and Tapu Lele can threaten out and overwhelm Toxapex with their STAB moves; however, none of them want to switch into a Toxic, Scald, or Knock Off.

Electric-types: Tapu Koko and Zapdos are examples of Pokemon that can threaten to OHKO Toxapex or deal serious damage to it. Zapdos in particular can remove Toxapex's Toxic Spikes; however, both need to be cautious of being heavily crippled by status effects or item removal.

Ground-types: Ground-type Pokemon such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Nidoking can deal heavy damage against it with their STAB moves; however, all of them can be worn down with Scald, and the former two can be potentially crippled by a burn, which can make them much less effective throughout the course of the game.

Taunt: Taunt is very detrimental to Toxapex, as it can be effectively shut down; Taunt users such as Tapu Fini and Heatran can render Toxapex useless and easily take advantage of it by using it as setup fodder in Tapu Fini's case or outright eliminate it through trapping in Heatran's case.

Future Sight: Future Sight can be troublesome for Toxapex. Slowbro, Slowking, and Galarian Slowking can open the door for wallbreakers such as Choice Band Melmetal and Kartana with a Future Sight, as Toxapex will be overwhelmed by the combination of Future Sight damage and their attacks.

sets.name: The Pex
sets.description:
Scald allows Toxapex to heavily damage Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Nidoking and potentially burn and cripple foes such as Garchomp and Ferrothorn, while Knock Off allows Toxapex to cripple Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers users such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Heatran that may switch into it. Haze prevents Toxapex from being used as setup fodder by Pokemon like Dragonite, Calm Mind Clefable, Volcarona, and Suicune. Toxic is great for putting Pokemon such as Slowbro, Tornadus-T, Hydreigon, and Mandibuzz on a timer, allowing Toxapex's offensive teammates to overwhelm them, while Toxic Spikes is an option for wearing down grounded Pokemon like Garchomp, Rillaboom, and Tapu Fini as well as defensive Pokemon like Tyranitar and Tangrowth; unfortunately, it can easily be removed, cannot target vital non-grounded Pokemon like Mandibuzz and Hydreigon, and is often absorbed by Poison-types such as opposing Toxapex and Galarian Slowking, which makes it inconsistent at spreading status. Lastly, Baneful Bunker is great for crippling Pokemon such as Tornadus-T and Rillaboom attempting to pivot against Toxapex and scouting Choice-locked Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Landorus-T and Tapu Lele, as well as potentially racking up additional Black Sludge recovery. Rocky Helmet allows Toxapex to punish Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Kartana while also punishing U-turn attempts from Pokemon such as Corviknight and Dragapult. Black Sludge can be used as an alternative item to gain additional recovery at the end of each turn while also helping Toxapex in Trick scenarios by crippling the Trick user. A Bold nature is generally preferred; however, an Impish can be used if Toxapex uses Knock Off over Scald.

Teammates like Dragapult and Rillaboom appreciate Toxapex's ability to spread poison and remove Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from Pokemon like Moltres, Mandibuzz, and Hydreigon. Bulky Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn can be very useful for Toxapex; Heatran hard checks most of the Psychic-types in the tier, as well as being able to potentially trap and remove them with Magma Storm, whereas Ferrothorn covers Toxapex's Psychic- and Electric-type weakness and appreciates Toxapex covering its Fire- and Fighting-type weakness; in return, and run Knock Off to free up a moveslot on Toxapex for another utility option. Dark-types such as Obstagoon, Hydreigon, and Mandibuzz can be very useful, as they can cover Toxapex's Future Sight weakness, making it less prone to being overwhelmed by it. Setup sweepers such as Suicune are very weak to Toxic Spikes, so they appreciate Toxapex's ability to absorb them.

sets.name: Defensive (Poison)
sets.description:
Toxapex is an amazing defensive Pokemon and pivot due to its great bulk, good defensive typing in Poison / Water, and Regenerator ability. Scald is great for spreading burns, allowing Toxapex to take on physical attackers even better. Recover combined with Black Sludge helps its longevity and makes it problematic for a lot of Pokemon to take down. Haze is very useful for checking setup sweepers such as Bisharp, Gyarados, and Kommo-o. Toxic Spikes cripples the opposing team by poisoning Pokemon upon entry and works especially well against Dragon-, Dark-, and Ghost-type teams. Toxic is another option for directly crippling Pokemon instead of relying on them to switch in, and it also allows Toxapex to poison Flying-types and Levitate users. Maximum investment in HP and Defense along with a Bold nature allows Toxapex to check threats such as Bisharp, Gyarados, and Dracovish. Toxapex's main role is to apply defensive pressure on the opposing team and switch into attacks that its teammates can't take very well. Although Toxapex doesn't hit very hard, it can cripple them with status and stall them out with Recover.

Galarian Weezing is a good partner because it provides a Ground immunity thanks to its Levitate and forms a defensive core with Toxapex. Galarian Weezing can also use Defog to prevent Toxapex and the rest of the team from getting overwhelmed by entry hazards. Drapion is immune to Psychic-type attacks that threaten Toxapex and provides useful utility with Knock Off by getting rid of the foe's item. Gengar is an offensive check to Psychic-types and a great revenge killer thanks to its high Speed, Special Attack, and coverage. Toxtricity works well as a wallbreaker and beats opposing Toxapex, which can otherwise be problematic for Poison teams. Salazzle threatens Ferrothorn with its Fire-type attacks, which otherwise is very annoying for Poison teams to deal with.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Water)
sets.description:
Toxapex is an amazing defensive Pokemon that fits on many teams because of its bulk, typing, and access to reliable recovery. Toxic allows Toxapex to cripple various Pokemon, while Haze is great for checking setup sweepers. These two moves, along with Recover, make Toxapex hard to take down for many teams across the board. Toxic Spikes can also be used to indirectly cripple types like Fairy and Dragon. Toxapex should be used as a defensive check to various Pokemon, and Toxic and Scald should be used liberally to spread status and wear down the opposition. When Toxapex is worn down, Regenerator should be taken advantage of in order to remain healthy. Maximum Defense and HP investment along with a Bold nature allows Toxapex to deal with threatening Pokemon such as Mimikyu, Bisharp, and Dragapult more comfortably.

Offensive Pokemon such as Seismitoad, Barraskewda, and Gyarados appreciate Toxapex's ability to switch into and wear down the opposing team using status. Toxapex is also prone to being beaten by wallbreakers, so offensive Pokemon such as the aforementioned Seismitoad and Barraskewda as well as Choice Scarf users like Rotom-W and Dracovish are appreciated to revenge kill threatening Pokemon like Gyarados, Indeedee, and Hydreigon. Other Pokemon such as Pelipper and Seismitoad synergize well defensively with Toxapex, with Pelipper providing a Ground-type immunity and Seismitoad taking on Electric-type attacks. Toxapex itself is great for absorbing status and taking Grass-type attacks alongside this.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
• Toxapex's extremely passive playstyle and unfortunate weakness to Ground-type attacks may not make it the first choice for a bulky Water-type, but its excellent support movepool and incredible defensive capabilities make a staple on stall teams.

  • Scald is Toxapex's ideal way to spread burns, and ensure that Ground-types don't switch into it for free.

  • Haze is very effective at stopping set-up opportunities.

  • Toxic lets Toxapex cripple a wide variety of defensive and support Pokemon, such as Porygon2, Cresselia, and Hippowdon.

  • Baneful Bunker is a good way to help stall out Dynamax turns, with a bonus of poisoning foes that use contact moves.

  • Poison Jab may be weak, but with a Relaxed nature, it deals good chip damage to incoming Tapu Fini, Tapu Koko, and Rillaboom. Tapu Fini in particular is an important target due to its habit of running Taunt.

almostanyability.comments:
Other Options

Volt Absorb is another option that provides teams with an immunity to Electric-type attacks, which is beneficial against Zapdos and Tapu Koko but struggles to recover against offensive teams. Unaware serves as a way to prevent setup sweepers with priority from killing Toxapex before it can Haze, but is more susceptible to Taunt users. Knock Off can be used over Scald as a strong option that enables Toxapex to maintain utility against Desolate Land users, but loses the threat of Scald burns versus physical attackers.

Checks and Counters

Water Absorb Pokemon: Generally Water Absorb pokemon such as Excadrill and Palossand are able to switch into Toxapex and threaten it with strong attacks, making it difficult for Toxapex to spread Scald Burns; however, this can be risky if Toxapex is yet to reveal that it isn't running Knock Off.

Desolate Land Pokemon: Offensive Desolate Land Pokemon such as Victini and Heatran are able to switch into Toxapex fairly easily if it doesn't have Knock Off, and they often threaten super effective coverage to force it out.

Special Attackers: Water-resistant special attackers such as Kyurem and Hydreigon are able to switch into Toxapex fairly easily because they aren't threatened by Scald and can do large amounts of damage with their STAB options.

Taunt Users: Due to its passive nature, Toxapex is highly susceptible to Taunt from setup sweepers such as Zapdos-Galar and Gengar. Other users such as Heatran are able to prevent Toxapex from making progress entirely.

Ground-Types: Common Ground-type Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Swampert, and Garchomp threaten to 2HKO or OHKO with super effective STAB attacks, but they have to be wary of a potential Scald or Gastro Acid on the switch.

Electric-Type attacks: Without Volt Absorb, Toxapex is extremely vulnerable to Electric-type coverage, even from pokemon such as Genesect whose STAB attacks are resisted.

Psychic-Type attacks: While Offensive Psychic-types like Latios, Alakazam, Tapu Lele can't always switch into a potential Scald or Knock Off, they threaten it out with their super effective STAB attacks. Setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Genesect, Togekiss often carry Psychic-type coverage in order to OHKO Toxapex as it attempts to Haze them.

sets.name: Prankster
sets.description:
Thanks to priority Haze and Gastro Acid and a good defensive typing, Prankster Toxapex is a great defensive Pokemon in AAA, being able to stop setup sweepers such as Terrakion, Bisharp, and Golisopod or instantly punish Poison Heal users like Snorlax and Tapu Fini with Gastro Acid. Priority Recover is also very notable; Toxapex can freely use Scald or Gastro Acid without needing to stay excessively healthy to check another Pokemon, since it can Recover first anyway. Toxapex's typing also allows it to switch in on various other Pokemon, including Fire-types such as Victini. Scald discourages physical attackers like Tapu Bulu from switching in on Toxapex. A Bold nature alongside 252 HP and 252 Defense EVs maximizes Toxapex's physical bulk to check Terrakion better. Depending on team needs, other abilities can be considered over Prankster, like Levitate for taking on Ground-types, but Prankster is still a better option overall.

Toxapex fits best on balanced and defensive teams that appreciate its defensive utility. Corviknight, especially Intimidate and Unaware variants, is an exceptional teammate; it checks Ground-types such as Garchomp and Landorus-T that threaten Toxapex while providing Defog support to prevent its team from being weakened by entry hazards. It also can check Noivern, which can easily beat Toxapex. However, as Corviknight can be sometimes overwhelmed by Noivern, more specific checks like Assault Vest Silvally-Electric and Jirachi can be considered instead. In return, Toxapex can notably take on Terrakion for Corviknight. Since Toxapex doesn't like taking Shadow Ball from Ghost-types like Gengar and Blacephalon, Pokemon such as Snorlax, Tyranitar, and Blissey can provide a switch-in to these Pokemon. Snorlax is a notable teammate because, thanks to Poison Heal, it can absorb status and Knock Off for Toxapex, enabling its longevity. Other Pokemon such as Poison Heal Clefable and Magic Bounce Hippowdon can be also considered for this role, as they offer similar support.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Rocky Helmet on Water / Poison Toxapex accumulates extra chip on physical attackers, particularly Extreme Speed and U-turn users such as Scizor, Entei, Pheromosa, and Arcanine. Water / Poison Toxapex can also utilize Knock Off over Haze, but without Haze it fails to check Calm Mind Clefable and Latias.

Checks and Counters

Ground-type Attackers: Ground-type attackers such as Landorus-T, Melmetal, and Heatran easily break past Toxapex. However, Scald from Water / Poison Toxapex can somewhat deter physical Ground-types.

Tapu Lele: Tapu Lele is a huge threat to Water / Poison Toxapex due to its powerful Psychic-type attacks. Choice Specs Tapu Lele is especially threatening, as it's also difficult for Toxapex's partners to deal with, and it can even break Dark / Poison Toxapex in some cases.

Garchomp: Garchomp breaks past Toxapex with little effort. Offensive Stealth Rock sets, such as Ground / Steel and Dragon / Steel, are generally immune to Toxic, and some run Lum Berry to avoid a burn from Scald as well. After just one Swords Dance, any Garchomp set can 2HKO either Toxapex set.

Heracross: Heracross can break past either Toxapex set easily with STAB Guts Facade. Additionally, thanks to Guts, Heracross doesn't care about burns from Scald. It can fear Knock Off if Flame Orb hasn't activated yet, but otherwise it is a solid check to Toxapex.

Hydreigon: Most of Hydreigon's type configurations do not struggle with Toxapex at all. While Hydreigon generally runs Ground-type, it sets itself apart from other Ground-type attackers, as its Water / Dragon set breaks Toxapex as well. Ground / Steel Hydreigon in particular is able to threaten Toxapex without fear of being poisoned.

Electric-type Attackers: Electric-type attackers such as Tapu Koko, Latios, and Clefable are all able to threaten Toxapex in some way, though they can struggle to break past Dark / Poison Toxapex in some cases. Clefable is less secure, as it can't break past Dark / Poison Toxapex reliably and runs the risk of Toxapex using Knock Off. Choice Specs Tapu Koko can 2HKO Toxapex if Stealth Rock is up or gain momentum with Volt Switch.

Substitute and Taunt: Since Toxapex is passive, relying heavily on chipping opponents with Toxic damage and usually needing mulitple hits to break Substitutes, Substitute and Taunt are both strong tools to exploit it.

sets.name: Specially Defensive Wall
sets.description:
With high bulk and only one weakness, Dark / Poison Toxapex is a potent defensive Pokemon in the metagame. Its typing allows it to be one of the most effective walls to strong special attackers such as Tapu Lele, Magearna, Alakazam, Volcarona, and Spectrier. Regenerator and Recover give it multiple tools to increase its longevity. Knock Off gives Toxapex its Dark typing while providing valuable team support. Toxapex's Poison-type moveslot is flexible, with Toxic Spikes providing the most team support. Toxic is a secondary option that more immediately poisons foes like Heavy-Duty Boots Volcarona and affects Flying-type and Levitate foes. Baneful Bunker is a less common option that allows Toxapex to scout moves from Choice item users and physical attackers or stall another turn of burn or poison damage. Haze is necessary to effectively stop special attackers such as offensive Clefable, Steel-type Magearna, and Poison-type Latias from setting up, as each is immune to Toxic damage. Haze also allows Toxapex to check a number of setup sweepers in a pinch, though it has to be cautious to not lose too much HP in the process.

Toxapex fits on most playstyles, but it truly thrives on balance and bulky offense teams, providing crucial support for both. Physically defensive Steel / Flying Pokemon such as Salamence and Buzzwole are great partners for Toxapex because they cover Ground-type Pokemon, which are easily the biggest threats to Toxapex. Offensive Flying-type and Levitate Pokemon like Tornadus-T, Latios, and Hydreigon can threaten defensive Ground-types that threaten Toxapex, such as Heatran, Landorus-T, and Coalossal. Offensive Pokemon that appreciate Toxic Spikes support, such as Victini, Garchomp, and Ground-type Hydreigon, are very valuable partners to Toxapex on bulky offense, as they can force opposing teams into difficult positions and capitalize on Toxic damage.

sets.name: Physically Defensive Wall
sets.description:
Water / Poison Toxapex is a pivot and wall that checks a various offensive Pokemon such as Entei, Arcanine, Pheromosa, and Latias. Scald is spammable thanks to its high burn chance, which threatens physical attackers such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Lycanroc-D. Toxic Spikes gives Toxapex a support option that prevents defensive Pokemon from coming in safely, which can greatly benefit Toxapex's teammates. Toxic is a secondary option that more immediately poisons foes like Heavy-Duty Boots Volcarona and affects Flying-type and Levitate foes. Baneful Bunker allows Toxapex to scout moves or stall another turn of burn or poison damage. Recover increases Toxapex's longevity and allows it to check threats more readily. For the last slot, Haze allows Toxapex to check a plethora of setup sweepers such as Fire / Fairy Clefable, Water / Poison Latias, and Cresselia.

Psychic-type attackers such as Tapu Lele and Volcarona can be huge threats to Toxapex, so it's important to have switch-ins to these attacks; bulky Steel-type Pokemon, namely Heatran, Hydreigon, Coalossal, and Magearna, are good examples. Additionally, Ground-type Heatran, Hydreigon, and Coalossal double as checks to offensive Electric-types such as Clefable, Tapu Koko, Latios, and Dragapult that Toxapex struggles to deal with. Similarly to specially defensive Toxapex, this set benefits greatly from offensive Pokemon that appreciate Toxic Spikes support such as Entei, Hydreigon, and Victini.

nationaldex.comments:
Other Options

Shed Shell may be used in order to pivot into Heatran's Magma Storm without repercussions. However, it serves no use outside of that, making it hard to justify over Black Sludge or Rocky Helmet.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Dangerous Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp and its Mega Evolution, Gliscor, and Excadrill all easily force Toxapex out with their STAB moves. Gliscor is a particularly effective countermeasure, as it doesn't fear Knock Off or Scald burns once Toxic Orb has been activated.

Psychic-types: Toxapex is heavily threatened by strong Psychic-types such as Mega Latias, Tapu Lele, Alakazam, and Mega Medicham. However, none of these bar Alakazam appreciate Toxic, and Mega Medicham must be wary of Baneful Bunker.

Electric-types: Tapu Koko, Magnezone, and Zapdos are capable of forcing Toxapex out with their STAB moves. However none of them, apart from Magnezone, appreciate Toxic. Electric-type coverage from the likes of Clefable and Victini can also hit Toxapex for great amounts of damage.

Future Sight: Toxapex is incredibly limited by Future Sight users in Slowbro and Slowking. Said move discourages Toxapex from switching into the threats it's supposed to check, in fear of being taken out by the combination of any attack plus Future Sight.

sets.name: The Pex
sets.description:
Toxapex is one of the most potent defensive Pokemon in National Dex due to its excellent defenses paired with a great typing, multiple methods of recovery, an immunity to Toxic, and the ability to punish a majority of the metagame. Said qualities allow it to wall a wide range of dangerous threats such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Scizor, Ash-Greninja, and Mega Charizard Y. In addition, its access to both Recover and Regenerator allows it to securely pivot into many additional threats, such as Mega Mawile, Aegislash, and Kartana, in order to scout their moves. Haze is useful in order to deter setup attempts from a vast array of threats, consisting of Pokemon such as Mega Scizor, Kartana, Aegislash, and Mega Mawile lacking Thunder Punch. Baneful Bunker is the preferred move in the fourth slot, as it allows Toxapex to punish the heavily threatening Mega Medicham, check Ash-Greninja more comfortably, scout for Z-Moves from the likes of Kartana and punish U-turn users such as Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T. Toxic may be run instead, as it allows Toxapex to directly cripple Pokemon such as Mega Latias, Gastrodon, Mega Tyranitar, and Slowbro. It also enables it to punish Defoggers such as Zapdos and Tapu Fini. Knock Off can be run over Scald or in the fourth slot as well, giving Toxapex a way to punish offensive and defensive Pokemon alike, such as Tapu Lele, Clefable, and Tapu Fini. Toxic Spikes can be run in the fourth slot too, as Toxapex's bulk gives it an ample amount of opportunities to set it up while also providing it with a good way of punishing switches. However, with the prominence of Toxic Spikes-immune Pokemon such as Clefable, Heatran, Gliscor, Zapdos, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots users such as Slowbro and Blissey, the output is often not very notable. The given EV spread in tandem with a Bold nature and Black Sludge recovery allows Toxapex to check strong physical attackers such as, Mega Lopunny, Swords Dance Aegislash, and Bisharp as reliably as possible. Rocky Helmet may be used instead in order to punish various physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny and Kartana.

Toxapex fits best on balance teams that benefit from its ability to check and disrupt a wide range of threats. Landorus-T and Ice Beam variants of Clefable and Mega Latias have great synergy alongside Toxapex, as they are able to pivot into and threaten out Ground-types such as Garchomp, Gliscor, opposing Landorus-T, and Excadrill. Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Corviknight, and Aegislash, can check specific dangerous Psychic-types such as Calm Mind Mega Latias and Tapu Lele and take advantage of Clefable, which fears nothing Toxapex can throw at it bar Knock Off. In return, Toxapex provides them with a switch-in to Fire-type attacks from the likes of Mega Charizard Y. Notably, Corviknight can also check the aforementioned Ground-types. If running Toxic Spikes, Pokemon that benefit from it such as Gliscor, Heatran, and Mega Lopunny, have a much easier time breaking through their checks. Reuniclus is another notable mention, as Toxic Spikes allows it to outlast grounded Dark-types such as Mega Tyranitar, Ash-Greninja, and Weavile. In return, it can use Pokemon drawn in by Toxapex, such as Clefable and Gliscor, as setup fodder and, very notably, counter Mega Medicham.

lc.overview: Mudbray is the one of the only viable Stealth Rock setters that isn't weak to Fighting, and its combination of bulk and power makes it an effective one. Its ability, Stamina, is great against U-turn users such as Vullaby and Fake Out users such as Mienfoo. Because of Mudbray's bulk, it walls many of the tier's premier attackers such as Timburr, physical Vullaby, and Pawniard while soft checking many other threats. It also has one of the best Attack stats in the tier and good coverage moves such as Heavy Slam, Close Combat, and Rock Slide. However, even with its good bulk and Attack, it lacks Speed and resistances. Mudbray's lacking defensive role compression means there are better Stealth Rock setters, such as Onix and Pawniard, and it is often taken advantage of by common Water- and Grass-types such as Staryu and Foongus.
lc.comments:
Other Options

Offensively, Mudbray can use High Horsepower to do more damage during Grassy Terrain, but it loses out on power when not in it. Defensively, Mudbray is a great tank and can use Toxic to wear down common checks or switch-ins. It can also use Substitute to soak up incoming damage, especially against physical attackers when it has racked up enough Stamina boosts. Substitute can also soak up status from moves such as Will-O-Wisp from the likes of Koffing. Finally, Roar allows Mudbray to check setup attackers such as Dragon Dance Onix.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Foongus and Ferroseed are able to 2HKO Mudbray with Giga Drain, while Mudbray is only able to 3HKO them after Giga Drain recovery. Foongus can also use Spore and put Mudbray to sleep; however, both Foongus and Ferroseed need to be wary of switching in on Earthquake. Grookey is an offensive Pokemon that Mudbray needs to be careful of, especially in Grassy Terrain if Mudbray lacks High Horsepower.

Water-types: Water-types such as Frillish, Shellos, Wingull, and Staryu are all able to deal massive damage to Mudbray with their super effective attacks, but most of them aren't able to switch in against Earthquake, except for Wingull. That being said, Mudbray is able to OHKO Wingull with Rock Slide, but is only able to 2HKO the others at best.

Koffing: Koffing gets 3HKOed by Mudbray but can reduce it to a passive wall with Will-O-Wisp.

Vullaby: Vullaby is immune to Earthquake, but it has to be wary of Mudbray's coverage moves.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Moves

Earthquake deals good damage, especially to Pokemon such as Pawniard and Mareanie. Heavy Slam hits at 120 BP against most Pokemon, provides good coverage alongside Earthquake, and hits Spritzee very hard. Furthermore, Heavy Slam is also a good midground to hit Vullaby hard. On the other hand, Rock Slide can be used over Heavy Slam to hit Vullaby harder and OHKO Wingull, but this would require more prediction. Close Combat is for Ferroseed and Porygon and can 2HKO both. Finally, Counter is a surprise option against Timburr, Mienfoo, and Vullaby that try to deal chip damage and works well with Berry Juice, as Mudbray will be taking hits.

Set Details
