However, Corviknight is often forced to click Roost to stay healthy, leading to a loss of momentum. It also exhibits very little offensive pressure, often relying on one offensive moveslot to help it check foes. Opting for Body Press makes Rillaboom more difficult to deal with, while Brave Bird weakens its matchup against Kartana and Bisharp. Opponents can take advantage of this by sending out Pokemon that resist its main move, forcing Corviknight to switch. Furthermore, Corviknight is especially prone to being trapped by Magnezone, which can open up a major hole in its team.
ou.comments:
Other Options

A Bulk Up set with maximum HP and Special Defense EVs, a Careful nature, and a moveset of Brave Bird / Bulk Up / Substitute / Roost is an option for a bulky wincon. This set is especially effective at Pressure stalling opposing Pokemon thanks to its sturdy Substitutes. 200 Speed EVs on the Defog set allow Corviknight to outspeed maximum Speed Modest Magnezone and use U-turn to avoid getting trapped. The loss of bulk is very noticeable, however. Iron Head is also an option to deal super effective damage to Fairy-types. However, it is very weak outside of this and an inferior option overall. Taunt can be used to prevent status moves like Leech Seed from Ferrothorn and Thunder Wave from Clefable, and it can also defend the team against setup sweepers in a pinch, but it has very little use otherwise.

Checks and Counters

Strong Special Wallbreakers: Strong special attackers such as Choice Specs Kyurem and Thunderbolt Tapu Lele easily 2HKO Corviknight. Dragapult can also fish for a Special Defense drop with Shadow Ball if it gets in safely. However, Kyurem dislikes Body Press, and Dragapult and Tapu Lele take a big chunk from Brave Bird.

Electric-types and Electric-type Coverage: Common Pokemon such as Zeraora, Tapu Koko, and Zapdos threaten Corviknight with super effective moves. Electric-type coverage moves on Clefable, Melmetal, and Tapu Lele allow these Pokemon to break through Corviknight as well. Magnezone gets a special mention because it traps Corviknight with Magnet Pull and easily beats it, which can open up a major hole in its team.

Fire-types and Fire-type Coverage: Heatran is one of the few Stealth Rock users able to beat Corviknight and keep entry hazards on the field. Volcarona threatens Corviknight with its STAB attacks and sets up on variants lacking Brave Bird. Corviknight also invites in Victini, giving it a free turn to use one of its strong attacking moves. Fire-type coverage lets Dragapult and Garchomp break through Corviknight as well. However, Heatran takes a good chunk from Body Press and Volcarona and Dragapult dislike Brave Bird.

Chip Damage: Contact punishment from Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin or Iron Barbs is problematic for Corviknight. Furthermore, if hazards are on the field and Corviknight keeps getting forced out before being able to use Defog, the repeated Stealth Rock damage makes its job of switching into Pokemon it's supposed to check more difficult.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
The listed EV spread allows Corviknight to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Psychic after Stealth Rock damage as well as the 2HKO from Choice Specs Dragapult's Shadow Ball from full HP. Maximum HP and Defense EVs is an alternative, although it takes considerably more damage from special attacks. Body Press OHKOes Bisharp and Weavile while also dealing decent damage to incoming Steel-types such as Heatran and Magnezone. U-turn is what makes Corviknight a great pivot, allowing it to keep momentum against Pokemon that switch in to it. Brave Bird is an alternative that hits Rillaboom, Urshifu-R, and Volcarona for super effective damage and prevents it from being setup fodder for the latter. However, teams especially weak to physical setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Garchomp and Kartana can make use of Iron Defense to completely wall those Pokemon while also making Body Press stronger. Corviknight's ability to wall most hazard setters makes it an excellent Defog user. Leftovers helps check more Pokemon in the long run thanks to the passive recovery. Rocky Helmet deals chip damage to U-turn and Knock Off spam and dissuades Urshifu-R from using Surging Strikes. Corviknight is often switching in on Knock Off from Pokemon such as Weavile, Bisharp, Rillaboom, and Kartana, so its item rarely lasts the entire match.

Many team archetypes appreciate Corviknight as a Defogger thanks to its strong defensive presence and pivoting ability. Defensive teams greatly appreciate its longevity and ability to take Knock Off, while more offensive teams take great advantage of its pivoting. Corviknight appreciates Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Hippowdon switching into Electric-type attacks from Zeraora, Tapu Koko, and Zapdos that threaten it. These Pokemon also threaten Heatran, one of the few Stealth Rock setters able to beat Corviknight. Slowking, Toxapex, and Heatran switch into Fire-types that threaten Corviknight such as Heatran for the former two and Volcarona for the latter two. Slowking and Blissey also sponge special attacks from Pokemon such as Nidoking that Corviknight has trouble repeatedly taking, and they can safely pivot into it with Teleport against strong physical attackers that threaten them like Kartana, Rillaboom, and Urshifu-R. Another great teammate is Clefable, as it appreciates Corviknight's ability to take on physical attackers that threaten it like Rillaboom, Bisharp, and Kartana, while Clefable takes on Dragon-types such as Hydreigon, Dragapult, and Kyurem that threaten Corviknight. It also can heal status with Aromatherapy. Strong wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Urshifu-R, Bisharp, and Dragapult appreciate Corviknight's slow pivoting with U-turn getting them in safely.

sets.name: Taunt + Bulk Up (Flying)
sets.description:
Sporting an excellent Steel / Flying typing with key immunities and resistances, great base stats, and a phenomenal ability, Corviknight is a vital member on Flying teams that compresses multiple roles into one, being able to function as a stallbreaker as well as a setup sweeper. Mirror Armor prevents Corviknight from having its stats lowered by common moves such as Aegislash's and Gengar's Shadow Ball and Hatterene's and Indeedee's Mystical Fire, as it will reflect back the stat drops instead. Taunt prevents passive Pokemon such as Galarian Corsola, Ferrothorn, and Hippowdon from statusing, setting up entry hazards, and phasing, respectively. Bulk Up allows Corviknight to boost its Attack and Defense, making it exceptionally hard to beat. Power Trip is used in conjunction with Bulk Up, which simultaneously boosts its Base Power to sky-high levels, to allow Corviknight to sweep teams, most notably Ghost, Steel, and Psychic teams. Roost provides Corviknight with reliable recovery throughout the match and Leftovers provides it with a source of passive recovery. As Bulk Up boosts Defense, maximum HP and Special Defense investment alongside a Careful nature allows Corviknight to take attacks from special attackers such as Indeedee, Hatterene, and Duraludon more easily.

Corviknight is able to setup any time during the game as long as its checks and counters are removed. Xatu is able to set dual screens for Corviknight, allowing it to set up more easily on Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Dragapult that can otherwise KO it, as well as prevent Stealth Rock from going up on the field and cripple faster foes with Thunder Wave. Choice Scarf Charizard is able to threaten Steel and Ice teams, which are both popular and troublesome matchups for Flying teams otherwise by outspeeding and OHKOing Pokemon like Bisharp and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan that threaten Corviknight. Gyarados threatens Fire-types such as Cinderace, Charizard, and Salazzle and can sweep Water teams with Power Whip and Earthquake; in return, Corviknight can sweep Steel teams which Gyarados struggles to break. Mandibuzz is able to provide Defog support to keep Corviknight healthy, resistance to Ghost-type attacks, and momentum with U-turn to help set up a sweep. Nasty Plot Togekiss is another setup sweeper that can paralyze threats like Hydreigon and Indeedee, break Pokemon like Clefable and Mandibuzz, be used in conjunction with Corviknight to form a wallbreaking core. Choice Scarf Togekiss can cripple Pokemon with Trick, potentially giving Corviknight a free setup opportunity. Pelipper and Swift Swim Mantine can also take care of Fire-types, and Pelipper's Drizzle additionally allows Corviknight to survive Fire-type attacks more easily.

sets.name: Defog (Flying)
sets.description:
Corviknight is an amazing Defogger for Flying teams because of its excellent defensive typing, bulk, and ability in Pressure. Its Steel typing allows it to comfortably take Rock- and Ice-type moves, which would typically be problematic, such as Tyranitar's and Terrakion's Stone Edge, Cloyster's Icicle Spear,and Mamoswine's Icicle Crash; it also provides Corviknight with a variety of resistances, allowing it to switch in on other Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gardevoir and Excadrill. Its Steel typing also gives it a Toxic immunity, meaning Corviknight can take on defensive Stealth Rock setters such as Hippowdon, Shuckle, Piloswine, and Seismitoad that may carry the move. Pressure is particularly good on this set, as it means Corviknight can PP stall Stealth Rock users and keep entry hazards off the field more easily in conjunction with Defog. Body Press hits Pokemon such as Bisharp, Cloyster, Mamoswine, Excadrill, and Tyranitar for super effective damage, allowing Corviknight to check these Pokemon reliably. U-turn is important for Corviknight, as it can grab momentum against Pokemon it can't beat like Toxapex and Aegislash and bring in a teammate to more reliably take them on. Throughout the game, Corviknight should aim to find opportunities where it can comfortably use Defog or grab momentum using U-turn by switching in on Pokemon it walls. Maximum HP and Defense investment allows Corviknight to check the aforementioned Pokemon in Mamoswine, Weavile, Cloyster, Excadrill, and Bisharp with more reliability while also boosting the power of Body Press to check these threats.

Because Flying teams are typically weak to Stealth Rock, all of Corviknight's teammates appreciate its incredible reliability as a Defogger to keep entry hazards off the field. Choice Scarf Charizard is a great teammate for Corviknight, as it can outspeed and beat threats to Corviknight such as Choice Scarf Duraludon, Hydreigon, Aegislash, and Heliolisk; Charizard also appreciates Corviknight's Defog due to its 4x Stealth Rock weakness. Choice Scarf Noivern is another teammate that can outspeed and beat Dragon-type Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dracovish and Choice Specs Dragapult. Corviknight's U-turn is also good for bringing Charizard and Noivern in comfortably in matchups such as Steel and Dragon, respectively. Togekiss is a great setup sweeper that can break through Pokemon with Nasty Plot in conjunction with Thunder Wave and Air Slash, such as Toxapex, Galarian Weezing, and Dragapult, that Corviknight can't get past. Mantine can be used as a secondary Defogger, switching into a variety of strong special attacks with its good special bulk and defensive typing, such as Seismitoad's and Keldeo's Hydro Pump, Choice Scarf Dragapult's and Charizard's Fire Blast, and Choice Specs Aegislash's Shadow Ball, working together with Corviknight to form a good defensive core that can remove hazards for the rest of the team.

sets.name: Bulk Up (Steel)
sets.description:
Corviknight's great bulk, amazing defensive typing, and access to Bulk Up make it a dangerous threat in the metagame that can be problematic to take down for unprepared teams. It's a staple for Steel teams because its typing gives it a very important Ground immunity that lets it check threats such as Excadrill as well as taking neutral damage from Fighting-type attacks. Special Defense investment is crucial because it allows Corviknight to comfortably switch into attacks such as Gengar's Shadow Ball and Flygon's Flamethrower. Mirror Armor is used to take on common Mystical Fire users, such as Hatterene, Indeedee, and Gardevoir, and lower their Special Attack. Mirror Armor can also help it avoid Special Defense drops from attacks like Shadow Ball. Bulk Up boosts Corviknight's already decent Defense, making it more difficult to take down, and increases its offensive pressure by boosting its Attack, allowing Brave Bird to break defensive Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Hippowdon more easily. Brave Bird is its best STAB move and hits threatening Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Kommo-o that take very little from its other attacking options for super effective damage. Alternatively, it can use Power Trip, which becomes very strong after a couple of boosts, to hit Ghost- and Psychic-types super effectively at the cost of not being able to take on Fighting-types as effectively. Roost, paired with Leftovers, gives Corviknight a form of recovery to support its bulky setup and increase its longevity. Taunt prevents Toxapex from using Haze, Hippowdon from phazing Corviknight with Whirlwind, Ferrothorn from setting up entry hazards, and other Pokemon from recovering, setting up, or using their own Taunt. Due to its great bulk, Corviknight can afford to switch into threatening attacks, as its main role is to apply defensive pressure. It should find opportunities to use Bulk Up against passive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and against Pokemon that don't threaten to 2HKO it such as Choice Scarf Terrakion.

Ferrothorn forms a great defensive core with Corviknight and provides an important resistance to Water for Steel teams, as they're threatened by powerful attacks such as Seismitoad's Hydro Pump. Ferrothorn can also use Leech Seed and set up entry hazards to soften up the opposing team to make it easier for Corviknight to sweep. Excadrill covers Corviknight's weakness to Electric-type attacks, such as Zeraora's Plasma Fists, and can threaten Electric- and Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Charizard with its Mold Breaker Earthquake and Rock Slide, respectively, as well as revenge killing threats such as Hydreigon and SubToxic Salazzle. Choice Scarf Duraludon is another great partner that can revenge kill troublesome Pokemon such as Dragapult and Hydreigon and use Thunder Wave to spread paralysis on the opposing team to give Corviknight an easier time dealing with otherwise faster foes. Aegislash appreciates Corviknight's Ground immunity and in return can wallbreak the opposing team to weaken Corviknight's checks. Aegislash's Fighting immunity allows it to check threats such as Terrakion, and its good bulk also lets it survive some attacks that threaten Corviknight, such as Hydreigon and Dragapult's Fire Blast, whose users Aegislash can OHKO in return. Jirachi is a good option for breaking Water teams with its great coverage, notably being able to threaten Keldeo and Toxapex with its STAB-boosted Psychic. Melmetal is a very powerful and bulky wallbreaker that can soften up the opposing team to allow Corviknight to set up more easily and win. Lucario and Bisharp can also break holes in the opponent's team by setting up with Nasty Plot and Swords Dance, respectively, and they're great against Dark- and Psychic-type teams.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
• When running maximum Defense investment alongside Iron Defense, Corviknight is a good physical wall that has several tools to differentiate itself from Celesteela, such as Roost.

  • Body Press alongside Iron Defense makes Corviknight very difficult to defeat with physical attacks following a boost and allows it to deal incredibly high damage with Body Press following Defense boosts.

  • Brave Bird allows Corviknight to hit Ghost-types and boost its Speed with Max Airstream, but Iron Head can be used to help ease the matchup against Swords Dance Mimikyu. Taunt can also be run here to stop status moves like Yawn, but this leaves Corviknight unable to damage Ghost-types.

  • Avoid using Dynamax on Corviknight unless it needs it to survive hits in a pinch, such as switching in against a boosted Mimikyu. Corviknight will lose the massive damage output from Iron Defense-boosted Body Press, and its damage output is tame against any Pokemon with decent defenses.

  • Mirror Armor is preferred over Pressure in order to survive against Max Phantasm Defense drops, allowing Corviknight to effectively defeat standard Mimikyu and physical Dragapult sets. This also punishes Intimidate Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Salamence, and Gyarados

Items

  • Sitrus Berry is the primary item, which helps Corviknight avoid many 2HKOs, such as Cinderace's Pyro Ball.

  • Leftovers can be used for long-term health recovery if that is preferred.

  • Rocky Helmet can be used for chip damage in matchups such as against Urshifu-R.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• Near-maximum special bulk and Maranga Berry allow Corviknight to consistently survive weaker super effective attacks and set up on Pokemon that would otherwise check it.

  • Taunt is the more traditional option for shutting down passive Pokemon, but Substitute can be used for stalling out PP more effectively or setting up on weak special attacks.

  • Pressure is the preferred ability to stall out weak super effective special attacks, but Mirror Armor can still be useful to help against Intimidate users, Mystical Fire attackers, and Max Phantasm users.

  • Dynamax allows Corviknight to survive otherwise lethal hits and can be used to sweep after Bulk Up boosts have been accumulated.

  • The given EV spread is designed to be as specially bulky as possible while still being able to outspeed defensive Celesteela and Iron Defense Corviknight sets to Taunt them.

sets.name: Fast Taunt
sets.description:
• This Corviknight set takes advantage of its relatively good natural bulk, Speed investment, and Bulk Up to outspeed the majority of bulky metagame options to take advantage of passive foes and opposing Corviknight to sweep opposing teams with boosted Brave Bird or Max Airstream.

  • Taunt is used to shut down status and boosting moves, allowing Corviknight to gain an advantage over slower Pokemon that have trouble damaging it. such as Hippowdon and Ferrothorn.

  • Substitute can be used to gain an advantage over status users while also easing prediction against foes switching out.

  • This Corviknight wants to Dynamax after setting up Bulk Up and when its natural checks, such as Rotom forms, are removed from the game or severely damaged. Following Speed boosts from Max Airstream, Corviknight becomes difficult to deal with for offensively oriented teams, as it will outspeed most Choice Scarf users at +2 Speed.

  • Mirror Armor is used to help beat Mimikyu one-on-one, outspeeding it after a Max Airstream and reversing Defense drops from Max Phantasm. It also let Corviknight punish Intimidate Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Salamence, and Gyarados.

Items

  • Lum Berry is used with Taunt generally to allow Corviknight to switch into moves such as Yawn, breaking Stealth Rock + Yawn cycles.

  • Leftovers is generally used in combination with Substitute, to gain passive health while being protected by Substitute.

EV Spreads

  • 108 HP / 148 Atk / 252 Spe with a Jolly nature: Maximum Speed allows this Corviknight to effectively Taunt all Corviknight while still having decent attacking power and health through partial investment in Attack and HP. It also can outspeed Jolly Cinderace at +1 Speed.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with a Jolly nature: This is a simple spread to maximize HP and Speed; it also lets Corviknight outspeed everything up to Jolly Cinderace at +1 Speed and survive hits better than the 148 Attack spread.

  • 252 HP / 60 Atk / 196 Spe with an Adamant nature: This EV spread allows Corviknight to outspeed positive-natured base 100 Speed Pokemon after a Max Airstream.

sets.name: Weakness Policy
sets.description:
• This Corviknight set is designed to bait in super effective attacks, using the combination of Dynamax and Corviknight's superb natural bulk to easily survive these attacks and hit back lethally with Max Airstream.

  • Bulk Up is the boosting move of choice, allowing Corviknight to augment its Attack when not in Dynamax forme, allowing it to hit harder and making it more difficult to take down with physical attacks.

  • Iron Head gives Corviknight a great chance to OHKO Dynamax Togekiss with Max Steelspike after Weakness Policy is activated.

  • Power Trip can be used to deal massive damage following Dynamax expiring through stat boost accumulation.

  • Body Press gives Attack boosts with Max Knuckle and allows Corviknight to hit Steel-types more effectively than other options.

  • Taunt allows you to stifle slower status moves, allowing Corviknight to set up on passive Pokemon.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with a Jolly nature: This is a simple spread to maximize HP and Speed; it also allows Corviknight to outspeed everything up to Jolly Cinderace at +1 Speed and survive hits better than the spreads invested in Attack.
  • 252 HP / 100 Atk / 156 Spe with an Adamant nature: These EVs are designed to outspeed positive-natured Dragapult after two Max Airstreams.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Corviknight has a brilliant Flying / Steel typing and good mixed bulk, allowing it to act as a good check to several offensive threats such as Excadrill, Choice Scarf Sawk, and Choice Scarf Dracovish. Additionally, Corviknight's access to status moves like Iron Defense and Roost lets it beat most physical threats that can't 2HKO it, such as Sawk, Golisopod, and Durant. 248 HP and 100 Defense EVs allow Corviknight to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Scarf Dracovish after Sitrus Berry and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan's Flare Blitz. 80 Special Defense, alongside the HP, lets Corviknight survive two Ice Beam from Choice Scarf Kyurem, letting Corviknight PP stall. The rest of the EVs are put into Speed, allowing Corviknight to outspeed non-Jolly Crustle and Gardevoir, if it receives a Choice Scarf through Trick. Generally, it's better to match Corviknight against physical threats that can't 2HKO it such as Crustle, Tyranitar, and Golisopod, as it can then use Iron Defense to bolster its Defense to the point where it can start to PP stall them via Pressure and use Roost to recover any incurred damage. Iron Head is Corviknight's main STAB move, and it allows Corviknight to hit Ice- and Fairy-types such as non-Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan, Whimsicott, and Gardevoir. Corviknight can also run Body Press, which will allow it to KO Choice Scarf Dracovish without waiting for it to run out of PP. This is expressly for the purpose of avoiding potential critical hits, and outside of this is wholly inferior to Iron Head. Corviknight can also handle Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dragapult and Choice Scarf Hydreigon through using Pressure to PP stall Fire Blast and slowly recover health until the foe struggles. An alternative spread of 56 HP / 252 Def / 200 Spe can be run in order to outspeed Modest Sylveon, avoiding Yawn and Fake Tears shenanigans, while still almost always beating Choice Scarf Dracovish. Corviknight in general can run many different Speed benchmarks, depending on what it needs to get done, which can let it beat opposing Taunt users such as bulky Mandibuzz, bulky Kommo-o, or physical threats, like Choice Band Diggersby.

Dragon-type Pokemon such as Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Haxorus appreciate Corviknight's ability to handle Ice- and Fairy-type Pokemon such as Galarian Darmanitan, and Sylveon. In return, they take advantage of the Fire- and Electric-type Pokemon that Corviknight struggles against, including Chandelure, Dracozolt, and Rotom-H. Galarian Darmanitan, in particular, pairs well with Corviknight, as it is able to check some Electric- and Dragon-type Pokemon such as Choice Specs Dragapult, Choice Specs Hydreigon, and Dracozolt. In return, Corviknight can handle Pokemon like Aegislash and Crustle and threaten the aforementioned Pokemon. Corviknight appreciates Electric-type Pokemon such as Dracozolt and Rotom-W, as they can handle Water-type Pokemon such as Dracovish and Inteleon, which Corviknight struggles to beat. On the other hand, the same Electric-types, benefit from Corviknight's typing and ability to defeat many Ground-types that would otherwise give them trouble, such as Rhyperior and Excadrill.

nationaldex.comments:
Other Options

Iron Head is an option over Brave Bird or Body Press, allowing Corviknight to defeat Calm Mind Clefable while still hitting Mega Tyranitar and Kyurem decently hard. Iron Defense in tandem with Body Press can be used on stall teams to keep pace with Swords Dance Garchomp and Landorus-T, but this role is often better filled by Skarmory or Quagsire. Taunt can be used to shut down passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Hippowdon, and Clefable while also blocking any attempt to set up and blow past Corviknight. Unfortunately, Corviknight's other moves have much greater opportunity costs than Taunt has benefits. Shed Shell can be used to escape Magnezone, but losing Leftovers or Rocky Helmet is extremely detrimental, and having little use against teams without Magnezone makes it very matchup dependent.

Checks and Counters

Electric-type Pokemon and Coverage: Magnezone, Tapu Koko, and Zeraora all use Corviknight as a free entry point thanks to their Flying resistance. The first in particular poses a huge threat to Corviknight, as it can trap it and remove it from the game. Similarly, Pokemon like Clefable and Mega Mawile often run Electric-type coverage that can beat down Corviknight.

Fire-types: Heatran and Mega Charizard Y are easily capable of breaking past Corviknight with their STAB moves. The latter in particular can repeatedly come in if Stealth Rock is not on the field thanks to Roost. However, both must be wary of switching into too many Brave Birds or Body Presses, or of Corviknight using them to pivot into a wallbreaker like Mega Medicham or Tapu Koko.

Substitute Ground-types: Landorus-T and Excadrill are normally walled by Corviknight, but if they decide to run Substitute, they can use it as setup fodder. As Corviknight cannot touch them without the proper move and U-turn can't break their Substitutes, they can simply set up safely behind a Substitute and break past it. It should be noted that Bulk Up and Iron Defense sets can set up alongside these Pokemon, making them non-issues.

sets.name: Defog Pivot
sets.description:
Corviknight's ability to compress several important defensive niches at once makes it a strong utility Pokemon on many teams. Its good matchups against common entry hazard setters in Garchomp, Landorus-T, Mega Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn, alongside Pressure to deplete the PP of their entry hazards, make it a fantastic Defogger. Brave Bird is preferred to threaten Rillaboom, Garchomp, Mega Medicham, and Landorus-T, but Body Press can be used if one's team is weak to Pokemon like Excadrill and Kartana, or if one wants to secure the Mega Tyranitar matchup while discouraging Heatran from switching in. U-turn allows Corviknight to take advantage of the Pokemon it checks by granting free switch-in opportunities to teammates, preserve momentum against Pokemon that seek to take advantage of it such as Heatran and Mega Charizard Y, and escape Magnezone on the switch. Alternatively, Bulk Up can be used over U-turn to better deal with the setup sweepers Corviknight is tasked with handling, like Gliscor and offensive Landorus-T, while also letting it act as a potent wincon. However, U-turn's utility makes Bulk Up generally inferior.

Pressure allows Corviknight to PP stall entry hazard moves of passive setters, such as Ferrothorn and Clefable lacking Calm Mind, as well as PP stall other Pokemon like Gliscor and Mega Tyranitar. 184 Defense EVs with an Impish nature allow Corviknight to not be OHKOed by +2 Continental Crush from Landorus-T, with the remaining EVs going to Special Defense to let it switch into Tapu Lele, Mega Latias, and Clefable better. Alternatively, a spread of 252 HP / 44 Def / 212 SpD with an Impish nature allows Corviknight to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Hidden Power Fire while also letting it withstand +2 Garchomp's Continental Crush. If running U-turn, using 0 Speed IVs with a Relaxed nature is an option to grab as much momentum as possible against Pokemon like Clefable, although being slower than Blissey and Mega Mawile can be problematic. Leftovers prevents Corviknight from being worn down too quickly. Alternatively, Rocky Helmet can be used to punish U-turn from the likes of Mega Scizor, Landorus-T, and Mega Lopunny.

Corviknight is heavily threatened by Fire-types like Heatran and Mega Charizard Y. Therefore, bulky Water-types like Slowbro, Slowking, Gastrodon, and Toxapex can form strong defensive cores with it. Gastrodon can also deal with a major roadblock in Zapdos; Slowbro and Slowking can form a pivot core with Corviknight; and Toxapex enjoys Corviknight checking most Ground- and Psychic-types. Corviknight has a mediocre matchup against Electric-types and Pokemon with Electric-type coverage, such as Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Mega Mawile. Teammates that can take these threats on, such as the aforementioned Gastrodon in Tapu Koko's case and Heatran in the case of the latter two, pair well with it. Corviknight can form pivot cores with Pokemon like Landorus-T and Mega Lopunny, with both appreciating Corviknight's ability to lure in Steel-types that they can take advantage of such as Aegislash, Magnezone, and Heatran. Pokemon that appreciate Corviknight's ability to get them in unscathed, such as Mega Medicham, Mega Mawile, and Weavile, make great partners. Weavile in particular is great at strengthening the matchup against Ground-types that Corviknight cannot properly force out, such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gliscor.

sets.name: Support (Psychic)
sets.description:
Thanks to a decent movepool, Orbeetle performs a utility role for Psychic teams, providing support through dual screens and Sticky Web. Dual screens support is great for Psychic teams, as it not only makes Orbeetle's teammates harder to revenge kill but also aids setup sweepers in setting up much more efficiently. Sticky Web, on the other hand, slows down faster threats like Choice Scarf Weavile and Gengar, allowing teammates like Choice Scarf Gardevoir and Jirachi to deal with such threats much more easily and to threaten opposing teams better. Orbeetle should be used early-game so that it can provide essential support to the team to have momentum going; however, when faced against teams with Magic Bounce users like Hatterene and Xatu, it's best not to set up Sticky Web recklessly, as it can backfire. U-turn should be used to switch into an appropriate teammate after Orbeetle has set screens or Sticky Web. Frisk allows Orbeetle to scout for items on the opposing teams. Maximum HP and Speed EVs with a Timid nature make Orbeetle as fast as possible to outspeed Pokemon like Rotom-H and Mamoswine while surviving as many hits as possible doing so. Light Clay increases the number of turns Reflect and Light Screen stay on the field.

All of Orbeetle's teammates appreciate it providing dual screens and Sticky Web support. Setup Pokemon like Calm Mind Hatterene, Nasty Plot Mew, Necrozma, and Reuniclus appreciate Orbeetle's support to set up more easily. Stallbreaker Mew can help prevent Pokemon like Corviknight and Pelipper from removing Sticky Web and dual screens. Other offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Jirachi and Gardevoir can outspeed faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Dragapult and Gengar with Sticky Web support. A wallbreaker like Indeedee benefits from the support provided by Orbeetle, granting it more chances to wreck havoc on the opposing team. Celebi can also be used for Stealth Rock and Healing Wish support, and it can also take on Water- and Ground-type Pokemon like Seismitoad and Excadrill for the team.

zu.comments:
Other Options

Thievul can be ran on Electric Terrain teams with Electric Seed, although the archetype isn't very effective. Thievul can use the combination of Throat Spray + Snarl or Sitrus Berry + Substitute to activate Unburden; however, these sets need several turns to set up and are often not worth using. Hyper Beam is Thievul's strongest move and an option on both sets to nuke Dark- and Fairy-types such as Silvally-Dark and Alcremie, but it is exploitable and gives the foe a free turn, and Thievul can outspeed and 2HKO most of these threats with its other moves. A Timid nature can be used on the Choice Specs set to give Thievul a better matchup against more offensive teams; however, a Modest nature lets Thievul break through special walls like Audino, Eviolite-less Clefairy, and Wishiwashi with a boost from Stakeout.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Thanks to their great special bulk and resistance to Thievul's STAB moves, Fairy-types such as Carbink, Alcremie, and Clefairy easily wall Thievul, even if non-specially defensive variants of them have to watch out for Stakeout-boosted Psychic.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Skuntank, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry tank Dark Pulse and Psychic and threaten Thievul. However, they aren't extremely reliable, as they still take heavy damage from Stakeout-boosted moves and Nasty Plot-boosted Burning Jealousy.

Fighting-types: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, Thievul fails to OHKO Fighting-types such as Poliwrath, Gurdurr, and Throh, which can take it out.

Faster Attackers: Due to its mediocre bulk, Choice Specs Thievul is forced out by faster attackers such as Silvally-Ground, Sawk, and Kangaskhan.

Specially Defensive Walls: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, specially defensive walls such as Audino, Wishiwashi, and Cryogonal can easily wall Thievul. However, Thievul can 2HKO them with its Stakeout- or Nasty Plot-boosted moves, so they have to be played carefully.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Thievul is a deadly wallbreaker thanks to the combination of Choice Specs and Stakeout. Psychic OHKOes Fighting-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath with a Stakeout boost and serves as its strongest move for Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy. Despite its low base power, Burning Jealousy is Thievul's strongest option for Dark-types such as Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian and lets Thievul force out some special walls like Frosmoth and Ferroseed. Knock Off is an alternative that cripples Eviolite-reliant walls such as Clefairy and Type: Null, letting Thievul beat them later with its other moves.

Thievul works best on offensive teams looking for a very powerful special wallbreaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Silvally-Ground can force in physical walls such as Qwilfish, Tangela, and Uxie, giving Thievul an opportunity to switch in. These partners can also break through specially defensive Pokemon that give Thievul a hard time, such as Clefairy, Audino, and Alcremie. Since Fairy-, Dark-, and Fighting-types such as Clefairy, Silvally-Dark, and Sawk threaten Thievul, checks to these types, such as Rapidash, Gurdurr, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. VoltTurn users such as Wishiwashi, Uxie, Rotom-S, and Silvally-Ground create opportunities for Thievul to activate Stakeout. Due to Thievul's average Speed tier, it struggles versus more offensive teams; therefore, fast Pokemon such as Cinccino and Choice Scarf Sawk make for great partners.

camomons.comments:
Other Options

Drednaw can run Superpower as its secondary STAB move for a Water / Fighting typing, but this leaves typing it unable to hit Water / Poison types like Toxapex well and is better run by Barraskweda. Stone Edge can also be used as Drednaw's secondary STAB move, but it is more unreliable and gives worse coverage overall.

Checks and Counters

Rillaboom: Rillaboom is able to resist both of Drednaw's STAB attacks, weaken Earthquake with Grassy Terrain, and OHKO it with Grassy Glide.

Opposing Weather: Drednaw heavily relies on rain support to perform, so opposing weather setters like Torkoal and Hippowdon hamper its ability to sweep and take on faster threats.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Mew, Latias, and Hydreigon can beat Drednaw, as they resist or are immune to its STAB moves. However, they fail to check Drednaw in rain after a Swords Dance.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Drednaw is a potent physically attacking Swift Swim user thanks to its fair Speed and access to Swords Dance. Rain-boosted Liquidation is Drednaw's strongest STAB move and pairs well with Earthquake, as they allow Drednaw to 2HKO Water-resistant foes as well as Flying-types and Levitate Fire-types like Mew and Hydreigon, respectively. Swords Dance makes Drednaw extremely threatening in rain, allowing it to 2HKO bulky Water-types like Mew, Slowbro, and Latias. Stone Edge lets Drednaw cover its defensive checks like Water / Flying Mew and Pelipper and Water / Dragon Hydreigon and Latias. Superpower is another coverage option that allows Drednaw to hit Levitate users like Steel / Dragon Hydreigon without relying on rain. Stealth Rock is another option to wear down Drednaw's checks through the battle. Max Speed EVs are needed to outspeed Choice Scarf Victini and +1 Volcarona while rain is active.

Drednaw's special attacking partners on rain teams like Kingdra, Latios, and Tornadus-T appreciate its ability to pressure specially defensive foes like RegenVest Slowking and Blissey. Drednaw needs rain support in order to perform, so Pelipper is required. Pelipper can also safely bring Drednaw in via U-turn and support it with other moves like Defog and Knock Off. Drednaw can struggle to break past Water / Flying Mew and is threatened by its rain-boosted STAB moves, so a Water-resistant partner like Dragon / Ghost Salamence makes a great teammate. Salamence can also check priority attackers like Rillaboom and Entei that can threaten to revenge kill Drednaw.

nfe.comments:
Other Options

A trapping set with Fire Spin can bait in and eliminate Hattrem, allowing Carkol to secure its entry hazards soon after its gone. Flash Fire and Steam Engine are also possible abilities for Carkol, but it doesn't really benefit from the immunity or the Speed boost.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: With ineffective coverage against these targets, Water-types like Wartortle, Marshtomp, and Mareanie have no problem switching into and countering Carkol.

Ground-types: Piloswine, Gabite, and Krokorok can eliminate Carkol in a single hit with Earthquake, but may fear switching into Will-O-Wisp.

Fighting-types: Gurdurr and Machoke take little to no damage from Carkol and can avoid being crippled by burns thanks to their ability Guts.

Entry Hazards: Carkol itself is vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, and may sometimes have a hard time keeping entry hazards off its side of the field, particularly against Ground-type hazard setters such as Piloswine and Marshtomp.

sets.name: Specially Defensive Spinner
sets.description:
Carkol has a niche as a wall in the NFE metagame with its ability to check special attackers such as Galarian Mr. Mime and Lampent thanks to its great defensive stats. A large utility movepool also allows Carkol to be a great teammate and support Pokemon, although its typing is often a problem for it as special attackers like Wartortle and Magmar carry strong coverage for it. Rapid Spin is one of Carkol's best utility moves, allowing it to remove entry hazards on the field such as Stealth Rock or Spikes, with Carkol also threatening common setters like Ferroseed and Roselia with Heat Crash. Heat Crash is Carkol's main attacking move, helping it against special attackers like Galarian Mr. Mime as well as the aforementioned Grass- and Steel-types. Alternatively, Rock Blast can threaten Fire-types like Lampent and Magmar. Spikes and Stealth Rock support Carkol's teammates by reliably weakening opposing threats as they switch in. Will-O-Wisp is Carkol's main defense against physical threats that can otherwise easily switch in such as Piloswine and Gabite. Flame Body is chosen over Flash Fire for its additional burn chance when facing pivots such as Golbat and Thwackey.

Carkol is a Pokemon that should be used throughout the game, where it can help its teammates by taking off entry hazards and walling special attackers until these are low on health. Pair it with physical walls like Galarian Corsola and Tangela that wall threats such as Piloswine and Gurdurr, respectively. Carkol does not have any reliable recovery, and therefore is limited as to how many times it can come into the field and spin away hazards. Given that Carkol is weak to Stealth Rock and has no defense against residual damage, using Wish passers or Healing Wish users like Clefairy and Hattrem can really help Carkol's longevity. Furthermore, Carkol also benefits from additional hazard pressure removal through the pairing of Magic Bounce Hattrem or Defog users like Golbat and Vullaby. Carkol is also very weak to Ground- and Water-types in general, so having a Grass-type like Tangela, Roselia, or Thwackey is recommended.

sets.name: Support (Rock)
sets.description:
Coalossal is great on Rock-type teams because of its access to Spikes and Rapid Spin enabling it to both set and remove entry hazards and its Fire typing allowing it to threaten Steel- and Grass-types like Ferrothorn and Rotom-C, come in on Grass-type attacks from Venusaur and Celebi, and troublesome Fairy-types like Hatterene. Spikes allows it to help chip opposing Pokemon on the switch in to help offensive teammates like Barbaracle and Tyranitar sweep. Fire Blast takes care of troublesome Steel- and Grass-types such as Ferrothorn, Jirachi, and Celebi. Heavy Slam allows Coalossal to greatly damage Fairy-types like Togekiss, Hatterene, and Mimikyu. Rapid Spin gives Rock teams a way to remove hazards like Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes in matchups such as Poison and Bug that could stop a teammate from sweeping. Flame Body is very good against physical attackers such as Jirachi and Bisharp to hinder them with a burn. Use Coalossal early-game to get down Spikes to make it easier for its teammates to sweep. It is also useful mid-game to help get rid of troublesome entry hazards. 252 HP and 252 Special Defense EVs with a Sassy nature let Coalossal take hits from Mew and Hatterene.

Setup sweepers such as Terrakion, Rhyperior, and Tyranitar appreciate Coalossal removing entry hazards like Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes that could stop them from sweeping. Barbaracle is an excellent teammate to take care of Ground-types such as Seismitoad and Mamoswine with Grass Knot and Liquidation, and it appreciates Coalossal to break Dugtrio's Focus Sash with Spikes. Shuckle can form a hazard stacking duo with Coalossal to further support setup Pokemon, setting Stealth Rock and Sticky Web to help its teammates such as Shell Smash Barbaracle, Swords Dance Terrakion, and Dragon Dance Tyranitar sweep. Tyranitar is also useful for setting sand that helps Coalossal stomach special attacks even better. Rhyperior is great for taking care of Corviknight with Smack Down + Earthquake, which Coalossal struggles to deal with. Terrakion can greatly help with taking care of Excadrill, Urshifu-S, and Hydreigon with Close Combat. Lycanroc-D helps to handle Poison-types such as Toxapex and can use Accelerock to finish off Pokemon like Volcarona and Scolipede. Lunatone can also be a good partner, as it can come in on Ground-type attacks due to Levitate and take care of troubling Pokemon like Toxapex thanks to its Psychic typing.

sets.name: G-Max Offensive
sets.description:
• With Steam Engine and an insane Gigantamax move in G-Max Volcalith, Coalossal threatens to become one of the fastest and most potent attackers in the metagame. When combined with a Surf user such as Dragapult or an Aqua Jet user such as Urshifu-R, Coalossal can easily maximize its Speed and gain a significant offensive boost from Weakness Policy.

  • Heat Wave is the Fire-type STAB move of choice due to it being a consistent spread move. It can also be used to set sun as Max Flare, which helps to mitigate Coalossal's otherwise severe weakness to Water. Said sun does remove Solar Beam's charge turn, but Solar Beam will usually be used as Max Overgrowth anyway.

  • Meteor Beam allows for the strongest G-Max Volcalith possible, which is the primary reason to run Coalossal thanks to its significant 1/6 damage to the targeted foe between turns.

  • Solar Beam via Max Overgrowth offers Coalossal a way through problematic Rock- and Water-types such as Regirock and Tapu Fini, as well as setting Grassy Terrain, lowering the power of incoming Earthquakes. Earth Power is responsible for beating threats such as opposing Coalossal and Nihilego while also boosting Coalossal's Special Defense with Max Quake.

  • 180 Speed EVs allow Coalossal to outspeed maximum Speed Venusaur in sun while at +6.

zu.comments:
Other Options

Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to consistently cripple opposing physical attackers, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Overheat is an alternative over Flamethrower, but its low PP and Special Attack drop make it less desirable than Flamethrower. Heat Crash is also a notable alternative, but Coalossal has trouble breaking Tangela with it. Similarly, Stone Edge can be used over Rock Blast, but its low PP and inaccuracy can be exploited by foes like Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Coalossal's 4x weakness to Water causes it to be threatened by the plethora of Water-types in ZU, such as Basculin, Qwilfish, and Wishiwashi. However, physical Water-types should be wary of being burned by Flame Body.

Ground-type Pokemon and Coverage: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Galarian Stunfisk are able to exploit Coalossal's 4x weakness to Ground and threaten it with Earthquake, which avoids Flame Body, or set up entry hazards; Silvally-Ground can also threaten Coalossal with its STAB move, but it has to watch out for Flame Body. Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan and Sawk can OHKO Coalossal with Earthquake and not activate Flame Body. Opposing Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash often carry Ground-type coverage moves to threaten Coalossal.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath can threaten Coalossal with their STAB options, although they dislike being burned.

Knock Off: Coalossal heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to consistently switch in and remove entry hazards. Losing it, combined with its lack of recovery, allows it to get easily worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Coalossal finds a distinct niche in ZU as a Spikes setter that provides good defensive utility against common foes such as Frosmoth, Articuno, and Rotom. It can force the aforementioned foes out to set up Spikes or remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Stealth Rock can be used if Coalossal is not paired with a Stealth Rock setter or if there is already a Rapid Spin user on the team. Rock Blast allows Coalossal to threaten Substitute users such as Frosmoth and Articuno and entry hazard removers such as Rotom-S and Altaria. Flamethrower lets Coalossal force out Tangela and Ferroseed, giving it the opportunity to reliably use Rapid Spin. Flame Body deters physical attackers like Cinccino and Silvally from spamming their STAB moves, and it can potentially cripple threats such as Silvally-Ground and physical Basculin in an emergency situation.

Coalossal can provide both entry hazard setting and removal for certain bulky offense teams. As Coalossal has 4x weaknesses to both Water and Ground, it is recommended to pair Coalossal with Grass-types such as Tangela and Ferroseed. Tangela is also able to tank hits from Fighting-types such as Sawk and Poliwrath, while Ferroseed is able to absorb Toxic from foes like Audino and Wishiwashi. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie and Alolan Persian can preserve Coalossal's Heavy-Duty Boots, letting it consistently pivot in to remove entry hazards; Uxie can also threaten the aforementioned Fighting-types.

zu.comments:
Other Options

An Adamant nature gives Flapple additional breaking power but leaves it outpaced by the likes of Frosmoth. A Choice Scarf set with a Jolly nature outpaces threats like Cinccino and Basculin, but it is still notably outpaced by Accelgor, faster Choice Scarf users like Sawk, and setup sweepers like +1 Silvally formes. A Dragon Dance set struggles to be very effective for the same reason, being revenge killed by faster Choice Scarf users like Sawk at +1 and by strong priority moves such as Piloswine's Ice Shard. Additionally, Flapple's poor bulk and defensive typing limit its setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: While they can't switch-in directly, faster Pokemon like Rotom-S, Accelgor, and Skuntank are able to outspeed and OHKO Flapple due to its poor bulk and defensive typing.

Ice-type Moves: Flapple's 4x weakness to Ice leaves it easily disposed of by faster Ice-types such as Articuno and Cryogonal, while Piloswine is able to OHKO Flapple with its priority Ice Shard. This weakness also leaves it susceptible to Ice-type coverage such as Basculin's Ice Beam.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Ferroseed and Perrserker resist both of Flapple's STAB moves, with the former threatening to cripple it with Knock Off or Thunder Wave and the latter threatening it offensively.

Fairy-types: While Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy are unable to switch into Grav Apple, they can take advantage of Flapple if it locks itself into Outrage or Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Flapple is a devastating wallbreaker thanks to its solid offensive typing in tandem with its Hustle-boosted attacks, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores consisting of Pokemon like Cofagrigus, Pyukumuku, and Audino. Grav Apple is Flapple's primary STAB move, with its Defense drop punishing switch-ins, reducing Flapple's reliance on prediction. A mixed Life Orb set with Draco Meteor allows Flapple to bypass Grass-resistant Pokemon and physical walls such as Altaria, Qwilfish, and Tangela. On the the other hand, a Choice Band set with Outrage handles specially bulky Grass-resistant Pokemon like Articuno and Frosmoth. Sucker Punch OHKOes faster offensive threats such as Choice Scarf Rotom as well as picking off Accelgor and Cinccino after some chip damage. Alternatively, Grassy Glide can be used on Grassy Terrain teams, threatening all faster Pokemon that do not resist Grass. Hustle does allow Flapple to 2HKO just about any Pokemon in the metagame, but its accuracy drop, combined with Flapple relying on a drawback-laden Draco Meteor or Outrage to dispatch Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Altaria, makes Flapple somewhat unreliable.

Flapple's poor bulk and defensive typing give it few direct switch-in opportunities, so it pairs well with bulky pivots that are able to bring it in safely such as Uxie, Wishiwashi, and Rotom-S. Alolan Sandslash and Qwilfish provide Flapple entry hazard support as well as pressuring Fairy-types like Alcremie and Clefairy. Special attackers such as Cramorant and Rotom appreciate Flapple's ability to pressure special walls like Wishiwashi, Altaria, and Audino. In return, Cramorant provides entry hazard removal, while Rotom forms an effective VoltTurn core with Flapple. Ninetales and Rapidash easily handle Ice- and Steel-types like Frosmoth, Articuno, and Ferroseed that Flapple struggles with, while Flapple can break down their checks such as Altaria and Wishiwashi. Late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Silvally formes appreciate Flapple's ability to break walls such as Cofagrigus and Pyukumuku, respectively. Flapple works well on Grassy Terrain teams, supporting its teammates by threatening conventional Grass-type checks like Altaria.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Grass)
sets.description:
Thanks to its Dragon typing and Thick Fat ability, Appletun plays an important role as a Fire-resistant Pokemon on Grass-type teams. Its high HP combined with its decent Special Defense allows it to comfortably tank special hits that aren't super effective such as Dragapult's Shadow Ball and Hydreigon's Dark Pulse. Investment in Special Defense is chosen because most Fire-type attacks are special and Appletun's most valuable trait is resisting Fire. Recover combined with Leech Seed, Protect, and Leftovers can be problematic to deal with, as it gives Appletun a lot of ways to recover HP and stall out the foe. Protect is also very important for scouting Choice users such as Dracozolt, Dragapult, and Hydreigon, allowing Grass teams to take advantage by making the right switch. Appletun's bulk allows it to pivot in on attacks that don't threaten to OHKO it such as Gengar's Focus Blast and gain momentum by using Leech Seed, followed up by Protect to scout the opponent's next move and gain more recovery from Leech Seed and Leftovers.

Ferrothorn forms a great defensive core with Appletun, as they cover each other's weaknesses. Appletun resists Fire-type attacks that threaten Ferrothorn and the rest of the team, while Ferrothorn is immune to Poison, resists Dragon, and takes neutral damage from Ice-, Flying-, and Bug-type attacks. This comes into play against threats such as Galarian Darmanitan, Choice Specs Hydreigon, and Indeedee, which have the coverage to threaten both Appletun and Ferrothorn, but Protect allows them to scout which move they're going for and make the appropriate switch. Ferrothorn can also set up entry hazards, which Appletun can take advantage of by using Leech Seed to force switches and Protect to scout Choice users, resulting in the opposing team taking a lot of damage. Whimsicott also covers Appletun's Dragon weakness and threatens Dragon-type teams, which are hard for Grass to deal with. Whimsicott also appreciates Appletun's Leech Seed to get recovery when it switches in on a Dragon-type attack. In addition, Whimsicott can use Encore on Pokemon trying to setup or lock them into a recovery or status move. Rotom-C threatens Flying-types, most notably Corviknight and Togekiss, which pose huge threats to Grass. Rillaboom is a good partner and great Choice Scarf user that can threaten Ferrothorn with Superpower, which otherwise would be very hard for Grass teams to break. Choice Scarf Rillaboom can outspeed and threaten some problematic Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Choice Scarf Gardevoir, and Dragapult.

pu.overview: Sandaconda is able to serve as a consistent Stealth Rock user and Electric-immune Pokemon with its natural bulk and Shed Skin. With Shed Skin and Rest, Sandaconda is able to remain healthy throughout the game to check Pokemon like Passimian, Aggron, and Silvally-Steel. Sandaconda also provides speed control with Glare, making it less easy to take advantage of. Sandaconda's decent Speed and Attack mean it can even commit to a Coil set, although its typing and poor Special Defense leaves it forced out by tier staples like Whimsicott. However, Sandaconda still faces competition from Palossand as a Stealth Rock user and Electric-immune Pokemon, as it has more consistent recovery and better bulk. Shed Skin is also not consistent, making it unsafe to be overly dependent on Rest.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Sandaconda is able to cripple Pokemon it cannot touch with Earthquake like Mesprit and Archeops with Glare. Rest is able to keep Sandaconda healthy and is more reliable in combination with Shed Skin. Rocky Helmet allows Sandaconda to wear down Pokemon such as Togedemaru. Leftovers gives Sandaconda more sustainability, but it is often switching into Knock Off from Pokemon like Passimian and Absol anyway. The Speed investment allows Sandaconda to outspeed Adamant Aggron. Pokemon like Togedemaru and Lanturn are able to provide Wish and cleric support respectively so Sandaconda is less reliant on Shed Skin, and can sponge special attacks from Pokemon such as Ribombee and Charizard. In return, Sandaconda can switch into strong physical attackers like Lycanroc and Archeops. Wallbreakers such as Gallade and Magmortar are able to capitalize on Sandaconda spreading paralysis. Sandaconda can run Stone Edge over Glare to hit Flying-types like Archeops at the cost of providing less support.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Cramorant finds a niche in ZU as a Defogger, threatening common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Piloswine. Roost is necessary to improve Cramorant's longevity and lets it consistently switch into the likes of Accelgor and Poliwrath. Surf activates Gulp Missile, allowing Cramorant to punish attackers, and can potentially paralyze them if Gulp Missile is activated when it has no more than 50% HP. Brave Bird complements Surf by weakening foes such as Qwilifish and Ferroseed while ignoring Ice Scales from Frosmoth, letting Cramorant OHKO it; Brave Bird also benefits from Gulp Missile lowering the foe's Defense stat when Cramorant is above 50% HP.

Although Cramorant is an effective Defogger, its 4x weakness to Electric makes it susceptible to Rotom formes. Checks to them such as Rhydon and Ferroseed are appreciated; Rhydon can also check Kangaskhan, while Ferroseed can take Toxic from foes such as Miltank and Wishiwashi. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes and Alolan Persian can improve Cramorant's longevity and let it consistently clear entry hazards by keeping Heavy-Duty Boots intact; in return, the former two appreciate Cramorant checking Frosmoth and the latter values it threatening opposing Ground-types. Cramorant's ability to inflict paralysis with Gulp Missile at low HP complements slow wallbreakers like Arctovish and Skuntank and aids them against fast attackers like Cinccino and Sawk. Powerful attackers such as Silk Scarf Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Cinccino appreciate Cramorant's Defog letting them consistently switch into battle.

Other Options

Hurricane is an alternative to Brave Bird that is weaker against Frosmoth and Ferroseed, but stronger against physically bulky Pokemon such as Poliwrath and Qwilfish. Substitute synergizes well with Gulp Missile, helping Cramorant reach the range for its Gorging forme; however, it is generally less effective than Cramorant's other moves. An offensive spread of 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe can be utilized with Hurricane to better offensively pressure foes such as Tangela and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom and Rotom-S can OHKO Cramorant.

Strong Attackers: Although they dislike taking damage and a potential paralysis from Gulp Missile, strong attackers such as Silvally-Dark and Kangaskhan are capable of easily KOing Cramorant.

Status: Toxic from foes like Wishiwashi and Miltank and Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Cofagrigus and Jellicent are some of the best ways to handle Cramorant, as residual damage does not activate Gulp Missile.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Arrokuda is primarily a revenge killer, using its vast movepool and coverage options to check a variety of threats. Close Combat is able to 2HKO Ferroseed and Cufant as well as OHKO Pawniard. Aqua Jet lets Arrokuda deal with more offensive teams by picking off their faster weakened Pokemon. Psychic Fangs destroys Croagunk and 2HKOes Mareanie, while Drill Run can also be run to deal super effective damage to Chinchou at the cost of only 2HKOing Croagunk. Lastly, Poison Jab is also an option to check and OHKO Cottonee and Morelull. This simple EV spread paired with a Jolly nature maximizes Arrokuda's Speed and offensive potential, while the 17 HP IVs ensure that Arrokuda only takes 1 HP of Life Orb recoil every attack by being at maximum 19 HP. However, if Berry Juice is opted for instead, make sure to have perfect IVs and add the remaining 28 EVs into HP for a little bit more longevity.

Entry hazard setters such as Ferroseed, Onix, and Pawniard benefit Arrokuda's ability to score more KOs thanks to the chip damage dealt to the foes by entry hazards throughout the game; with one layer of Spikes up, Mareanie often drops to Psychic Fangs after a Liquidation, while Ferroseed usually drops to Close Combat after a Liquidation. VoltTurn users like Vullaby and Chinchou allow for Arrokuda to switch in safely due to its poor bulk, while Arrokuda benefits these three users in particular by checking Onix and other Rock- or Ground-types to more easily spam a singular move.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Barraskewda's strong Attack and incredible Speed paired with Swift Swim make it an imposing sweeper under rain. Its diverse coverage makes it difficult to switch into. The coverage allows it to cover threats to Water-type teams such as Close Combat for Ferrothorn, Psychic Fangs for Toxapex, and Crunch for Dragapult. Choice Band allows Barraskewda to break teams without suffering chip damage that would make it more susceptible to priority. On the other hand, Life Orb takes greater advantage of its coverage.

As Water-type Pokemon are generally slow, Barraskewda helps its teammates by eliminating very fast threats like Dragapult. Pelipper is a great teammate, as it sets up the rain, which makes Barraskewda into a potent sweeper. Other Swim Swim users, like Seismitoad and Drednaw, are excellent partners, as they help break the opposing team. In particular, Seismitoad is a good partner, as it can break physical walls for it, while Barraskewda breaks specials walls. Toxapex also helps by withering down the foe and coming into priority attacks that threaten Barraskewda. Gyarados and Barraskewda have strong synergy, as they can wallbreak for each other, allowing the other to sweep late-game.

ru.overview: Choice Specs Toxtricity is arguably RU's most threatening immediate attacker thanks to its Punk Rock-boosted Boomburst, which has very few consistent switch-ins. Pokemon with the typing or special bulk to take Boomburst, like Stakataka and Porygon2, are vulnerable to Toxtricity's coverage or lose momentum to Volt Switch. Though slow, Toxtricity poses a massive early-game threat to offensive teams, as staples like Noivern cannot immediately OHKO it and fear getting OHKOed in return. Its resistances let it even switch into and punish Cobalion, Roserade, and Raikou once or twice, especially if they go for utility moves. Once Toxtricity has taken some damage, however, it becomes much less of a threat, as its low Speed and bulk will make it easy for many Pokemon to pick off. Its vulnerability to Stealth Rock and Spikes worsens this issue, especially in a metagame full of pivots using Heavy-Duty Boots, which incentivizes conventional offensive teams to forgo entry hazard removal. It faces competition from RU's other top Electric-types, Raikou and Xurkitree; the former's naturally high Speed lets it remain a threat to offense all game long, while the latter can use Choice Scarf to similarly threaten offense or Heavy-Duty Boots to wallbreak like Toxtricity without fearing entry hazards. Both Electric-types are always faster than offensive Togekiss, which can overcome weakened Toxtricity with Air Slash flinches.
ru.comments:
Other Options

A Shift Gear set using Boomburst, Overdrive, Drain Punch, and Life Orb or Throat Spray with maximum Special Attack and Speed investment and a Mild or Hasty nature can be a nasty surprise sweeper that beats and sets up on Porygon2. With so many other sweepers and Choice Scarf users available, including Sharpedo, Cloyster, Mimikyu, Xurkitree, and Heracross, dedicating Toxtricity to the role is usually unnecessary and a waste of its power.

Checks and Counters

Entry Hazards and Offensive Pressure: Offensive teams often won't have a solid switch-in to Toxtricity beyond a one-time check like Steelix; they bank on trading damage with it or wearing it down with Stealth Rock and Spikes until it's in KO range of faster Pokemon. Toxtricity's unremarkable bulk means this won't take long. Most aggressive teams will also give Toxtricity very few opportunities to directly switch in.

Ghost-types: The presence of a Ghost-type forces Toxtricity to think twice about spamming Boomburst, limiting how much damage it can get out of its attack opportunities. Golurk and Lightning Rod Alolan Marowak are even immune to Electric, meaning Toxtricity has to risk using the generally mediocre Snarl or Sludge Bomb. Colbur Berry Dhelmise can take a hit from Toxtricity pretty well. Ghost-types generally work well with Ground-types by maximizing the number of predictions Toxtricity has to make.

Porygon2: Punk Rock halves damage taken from sound-based moves, making Trace Porygon2 a very reliable switch-in to Toxtricity, albeit one wide open to Volt Switch.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Snorlax and Registeel can stand up to Toxtricity's attacks for a while, though they lose momentum to Volt Switch and are easily pressured. Diancie and Stakataka can switch into Boomburst but hate Electric-type attacks. Steelix and Assault Vest Reuniclus can switch into Boomburst once and threaten to KO in return.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Punk Rock Toxtricity's Boomburst has obscene power and coverage, OHKOing or 2HKOing most Pokemon and even 3HKOing Steelix and Rhyperior. Overdrive is a consistent Electric-type attack that punishes Boomburst switch-ins like Stakataka and Diancie. Volt Switch lets Toxtricity bring a threatening teammate in against relatively consistent checks like Porygon2 and Registeel. Sludge Bomb can poison bulky switch-ins, 2HKOes Alolan Marowak, and OHKOes Trace Gardevoir. Snarl catches the occasional Golurk along with OHKOing Alolan Marowak. Toxtricity's Speed tier isn't crowded, so it can get away with a Modest nature. Running a Timid nature is advantageous against other Toxtricity, though it makes Pokemon harder to OHKO with Boomburst.

Proactive teams using offensive pivots like Noivern and Volt Switch Cobalion are best at giving Toxtricity chances to freely attack and compensating for its poor Speed. Flygon and Mienshao are U-turn users that pivot on switch-ins like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing, which healthy Toxtricity is then free to exploit. They form a VoltTurn core with Toxtricity as well, giving defensive teams a miserable time. Other Fighting-types like Heracross punish bulky Normal- and Steel-types for switching into Boomburst. Toxtricity is a very self-sufficient attacker once it's made it into the battle, so its team doesn't need to give it much specific support; just have a plan for when common threats switch in to revenge kill it.

sets.name: Wallbreaker (Electric)
sets.description:
Thanks to its ability in Punk Rock increasing its sound-based moves incredibly and Choice Specs, Toxtricity can act as the premier special wallbreaker for Electric teams. When combined, Overdrive and Boomburst cover the majority of the metagame and can prove difficult to deal with for teams that lack key resistances to this combination. Volt Switch allows Toxtricity to act as a pivot that can be used when predicting a Pokemon that resists the two aforementioned moves to come into the field such as Ferrothorn. Maximum Speed investment is used in order to allow it to outspeed the majority of the unboosted metagame with Sticky Web support.

Toxtricity has a notably difficult time dealing with Pokemon that resist both Overdrive and Boomburst, such as Ferrothorn and Excadrill, and as such, it appreciates Pokemon with Fire-type coverage such as Dracozolt. Furthermore, due do its very middling Speed, Sticky Web support from Vikavolt is greatly needed in order for it to outspeed opposing Pokemon. Finally, slow pivot support from Pokemon like Rotom-W immensely benefits Toxtricity, allowing it to be brought in safely and gain KOs, as its mediocre defenses disallow it from taking on many attacks. Both Vikavolt and Rotom-W's ability in Levitate helps Toxtricity by allowing them to deal with Ground-type attacks for it as well.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Poison)
sets.description:
Toxtricity is a strong wallbreaker thanks to its solid Special Attack combined with Choice Specs and its access to Overdrive and Boomburst, which get boosted by its Punk Rock ability. Sludge Wave is primarily used against Fairy- and Grass-type Pokemon, as otherwise, Boomburst is its most powerful attack. Volt Switch allows Toxtricity to pivot and give its teammates safe switches in or put its foe in range of its attack the next time it switches in. Toxtricity's part-Electric typing makes it very valuable against Water- and Flying-type teams and allows it to break Corviknight, which is otherwise a threat to Poison. Its Speed and bulk are mediocre, hence it prefers switching in on passive Pokemon that can't do too much damage or being brought in on a predicted switch.

Galarian Weezing covers Toxtricity's big weakness to Ground-type attacks and can remove entry hazards that hinder Toxtricity's longevity with Defog. Drapion is immune to Psychic-type attacks that threaten Toxtricity and can set up Toxic Spikes to weaken the opponent's team to support Toxtricity's wallbreaking. Drapion also has access to STAB Knock Off, which provides useful utility in removing the foe's item. Gengar is a great revenge killer that can handle faster threats such as Hydreigon and Galarian Darmanitan. Salazzle helps break Steel-type Pokemon, notably Ferrothorn, which are problematic for Poison teams to deal with. It can also annoy many teams with its Corrosion-boosted Toxic combined with Substitute and Protect, and it pivots into Toxapex. Defensive Vileplume is a great partner for checking Mold Breaker Excadrill thanks to its typing, which lets it take neutral hits from Ground, and access to Strength Sap and Sleep Powder, which allow it to consistently check it. Toxapex acts as a great pivot to strong attacks that threaten Toxtricity such as Charizard's Fire Blast and Weavile's Icicle Crash.

pu.overview: Centiskorch makes for a great wallbreaker thanks to its fantastic movepool and great Attack, allowing it to beat most physically defensive walls and Fire-resistant Pokemon like Palossand, Gigalith, and Jellicent. Its ability Flash Fire, decent special bulk, and typing allow it to switch into threats like Magmortar and Ribombee, although its lack of recovery means it can't do so very often. However, Centiskorch's mediocre defensive typing, Speed, and Defense leave it susceptible to many faster threats like Absol, Archeops, Basculin, and Passimian, which also makes it harder to get it in the field safely.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Fire Lash makes Centiskorch harder to switch into, and it allows Centiskorch to get past defensive behemoths like Weezing and Palossand more easily. Power Whip hits Ground-, Rock-, and Water-types, and Knock Off allows Centiskorch to cripple foes reliant on their items. Due to its poor physical bulk, typing, and Speed, Centiskorch greatly appreciates teammates capable of bringing it in safely; Archeops, Togedemaru, and Ribombee are great examples, as they all appreciate it weakening down their answers like Gigalith. Basculin is another great example, as it enjoys Centiskorch softening up Jellicent. Answers to Flying-, Rock-, and Water-types like Charizard, Aggron, and Kabutops are greatly appreciated, as Centiskorch often finds itself forced out by them. This makes Regirock and Palossand great partners as they can also support it with their Stealth Rock, giving it an easier time wallbreaking.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Due to its ability to boost its stats with Bulk Up as well as its access to semi-reliable recovery in Drain Punch, Grapploct can function as a solid wincon on balance teams while also being able to check physical attackers such as Morpeko. Brutal Swing allows Grapploct to hit Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Musharna and Gourgeist, whereas Sucker Punch gives it the ability to hit faster Pokemon such as Boltund as well as deal with offensive teams in general. The given HP and Defense investment lets Grapploct avoid the 2HKO from Life Orb Drednaw's Liquidation after Stealth Rock, while the Special Defense EVs let it take Modest Choice Specs Glaceon's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock.

Psychic-types such as Mr. Rime, Beheeyem, and Galarian Rapidash can handle Poison-types like Mareanie for Grapploct, while they in turn appreciate Grapploct's ability to handle Dark-types like Morpeko. Morpeko in turn aids Grapploct in dealing with Ghost- and Psychic-types, which Grapploct can struggle against while Beheeyem can provide slow momentum for Grapploct with Teleport. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Roselia and Stunfisk further aid Grapploct in wearing down foes. Fairy-types such as Galarian Rapidash and Shiinotic are difficult for Grapploct to deal with as well, so Pokemon such as Roselia, Drednaw, Mawile, and Flareon make for decent partners. Mawile and Pawniard also provide Knock Off support to weaken bulkier Pokemon such as Mareanie that can be problematic for Grapploct to handle. Healing Wish support from Pokemon such as Mr. Mime and Galarian Rapidash can provide Grapploct with a second chance to sweep.

ru.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently due to be revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Polteageist functions as an effective sweeper on hyper offense teams due to a combination of good stats, ability in Cursed Body, and movepool. Strength Sap lowers the Attack of Pokemon like Incineroar to where it is unable to KO Polteageist and provides reliable recovery. It can also aid Polteageist in beating Incineroar provided that Misty Terrain is active. Shadow Ball either OHKOes or 2HKOes most Pokemon that don't resist it. Giga Drain allows Polteageist to OHKO Water / Ground types such as Gastrodon and Seismitoad and hit bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune for super effective damage. Alternatively, Polteageist can run Stored Power over Giga Drain in order to hit neutral targets such as Crobat, Raikou, and Golisopod for more damage. White Herb reverses the stat drops from Shell Smash and enables Polteageist to take on Incineroar. The given Defense EVs let Polteageist survive a -1 Darkest Lariat from Incineroar from full health, while 224 Speed EVs allow it to outspeed Choice Scarf Mienshao after one Shell Smash boost.

Polteageist's sweeps can be cut short by status ailments such as poison. Hence, it appreciates Misty Terrain support from the likes of Galarian Weezing, which can also support it with Memento, allowing it to set up on an effected foe. Polteageist also struggles to break through specially defensive Steel-types such as Registeel, meaning that Ground- and Fighting-type Pokemon such as Rhyperior and Heracross are great teammates for it. Entry hazard support from the likes of Roserade and Necrozma eases Polteageist's ability to sweep through teams. Lastly, Polteageist appreciates dual screens support from the likes of Klefki and Froslass, which allows it to set up relatively safely.

uu.overview: Polteageist's primary role in the UU metagame is as a late-game sweeper; with support to eliminate its weaknesses to priority moves and Dark-types, it becomes a premier offensive threat. Shell Smash and powerful coverage options like Giga Drain and Stored Power make it a threatening setup sweeper that can easily OHKO much of the tier. However, Polteageist's frail defensive stats means it needs significant team support to truly be a consistent threat; while it's a powerful sweeper, it's still a predictable one due to having only one viable set, unlike other setup sweepers such as Necrozma and Kommo-o. Additionally, Polteageist struggles to break through Dark-types like Zarude and Galarian Moltres. The potential upside of using Polteageist is huge, but its weakness to entry hazards and priority alongside its inability to break through several common metagame threats can easily hamper its success. Polteageist works best with Psychic Terrain support to neutralize its weakness to priority, and while it can succeed with dual screens support, there are several other setup sweepers that require less support and are easier to justify.
uu.comments:
Other Options

White Herb can be used in place of Focus Sash to restore the reduced defenses from Shell Smash, making Polteageist less immediately weak to priority moves like Lycanroc-D's Accelerock. Hyper Beam can be run as a nuke to nearly always OHKO Zarude while retaining the ability to OHKO Krookodile, but it's situational and leaves Polteageist open to being set up on or revenge killed.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types : Dark-types like Zarude, Galarian Moltres, and Incineroar, can all stomach a boosted Shadow Ball with ease, and immunity to Stored Power means they need to be weakened significantly before Polteageist can break through them. Additionally, Galarian Moltres can use Polteageist as setup fodder.

Priority Moves: Without Psychic Terrain support, Polteageist is extremely vulnerable to priority. Defense drops from Weak Armor and Shell Smash combined with its poor defensive stats means that common priority users like Aegislash, Lycanroc-D, and Crawdaunt can easily OHKO it.

Entry Hazards: Entry hazards break Polteageist's Focus Sash on entry, making it harder to set up, while Sticky Web prevents it from outspeeding common speed control Pokemon it otherwise would, like Choice Scarf Zarude, Barraskewda, and Choice Scarf Krookodile.

Specially Defensive Walls: Polteageist can boost past Chansey and overwhelm it, but other special walls like Umbreon, Celesteela, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can easily check it. However, Psychic Terrain lets Polteageist muscle past Celesteela after two Shell Smash boosts.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Stored Power takes advantage of Shell Smash and Weak Armor boosts to boost its Base Power, and it provides powerful coverage. Giga Drain offers important coverage against threats like Krookodile and allows Polteageist to recover HP, eliminating entry hazard and chip damage and restoring the usefulness of a nullified Focus Sash. Weak Armor further boosts Polteageist's Speed past threats like Timid Venusaur in sun and Adamant Barraskewda in rain, and it boosts Stored Power even further.

Psychic Terrain blocks common priority moves like Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Mamoswine's Ice Shard and prevents them from revenge killing Polteageist. It also boosts Stored Power, allowing Polteageist to OHKO Pokemon like bulky Salamence that would otherwise tank a hit and OHKO in return. As such, Indeedee-F is a perfect partner: it sets up Psychic Terrain on the switch, it can help lure in and weaken threats like Zarude, and it can offer last-ditch support with Healing Wish.
